Instructions: 1. While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. | 2. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. | 3. Hold the contracted position for a second and squeeze the biceps hard. | 4. Slowly bring the weight back down to the starting position.

1. Stand up straight with a dumbbell in each hand at arm's length. | 2. Raise one dumbbell and twist your forearm until it is vertical and your palm faces the shoulder. | 3. Lower to original position and repeat with opposite arm
1. Hold the dumbbells with a neutral grip (thumbs facing the ceiling). | 2. Slowly lift the dumbbell up to chest height | 3. Return to starting position and repeat.

1. Stand up straight with a kettlebell in both hands in front of your pelvis. | 2. Raise the kettlebell bending your arms at the elbow until the kettlebell is level with your chest. | 3. Lower to the starting position and repeat.

1. Sitting on a chair with your legs apart, rest your arm against your thigh and hold the kettlebell with your arm extended towards the floor. | 2. Bending your arm at the elbow, lift the kettlebell until your palm faces your shoulder. | 3. Lower to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand behind a bench, with your chest leaning over the edge of the bench. | 2. With one arm resting on the bench, hold the kettlebell, bending the arm at the elbow. | 3. Lower your arm using the bench as a guide, keeping your forearm straight. | 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand up straight with a kettlebell in one hand with your forearm facing out. | 2. Raise the kettlebell, bending your arm at the elbow and keeping your forearm vertical until your palm faces the shoulder. | 3. Lower to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Raise your arms out to your sides, bringing them up to shoulder level. | 3. Rotate your palms so they are facing the ceiling. | 4. Then, change direction and rotate the arms as much as you can.

1. Stand an arms width away from the wall. | 2. Raise your arms out behind you, and place them on the wall with your fingers pointing up. | 3. Bend your knees whilst keeping your hands in the same position.
1. Bend your arm at the elbow, raising your hand to your shoulder. | 2. Using your other hand, stretch the arm down to its full extent.
1. Stand facing the wall, an arm's width away. | 2. Place your hand on the wall with your fingers pointing down. | 3. Lean slightly into the wall to feel the stretch in your bicep.

1. Stand one foot in front of the other with the wall to your right, an arms width away. | 2. Place your hand on the wall, fingers pointing away from you. | 3. Gently lean forward, keeping your hand stationary. | 4. Repeat with the other arm.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Start with a neutral grip. Flex at the elbow. While flexing twist your palm. When you hit the top of the movement your palm should be facing upward.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Face your palm downwards. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Use a neutral grip thumb facing up pinky-facing down). Flex at the elbow and extend.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. Point your palms straight forward. | 2. Flex your elbow until you feel your biceps contract. Then fully extend elbows.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. Use a neutral grip. | 2. Flex your elbow until you feel your biceps contract. Then fully extend elbows.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. . Point your palms toward your thighs. | 2. Flex your elbow until you feel your biceps contract. Then fully extend elbows.

1. Grab the dumbbells with a pronated (overhand) grip. You can do this exercise thumbless if it's more comfortable on your wrists. | 2. Flex at the elbows until your biceps touch your forearms. Try not to let your elbows flair outward.

1. Take a double overhand grip that's about shoulder width. Flex your elbows while keeping your elbows tucked in. Try not to let them flare out. | 2. Curl until your forearm presses into your bicep. Then fully extend your elbows at the bottom of each rep.
1. Hold the dumbbells with a neutral grip (thumbs facing the ceiling). Seated on an incline bench. | 2. Slowly lift the dumbbell up to chest height | 3. Return to starting position and repeat.

1. Lay on an incline bench. | 2. Grab the dumbbells with a pronated (overhand) grip. You can do this exercise thumbless if it's more comfortable on your wrists. | 3. Flex at the elbows until your biceps touch your forearms. Try not to let your elbows flair outward.

1. Lay on an incline bench with your palms facing forward. | 2. Flex at the elbows until your forearms touch your biceps. | 3. When you hit the top of the movement, rotate your palms and then lower the dumbbells slowly.

1. Start with a with a dumbbell in one hand and your elbow resting on the bench. | 2. From this starting position, curl the dumbbell up towards your shoulder, keeping your upper arm stationary on the bench.
1. Lay on an incline or preacher curl bench. | 2. Let your arms hang freely off the edge of the bench. | 3. Fully flex your elbow and fully extend your elbow on each rep.

1. Start by placing your forearms on a flat bench and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. From this starting position, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body and your core engaged. | 3. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbells to your sides, with your palms facing inward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while rotating your wrists so that your palms face your shoulders at the top of the movement.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

Exercise Name: Plate Curl To Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back behind the head to the starting position of a tricep extension. | 5. Push the plate back up overhead, then lower it back to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

1. Lower into a squat position, keeping the plate at chest height. | 2. Slowly curl the plate towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body. | 3. Hold for a moment at the top of the curl before lowering the plate back to chest height. | 4. Repeat the curls as you hold the squat position.
1. Anchor a band to a high point. | 2. Start with your feet staggered and your elbows high. | 3. Flex your elbows while keeping your arms high. Curl the band to your forehead.
1. Start with the band anchored to something high with your feet staggered and a neutral grip. | 2. Keep your elbows high. Curl until your fists are at your forehead.
1. Start with a band attached to a high point, your feet staggered, and an overhand grip. | 2. Flex your elbows pulling your forearms to your biceps. Your fists should land by your forehead.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with the band under both feet. | 2. Grasp the handles of the band with both hands, keeping your arms straight and extended in front of you. | 3. Keep your back straight, abs engaged, and shoulders relaxed as you curl your hands towards your shoulders, bending at the elbows.

1. Start by standing on the center of the band with both feet, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Hold the band with both hands, palms facing down, arms extended straight in front of you. | 3. Slowly curl your hands towards your shoulders, pulling the band tight, then lower your arms back to the starting position, keeping tension on the band throughout the exercise.

1. Sit on a flat bench with your feet flat on the floor and your back straight. | 2. Lean forward and place your elbow on the inside of your leg. | 3. Curl the dumbbell while keeping your elbow against your leg. Make sure to fully extend your elbow on each rep.
1. Hold the TRX straps with an underhand grip and lean back and away from the anchor point. | 2. Keep your elbows high as you flex your elbows. Pull your fists toward your forehead.
1. Grab the TRX straps and lean away from the anchor point. | 2. Maintain a neutral grip. Flex your elbows and pull your fists to either sides of your temples.

1. Stand facing the TRX straps and grasp the handles with both hands, palms facing away from your body. | 2. Walk back until the straps are taut, keeping your arms straight. | 3. Slowly curl your hands towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body.

1. Position a barbell in a landmine or corner of a room and stand facing it with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grasp the end of the barbell with a neutral grip, keeping your arms straight and your shoulders relaxed. | 3. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso until it is almost parallel to the ground. | 4. Pull the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together as you row the weight up.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Place the band at about eye level. Fall into a kneeling position. | 2. The knee that is on the ground should be the same side as the working arm. Stick your chest out. | 3. And then pull your elbow straight back. Flex your lats and then extend into the starting position.

1. Position a barbell in a landmine or corner of a room and stand facing it with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grasp the end of the barbell with an overhand grip, keeping your arms straight and your shoulders relaxed. | 3. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso until it is almost parallel to the ground. | 4. Pull the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together as you row the weight up.

1. Position a barbell in a landmine or corner of a room and stand facing sideways with a staggered stance and your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grasp the end of the barbell with an overhand grip, keeping your arms straight and your shoulders relaxed. | 3. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso until it is almost parallel to the ground. | 4. Pull the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together as you row the weight up. | 5. *Named after the late John Meadows

1. Start hinged forward with a flat back and the plates resting on the floor. Make sure your elbows are fully extended. | 2. Pull the bar to your sternum. | 3. Return the plates back to the floor and let the bar come to a full dead stop. | 4. Then initiate the next rep.

1. Grab the barbell with an overhand grip. Hinge forward while keeping your back flat until your torso is about parallel with the ground. | 2. Let your arms hang freely. | 3. Pull the bar to your torso while tucking your elbows in slightly. | 4. Extend your elbows fully before initiating the next rep.

1. Begin by standing in front of a barbell with your feet about hip-width apart and your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the barbell with a pronated (overhand) grip, positioning the barbell about an inch away from your shins. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, use your back muscles to lift the barbell straight up towards your chest. | 4. As the barbell reaches your chest, rotate your wrists so that your palms are facing towards your body (supinated grip), and then lower the barbell back to the starting position.

1. Begin by standing in front of a barbell with your feet about hip-width apart. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the barbell with a supinated (underhand) grip, positioning the barbell about an inch away from your shins. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, use your back muscles to lift the barbell straight up towards your chest. | 4. As the barbell reaches your chest, pause briefly, and then lower the barbell back to the starting position.

1. The dumbbells should be set on the ground. Hinge forward while keeping a flat back. | 2. Pull one elbow back toward the ceiling and then return the dumbbell to the ground softly. | 3. Then pull with the other arm.
1. Place one hand and one knee on a bench. Make sure you keep a flat back. | 2. Pull the dumbbell toward the ceiling. | 3. Make sure to avoid any jerking or rotating.
1. Lay on an incline bench that is between 30-45 degrees high. | 2. Let your arms hang freely. Pull your elbows straight back toward the ceiling.

1. The dumbbells should be placed on the floor. | 2. Hinge forward with a flat back and grab the dumbbells. | 3. Pull both dumbbells back and your elbows toward the ceiling. | 4. Return the dumbbells back to the floor softly on each rep.

1. Start by standing in front of a flat bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Place your other hand on the bench for support, and bend at the waist so that your chest is parallel to the ground. | 3. From this starting position, row the dumbbell up towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blade together as you do so. | 4. Make sure to keep your elbow close to your body and your core engaged throughout the movement.

1. Start by placing your elbow on one knee. | 2. Hold a dumbbell in your other hand, with your palm facing inwards towards your body. | 3. From this starting position, row the dumbbell up towards your chest, keeping your elbow close to your body and your core engaged.

1. Make sure to keep your elbow close to your body and your core engaged throughout the movement. | 2. Bend forward at your hips while maintaining a flat back. | 3. Pull the plate toward your upper abdomen. | 4. Lower the weight in a controlled manner and repeat.

1. Stand with feet staggered and one hand on a bench/box. Hold a dumbbell in the opposing hand. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips, keeping the back flat, and eyes facing forward. The weight should hang directly below the shoulders. | 3. Start with an overhand grip, as you pull rotate the dumbbell. When your upper arm reaches your side your palm should be facing forward.

1. Stand with feet staggered and one hand on your knee. Hold a dumbbell in the opposing hand. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips, keeping the back flat, and eyes facing forward. The weight should hang directly below the shoulders. | 3. Start with an overhand grip, as you pull rotate the dumbbell. When your upper arm reaches your side your palm should be facing forward.

1. Grab both dumbbells and hinge forward at the hips. Make sure you keep a flat back. | 2. The closer your torso is to parallel with the ground the longer the range of motion will be at your shoulder. The better the results you'll get from the exercise. | 3. Let your arms hang freely, maintain an underhand grip, and then pull your elbow joint straight back toward the ceiling.

1. Grab the TRX straps and lean away from the anchor point until the strap is taut. | 2. Start with an overhand grip. Pull your elbows back and rotate your grip. | 3. By the time your elbows reach your side, your palms should be facing upwards.

1. Lie down on your back with your legs straight and arms at your sides. | 2. Close your eyes and take deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. | 3. Allow your body to completely relax and let go of any tension. | 4. Hold for several minutes and then slowly come back up to a seated position.

1. Begin in a squatting position with your feet together and your knees apart. | 2. Place your hands on the floor in front of you, shoulder-width apart. Keep your arms straight and engage your core. | 3. Slowly shift your weight forward and lift your feet off the ground, coming onto your tiptoes. | 4. Bend your elbows and lean your weight onto your hands, shifting your knees towards your upper arms. | 5. Gently lift one foot off the ground, and then the other, balancing on your hands. Hold the pose for a few breaths before releasing back to the ground.

1. Begin on your hands and knees with your hands shoulder-width apart and your knees hip-width apart. | 2. Spread your fingers wide and press down into your palms, making sure that your fingers are evenly spaced and facing forward. | 3. Tuck your toes under and lift your knees off the ground, straightening your legs as much as possible. | 4. Press your hips up and back, bringing your body into an inverted "V" shape. | 5. Keep your arms straight and your shoulder blades spread apart, and try to press your heels down towards the ground. | 6. Hold the pose for several breaths, then release and return to your starting position.

Exercise Name: Downward Dog With Fingers Facing Feet
Instructions: 1. Begin in the same starting position as the previous exercise, with your hands and knees on the ground. | 2. Spread your fingers wide and turn your hands so that your fingers are facing towards your feet. | 3. Tuck your toes under and lift your knees off the ground, straightening your legs as much as possible. | 4. Press your hips up and back, bringing your body into an inverted "V" shape. | 5. Keep your arms straight and your shoulder blades spread apart, and try to press your heels down towards the ground. | 6. Hold the pose for several breaths, then release and return to your starting position.

1. Begin in a downward-facing dog pose. | 2. Slowly lift one leg up towards the ceiling, keeping your hips level and your toes pointed. | 3. Bend your lifted leg and try to touch your toes to the back of your head. | 4. Once you have a firm grip with your toes, slowly begin to twist your torso towards the lifted leg. | 5. Keep your hands and feet firmly planted on the ground as you hold the pose for a few breaths. Release the pose and repeat on the other side.

1. Sit cross-legged on the floor. | 2. Extend your arms straight out in front of you, palms facing forward. | 3. Cross your right arm over your left arm and interlace your fingers. | 4. Pull your hands away from your body and hold for a few breaths, then release and repeat with the opposite arm on top.

1. Stand beside the landmine with your feet shoulder-width apart while grasping the end of the landmine barbell with the hand farther away from the landmine attachment, palm facing up and your elbow close to your side. | 2. Curl the barbell up towards your opposite shoulder, contracting your bicep muscles, then slowly lower the barbell back down. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Start on one knee facing the landmine, holding the end of the barbell with your hand on the side of your forward leg. | 2. While keeping your elbow braced against the inside of your knee, curl the barbell upward towards your shoulder, then lower it back down with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.
1. Hold the bosu vertically. | 2. Flex your elbows curling the bosu toward your chin.
1. Hold bosu and hinge forward. | 2. Pull bosu towards chest, squeezing shoulder blades.
1. Hold a neutral grip. | 2. Flex your elbows until your forearms touch your biceps. | 3. Extend your elbows fully to finish each rep.
1. Hold bosu and hinge forward. | 2. Pull bosu towards chest, squeezing shoulder blades.
1. Take a staggered stance and hinge forward. | 2. Grab one of the handle attachments and pull your elbow toward the ceiling.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell in one hand. | 2. Bend at hips, row kettlebell to chest. | 3. Alternate hands for each row.
1. Grab two kettlebells, stand tall. | 2. Curl kettlebells toward chest. | 3. Lower kettlebells, repeat.
1. Stand with kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, grab kettlebell, pull to chest and rotate at the torso
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. | 2. Hold kettlebell with palms facing down. | 3. Lift kettlebell toward shoulders, squeezing biceps, then lower with control.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a kettlebell in each hand. | 2. Hinge at hips, keep back straight, and pull both kettlebells to hips.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. On the same side as the working arm, step back and rotate outwards. | 3. Pull your elbow back while flaring your elbow out.

1. Use a bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a rope attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Use a neutral grip thumb facing up pinky-facing down). Flex at the elbow and extend.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. Start with an overhand grip. As you pull your elbow back, rotate your palm until it faces upward.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Sit on a bench facing away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Underhand Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm upward. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Neutral Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm toward the midline of your body. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine and sit on the bench. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Use a neutral grip thumb facing up pinky-facing down). Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine and sit on the bench. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Face your palm downwards. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Face your palm downwards. Flex at the elbow and extend.
1. Stand facing away from the cables and grab two handle attachments. | 2. Take a neutral grip, flex your elbows, and extend.
1. Grab a barbell with an underhand grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight back and let the bar drag against your upper body (or very close to it).

1. Grab a v bar and place it under the bar's collar. | 2. Hinge forward with a flat back and pull your elbows straight back toward the ceiling. | 3. Fully extend your elbows before initiating the next rep.

1. Use the V Bar attachment. | 2. Hold the attachment as you sit on the machine and put your legs under the leg pads. | 3. Pull the bar to your clavicle, then raise back up until your arm are extended.

1. Use the Straight Bar attachment. Hold with an underhand grip. | 2. Hold the attachment as you sit on the machine and put your legs under the leg pads. | 3. Pull the bar to your clavicle, then raise back up until your arm are extended.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. | 2. Hold a kettlebell with palms facing down. | 3. Lift kettlebell toward shoulders, squeezing biceps, then lower with control.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Row On Bench
Instructions: 1. Start by standing in front of a flat bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a kettlebell in one hand. | 2. Place your other hand on the bench for support, and bend at the waist so that your chest is parallel to the ground. | 3. From this starting position, row the kettlebell up towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blade together as you do so. | 4. Make sure to keep your elbow close to your body and your core engaged throughout the movement.
1. Grab the bar with an underhand grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight back and let the bar drag against your upper body (or very close to it).
1. Start hinged forward with a flat back. Make sure your elbows are fully extended. | 2. Pull the bar to your sternum.

1. Begin by standing in front of a bar with your feet about hip-width apart. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the bar with a supinated (underhand) grip, positioning the bar about an inch away from your shins. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, use your back muscles to lift the bar straight up towards your chest. | 4. As the bar reaches your chest, pause briefly, and then lower the bar back to the starting position.

1. Stand with a band looped under both feet and the band grasped in both hands. | 2. Do a light hop and bring your feet outward while simultaneously flexing the elbows. | 3. Bring both feet back together and extend the elbows.

1. Grab a barbell with a shoulder width pronated or supinated grip. | 2. Bend forward at your hips while maintaining a flat back. | 3. Pull the weight toward your upper abdomen. | 4. Lower the weight in a controlled manner and repeat.

1. Use a handle attachment set all the way to the top of the cable crossover machine. | 2. Walk a few steps away from the cable machine. Face your body sideways. | 3. Face your palm up toward the ceiling. Then pull your elbow in toward your rib cage.

1. Sit with your back straight on the machine and grip the handles. | 2. Pull the handles back using your arms. Your legs and torso should be at a 90 angle. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handles towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.
1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Let your arms hang freely, then pull your elbows straight back toward the ceiling.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, shifting one foot behind you. Hold the kettlebell in the same hand as the leg shifted backwards. | 2. Bend forwards at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knee, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Hinge forward at the hips while maintaining a flat back. Try to get your torso as close to parallel with the ground as your mobility will allow for. | 2. Let your arms hang in front of you. Pull your elbows back towards the ceiling while flaring your elbows outward.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your upper chest and then lower the kettlebell- repeat.

1. Use the Straight Bar attachment. | 2. Hold the attachment as you sit on the machine and put your legs under the leg pads. | 3. Pull the bar to your clavicle, then raise back up until your arm are extended.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, kettlebell in each hand, hinge at hips. | 2. Pull kettlebells while flaring your elbows, squeezing shoulder blades. Keep back flat.

1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a row bar. | 2. Pull the handles back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handles towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

1. Hold the TRX strap with one hand. | 2. Lean back until the strap is taut. Fully extend your elbow. | 3. Pull your elbow behind the body. Make sure to avoid twisting. Try to keep your shoulders even.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 2 Opposite Shoulder Tap 4Pt Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to the 4 point position (on all fours). 90 angles at hips and shoulder and neutral spine. | 2. Lift your knees slightly off the ground supporting your weight on palms and toes. | 3. Maintain a toe placement roughly at shoulder width (the wider the leg stance the easier the exercise - the narrower the stance the more difficult it becomes. | 4. Tap your opposite shoulder with your fingertips.

1. Sit on seat, feet strapped in, grip handle with arms extended. | 2. Push with legs, lean back slightly, pull handle to lower ribs. | 3. Extend arms, lean forward from hips, bend knees to return to start.

Exercise Name: Cardio Row Erg Rower Arms Only
Instructions: 1. Make sure your feet are strapped in tightly. | 2. Without bending your legs, pull the handle to your ribcage. | 3. Fully extend your elbows before initiating the next rep.

Exercise Name: Cardio Row Erg Rower Four Stroke Sprint Start
Instructions: 1. Sit on seat, feet strapped in, grip handle with arms extended. | 2. Push with legs, lean back slightly. Do four small pulls with increasing distance on each rep. | 3. Extend arms, lean forward from hips, bend knees to return to start.

1. Position yourself on preacher bench; grasp EZ bar with underhand grip, elbows extended. | 2. Slowly curl bar towards shoulders; keep upper arms stationary, focus on biceps. | 3. Lower bar back to starting position; maintain control, repeat for reps.

1. Sit on preacher bench, grip EZ bar overhand at shoulder width, elbows resting on pad. | 2. Curl bar towards chin, keep elbows stable. | 3. Lower bar slowly to starting position, maintaining control throughout.

1. Sit at preacher bench, hold dumbbells in each hand with arm extended, palm facing up. | 2. Curl dumbbells towards shoulder, keeping upper arm stationary and elbows in. | 3. Lower dumbbell slowly back to start.

1. Adjust weight for assistance. Stand on platform, grip handles above shoulder-width. Knees on pad if available. | 2. Slowly pull up until chin is above the bar. Keep elbows close, core engaged. | 3. Lower back with control. Pause at bottom. Repeat for reps.

1. Adjust weight for assistance. Stand on platform, grip handles above shoulder-width. Knees on pad if available. | 2. Slowly pull up until chin is above the bar. Keep elbows close, core engaged. | 3. Lower back with control. Pause at bottom. Repeat for reps.

1. Adjust weight for assistance. Stand on platform, grip handles above shoulder-width. Knees on pad if available. | 2. Slowly pull up until chin is above the bar. Keep elbows close, core engaged. | 3. Lower back with control. Pause at bottom. Repeat for reps.

1. Adjust weight for assistance. Stand on platform, grip handles above shoulder-width. Knees on pad if available. | 2. Slowly pull up until chin is above the bar. Keep elbows close, core engaged. | 3. Lower back with control. Pause at bottom. Repeat for reps.

1. Sit on the machine, feet flat, and grab the handles with palms facing up, keeping your back straight. | 2. Pull handles towards your lower abdomen, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Keep elbows close to your body. | 3. Slowly return to the starting position, fully extending your arms without locking elbows. Repeat for desired reps.
1. Grasp the chin-up bar with an underhand grip, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Place your feet on the ground, legs bent slightly. | 3. Use your legs to assist as you pull your chin above the bar.
1. Grasp the chin-up bar with an underhand grip, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Place your feet on the ground, legs bent slightly. | 3. Use your legs to assist as you pull your chest to the bar.
1. Grasp the chin-up bar with a mixed grip, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Place your feet on the ground, legs bent slightly. | 3. Use your legs to assist as you pull your chin above the bar.
1. Grasp the chin-up bar with an overhand grip, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Place your feet on the ground, legs bent slightly. | 3. Use your legs to assist as you pull your chin above the bar.
1. Hang from a bar with your feet on the floor. | 2. Break at the elbows and curl your body towards the bar.
1. Grab the bar with a close grip. Feet on the floor. | 2. Break at the elbow and curl your body toward the bar.
1. Place your elbow on one knee and your hand underneath the other leg. Keep the leg that's over your hand extended. | 2. Curl the working arm and use your leg as the resistance.
1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with an underhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.
1. Set up rings at a high point. | 2. Grip rings and lean back, arms extended. | 3. Pull chest to rings, keeping body straight.

1. Stand holding gymnastic rings with your arms extended in front of you, palms facing up. | 2. Curl rings towards shoulders, squeezing biceps. | 3. Slowly lower rings back to starting position, keeping control. Repeat.
1. Hold the dumbbells with an underhand grip. Seated on an incline bench. | 2. Slowly lift the dumbbell up to chest height | 3. Return to starting position and repeat.

1. Stand up straight and hold a dumbbell in one arm. Perform a bicep curl across your body | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder and rotate palm and elbow out. | 3. Point the elbow towards the ceiling while the dumbbell remains just over the shoulder. | 4. Extend your elbow to raise the dumbbell over your head. Start lowering your arm to your side as you turn the palm to face down

1. Abduct your arm at 90 palm facing down. | 2. Bend your elbow and wrist bringing your front of your fingertips to your temple while leaning the head towards the the arm. | 3. Lean the head away from the arm as you extend the elbow and flex the wrist. | 4. Alternate between positions to mobilise the ulnar nerve.

1. Abduct your arm at 90 palm facing down. | 2. Bend your elbow and wrist to bring the palm to face the ceiling while leaning the head towards the opposite shoulder. | 3. Find the position of maximum tension (without pain) and hold. | 4. To increase the stretch, press the palm against the face and try to point the elbow up.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you). Use a dip belt and the let the weight hang between your legs. | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you). Use a dip belt and the let the weight hang between your legs. | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body in an "L" position and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.
1. Anchor the band to a stable point. | 2. Take a half squat position and hold there. | 3. Perform a row while holding the squat position.

Exercise Name: Band Squat Hold Single Arm Row
Instructions: 1. Anchor the band to a stable point and take a half squat position. | 2. Hold the band loop in one hand and pull your elbow straight back.
1. Anchor band to a stable point. | 2. Step back until there is no slack in the band and hold the end of the band with one hand. | 3. Pull through the elbow straight back.
1. Anchor the band to a high point. Go into a seated position. | 2. Grab the loop of the band and pull your upper arm to your side.
1. Adjust the seat to fit your height and place your elbows on the elbow pad. | 2. Grab the handles and flex your elbows.

1. Grip the handles with the palms facing down. | 2. Sit on the machine and press your knees into the knee pad. | 3. Pull the handles until your upper arm is even with your torso, or just behind your torso. | 4. Extend until your elbows are fully extended before initiating the next rep.

Exercise Name: Machine Seated Plate Loaded Preacher Curl
Instructions: 1. Sit at the bench and rest the back of your arms on the preacher bench. | 2. Grab the handles. Curl the weight up until your elbows are fully flexed. | 3. Lower until the point just before the weight rests at the bottom.

Exercise Name: Machine Standing Plate Loaded Preacher Curl
Instructions: 1. Rest the back of your arms on the preacher bench. | 2. Grab the handles. Curl the weight up until your elbows are fully flexed. | 3. Lower until the point just before the weight rests at the bottom.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set to about elbow height. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Hold the dumbbells with an underhand grip. Seated on a bench. | 2. Start with the dumbbells pointed toward the ceiling, then lower the dumbbells toward your sides. | 3. Fully extend your elbows, but don't let your upper arm fall behind your torso.
1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips pushed toward the ceiling. | 2. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Bench Braced Hammer Flat Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips pushed toward the ceiling. | 2. Take a neutral grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Bench Braced Hammer Incline Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips lowered toward the floor. | 2. Take a neutral grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.
1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips lowered toward the floor. | 2. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Bench Braced Reverse Flat Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips pushed toward the ceiling. | 2. Take an overhand grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Bench Braced Reverse Incline Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips lowered toward the floor. | 2. Take an overhand grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows. | 3. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips lowered toward the floor. | 4. Take an overhand grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.
1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips pushed toward the ceiling. | 2. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Bench Braced Flat Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench with the back of your working arm pressed into the side of the bench. Keep your hips all the way up. | 2. Fully extend your elbow and feel a stretch through your bicep, then curl. | 3. Stop before the dumbbell is pointed at the ceiling to keep tension on your biceps.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Bench Braced Hammer Flat Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips pushed toward the ceiling. | 2. Use a hammer grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Bench Braced Hammer Incline Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips down. | 2. Take a neutral grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Bench Braced Incline Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips lowered toward the floor. | 2. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Bench Braced Reverse Flat Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips pushed toward the ceiling. | 2. Use an overhand grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Bench Braced Reverse Incline Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay off the side of a bench and place the back off your arms on the edge of your bench. Keep your hips lowered toward the floor. | 2. Take an overhand grip. Fully extend your elbows and then flex the elbows.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up and lean backwards. Try to touch your chest to the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the rings shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the rings. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the rings shoulder width apart with a pronated grip (palms facing away). | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up and rotate your fists until your chin is past the rings. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.
1. Hold the dumbbells with a neutral grip (thumbs facing the ceiling). | 2. Slowly lift the dumbbell up to chest height | 3. Return to starting position and repeat.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. | 2. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. | 3. Hold the contracted position for a second and squeeze the biceps hard. | 4. Slowly bring the weight back down to the starting position.

1. Use a bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a rope attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Use a neutral grip thumb facing up pinky-facing down). Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Sit on a bench facing away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.
1. Grab a barbell with an underhand grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight back and let the bar drag against your upper body (or very close to it).
1. Grab the bar with an underhand grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight back and let the bar drag against your upper body (or very close to it).

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set to about elbow height. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Leaning across the back section of the bench, with feet firmly on the floor and with arms hanging to the sides. | 2. Holding the kettlebell in both hands engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. Release the shrug.

Exercise Name: Traps mid back Stretch Variation Two
Instructions: 1. Sit on the ground and lay one leg flat and the other over the top. | 2. Hold your leg with the same side arm and slowly rotate your hips and back. | 3. Hold at the peak of the stretch, then slowly return to starting position. | 4. Switch sides and repeat.

Exercise Name: Traps mid back Stretch Variation One
Instructions: 1. Stand up with your feet shoulder width apart. Place one arm across the front of your chest at shoulder height, press the forearm of your other arm above the elbow, hooking the stretching arm with your hand. | 2. Press the arm until it is straight and rotate your upper torso to engage the stretch even deeper. | 3. Repeat with your other arm.

1. Use a bar attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Stand up with the attachment in hand, walk a couple of steps back make sure you are standing upright and not leaning backwards. | 3. Retract your shoulder blades and then protract to return to the starting position.
1. Lay on an incline bench with your arms hanging freely. | 2. Pull your shoulder blades back toward the ceiling.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding dumbbells with both hands in front just past shoulder width. | 2. Bend forward at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together.
1. Anchor the band at shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades straight back in schools. Then protract to the starting position.

1. Position a barbell in a landmine or corner of a room and stand facing it with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grasp the end of the barbell with a neutral grip, keeping your arms straight and your shoulders relaxed. | 3. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso until it is almost parallel to the ground. | 4. Pull the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together as you row the weight up.

1. Stand with your mid-foot under the bar and grip the bar with your hands, about a shoulder width apart. | 2. Bend your knees, then lift the bar by straightening your back. It is important to keep your back straight. | 3. Stand to your full height and hold. | 4. Lower the bar to the floor by bending your knees and keeping your back straight.

1. Sit with your back straight on the machine and grip the handles. | 2. Pull the handles back using your arms. Your legs and torso should be at a 90 angle. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handles towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.
1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Grab both dumbbells and hinge forward at the hips. Make sure you keep a flat back. | 2. The closer your torso is to parallel with the ground the longer the range of motion will be at your shoulder. The better the results you'll get from the exercise. | 3. Let your arms hang freely, and then pull your elbow joint straight back toward the ceiling.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Return to standing position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Holding the kettlebell in both hands engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. Release the shrug.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.
1. Use a bench or an object to elevate your feet. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat
1. Grab the band with a shoulder width grip. Point your arms straight in front of you. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades and shoulder joint until the band taps your chest.

1. Brace your off arm against something stable (bench, box). Stagger your stance so your leg on the side of your working arm is back. | 2. Try to get your torso to parallel with the ground. That will extend your range of motion. | 3. Let your arm hang freely and then pull your elbow back. Imagine you've got a tennis ball in your armpit and squeeze it each rep.

1. Hinge forward at the hips while maintaining a flat back. Try to get your torso as close to parallel with the ground as your mobility will allow for. | 2. Let your arms hang in front of you. Pull your elbows back towards the ceiling while flaring your elbows outward.
1. Start with a band anchored to a high point. Stagger your stance. | 2. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose.

1. Start by standing between the two anchored bands with your feet shoulder-width apart and the bands positioned at a high point. | 2. Grasp the ends of each band with your hands, keeping your palms facing each other. | 3. Keeping your arms slightly bent and your back straight, slowly pull the bands away from your body until your arms are extended straight out to the sides. Hold for a second, then slowly release back to the starting position. Repeat for desired reps.

Exercise Name: Plate Internally Rotated Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. With plates in either hand, bend your knees with your feet slightly bowed out. Hinge forward with a flat back. | 2. Maintain an overhand grip and internally rotated shoulders. | 3. Raise your arms backward toward the ceiling while maintaining a light band in your elbows.

1. Keep your back straight and bend forward slightly at the waist. | 2. With arms extended, raise the weights out to your sides until they are in line with your shoulders. | 3. Pause briefly and then lower the weights back to the starting position.

1. Stand facing away from the TRX straps and grab the handles with both hands. | 2. Step forward so that your body is in a plank position, with your arms straight and your body in a straight line from your head to your heels. | 3. Keeping your arms straight, slowly lift your arms out to the side, keeping them at the same height as your shoulders. Your body should form a "T" shape.

1. Stand facing away from the TRX straps and grab the handles with both hands. | 2. Step away so your body is leaning away from the anchor point. | 3. Flex your elbows and pull your elbows straight back behind your body. | 4. Make sure to keep your elbows flared outward.

1. Hold the TRX straps and lean away from the anchor point. | 2. Pull your elbows back while externally rotating your shoulder joint. Your arms should make a W shape at the back portion of the exercise.

1. Begin on your hands and knees with your wrists directly under your shoulders and your knees directly under your hips. | 2. Inhale and arch your back, lifting your tailbone and head towards the ceiling, while lowering your belly towards the floor. | 3. Exhale and round your spine, tucking your chin towards your chest, and bringing your tailbone towards your knees. | 4. Repeat these movements, flowing smoothly between the two poses, for several breaths.

1. Begin seated with your legs extended in front of you. | 2. Bend your right knee and place your foot on the floor next to your left thigh. | 3. Inhale and reach your left arm up towards the ceiling. | 4. Exhale and twist to the right, placing your left elbow on the outside of your right knee. Hold for a few breaths and then repeat on the other side. | 5. Begin seated with your legs extended in front of you. | 6. Bend your right knee and place your foot on the floor next to your left thigh. | 7. Inhale and reach your left arm up towards the ceiling. | 8. Exhale and twist to the right, placing your left elbow on the outside of your right knee. Hold for a few breaths and then repeat on the other side.

Exercise Name: Revolved Side Angle Pose With Prayer Hands
Instructions: 1. Begin in Warrior II pose, with your right foot forward and your left foot back. | 2. Bring your hands together in a prayer position at your heart. | 3. Exhale and twist your torso to the right, placing your left elbow on the outside of your right knee. | 4. Hold for several breaths and then repeat on the other side.

Exercise Name: Revolved Side Angle Pose With Prayer Hands Beginner
Instructions: 1. Begin in a low lunge position with your right foot forward and your left knee on the ground. | 2. Bring your hands together in a prayer position at your heart. | 3. Exhale and twist your torso to the right, placing your left elbow on the outside of your right knee. | 4. Hold for several breaths and then repeat on the other side.

1. Begin seated with your legs extended in front of you. | 2. Bend your right knee and place your foot on the floor next to your left thigh. | 3. Inhale and reach your left arm up towards the ceiling. | 4. Exhale and twist to the right, placing your left elbow on the outside of your right knee. Hold for a few breaths and then repeat on the other side.

1. Use the Straight Bar attachment. | 2. Hold the attachment as you sit on the machine and put your legs under the leg pads. | 3. Pull the bar to your clavicle, then raise back up until your arm are extended.

1. Use the V Bar attachment. | 2. Hold the attachment as you sit on the machine and put your legs under the leg pads. | 3. Pull the bar to your clavicle, then raise back up until your arm are extended.
1. Hold bosu and hinge forward. | 2. Pull bosu towards chest, squeezing shoulder blades.
1. Take a staggered stance and hinge forward. | 2. Grab one of the handle attachments and pull your elbow toward the ceiling.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, kettlebell in each hand, hinge at hips. | 2. Pull kettlebells while flaring your elbows, squeezing shoulder blades. Keep back flat.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold one kettlebell in each hand at your sides, and lean forward. | 2. Lift your shoulders backward while keeping arms straight. | 3. Lower shoulders back down, repeat for desired reps.

1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a row bar. | 2. Pull the handles back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handles towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Underhand Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm upward. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Neutral Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm toward the midline of your body. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Rear Delt Row
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment, grab with an overhand grip and take a position with the cable crossing your body. | 2. Pull your elbows back while flaring your elbows outward.

1. Sit on a bench. Put your chest in your lap. Try to get your torso as close to parallel with the ground as your mobility will allow for. | 2. Let your arms hang in front of you. Pull your elbows back towards the ceiling while flaring your elbows outward.

1. Start in a plank position. Push your hips up toward the ceiling. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat

1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. Leave your feet on the floor. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. Use your legs top assist you up. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grab a door frame or a rack and place your feet near the frame. | 2. Start with your elbows extended, row your body towards your hands. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Lie on your front, arms outstretched to the side. | 2. Raise head and chest off the ground. | 3. Raise and lower your arms (flapping wings motion) by contracting and relaxing the muscles in between your shoulder blades.
1. From the standing or seated position straighten your back. | 2. Pull the shoulders back but keep them relaxed. | 3. Move shoulders backwards and return to the starting, relaxed position.
1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. Place a plate on your chest. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. Weight hanging between your legs. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. Pull your legs up until you're in an "L" position. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.
1. Press your chest into the chest pad and grab the horizontal handles with an overhand grip. | 2. Pull the handles toward you, make sure your elbows stay flared out.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width, and keep your back straight. | 2. Drive through your legs, extending your hips, knees, and ankles explosively while pulling the barbell upward. | 3. As the bar rises, pull it close to your body, leading with your elbows until it reaches chest level.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, gripping the barbell with a wide (snatch-width) grip. Keep your back straight, chest up, and bar close to your body. | 2. Drive through your legs, extending your hips, knees, and ankles while pulling the barbell up explosively. | 3. Shrug your shoulders forcefully and pull the bar as high as possible, keeping elbows above the bar. | 4. Lower the bar back to the starting position in a controlled manner and reset for the next rep.
1. Grasp the rings with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the rings. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Position your thighs on the padding and hook your feet on the platform supports. | 2. Keeping your back straight, slowly bend at your waist until your legs and back are at a 45 angle. | 3. Slowly raise your body to the starting position.

1. Lay flat against the ground with your knees at an angle and your feet flat against the floor. | 2. Grab your legs just below the knees, and pull your legs towards your chest. | 3. Pause at the apex of the stretch, then return to the starting position.

1. Lay on your back with your arms at either side. | 2. Raise your knees so that they are pointing straight towards the ceiling. Keeping your legs pressed together, rotate your hips to either side. | 3. Repeat this motion as necessary.

1. Lay flat on the floor with your arms at either side. | 2. With one leg, hook one foot under the joint of your other leg. | 3. Rotate your hips so that your knees are pointing sideways, keeping your hooked leg flat against the floor. | 4. Pause at the apex of the stretch and repeat with your other leg.

1. Sit on the floor with the tops of your feet pointed and flat on the ground. Move your arms out in front of you in the diving position, placing your palms flat against the ground. | 2. With your arms fully extended, rest your buttocks on the heels of your feet, you can crawl your hands forward to extend the stretch if need be. | 3. Hold the extended position for a few seconds, and return to starting position.

1. Lie face down on the floor with your arms fully extended in front of you. | 2. Simultaneously raise your arms, legs and chest off of the floor and hold the position. | 3. Slowly lower your arms, legs and chest back to the starting position. Repeat.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate in front of the feet, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend the hips and knees to grip the plate with palms facing the body. | 3. Keeping the back straight, stand up while lifting the plate off the ground. | 4. Return the plate back to the starting position by bending the hips and knees, keeping control of the plate.

1. Lay flat on the ground on your stomach with your arms extended overhead. Hold a dumbbell with a neutral grip. | 2. Lift your legs and chest off the ground simultaneously and hold for a 1 count at the top. | 3. Relax your lower back and lower your legs and chest back to the floor.

1. Stand with your mid-foot under the bar and grip the bar with your hands, about a shoulder width apart. | 2. Bend your knees, then lift the bar by straightening your back. It is important to keep your back straight. | 3. Stand to your full height and hold. | 4. Lower the bar to the floor by bending your knees and keeping your back straight.

1. Grab both dumbbells and hinge forward at the hips. Make sure you keep a flat back. | 2. The closer your torso is to parallel with the ground the longer the range of motion will be at your shoulder. The better the results you'll get from the exercise. | 3. Let your arms hang freely, and then pull your elbow joint straight back toward the ceiling.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Return to standing position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell between your legs, with your knees slightly bent. | 2. Keeping your back straight, swing the kettlebell upwards until the kettlebell is level with your chest and carefully lower. | 3. Repeat

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, shifting one foot behind you. Hold the kettlebell in both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees and keep your back straight. | 3. Return to the upright position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your chest. | 2. Bend forward at the hips keeping your back and knees straight and the kettlebell close to your chest. | 3. Return to standing position and thrust your pelvis forward.

1. Stand with your feet a little past shoulder width apart with a slight bend at your knee. Place your hands behind the back of your head. | 2. Keeping your back straight, rotate your hips to bring your shoulders down towards the floor. Stop when your chest is parallel with the floor.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Get your elbows directly underneath the bar, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.

1. Start with a straight bar or ez bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back. | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement while lifting one of your legs. Then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. Compete your given amount of reps, then switch to opposite leg. | 4. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back.

1. This exercise works best with a rope attachment but can be done with anything. The attachment should be set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine, straddle the cable itself, and grab the attachment. Walk a few steps away. | 3. Break at the hips while maintaining a flat back and mostly extended knees. | 4. Push hips forward until you are back in a standing position.

Exercise Name: Cable Standing Straight Leg Glute Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set to the bottom of the crossover machine. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.
1. Anchor the band at hip level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back while keeping your back flat until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings.

1. Anchor the band to the lowest point possible. Straddle the band and then grab with both hands. | 2. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 3. Push your butt back until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Then extend the hips back into the starting position.

1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Hinge until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 4. Push your hips back forward until you are in a standing position.

1. Hold the dumbbell in a goblet position. With your elbows directly under your fists. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees MOSTLY extended. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Stand with a shoulder width stance. Push your butt back while leaving your knees MOSTLY extended. | 2. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward to complete the rep. | 3. Do not push your hips all the way forward. This will hyperextend your spine. Just go to a normal standing position.

1. Place the bar on your traps. You may need a pad so the bar doesn't dig into your cervical spine. | 2. Push your hips straight back. Your knees should stay MOSTLY extended (think soft knees). Also make sure to | 3. Look for what feels like a stretch in your hamstrings. The stretch feeling means you're likely nearing the end of your Range of Motion without rounding your spine. | 4. When you feel the stretch push your hips forward until you're in a standing position.

1. Place the bar between your traps and rear delts. Pull your shoulder blades back to give the bar a shelf to sit on. | 2. Push your hips back until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. This means you're nearing the end of your Range of Motion with out rounding your spine. | 3. When you feel the stretch push your hips forward until you'e in a standing position.

1. Stance width can vary with a sumo DL. Some prefer toes near the plates. Others prefer a more narrow stance to get more drive off the floor. | 2. Make sure your arms are inside your legs. The bar should be just over your mid-foot. Flatten your back and push your heels into the floor. | 3. Try to extend your knees and hips simultaneously.

1. Take a shoulder width, double overhand or mixed grip. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and place a barbell on the floor in front of you. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, positioning your hands just outside of your hips. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, lift the barbell off the floor by extending your hips and knees. | 4. As you lift the barbell, pull your shoulders back and squeeze your glutes to fully extend your hips at the top of the movement.

1. Stand in front of a box or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell resting on your upper back. | 2. Lower your body into a squat position, sitting back onto the box and pausing for a moment before standing back up. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the standing position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell resting on your upper back. | 2. Lower your body into a squat position, pausing for a moment at the bottom of the movement before standing back up. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the standing position.

1. Start hinged forward with a flat back and the plates resting on the floor. Make sure your elbows are fully extended. | 2. Pull the bar to your sternum. | 3. Return the plates back to the floor and let the bar come to a full dead stop. | 4. Then initiate the next rep.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart, with your toes pointed slightly outward. | 2. Place a barbell on the floor behind you, with the weight plates on either side. | 3. Bend down and grab the barbell with an overhand grip, your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Keep your back straight and your shoulders down as you grip the bar. | 4. Stand up straight, lifting the barbell off the ground and pulling it toward your hips. Keep your elbows close to your body and your shoulders down as you do this.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart, with your toes pointed slightly outward. | 2. Place a barbell on the floor in front of you, with the weight plates on either side. Make sure that the bar is directly in line with your feet. | 3. Bend down and grab the barbell with an overhand grip, your hands much wider than shoulder-width apart. Keep your back straight and your shoulders down as you grip the bar. | 4. Stand up straight, lifting the barbell off the ground and pulling it toward your hips. Keep your elbows close to your body and your shoulders down as you do this. | 5. Slowly lower the barbell back to the ground, making sure to keep your back straight and your shoulders down throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart. The bar should be in a rack or box so it's lifted off the ground. | 2. Grab the barbell with an overhand grip, your hands should be much wider than shoulder-width apart. | 3. Hing forward at the hips keeping your knees mostly extended. Hinge until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you are back in a standing position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a barbell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the barbell down towards the ground. | 3. As the barbell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the barbell on the opposite side of your body.

1. Begin by standing in front of a barbell with your feet about hip-width apart. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the barbell with a supinated (underhand) grip, positioning the barbell about an inch away from your shins. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, use your back muscles to lift the barbell straight up towards your chest. | 4. As the barbell reaches your chest, pause briefly, and then lower the barbell back to the starting position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet about hip-width apart and holding a barbell in the crook of your elbows, with your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and lower your torso forward until it is nearly parallel to the ground. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and raise your body back to the starting position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet about hip-width apart and holding a barbell in the crook of your arms, near your belly. Your palms should be facing towards your body. | 2. Sit back and lower your body down until your thighs are parallel to the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and stand back up to the starting position.

1. Place two dumbbells on your shoulders and make sure you force your elbows upward. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees. | 3. When you reach parallel (hamstrings parallel with the ground) pause for 1-3 seconds. Then push through your heels back to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Leg Single Arm Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Start by standing on one leg with a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Slowly bend at the hips and lower the dumbbell towards the ground while extending your free leg behind you. | 3. Keep your core engaged and your back straight as you lower the weight. | 4. Once the dumbbell is close to the ground, push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Leg Stiff Leg Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Start by standing on one leg with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two dumbbells. | 2. From this starting position, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbell towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 3. Once you feel a stretch in your hamstring, slowly return to the starting position. | 4. Make sure to keep your standing leg slightly bent and avoid rounding your back as you lower the dumbbell.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated on a step or weight plate. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the dumbbells towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 4. Once the dumbbells are below your knees, drive through your heels to stand back up to the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Place the dumbbells on the ground between your feet. | 3. From this starting position, bend your knees and lower your body down into a squat. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in both hands. | 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to swing the dumbbell between your legs. | 3. From this starting position, explosively extend your hips and swing the dumbbell up to chest height. | 4. Allow the momentum of the swing to carry the dumbbell back down between your legs, and then repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Exercise Name: Plate Single Leg Pinch Grip Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and facing forwards. Grip the sides of a weight plate with your palms facing down. | 2. Balance on one foot, as you raise the weight keep your arms and back straight, while you bring your other foot back towards the ground | 3. Keep four raised leg straight and in alignment with your back as you lower the plate back down to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held in front of you, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held behind the neck and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Engage your core and straighten your legs to lift the plate off the ground. | 2. Stand on one leg, keeping the other leg off the ground, while holding the plate in front of your body. | 3. Keep your back straight and maintain a neutral head position while looking straight ahead. | 4. Lower the plate back down to the ground while keeping your balance on one leg.

1. Stand facing the plate with your feet shoulder-width apart and the plate positioned between your feet. | 2. Bend down and grasp the plate from the top edges with both hands, making sure your thumbs and fingers are evenly spaced. | 3. Keep your back straight, chest up and core engaged, and stand up with the plate, keeping it close to your body. | 4.
