Lower the plate back down to the ground, keeping control and maintaining good posture.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a weight plate. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plate towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 4. Once the plate is below your knees, drive through your heels to stand back up to the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two plates with a pinch grip. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plates towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged.

1. Grasp the TRX handles with both hands, keeping your arms extended and your shoulders away from your ears. | 2. Keep your abs engaged, roll forward onto your toes, and extend your arms in front of you. | 3. Slowly lower your body down to the ground, keeping your arms straight and your abs engaged. | 4. When your head gets between your arms, pause for a moment and then use your abs to pull your body back up to the starting position.

1. Lie down on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. | 2. Lift your feet off the floor and bring your knees towards your chest. | 3. Reach inside your knees and hold onto the outside edges of your feet. | 4. Gently pull your knees towards your armpits and rock side to side for a few breaths.

1. Start by lying down on your stomach on a yoga mat or a comfortable surface. | 2. Place your elbows underneath your shoulders, keeping your forearms parallel to each other. | 3. Press your palms and forearms firmly into the ground to lift your chest up, while keeping your hips and legs relaxed. | 4. Make sure your shoulders are relaxed and away from your ears. Gently roll your shoulder blades down and back to open up your chest. | 5. Lengthen your spine by lifting the crown of your head towards the ceiling, while keeping your chin tucked in slightly.

1. Stand in front of the landmine with your feet hip-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with both hands, palms facing each other, and hold it in front of your thighs. | 2. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, hinge at the hips and push your hips back, allowing the landmine to travel down your thighs. Lower the landmine by bending forward at the hips while keeping your back flat, allowing the barbell to move closer to the floor. Continue the movement until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, keeping your legs relatively straight but with a slight bend in the knees. | 3. Reverse the movement by pushing your hips forward and driving through your heels while keeping your back straight. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.
1. Hold medicine ball while standing on one leg. | 2. Hinge forward on one leg, extending other leg behind. | 3. Return to starting position. Repeat on other leg.
1. Hold the end of the bar in front of you. | 2. Pop your hips, pull your elbows up to the ceiling, and get underneath the bar.

1. Grab a v bar and place it under the bar's collar. | 2. Hinge forward with a flat back and pull your elbows straight back toward the ceiling. | 3. Fully extend your elbows before initiating the next rep.

Exercise Name: Bosu Ball Single Leg Hip Thrust
Instructions: 1. Sit on Bosu, lean back, one foot on the floor. | 2. Drive hips upward, squeezing glutes, one leg extended. | 3. Lower hips back down and switch legs.
1. Lie face down on Bosu, arms extended. | 2. Lift arms, chest, and legs off the Bosu. | 3. Hold for a moment, then lower back down.
1. Take an overhand grip. | 2. Keep your knees mostly extended and hinge forward at the hips. | 3. Keep a flat back.
1. Hold medicine ball while standing on one leg. | 2. Hinge forward on one leg, extending other leg behind. | 3. Return to starting position. Repeat on other leg.
1. Place one foot firmly on the ground and one foot behind the other. Bend the knee on your back leg. | 2. Hinge forward until you feel a stretch in your front leg.
1. Start prone, hands under shoulders. | 2. Inhale, lift chest, arch back. | 3. Elongate neck, gaze up. Breathe, hold. Release, exhale.

1. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 2. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.
1. Lie face down on a mat. | 2. Hold dumbbells out in front | 3. Lift arms and legs simultaneously, squeezing lower back.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, swing kettlebell between legs. | 3. Swing kettlebell up, switch hands at the top, and repeat in a fluid motion.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. | 2. Bend at hips and knees to lift kettlebells. | 3. Stand tall, then lower.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebells outside legs | 2. Hinge at hips, swing kettlebells forward, then back. | 3. Thrust hips to swing kettlebells upward, keeping arms straight.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, grip kettlebell, and swing it overhead. | 3. Extend hips and knees, lock out arms at the top.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding kettlebells in front. | 2. Hinge at hips, keeping back straight, and lower kettlebells towards ground. | 3. Return to start position, squeezing glutes at the top.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs, grip with one hand, hinge at hips. | 2. Swing kettlebell forcefully forward, using hip thrust, arm straight. | 3. Swing kettlebell back between legs, repeat for desired reps.
1. Begin with feet hip-width apart, one foot forward, kettlebell between feet. | 2. Hinge at hips, grip kettlebell, and stand tall. | 3. Lower kettlebell with control, then repeat.

1. Lower kettlebell with control, then repeat. | 2. Explosively thrust hips forward, swing kettlebell to chest height. | 3. Repeat for desired reps, keeping core engaged and maintaining a staggered stance for balance.

1. Stand with feet wide apart, toes pointing slightly outward, and kettlebell on the floor between your feet. | 2. Bend at hips and knees, keeping back straight, and grip the kettlebell handle. | 3. Lift the kettlebell by extending hips and knees, stand up straight, and return to the starting position.

1. Begin by lying face down on the floor with a kettlebell in each hand, arms extended. | 2. Lift your chest and legs off the ground simultaneously while squeezing your glutes and raising the kettlebells. | 3. Lower your body and kettlebells back to the floor, then repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, kettlebell in one hand, arm fully extended, and hinge at hips. | 2. Lift opposite leg straight behind you, forming a straight line from head to heel. | 3. Hold for 15-30 seconds, switch sides, and repeat for a balanced kettlebell superman hold.

1. Start with a kettlebell between your legs, hinge at hips, swing it upward. | 2. Lift kettlebell to chest level, elbows high, engaging shoulders. | 3. Lower kettlebell back down, maintaining control. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Start with a straight bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back. | 2. Stand with a staggered stance. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Use an ankle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set to hip height. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Start with handles set to the bottom of the machine. Grab a box, stand on top of the box, squat the weight up into a standing position. | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

Exercise Name: Cable Incline Bench Straight Leg Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. Put the bench at incline level. The cable should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.
1. Hold a plate in both hands. | 2. Pull your arms and legs off the ground while and hold that position.

1. Lay flat on the ground on your stomach with your arms extended overhead. Hold a plate with a neutral grip. | 2. Lift your legs and chest off the ground simultaneously and hold for a 1 count at the top. | 3. Relax your lower back and lower your legs and chest back to the floor.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Place the bar in your elbows, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.

1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set halfway up the crossover machine. | 2. Start with a bent knee position. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet about hip-width apart and holding the bar in the crook of your elbows, with your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and lower your torso forward until it is nearly parallel to the ground. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and raise your body back to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Cable Standing Straight Leg Mid Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set to halfway up the crossover machine. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Stand with a shoulder width stance holding one dumbbell. Push your butt back while leaving your knees MOSTLY extended. | 2. Reach toward the opposing leg. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward to complete the rep. | 3. Do not push your hips all the way forward. This will hyperextend your spine. Just go to a normal standing position.
1. Start hinged forward with a flat back. Make sure your elbows are fully extended. | 2. Pull the bar to your sternum.

1. Take a shoulder width, double overhand or mixed grip. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Stance width can vary with a sumo DL. Some prefer toes near the plates. Others prefer a more narrow stance to get more drive off the floor. | 2. Make sure your arms are inside your legs. The bar should be just over your mid-foot. Flatten your back and unrack the bar | 3. Leave your knees mostly extended and flex and extend your hips.

1. Begin by standing in front of a bar with your feet about hip-width apart. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the bar with a supinated (underhand) grip, positioning the bar about an inch away from your shins. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, use your back muscles to lift the bar straight up towards your chest. | 4. As the bar reaches your chest, pause briefly, and then lower the bar back to the starting position.

1. Pull your shoulder blades back really hard and place the bar on your posterior delts. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees to initiate the squat. | 3. Aim to get your hamstrings to parallel with the ground. Push your heels into the floor and squat back up to a standing position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, lifting one foot off the floor behind you. Hold the kettlebell in the same arm as the lifted leg. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you extend your lifted leg behind you, keeping your back straight - holding out your arm to the side for balance. | 3. Return to the upright position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent and raise one leg. | 2. Without changing the bend in your knee, bend at your hips, and lower your torso until it's almost parallel to the floor. | 3. Tense your glutes and then bring yourself back to the starting position.

1. Begin by standing in front of a barbell with your feet about hip-width apart and your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the barbell with a pronated (overhand) grip, positioning the barbell about an inch away from your shins. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, use your back muscles to lift the barbell straight up towards your chest. | 4. As the barbell reaches your chest, rotate your wrists so that your palms are facing towards your body (supinated grip), and then lower the barbell back to the starting position.

1. Grab the end of the landmine and stand perpendicular to the bar. | 2. Lift your inside leg and keep your outside leg planted. | 3. Push your hips back keeping your knees mostly extended. When you feel the stretch in your hams, push your hips forward until you are standing upright.

1. Stand in a staggered position. With the back leg bent and the front mostly extended. | 2. Push your hips back until you feel a stretch through your front hamstring. | 3. Push your hips back forward until you are standing.

1. The dumbbells should be set on the ground. Hinge forward while keeping a flat back. | 2. Pull one elbow back toward the ceiling and then return the dumbbell to the ground softly. | 3. Then pull with the other arm.

1. Lay on your front placing your palms under your shoulders | 2. Keep the elbows bent and close to your body | 3. Lift your upper body off the ground supporting your weight on your forearms | 4. Keep the hips on the ground

1. Lay on your front placing your palms under your shoulders | 2. Keep the elbows bent and close to your body | 3. Lift your upper body off the ground supporting your weight on your palms | 4. Keep the hips on the ground

1. Stand up straight with a good form. | 2. Send your hips back and start tilting the upper body. | 3. Maintain a straight back as you aim for your toes. | 4. Your range depends on your hamstring flexibility.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a kettlebell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the kettlebell down towards the ground. | 3. As the kettlebell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the kettlebell on the opposite side of your body.

1. Lie on your front with your arms extended and above your head. | 2. Point the thumbs up. Try to raise your arms off the ground keeping them straight. | 3. Bend your elbows to the side and form the letter "W" with your arms. | 4. Extend to the "I" position but do not rest on the ground
1. Lie on your back and flatten you lower back against the ground | 2. Pull one knee towards your chest and then across your body till it forces your lower back into a rotated position.

1. Lie on your front leaning your forehead on the back of your palms. | 2. Ask someone to hold your ankles or secure them under a supportive structure. | 3. Squeeze your glutes and tilt your hips backwards (flattens the front of your hips against the ground). | 4. Raise your chest off the ground and lower it without resting on the ground before the next rep.

1. Lie on your front leaning your forehead on the back of your palms. | 2. Squeeze your glutes and tilt your hips backwards (flattens the front of your hips against the ground). | 3. Raise your chest off the ground and lower it without resting on the ground before the next rep

1. Lie on your front and bring your arms into the "W" position. | 2. Squeeze your glutes and tilt your hips backwards (flattens the front of your hips against the ground). | 3. Raise your chest off the ground and lower it without resting on the ground before the next rep.

1. Lie on your front and bring your arms in the "I" position, thumbs pointing the ceiling. | 2. Squeeze your glutes and tilt your hips backwards (flattens the front of your hips against the ground). | 3. Raise your chest off the ground and lower it without resting on the ground before the next rep.

Exercise Name: Lumbar Extensor Mobilisation Supine Bent Knees Peanut Tool
Instructions: 1. Lie on your back with your feet on a bench. Place a peanut tool under your lower back. | 2. Adjust pressure by pressing your heels into the bench. Roll back and forth or side to side | 3. Maintain a neutral lower back (do not tilt the pelvis).

1. Lie on your back with bent knees. | 2. Hug your knees and pull them towards your chest. | 3. Feel your lower back come off the ground. | 4. You can add a you can add an abduction to target the hips as well.

1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and the feet flat on the ground. | 2. Keep your knees and ankles together. Drop both knees towards the same side. | 3. Stay in this position and breathe deep and slow. | 4. To increase the intensity of the stretch you can reach up with your arms.

1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and the feet flat on the ground. | 2. Drop your knees towards one side before moving towards the other. | 3. To increase the intensity of the stretch you can reach up with your arms.

1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and the feet flat on the ground. | 2. Drop your knees towards one side then place your ankle on the opposite knee. | 3. To increase the intensity of the stretch you can reach up with your arms.

1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and the feet flat on the ground. | 2. Cross your legs. Drop your knees towards one side before moving towards the other. | 3. To increase the intensity of the stretch you can reach up with your arms.

1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and the feet flat on the ground. | 2. Drop your knees towards one side and add a kick at the end of range. | 3. To increase the intensity of the stretch you can reach up with your arms.
1. Sit on your heels and reach out your arms on the floor while pressing the chest towards the ground.
1. Sit on your heels and reach out your arms on a box or foam roller while pressing the chest towards the ground.

1. Lie on the floor keeping your knees bent and the feet on the floor. | 2. Place a massage ball under your lower back and move around till the ball presses into a tight/sore spot. | 3. If you use a foam roller you would have to be seated and leaning back into the roller.

1. Place a box behind you and one foot on it. Keep your chest up and the back straight | 2. Tilt at the hips to perform a deadlift. Use the box for balance and support | 3. Make sure you straighten your back leg when performing the deadlift. | 4. As you get comfortable with the movement, try to lift the leg off the box when you reach the end range of the deadlift.

1. Lie on your front with your arms by your side, palms facing down. | 2. Tense your back muscles to raise both ends of your body off the ground. | 3. Keep your core engaged as you will be supporting your weight on your belly.

1. Lie on your front, arms above head. Squeeze glutes to protect lower back | 2. Raise your chest and arms off the ground. Adduct (bring your arms by your hips) | 3. You can touch down and repeat the whole movement, or remain off the ground and just perform the "swipes."

1. Lie on your front, arms above head. Squeeze glutes to protect lower back | 2. Raise your chest and arms off the ground. Adduct (bring your arms by your hips) in an alternating fashion. | 3. You can touch down and repeat the whole movement, or remain off the ground and just perform the "swipes."

1. Stand in front of a box or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart with a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Lower your body into a squat position, sitting back onto the box and pausing for a moment before standing back up. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the standing position.

1. Stand up straight with a good form. | 2. Send your hips back and start tilting the upper body. | 3. Maintain a straight back as you aim for your toes. | 4. Lower the bar to the floor by bending your knees and keeping your back straight.

1. Stand in front of a box or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart with a kettlebell in a goblet position. | 2. Lower your body into a squat position, sitting back onto the box and pausing for a moment before standing back up. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the standing position.
1. Stand tall, hinge at hips, and reach hands to the floor. | 2. Walk hands forward into a plank position. | 3. Walk feet towards hands and repeat the motion.

1. Stand with your mid-foot under the bar, plates should be on blocks, and grip the bar with your hands, about a shoulder width apart. | 2. Bend your knees, then lift the bar by straightening your back. It is important to keep your back straight. | 3. Stand to your full height and hold. | 4. Lower the bar to the floor by bending your knees and keeping your back straight.
1. Set up for a standard deadlift, grip the barbell. | 2. Lift, pause at knee height. | 3. Hold briefly, then complete the lift; reset and repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with your mid-foot under the bar, feet should be on a plate or elevated platform, and grip the bar with your hands, about a shoulder width apart. | 2. Bend your knees, then lift the bar by straightening your back. It is important to keep your back straight. | 3. Stand to your full height and hold. | 4. Lower the bar to the floor by bending your knees and keeping your back straight.

1. Stand centered over the barbell, feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grip the bar with both hands, one in front, one behind. | 3. Lift by driving through your heels, keeping your back straight, then lower slowly.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart with the bar on the ground at your side. | 2. Lift the bar to your side and walk for the allotted amount of time or distance. | 3. Set the bar down and switch sides.
1. Set up for a sumo deadlift, grip the barbell. | 2. Lift, pause at knee height. | 3. Hold briefly, then complete the lift; reset and repeat for desired reps.
1. Sit on the machine and place your upper back on the rolling pad. | 2. Extend your hips and lower back. Make sure not to hyperextend your spine.
1. Lay on the pad and grab the handles. | 2. Slip your legs into the belt loop. | 3. Push your legs back until they are horizontal with the ground. | 4. Lower back to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip the bar just outside your knees. Pull the bar from the floor by driving through your legs, keeping your back straight. | 2. As the bar reaches your hips, extend explosively, shrug, and drop under to catch it in a front squat position with elbows high. Stand up tall. | 3. Dip slightly, then drive through your legs to push the bar overhead. | 4. Stabilize the bar overhead, lock arms, then bring feet together before lowering the bar safely.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width, and keep your back straight. | 2. Drive through your legs, extending your hips, knees, and ankles explosively while pulling the barbell upward. | 3. As the bar rises, pull it close to your body, leading with your elbows until it reaches chest level.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip the barbell with a wide overhand grip, and keep your back straight and core engaged. | 2. Lift the barbell by explosively extending your hips, knees, and ankles while keeping the bar close to your body. | 3. As the bar reaches chest level, rotate your wrists and elbows up and back, transitioning into an overhead press. | 4. Fully extend your arms overhead, stabilize the bar, then lower it back to the starting position with control.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, barbell over midfoot. Grip the bar wide (outside shoulders), hook grip recommended. | 2. Keep chest up, back straight, and drive through heels to lift the bar off the ground, keeping it close to your body. | 3. As the bar reaches mid-thigh, explode upwards by extending hips, knees, and ankles, shrugging shoulders and pulling the bar high. | 4. Drop under the bar slightly, catching it overhead with arms locked out. Stand up fully to complete the lift.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, barbell over midfoot. Grip the bar wide with an overhand grip, chest up, and back straight. | 2. Lift the bar by driving through your legs, keeping it close to your body. Extend your hips and knees while maintaining a straight back. | 3. Explosively extend your hips, knees, and ankles while shrugging your shoulders. Pull yourself under the bar as it moves upward. | 4. Drop into a deep squat while locking the bar overhead. Stabilize, then stand up fully to complete the lift.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, gripping the barbell with a wide (snatch-width) grip. Keep your back straight, chest up, and bar close to your body. | 2. Drive through your legs, extending your hips, knees, and ankles while pulling the barbell up explosively. | 3. Shrug your shoulders forcefully and pull the bar as high as possible, keeping elbows above the bar. | 4. Lower the bar back to the starting position in a controlled manner and reset for the next rep.

1. Begin by standing with your feet on a plate and holding a barbell in the crook of your arms, near your belly. Your palms should be facing towards your body. | 2. Step back with one foot off the plate and lower your back knee to the floor. | 3. Push through your front leg and bring your back foot to the plate.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. Hold a plate up to your chest. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Lie face-down on a stability ball, hips centered, feet anchored, hands behind your head. | 2. Engage your core, lift your upper body until aligned with legs, keeping your neck neutral. | 3. Lower your torso slowly back to the starting position, maintaining control and steady breathing.

1. Lie face down on a stability ball, hands on the floor, legs extended straight. | 2. Engage glutes and lower back, raising legs until aligned with your torso. | 3. Slowly lower legs back down without touching the ground, maintaining core engagement. Repeat.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Half Kneeling Goblet Romanian Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Place one knee on a bench and hold a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place one knee on a bench and hold a dumbbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place one knee on a bench. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Half Kneeling Goblet Romanian Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Place one knee on a bench and hold a kettlebell in a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place one knee on a bench and hold a kettlebell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Grab the bar and hang, your body still and your legs straight. | 2. Slowly draw your knees up to your chest | 3. Once you have raised your knees as high as possible, lower your legs and repeat. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise. | 4. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise.
1. Start in a kneeling position with your hands planted on the ground. | 2. Pick your knees up off the ground. Hold in this position with a flat back.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your hands further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your arms extended over head. | 2. Pick your upper back and your legs off the ground. Your body should be in a banana shape. | 3. Hold in this position.

1. Lay on your back with your arms palms down on either side. | 2. Keep your legs together and as straight as possible. | 3. Slowly raise your legs to a 90 angle, pause at this position, or as high as you can reach your legs, and then slowly lower your legs back down. | 4. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise.

1. Hold the Ab Roller with both hands and kneel on the floor with your feet up and crossed. | 2. Slowly roll the ab roller straight forward, stretching your body into a straight position. | 3. After a pause at the stretched position, start pulling yourself back to the starting position. This should be a slow and controlled movement.

1. To perform a bodyweight mountain climber, start in a plank position with your hands placed directly under your shoulders. | 2. Bring your right knee towards your chest, keeping your foot close to your hand. Quickly switch legs, bringing your left knee towards your chest. | 3. Continue this movement, alternating legs, at a quick pace for a set amount of time or repetitions.

1. Start in a bench press position with your legs elevated. Try to keep your knees with a slight bend in them. | 2. Unrack the bar then initiate the rep. | 3. Bring the bar to your torso and tap your ribcage before pressing back to the ceiling.
1. Place your feet in the TRX stirrups and get in to a hand plank position. | 2. Pull your knees to your chest and flex your abs.

1. Start in a plank position with the TRX straps adjusted to mid-calf length. Place your feet in the TRX stirrups. | 2. Keep your abs engaged, and bring one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended behind you. | 3. Switch legs, bringing the opposite knee towards your chest while keeping your abs engaged and your back straight.
1. Place your feet in the stirrups and get in to a plank position. | 2. Pull your hips straight up toward the ceiling. | 3. Lower your hips until you're back in a plank position.
1. Stand in front of a low box. | 2. Bring one foot to the edge of the box and alternate as quickly as possible. | 3. Only lightly tap your feet to the box.
1. Place forearms on medicine ball, extend legs. | 2. Maintain straight body position for desired time.
1. Stand in front of a low box. | 2. Bring one foot to the edge of the box and alternate as quickly as possible. | 3. Only lightly tap your feet to the box.
1. Stand next to Bosu, step up and over it. | 2. Repeat, moving laterally side to side. | 3. Keep a steady pace, engaging core muscles.
1. Lie on your back. | 2. Bend knees, hands behind head. | 3. Twist torso, touch elbow to opposite knee. Repeat.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your elbows further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Sit in a v position. | 2. Pull legs and torso together. | 3. Extend back into the starting position.
1. Place your feet on the rower seat and get in to a hand plank position. | 2. Pull your knees to your chest and flex your abs.
1. Place your feet on the rower seat and get in to a plank position. | 2. Pull your hips straight up toward the ceiling. | 3. Lower your hips until you're back in a plank position.
1. Put a hip thrust pad on the smith machine bar at neck height. Put both arms over the bar and pull your feet off the ground. | 2. Pull your knees to your chest and flex your abs.

Exercise Name: Smith Machine Reverse Crunch Hip Raise
Instructions: 1. Lay flat on the ground. With your feet on the bar. | 2. Lift your hips off the ground.
1. Do a light hop and split your stance. | 2. Land lightly on your toes, and then bring the opposing leg forward.
1. Bring one leg forward and then the other. | 2. Bring the original leg backwards and then the other.

1. While seated on a bench, place your palms on the bench by your sides | 2. Palm placement should allow room for the fingers to grip the edge of the bench | 3. Try to lift your bodyweight off the bench by pushing the palms into the bench | 4. Lockout your elbows and repeat or hold isometrically

1. While seated on a bench, place your palms on the bench by your sides | 2. Palm placement should allow room for the fingers to grip the edge of the bench | 3. Try to lift your bodyweight off the bench by pushing the palms into the bench | 4. Lockout your elbows and hold isometrically

1. Lie on your back. Raise your legs but bend your knees | 2. Keep a 90 angle at hips and knees. Lower your toes to the ground without bending your knees | 3. Make sure you maintain a flat lower back against the ground throughout the movement.
1. Lie on your back, arms by sides, legs straight. | 2. Lift one leg to a 45-degree angle. | 3. Lower leg, lift opposite leg; alternate smoothly.
1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat on the floor. | 2. Raise both knees towards your chest. | 3. Lower back down without touching the floor; repeat for desired reps.
1. Grip bar, hang with arms extended, body straight. | 2. Engage core, lift knees towards chest. | 3. Lower legs back down, maintain controlled movement.
1. Grip bar, hang with arms extended, body straight. | 2. Engage core, lift knees towards chest. | 3. Hold that position for the specified amount of time.

1. To perform a bodyweight mountain climber, start in a plank position with your hands placed directly under your shoulders. | 2. Bring your right knee towards your chest, keeping your foot close to your hand. Quickly switch legs, bringing your left knee towards your chest. | 3. Continue this movement, alternating legs, at a slow pace for a set amount of time or repetitions.

1. Start in a plank position with your feet on a stability ball and hands on the floor. | 2. Engage your core and tuck your knees toward your chest, rolling the ball forward carefully. | 3. Extend your legs back to the starting position, maintaining balance and control throughout the movement.
1. Place your feet on the ball and get in to a plank position. | 2. Pull your hips straight up toward the ceiling. | 3. Lower your hips until you're back in a plank position.

1. Lay flat on your back with your knees bent and your feet flat on the ground, about a foot from your lower back. | 2. Place your fingertips on your temples with your palms facing out. | 3. Draw your belly into the base of your spine to engage the muscles, then raise your head and shoulders off the floor. Return to starting position and repeat.
1. Start in a kneeling position with your hands planted on the ground. | 2. Pick your knees up off the ground. Hold in this position with a flat back.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your hands further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your arms extended over head. | 2. Pick your upper back and your legs off the ground. Your body should be in a banana shape. | 3. Hold in this position.

1. Hold the bar with a slightly wider than shoulder width grip. Push the bar up toward the ceiling and maintain that elbow extension. | 2. Flex your abs and sit-up. Aim to get your torso vertical while maintaining the barbell overhead.

1. Use a double handle attachment and set the cable all the way to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps forward then fall into a kneeling position. | 3. Push your hips back and flex your abs, then push hips forward until in the starting position.

1. Hold the Ab Roller with both hands and kneel on the floor with your feet up and crossed. | 2. Slowly roll the ab roller straight forward, stretching your body into a straight position. | 3. After a pause at the stretched position, start pulling yourself back to the starting position. This should be a slow and controlled movement.

1. Lay flat on your back with straight legs and hold the kettle bell above your chest at arms length. | 2. Draw your belly into the base of your spine to engage the muscles, then raise your head and shoulders off the floor with the kettlebell raised at arms length above your chest. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your spine neutral. Extend you arms so your fists are pointed at the ceiling. | 2. Sit-up by flexing your abs. Continue to reach for the ceiling for the entire rep.

1. Lay flat on the ground and hold the end of the bar with your arms extended. | 2. Raise your back off the ground until you are sitting at a 90 degree angle. | 3. Then lower slowly back to the floor.
1. Lie facing partner, knees bent. | 2. Sit up, toss medicine ball to partner. | 3. Catch and lower down. Repeat for desired reps.
1. Place forearms on medicine ball, extend legs. | 2. Maintain straight body position for desired time.
1. Lift medicine ball overhead. | 2. Slam ball down to ground with force.
1. Lie on back, bosu elevated toward the ceiling. | 2. Sit up, engaging core muscles. | 3. Lower back down to complete one situp.
1. Lie on your back. | 2. Bend knees, hands behind head. | 3. Twist torso, touch elbow to opposite knee. Repeat.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your elbows further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Lie flat, knees bent. | 2. Lift upper body. | 3. Lower back down

1. Use a rope attachment and set the cable all the way to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps forward then fall into a kneeling position. | 3. Push your hips back and flex your abs, then push hips forward until in the starting position.

1. Use a rope attachment and set the cable all the way to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps forward then fall into a kneeling position. | 3. Push your hips back and flex your abs, then push hips forward until in the starting position.

1. Set up the Smith machine bar at an appropriate height. | 2. Lie on your back beneath the bar, gripping it with your hands. | 3. Engage your core, lift your upper body toward the bar, and exhale. | 4. Lower your upper body back down in a controlled manner, inhaling.

1. Adjust the machine in accordance with your height and place your shoulders underneath the padded lever. | 2. The balls of your feet should be supporting your weight on the calve block, your heels extending off of it. | 3. Extend your heels upwards while keeping your knees stationary, and pause at the contracted position. | 4. Slowly return to the starting position. Repeat.

1. Get comfortable on the machine, then place your lower thighs beneath the padded lever. Place your toes and the balls of your feet onto the foot supports. | 2. Prevent the weight from slipping forward by gripping the handles, and release the safety bar. Lower the weight until your calves are extended. | 3. Push your heels up to lift the padded lever and hold the contracted position, then slowly lower back down to the starting position. Repeat.

1. Standing straight with a kettlebell in one hand, lift the same foot as the side without the kettlebell off the floor. | 2. Raise your heel upwards while keeping your knees stationary. | 3. Pause when your heels are fully extended and then slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Standing straight with a kettlebell in each hand, raise your heels upwards while keeping your knees stationary. | 2. Pause when your heels are fully extended and then slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Sitting comfortably on a chair with your core stomach muscles engaged, place your feet on the floor. | 2. Place the kettlebell on your legs, just above the knees and raise your heels upwards off the floor. | 3. Pause when your heels are fully extended and then slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Balance the balls of your feet on the platform, leaning forward to use the wall to assist with balance. Engage your calves so that your feet are flat before beginning the stretch. | 2. Lower the heels of your feet towards the ground and pause, then push through the balls of your feet like you are standing tip toe, pausing at the apex of the stretch. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. With both feet flat on the ground, place one leg in front of your shoulder, your other leg should mirror this position behind your other shoulder. In the starting position both of your knees should be straight. | 2. Place the palms of your hands against the wall at shoulder height in front of you, lean towards the wall and bend your front leg at the knee while keeping your back leg straight. | 3. Pause at the apex of the stretch and return to the starting position. Switch the position of your legs and repeat.

1. Place the ball of your foot against the wall with your heel on the ground. Place your hands on the wall in front of your shoulders. | 2. Keeping your knee straight, slowly lean towards the wall, pause for a few seconds when you feel the stretch extending through your calf muscle. | 3. Return to the starting position, and repeat the stretch with your other leg.

1. Point your toes into the floor. | 2. Slowly walk forwards and backward | 3. Keep your heels in the air as long as possible while walking. | 4. It may be beneficial to do this last at the end of your workout.

1. Balance on the balls of your feet on the platform or plates, leaning forward to use the wall to assist with balance. | 2. Lower the heels of your feet towards the ground and pause, then push through the balls of your feet like you are standing tip toe, pausing at the apex of the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.
1. Walk forward and push your toe into the ground | 2. Lift you heel off the ground each step and tense your calf muscle | 3. Repeat on each leg and walk forward slowly

1. Place the bar on your back | 2. Start with feet flat on the ground | 3. Extend your heels upwards while keeping your knees stationary, and pause at the contracted position. | 4. Slowly return to the starting position. Repeat.

1. Use a straight bar or ez bar attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Walk a few steps back. | 3. Pull your heels straight up until you feel a contraction in your calves and then back to original position.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. | 2. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 3. Lean back slightly. Raise your heels straight up and down

1. Stand tall with your feet on the ground. You can put the the balls of your feet on top of a plate to extend the range of motion. | 2. Imagine you have a string attached to your heels and pull your heels up toward the ceiling.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. | 2. Shift your weight onto the balls of your feet and raise stay flat footed. Using your calf muscles, mimic a jumping motion but don't leave the floor. | 3. Explode onto your tip toes and hold for a second. | 4. Bring your heels back to the floor then initiate the next rep.

1. Start by sitting on a bench with a barbell resting on your knees. Your feet should be flat on the ground, about hip-width apart. | 2. Place your hands on the barbell for support, and lift your heels off the ground. | 3. Hold this position for a moment, then slowly lower your heels back to the ground.

1. Begin by standing on a raised surface (such as a step or box) with the balls of your feet on the edge of the surface and your heels hanging off. Hold a barbell across your upper back and shoulders, using an overhand grip. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels up as high as you can. | 3. Lower your heels back down to the starting position, allowing your calves to stretch.

1. Start by sitting on a bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and a dumbbell in each hand placed on each leg. | 2. From this starting position, raise your heels as high as you can by pushing up through your toes. | 3. Slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Hold the TRX straps under your arms and the handles in your armpits. | 2. Lean forward against the straps. | 3. Keep your body straight and initiate the calf raise by raising your heels off the ground.

1. Begin in a downward-facing dog position with your hands shoulder-width apart and your feet hip-width apart. | 2. Lift your right foot off the mat and place your right toes on top of your left heel. | 3. Press your palms and fingers firmly into the mat and lift your hips up towards the ceiling, deepening the stretch in your hamstrings and calves. | 4. Hold the pose for a few breaths, and then release by slowly walking your hands back out to a downward-facing dog position.

1. Start standing with a flat and vertical block on the matt | 2. Bend forward, placing hand on vertical block, and front of foot on the flat block. | 3. Press the bottom of your foot towards the ground, and repeat on each side.

1. Begin in a downward-facing dog position with your hands shoulder-width apart and your feet hip-width apart. | 2. Walk your feet towards your hands, bending your knees as needed to allow your heels to touch the mat. | 3. Press your palms and fingers into the mat and lift your hips up towards the ceiling to deepen the stretch in your hamstrings and calves. | 4. Hold the pose for a few breaths, and then release by slowly walking your hands back out to a downward-facing dog position.

1. Stand facing the barbell, holding the end of the barbell close to your chest in both hands with your elbows tucked in to your sides. | 2. Drive though the balls of your feet to raise your heels off the ground, squeezing your calves, with a focus on making sure your ankles do not turn out or in. | 3. Lower your heels back down to the ground and repeat for the desired number of reps.
1. Stand on Bosu with feet hip-width apart. | 2. Rise up on toes, squeezing calves. | 3. Lower heels back down to complete one rep.
1. Sit on the bench with the bar attachment over your legs. | 2. Raise your heels up to the ceiling.
1. Hold the two handles and stand tall. | 2. Raise your heels as high as possible.

1. Use a straight bar or ez bar attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Walk a few steps back. | 3. Pull your heels straight up until you feel a contraction in your calves and then back to original position.

1. Standing straight with a kettlebell in a goblet position, raise your heels upwards while keeping your knees stationary. | 2. Pause when your heels are fully extended and then slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Start by sitting on a bench with a barbell resting on your knees. Your feet should be flat on the ground, about hip-width apart. | 2. Exercise Name: Cardio In In Out Out Shuffle
Instructions: 1. Start with your feet side by side. | 2. Bring one foot laterally, then the other. | 3. Return the first foot to its starting position, then the other.
1. Stand on the edge of a step (on the balls of your feet) | 2. Support your weight in this position for the given amount of time | 3. You should feel your calves working

Exercise Name: Calf Raise 1C Bilateral Eccentric From Box
Instructions: 1. While standing on the edge of a step, shift your weight on your toes while quickly raising the heals | 2. Hold the top position for a split second and then very slowly lower your heels below the level of the step until you start feeling a stretch in the calves | 3. Try to avoid muscular (calf) contraction while raising the heels and then exert muscular contraction on the eccentric phase | 4. Pause on both ends of range

1. Use the edge of a step to place the balls of your feet on | 2. Raise the heels, before lowering them below the level of the step, or until you feel a stretch in the calves | 3. Try pausing on both ends of range for a split second | 4. You should feel your calves working

1. From the standing position, shift your weight onto the balls of your feet | 2. Raise the heels off the ground, and hold the position for the duration specified | 3. You should feel your calves working

1. Raise both heels off the ground, shift your weight onto the working leg while the opposite leg is suspended. | 2. Hold the top position for a split second and then very slowly lower your heel to the ground | 3. Try to avoid muscular (calf) contraction while raising the heel and then exert muscular contraction on the eccentric phase

1. From the standing position, shift your weight onto onto one foot | 2. Raise the heel of the working leg off the ground, before lowering it back to the ground | 3. Do not rest at the bottom. As soon as you feel your heel touch the ground, repeat the movement | 4. You should feel your calf working

Exercise Name: Calf Raise 2C Eccentric Unilateral From Box
Instructions: 1. While standing on the edge of a step, use both legs to raise your heels, before shifting your weight onto the working leg | 2. Hold the top position for a split second and then very slowly lower your heel below the level of the step or until you start feeling a stretch in the calf | 3. Try to avoid muscular (calf) contraction while raising the heels and then exert muscular contraction on the eccentric phase

1. Use the edge of a step to place the balls of one foot on | 2. Raise the heel, before lowering it below the level of the step, or until you feel a stretch in the calf | 3. Try pausing on both ends of range for a split second

1. From the standing position, bend your knees till you get to a squated or semi-squated position | 2. Maintain the squat while raising both heels off the ground | 3. Hold the position for a split second before lowering your heels again | 4. Do not rest at the bottom. As soon as you feel your heels touch the ground, repeat the movement

1. From the standing position, bend your knees till you get to a squated or semi-squated position. Be close to a pole or squat rack to use for balance | 2. Maintain the squat while shifting your weight onto the working leg and raising the other off the ground | 3. Raise your heel off the ground | 4. Hold the position for a split second before lowering your heel again | 5. Do not rest at the bottom. As soon as you feel your heel touch the ground, repeat the movement

1. From the standing position, shift your weight onto the balls of one foot. | 2. Raise your heel off the ground, and hold the position for the duration specified | 3. You should feel your calf working.

1. Stand on a box. From the standing position, shift your weight onto the balls of one foot. | 2. Lower the heels of your feet toward the ground, and hold the position for the duration specified | 3. You should feel your calf stretching.
1. Stand on the edge of a box, knees extended. | 2. Let your weight push your heels towards the ground. | 3. You should feel your calves being stretched.
1. Get yourself in the pushup position. | 2. Straighten your knees and try to push one heel down towards the ground. | 3. Cross your other leg over the top to apply extra pressure to the stretch.
1. Stand on the edge of a box, knees extended. | 2. Bend one leg while allowing the weight to push the heel of your straight leg towards the ground. | 3. You should feel your calves being stretched.

1. Stand by a wall but not too close. | 2. Place the palms on the wall and extend one leg behind you, while slightly bending the front leg. | 3. Push the wall in order to drive the heel of the extended leg into the ground till you feel a stretch in your calf.
1. Sit on the floor using your palms or elbows to lean back onto. | 2. Attach one end of a band around your toes and hold onto the other. | 3. Point and flex the toes against the resistance.

1. Start with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Quickly tap your feet while moving laterally.
1. Start with a wide stance. | 2. Shuffle sideways for a specified distance while maintaining a quarter squat position.

1. Stand feet shoulder-width, knees slightly bent, arms behind you, eyes forward. | 2. Swing arms backward, squat deeply, loading legs for explosive power. | 3. Swing arms, explode forward, extend legs mid-air, land softly on both feet.

1. Stand feet shoulder-width, knees slightly bent, arms behind you, eyes forward. | 2. Swing arms backward, squat deeply, loading legs for explosive power. | 3. Swing arms, explode forward, extend legs mid-air, land softly on both feet. | 4. Shuffle back to the starting position.
1. Quickly tap each foot to the ground.

1. Stand with feet together, arms in front at chest level, palms touching. | 2. Spread legs wide, simultaneously swing arms out to sides, palms facing forward. | 3. Jump back to starting position, bringing arms together again quickly. Repeat rhythmically.

1. Set up two cones at a specified distance. | 2. Stay low and sprint quickly to the second cone. | 3. Hinge forward and tap the cone, then turn and sprint to the original cone. | 4. Repeat for the desired time or reps.
1. Pick up one leg off the ground. | 2. Hop forward and backward quickly while staying on your toes.
1. Pick up one leg off the ground. | 2. Hop laterally quickly while staying on your toes.

Exercise Name: Cardio Skater To Single Leg Burpee
Instructions: 1. Leap sideways, land on right foot, left leg behind to the side. | 2. Drop into a single-leg burpee, right leg only, hands to ground. | 3. Return to standing on right, leap sideways to left, repeat with left leg.

1. Stand tall, feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent, ready to move. | 2. Quickly drive knees up towards chest, alternating legs, pumping arms in rhythm. | 3. Gradually speed up, maintaining high knees and arm movement, breathe steadily.

1. Stand close to a wall on a narrow, staggered stance (toes of the back leg should be at the same level as the heel of the front leg). | 2. Keep your weight on the back leg as you bend your knees. | 3. Hold the position for the prescribed duration.

Instructions: 1. Start with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. | 2. Shift your weight onto the balls of your feet and raise stay flat footed. Using your calf muscles, mimic a jumping motion but don't leave the platform. | 3. Explode onto your toes and hold for a second.

Instructions: 1. Adjust the machine in accordance with your height. | 2. The balls of your feet should be supporting your weight on the bottom of the platform, your heels extending off of it. | 3. Extend your heels upwards while keeping your knees stationary, and pause at the contracted position. | 4. Slowly return to the starting position. Repeat.

Pause when your heels are fully extended and then slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Instructions: 1. Standing straight with a kettlebell in one hand, lift the opposing foot off the floor. | 2. Raise your heel upwards while keeping your knees stationary. | 3. Pause when your heels are fully extended and then slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Get yourself in the pushup position. | 2. Straighten your knees and try to push one heel down towards the ground. | 3. Cross your other leg over the top to apply extra pressure to the stretch.
