Exercise Name: Core Stability Regression Crosslateral Limb Raise Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Tap the hand of the working arm on the ground to find your balance. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 3. Hold for a split second and then try to bring your elbow to your opposite knee by driving both towards the centre of the body. | 4. Spine might curve slightly but you should not shift your hips during the movement.
1. Sit on a bench. | 2. Cross the ankle of one leg over the knee of the other. | 3. Push your knee away from you and lean forward for a specified amount of time.
1. Stand on a bosu ball and balance on one leg. | 2. Try to bend and extend the knee of the supporting leg (single leg squat) while keeping your balance.
1. Stand in front of a bench or box. Lift one leg in front you supporting yourself on the other leg. | 2. Try to sit on the box in a controlled manner. Use both legs to stand back up

1. From the standing position lower your body into a squat. | 2. Shift your weight onto one leg (the other is still in contact with the ground for balance). | 3. Use the loaded leg to lift your body into standing position.

1. From the standing position shift your weight onto the working leg and keep the other one suspended behind you | 2. Tilt at the hips and lean over as you are bending the loaded knee | 3. Bring your back knee close to the ground before standing back up.

1. Place a box behind you and one foot on it. Keep your chest up and the back straight | 2. Tilt at the hips to perform a deadlift. Use the box for balance and support | 3. Make sure you straighten your back leg when performing the deadlift. | 4. As you get comfortable with the movement, try to lift the leg off the box when you reach the end range of the deadlift.

Exercise Name: Side Step On And Off Box
Instructions: 1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart. Your feet should be slightly pointed outward, and your shoulders should be down and relaxed. | 2. Place a step or box beside you, and step up onto it with one foot. Then bring the other foot to the box.
1. Sit on your heels and reach out your arms on a box or foam roller while pressing the chest towards the ground.

1. Attach a band to a fixed point. Wrap the loose end of the band around your ankle. | 2. Face the attachment point. Shift you weight onto one leg (use balancing aids if needed). | 3. Extend your working leg and maintain the position.

1. Start on the 4 point position (on all fours). | 2. Straighten and raise one leg till it is parallel to the ground. | 3. Make sure your spine remains in a neutral position. | 4. If you feel your lower back stiff or sore when performing this exercise, ask a trainer or therapist to guide you through.
1. Sit on your heels and reach out your arms on the floor while pressing the chest towards the ground.

Exercise Name: Prone Single Leg Hip Extension Hold
Instructions: 1. Lie on your stomach. | 2. Secure your lower back by tilting your hips backwards. | 3. Raise one leg and hold the position for the specified duration.

Exercise Name: Hip Extension External Rotation Pulses 4Pt Position
Instructions: 1. Start on the 4 point position (on all fours). | 2. Straighten and raise one leg till it is parallel to the ground and externally rotate the leg (knee aims out). | 3. Perform small upward movements while maintaining the externally rotated position of the knee. | 4. Make sure your spine remains in a neutral position.

1. Start on the 4 point position (on all fours). | 2. Straighten and raise one leg till it is parallel to the ground. | 3. Maintain the position but externally rotate the leg (knee aims out) | 4. If you feel your lower back stiff or sore when performing this exercise, ask a trainer or therapist to guide you through.

1. Start on the 4 point position (on all fours). | 2. Straighten and raise one leg till it is parallel to the ground. | 3. Make sure your spine remains in a neutral position. | 4. If you feel your lower back stiff or sore when performing this exercise, ask a trainer or therapist to guide you through.

Exercise Name: Glute Piriformis Mobilisation 1 Floor Seated Lacrosse Ball
Instructions: 1. Sit on a massage ball distributing your weight between feet, palm and glute. | 2. Lean to the side and try to find a tight/painful spot while wiggling on the ball. | 3. Follow the pain as it shifts around your glute.
1. Sit on a bench. | 2. Cross the ankle of one leg over the knee of the other. | 3. Pull your knee toward you and hold for a specified amount of time.
1. Sit on a bench. | 2. Cross the ankle of one leg over the knee of the other. | 3. Press the knee of the crossed leg outwards.

1. Lie on your back with bent knees and feet on the floor. | 2. Cross the ankle of your one leg over the knee of the other. | 3. Reach in between your legs, grabbing the thigh of the leg that is still on the ground. | 4. Pull that leg towards your chest.

Exercise Name: Glute Stretch Knee Pull Dynamic Standing
Instructions: 1. Stand up straight with a good form. | 2. Alternate between pulling your knees towards you chest. | 3. Make sure you maintain an upright posture throughout the movement.
1. Lie on your back. | 2. Bend one knee and pull it towards your chest. | 3. Maintain the stretch for a few seconds before swapping legs.

1. Stand up straight with a good form. | 2. Send your hips back and start tilting the upper body. | 3. Maintain a straight back as you aim for your toes. | 4. Your range depends on your hamstring flexibility.

1. Stand up straight with a good form. | 2. Send your hips back and start tilting the upper body. | 3. Maintain a straight back as you aim for your toes. | 4. Lower the bar to the floor by bending your knees and keeping your back straight.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 5 Crosslateral Limb Raise Into Knee Elbow Tuck Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 3. Hold for a split second and then try to bring your elbow to your opposite knee by driving both towards the centre of the body. | 4. Spine might curve slightly but you should not shift your hips during the movement.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 4 Crosslateral Limb Raise Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Maintain a toe placement roughly at shoulder width (the wider the leg stance the easier the exercise - the narrower the stance the more difficult it becomes. | 3. Tap your opposite shoulder with your fingertips. | 4. Do not tilt or shift your hips. Do not round or arch your back.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 1 Crosslateral Limb Raise 4Pt Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to the 4 point position (on all fours) | 2. 90 angles at hips and shoulder and neutral spine | 3. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 4. Hold for a split second and bring back to starting position
1. Balance on one leg | 2. Try to tap your targets with the toes of your suspended leg | 3. The goal is to maintain balance while moving your leg towards the target and back

1. Lay on your side with knees bent and a loop band around them. 90 angle at hips, knees and feet. | 2. Externally rotate the top knee without dropping your hip back | 3. Hold for a split second (or as indicated by therapist/trainer) and return to starting position without resting on the under knee

Exercise Name: Clamshells 3 Internal External Rotations Side Lying
Instructions: 1. Lay on your side with knees bent. 90 angle at hips, knees and feet. | 2. Lift your top leg a few centimeters off of the under leg (15-20cm) | 3. Externally rotate the top knee without dropping your hip back. | 4. Hold for a split second (or as indicated by therapist/trainer) and then internally rotate the knee

1. Lay on your side with knees bent. 90 angle at hips, knees and feet. | 2. Lift your top leg slightly so no support is coming from the under leg. | 3. Externally rotate the top knee without dropping your hip back | 4. Hold for a split second (or as indicated by therapist/trainer) and return to starting position

1. Lay on your side with knees bent. 90 angle at hips, knees and feet. | 2. Externally rotate the top knee without dropping your hip back | 3. Hold for a split second (or as indicated by therapist/trainer) and return to starting position without resting on the under knee
1. Lie on your back and flatten you lower back against the ground | 2. Pull one knee towards your chest and then across your body till it forces your lower back into a rotated position.

1. Start from the standing position. Lower your body into a semi-squatted position | 2. Push off the ground with two legs to perform the jump and land on the box. Jump off the box in the same manner | 3. Land on one leg, on the ground, making sure to absorb the impact by bending the knee as much as needed. | 4. Absorb the impact by bending the knees when landing. Try to maintain your balance

Exercise Name: Jump Off Box Single Leg Landing
Instructions: 1. Start from the standing position on a box. Lower your body into a semi-squatted position | 2. Push off the box with two legs to perform the jump. | 3. Land on one leg, on the ground, making sure to absorb the impact by bending the knee as much as needed.

1. Start from the standing position. Lower your body into a semi-squatted position. | 2. Push off the ground with two legs to perform the jump. | 3. Land on one leg, making sure to absorb the impact by bending the knee as much as needed.

1. From the standing position raise one knee till the thigh is parallel to the ground. | 2. Bring the knee to your side without rotating the hips. | 3. The knee drives the movement and the ankle lags slightly behind.

1. Attach a band to an anchor point and face away from the anchor point. | 2. Loop the other end of the band around your hips. | 3. While keeping your knees extended, shift your hips back, then forward against the band.

1. From the standing position perform a walkout (use to palms to "walk" into the push up position). | 2. Bring your leg to the side and place the foot by your palm. | 3. Rotate towards the ceiling and then towards the ground, pressing the hips towards the ground.

Exercise Name: Abductor Leg Raise Side Lying Isometric
Instructions: 1. Stabilise yourself in the side lying position, using your upper arm and under leg | 2. Raise your upper leg till it is parallel to the ground and hold isometrically for the specified amount of time. | 3. Feel your bum (glute med) and the lateral line of your leg worked

1. Stabilise yourself in the side lying position, using your upper arm and under leg | 2. Raise your upper leg till it is parallel to the ground. This is your starting point. | 3. Raise your leg and lower back to parallel for the specified amount of reps and/or sets | 4. Feel your bum (glute med) and the lateral line of your leg worked
1. Stand tall, hinge at hips, and reach hands to the floor. | 2. Walk hands forward into a plank position. | 3. Walk feet towards hands and repeat the motion.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Maintain the natural arch in your back, squeezing your shoulder blades and raising your chest. | 2. Grip the bar across your shoulders and support it on your upper back. Unwrack the bar by straightening your legs, and take a step back. | 3. Bend your knees as you lower the weight without altering the form of your back until your hips are below your knees. | 4. Raise the bar back to starting position, lift with your legs and exhale at the top.

1. Find a box or bench that is roughly knee height or a few inches lower. (The lower the box is the lower the mobility requirement). | 2. You can either place your toes or the top of your foot on the box. Point your front foot forward or slightly turned outwards and break at the knees and hips simultaneously. | 3. Aim to get your front leg to hit parallel depth (hamstring parallel with the ground) or lower. | 4. The further forward your front foot is, the longer the Range of Motion is at your hips. The further back your front foot is, the longer the ROM at your knees.

1. Sit on the ground with a bench behind you. Have the barbell over your legs just above your hips. | 2. Lean back against the bench so that your shoulders are resting upon it, stretch your arms out to either side using the bench as support. | 3. Raise the weight by driving through your feet and extending your hips upwards. Support the weight with your shoulders and feet. | 4. Slowly extend as far as you can, and then slowly return to the starting position.

1. Stand with a barbell at your shins with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Bend forward at your hips and keep your knees as fully extended as possible. | 3. Grab the barbell and then extend your hips while maintaining a straight back. | 4. From the standing position, lower the weight in a controlled manner. | 5. You can either lower the weight to the floor or before you touch the floor, depending on your mobility.

1. Stand facing the barbell while holding the end of the bar at your side with one hand. | 2. With the leg on the same side of your body as the barbell, lunge backward and across your body at a 45 degree angle while keeping your weight on your front heel to lower your back knee gently to the ground. | 3. Drive through your front heel as you step back to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Start facing the barbell while holding the end of the bar in the goblet position in front of your chest with your elbows close to your sides. | 2. Step backward and across your body with one leg at a 45 degree angle while keeping your weight on your front heel to gently lower your back knee to the ground. | 3. Drive through your front heel as you step back up and to the starting position. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Step your left foot behind and to the right of your right foot, crossing it behind your right leg. | 3. Bend your knees and lower your hips down and back, as if you were about to sit in a chair. | 4. Push through your right heel to straighten your right leg and return to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso. | 2. Step back and across the body with the right foot, bending both legs to lower into a lunge position. | 3. Push through the front foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Repeat on the other side by stepping back and across with the left foot. | 5. Continue alternating sides for desired reps.

1. Lie on your back on the floor with your knees bent and your feet flat on the ground. Place a barbell across your hips and grasp it with both hands. | 2. Keeping your arms straight, push through your heels to lift your hips off the ground and raise the barbell. | 3. Hold the bridge position for a moment, then slowly lower your hips back to the starting position.

1. Place your shoulder blades against a box or bench that won't move. | 2. Both your feet should be planted and your heels should not come off the floor. Point your toes forward. | 3. Break at the hips. Seek the longest range of motion possible. Focus on the top end of the movement. Push your hips as high as possible on each rep.

1. Setup a landmine with your back on a box. | 2. Lay the end of the bar over your hip. | 3. Push your hips toward the ceiling until you feel a contraction, then bring your hips back toward the floor.

1. Grab the end of the landmine and stand perpendicular to the bar. | 2. Lift your inside leg and keep your outside leg planted. | 3. Push your hips back keeping your knees mostly extended. When you feel the stretch in your hams, push your hips forward until you are standing upright.
1. Hold the end of the bar in front of you. | 2. Pop your hips, pull your elbows up to the ceiling, and get underneath the bar.

1. Hold the end of the bar in a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees. | 3. Reach at least parallel with the ground before pushing through your heels back to the starting position.

1. Stand in a staggered position. With the back leg bent and the front mostly extended. | 2. Push your hips back until you feel a stretch through your front hamstring. | 3. Push your hips back forward until you are standing.
1. Stand with a wide stance and straddle over the end of the bar. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees, and grab the bar. | 3. Stand up with the bar.

1. Hold the bar with a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and sink into a squat. | 3. Push through your heels and squat back up. Use the momentum you generate at the legs to push the bar over head. | 4. Let the bar return to the goblet position before starting the next rep.

1. Stand in front of a box. | 2. *Start with a low box if this is your first time* | 3. Sink into a quarter of half squat and then pop your hips forward. | 4. Try to land in the middle of the box as softly as possible to minimise impact on your joints.

1. Stand on top of a box. Step off of the box and land on the floor. | 2. Land as softly as possible. Squat as you land to minimise impact on your joints. | 3. Go straight into another hop after you've landed. This will help you learn to absorb impact.
1. Setup two boxes. One to jump on and one to sit. | 2. Go from a seated position and pop your hips forward forcefully. | 3. Jump and land on the box softly.
1. Stand with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Jump onto your box and land with one foot. | 3. Try to land in the middle of the box and land as softly as possible.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding medicine ball close. | 2. Squat down, keeping ball close to head and chest. | 3. Stand back up, squeezing glutes. Repeat for desired reps.

Exercise Name: Medicine Ball Clean And Press Slam
Instructions: 1. Hold the medicine ball with an overhand grip. | 2. Lift the ball explosively, clean it to shoulder height. | 3. Press the ball overhead, then slam it to the ground.
1. Hold medicine ball overhead. | 2. Step back into lunge position. | 3. Return to starting position. Repeat on other leg.
1. Toss medicine ball up, catch with both hands. | 2. Repeat toss and catch for desired reps.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Maintain the natural arch in your back and put the bar on your back. Squeezing your shoulder blades and raise your chest. | 2. Grip the bar across your shoulders and support it on your upper back. Unwrack the smith machine by straightening your legs. | 3. Bend your knees as you lower the weight without altering the form of your back until your hips are below your knees. | 4. Raise the bar back to starting position, lift with your legs and exhale at the top.

1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set to the bottom of the crossover machine. | 2. Break at the knee, push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Sit on the ground with a bench behind you. Place both feet on a plate or low box. Have the barbell over your legs just above your hips. | 2. Lean back against the bench so that your shoulders are resting upon it, stretch your arms out to either side using the bench as support. | 3. Raise the weight by driving through your feet and extending your hips upwards. Support the weight with your shoulders and feet. | 4. Slowly extend as far as you can, and then slowly return to the starting position.

1. Sit on the ground with a bench behind you. Place both feet on a plate or low box. Have the dumbbell over your legs just above your hips. | 2. Lean back against the bench so that your shoulders are resting upon it, stretch your arms out to either side using the bench as support. | 3. Raise the weight by driving through your feet and extending your hips upwards. Support the weight with your shoulders and feet. | 4. Slowly extend as far as you can, and then slowly return to the starting position.

1. Sit on the ground with a bench behind you. Have the bar over your legs just above your hips. | 2. Lean back against the bench so that your shoulders are resting upon it, stretch your arms out to either side using the bench as support. | 3. Raise the weight by driving through your feet and extending your hips upwards. Support the weight with your shoulders and feet. | 4. Slowly extend as far as you can, and then slowly return to the starting position.
1. Hold a dumbbell at your chest, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step one leg diagonally back into a lunge. | 3. Alternate legs, keeping your chest up and core engaged.
1. Hold a kettlebell at your chest, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step one leg diagonally back into a lunge. | 3. Alternate legs, keeping your chest up and core engaged.

1. Grab the handles, place one knee on the pad, and the foot of the working leg on the foot plate. | 2. Push your working leg back until you feel your glute contract, then return to the starting position without resting the weights.

1. Sit on the floor, place upper back on a stability ball, feet flat, knees bent. | 2. Drive hips upward by squeezing glutes, forming a straight line from shoulders to knees. | 3. Lower hips slowly without touching the floor, maintaining core engagement, then repeat.

1. Stand with a barbell at your shins with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Bend forward at your hips and keep your knees as fully extended as possible. | 3. Grab the barbell and then extend your hips while maintaining a straight back. | 4. From the standing position, lower the weight in a controlled manner. | 5. You can either lower the weight to the floor or before you touch the floor, depending on your mobility.

1. Lay down on the machine, placing your legs beneath the padded lever. Position your legs so that the padded lever is below your calve muscles. | 2. Support yourself by grabbing the side handles of the machine, and slowly raise the weight with your legs, toes pointed straight. | 3. Pause at the apex of the motion, then slowly return to starting position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Return to standing position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell between your legs, with your knees slightly bent. | 2. Keeping your back straight, swing the kettlebell upwards until the kettlebell is level with your chest and carefully lower. | 3. Repeat

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, lifting one foot off the floor behind you. Hold the kettlebell in the same arm as the lifted leg. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you extend your lifted leg behind you, keeping your back straight - holding out your arm to the side for balance. | 3. Return to the upright position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, shifting one foot behind you. Hold the kettlebell in both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees and keep your back straight. | 3. Return to the upright position and repeat.

1. Sit on the floor with your legs out in front of you. | 2. Reach forward to try and touch your toes. Reach as far forward as you can go. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then return to starting position.

1. Sit on the floor with one leg outstretched and the other bent at the knee, foot resting on the opposite inner thigh. | 2. Reach forward to touch the toes of the outstretched leg. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then return to starting position.
1. Stand with one foot in front of the other. | 2. Bend your rear leg as much as you can, keeping the front leg straight. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then return to starting position.

1. Lie down with your legs reaching up the wall. your bum should be slightly off the floor. | 2. Bend one leg and leave the other outstretched. | 3. Push your thigh towards the wall. | 4. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then return to starting position.

1. Stand with your feet a little past shoulder width apart with a slight bend at your knee. Place your hands behind the back of your head. | 2. Keeping your back straight, rotate your hips to bring your shoulders down towards the floor. Stop when your chest is parallel with the floor.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent and raise one leg. | 2. Without changing the bend in your knee, bend at your hips, and lower your torso until it's almost parallel to the floor. | 3. Tense your glutes and then bring yourself back to the starting position.

1. Go to your knees and ask someone to hold your ankles. | 2. Put your hands in front of you | 3. With a slight bend in your knees slowly bring your body to the ground (slower is better) | 4. Push up and reset to the starting position.

1. Start with a straight bar or ez bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back. | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement while lifting one of your legs. Then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. Compete your given amount of reps, then switch to opposite leg. | 4. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back.

1. This exercise works best with a rope attachment but can be done with anything. The attachment should be set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine, straddle the cable itself, and grab the attachment. Walk a few steps away. | 3. Break at the hips while maintaining a flat back and mostly extended knees. | 4. Push hips forward until you are back in a standing position.
1. Use an ankle attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Stand upright or try bending slightly forward. | 3. Flex at the knee and pull your ankle straight back.
1. Anchor the band at hip level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back while keeping your back flat until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings.

1. Anchor the band to the lowest point possible. Straddle the band and then grab with both hands. | 2. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 3. Push your butt back until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Then extend the hips back into the starting position.

1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Hinge until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 4. Push your hips back forward until you are in a standing position.

1. Hold the dumbbell in a goblet position. With your elbows directly under your fists. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees MOSTLY extended. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Stand with a shoulder width stance. Push your butt back while leaving your knees MOSTLY extended. | 2. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward to complete the rep. | 3. Do not push your hips all the way forward. This will hyperextend your spine. Just go to a normal standing position.

1. Place the bar on your traps. You may need a pad so the bar doesn't dig into your cervical spine. | 2. Push your hips straight back. Your knees should stay MOSTLY extended (think soft knees). Also make sure to | 3. Look for what feels like a stretch in your hamstrings. The stretch feeling means you're likely nearing the end of your Range of Motion without rounding your spine. | 4. When you feel the stretch push your hips forward until you're in a standing position.

1. Place the bar between your traps and rear delts. Pull your shoulder blades back to give the bar a shelf to sit on. | 2. Push your hips back until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. This means you're nearing the end of your Range of Motion with out rounding your spine. | 3. When you feel the stretch push your hips forward until you'e in a standing position.

1. Take a shoulder width, double overhand or mixed grip. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your chest. | 2. Bend forward at the hips keeping your back and knees straight and the kettlebell close to your chest. | 3. Return to standing position and thrust your pelvis forward.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart, with your toes pointed slightly outward. | 2. Place a barbell on the floor in front of you, with the weight plates on either side. Make sure that the bar is directly in line with your feet. | 3. Bend down and grab the barbell with an overhand grip, your hands much wider than shoulder-width apart. Keep your back straight and your shoulders down as you grip the bar. | 4. Stand up straight, lifting the barbell off the ground and pulling it toward your hips. Keep your elbows close to your body and your shoulders down as you do this. | 5. Slowly lower the barbell back to the ground, making sure to keep your back straight and your shoulders down throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart. The bar should be in a rack or box so it's lifted off the ground. | 2. Grab the barbell with an overhand grip, your hands should be much wider than shoulder-width apart. | 3. Hing forward at the hips keeping your knees mostly extended. Hinge until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you are back in a standing position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet about hip-width apart and holding a barbell in the crook of your elbows, with your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and lower your torso forward until it is nearly parallel to the ground. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and raise your body back to the starting position.
1. Lay flat on a bench with a dumbbell between your feet. | 2. Flex your knees and raise the dumbbell until the soles of your shoes are pointed at the ceiling.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Leg Single Arm Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Start by standing on one leg with a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Slowly bend at the hips and lower the dumbbell towards the ground while extending your free leg behind you. | 3. Keep your core engaged and your back straight as you lower the weight. | 4. Once the dumbbell is close to the ground, push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Leg Stiff Leg Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Start by standing on one leg with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two dumbbells. | 2. From this starting position, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbell towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 3. Once you feel a stretch in your hamstring, slowly return to the starting position. | 4. Make sure to keep your standing leg slightly bent and avoid rounding your back as you lower the dumbbell.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated on a step or weight plate. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the dumbbells towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 4. Once the dumbbells are below your knees, drive through your heels to stand back up to the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in both hands. | 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to swing the dumbbell between your legs. | 3. From this starting position, explosively extend your hips and swing the dumbbell up to chest height. | 4. Allow the momentum of the swing to carry the dumbbell back down between your legs, and then repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Exercise Name: Plate Single Leg Pinch Grip Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and facing forwards. Grip the sides of a weight plate with your palms facing down. | 2. Balance on one foot, as you raise the weight keep your arms and back straight, while you bring your other foot back towards the ground | 3. Keep four raised leg straight and in alignment with your back as you lower the plate back down to the starting position.

1. Engage your core and straighten your legs to lift the plate off the ground. | 2. Stand on one leg, keeping the other leg off the ground, while holding the plate in front of your body. | 3. Keep your back straight and maintain a neutral head position while looking straight ahead. | 4. Lower the plate back down to the ground while keeping your balance on one leg.

1. Loop the band around a sturdy anchor point such as a weightlifting rack or a door handle. | 2. Lie on your back with your heels placed inside the band. Make sure the band is centered under your heels and your feet are hip-width apart. | 3. Using your hamstrings, curl your heels towards your glutes while keeping your hips on the ground.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a weight plate. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plate towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 4. Once the plate is below your knees, drive through your heels to stand back up to the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two plates with a pinch grip. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plates towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged.

1. Start by facing the TRX straps and positioning yourself in a push-up position with your hands on the ground and your feet in the TRX foot cradles. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and body in a straight line, bend your knees and bring your heels towards your glutes. | 3. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, then slowly lower your legs back to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held behind the neck and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held in front of you, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Lay flat on the ground with both feet planted. Make sure you keep your heels glued to the floor. | 2. Place the dumbbell on your hips. Push your hips toward the ceiling until you feel your glutes contract. | 3. Then return to the floor.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a barbell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the barbell down towards the ground. | 3. As the barbell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the barbell on the opposite side of your body.

1. Take a big step backwards with your left leg, lowering your body until your left thigh is parallel to the ground and your right knee is bent at a 90-degree angle. | 2. Push through your right heel to return to standing, bringing your left leg back to starting position. | 3. Repeat the movement on the other side, stepping backwards with your right leg and lowering your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground and your left knee is bent at a 90-degree angle.

1. Start in a tabletop position with your hands and knees on the floor. | 2. Step your right foot forward, placing it between your hands. | 3. Straighten your right leg and flex your toes towards your face, keeping your hands on the floor for support. | 4. Hold for several breaths, then switch sides and repeat.

1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. | 2. Inhale and lengthen your spine, then exhale and fold forward from your hips, keeping your spine long. | 3. Reach for your feet or ankles, keeping your elbows straight. | 4. Hold for several breaths, then release.

1. Begin in Tadasana (Mountain Pose). | 2. Step your left foot back about 3-4 feet and place your heel down, keeping your toes pointing forward. | 3. Inhale and lengthen your spine, then exhale and fold forward from your hips, bringing your hands to the floor on either side of your right foot. | 4. Hold for several breaths, then switch sides and repeat.

1. Begin in Tadasana (Mountain Pose) with two blocks at the top of your mat. | 2. Step your left foot back about 3-4 feet and place your heel down, keeping your toes pointing forward. | 3. Place the blocks on either side of your right foot at a height that allows you to comfortably place your hands on them. | 4. Inhale and lengthen your spine, then exhale and fold forward from your hips, bringing your hands to the blocks. Hold for several breaths, then switch sides and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. | 2. Hinge forward at your hips, reaching your hands towards the ground. | 3. Allow your head to hang heavy and feel a stretch in the back of your legs. | 4. Hold for a few breaths and then slowly roll up to a standing position.

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and place a block on the ground in front of you. | 2. Hinge forward at your hips and place your hands on the block. | 3. Allow your head to hang heavy and feel a stretch in the back of your legs. | 4. Hold for a few breaths and then slowly roll up to a standing position.

1. Start in mountain pose, standing with your feet hip-width apart and arms at your sides. | 2. Step your left foot back about 3-4 feet and raise it off the ground, while keeping your right foot facing forward. | 3. Inhale and reach your arms forward, parallel to the ground. | 4. Exhale and hinge forward at your hips, bringing your torso parallel to the ground and extending your left leg straight back. Keep your arms and right leg straight and hold the pose for a few breaths | 5. inhale and return to mountain pose. Repeat on the other side.

Exercise Name: Wide Legged Standing Forward Bend Holding Heels
Instructions: 1. Start standing at the top of your mat with your feet wide apart. | 2. Start standing at the top of your mat with your feet wide apart. | 3. Exhale and fold forward from your hips, bringing your hands up and over your head towards the ground. | 4. Hold for a few breaths and then release the hands and come back up to standing.

1. Position yourself on a glute ham raise machine or find a suitable substitute like a stability ball or bench. | 2. Adjust the equipment to fit your body by setting the footplate at an appropriate height and making sure your feet are securely anchored. | 3. Begin the movement by slowly lowering your upper body towards the ground while keeping your torso and legs aligned. | 4. Once you reach the lowest point where your body is parallel to the ground or as far as you can comfortably go, pause briefly. | 5. Engage your glutes and hamstrings again as you push yourself back up to the starting position, using the strength of your posterior chain muscles.

1. Stand in front of the landmine with your feet hip-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with both hands, palms facing each other, and hold it in front of your thighs. | 2. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, hinge at the hips and push your hips back, allowing the landmine to travel down your thighs. Lower the landmine by bending forward at the hips while keeping your back flat, allowing the barbell to move closer to the floor. Continue the movement until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, keeping your legs relatively straight but with a slight bend in the knees. | 3. Reverse the movement by pushing your hips forward and driving through your heels while keeping your back straight. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Sit on the machine. Adjust the back pad to where the leg pad is just above your knees. | 2. Adjust the leg pad that goes on your lower leg until it's on your achilles. | 3. Use the two handles to push your self back in the chair. Curl your legs as far as possible, and then extend your knees. (Do not hyperextend)

1. Grab the end of the landmine and stand perpendicular to the bar. | 2. Lift your inside leg and keep your outside leg planted. | 3. Push your hips back keeping your knees mostly extended. When you feel the stretch in your hams, push your hips forward until you are standing upright.

1. Stand in a staggered position. With the back leg bent and the front mostly extended. | 2. Push your hips back until you feel a stretch through your front hamstring. | 3. Push your hips back forward until you are standing.
1. Hold medicine ball while standing on one leg. | 2. Hinge forward on one leg, extending other leg behind. | 3. Return to starting position. Repeat on other leg.
1. Take an overhand grip. | 2. Keep your knees mostly extended and hinge forward at the hips. | 3. Keep a flat back.
1. Hold medicine ball while standing on one leg. | 2. Hinge forward on one leg, extending other leg behind. | 3. Return to starting position. Repeat on other leg.
1. Place one foot firmly on the ground and one foot behind the other. Bend the knee on your back leg. | 2. Hinge forward until you feel a stretch in your front leg.

1. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 2. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, swing kettlebell between legs. | 3. Swing kettlebell up, switch hands at the top, and repeat in a fluid motion.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. | 2. Bend at hips and knees to lift kettlebells. | 3. Stand tall, then lower.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebells outside legs | 2. Hinge at hips, swing kettlebells forward, then back. | 3. Thrust hips to swing kettlebells upward, keeping arms straight.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, grip kettlebell, and swing it overhead. | 3. Extend hips and knees, lock out arms at the top.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding kettlebells in front. | 2. Hinge at hips, keeping back straight, and lower kettlebells towards ground. | 3. Return to start position, squeezing glutes at the top.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs, grip with one hand, hinge at hips. | 2. Swing kettlebell forcefully forward, using hip thrust, arm straight. | 3. Swing kettlebell back between legs, repeat for desired reps.
1. Begin with feet hip-width apart, one foot forward, kettlebell between feet. | 2. Hinge at hips, grip kettlebell, and stand tall. | 3. Lower kettlebell with control, then repeat.

1. Lower kettlebell with control, then repeat. | 2. Explosively thrust hips forward, swing kettlebell to chest height. | 3. Repeat for desired reps, keeping core engaged and maintaining a staggered stance for balance.

1. Start with a kettlebell between your legs, hinge at hips, swing it upward. | 2. Lift kettlebell to chest level, elbows high, engaging shoulders. | 3. Lower kettlebell back down, maintaining control. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Start with a straight bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back. | 2. Stand with a staggered stance. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Start with handles set to the bottom of the machine. Grab a box, stand on top of the box, squat the weight up into a standing position. | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.
1. Bring a bench over to the cable stack, put the cable at head height (when seated). Use an ankle attachment. | 2. Sit on the bench. | 3. Flex at the knee and pull your ankle straight back.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Leg Laying Leg Curl
Instructions: 1. Bring a bench over to the cable stack, put the cable all the way at the bottom. Use an ankle attachment. | 2. Lay on the bench. | 3. Flex at the knee and pull your ankle straight back.

1. Begin by standing with your feet about hip-width apart and holding the bar in the crook of your elbows, with your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and lower your torso forward until it is nearly parallel to the ground. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and raise your body back to the starting position.

1. Stand with a shoulder width stance holding one dumbbell. Push your butt back while leaving your knees MOSTLY extended. | 2. Reach toward the opposing leg. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward to complete the rep. | 3. Do not push your hips all the way forward. This will hyperextend your spine. Just go to a normal standing position.

1. Take a shoulder width, double overhand or mixed grip. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Stance width can vary with a sumo DL. Some prefer toes near the plates. Others prefer a more narrow stance to get more drive off the floor. | 2. Make sure your arms are inside your legs. The bar should be just over your mid-foot. Flatten your back and unrack the bar | 3. Leave your knees mostly extended and flex and extend your hips.

1. Sit back in the seat. Use the two handles to push yourself back into the chair. | 2. Flex your ankles and point your toes upward. | 3. Flex your knee bringing the pad backward, extend your knee without allowing the weight to touch back down.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate in front of the feet, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend the hips and knees to grip the plate with palms facing the body. | 3. Keeping the back straight, stand up while lifting the plate off the ground. | 4. Return the plate back to the starting position by bending the hips and knees, keeping control of the plate.
1. Get the treadmill up to a comfortable speed where you are doing a light jog.
1. Get the treadmill up to a speed where you are doing a sprint.
1. Get the treadmill up to a comfortable speed where you are doing a walk.
1. Perform s sprint in a figure eight pattern. | 2. Make sure to stay low.

1. Stand up straight with a good form. | 2. Send your hips back and start tilting the upper body. | 3. Maintain a straight back as you aim for your toes. | 4. Your range depends on your hamstring flexibility.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a kettlebell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the kettlebell down towards the ground. | 3. As the kettlebell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the kettlebell on the opposite side of your body.

1. Lie on your back with knees slightly bent and heels dug in. | 2. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt (flatten your lower back on the ground). | 3. Press the heels into the ground to raise your hips off it. | 4. Hold the position for the specified duration.

Exercise Name: Hamstring Bridge With Elevated Legs Box Bilateral
Instructions: 1. Lie on your back. Place your heels on a box or bench, having a 90 angle at hips and knees. | 2. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt (flatten your lower back against the ground). | 3. Push through your heels into the box, lifting your hips up to the point where there is a straight line from your chest to your knees.

Exercise Name: Hamstring Bridge With Elevated Legs Box Unilateral
Instructions: 1. Lie on your back. Place one heel on a box or bench, having a 90 angle at hip and knee. | 2. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt (flatten your lower back against the ground). | 3. Push through your heel into the box, lifting your hips up to the point where there is a straight line from your chest to your knees.
1. Lie on your back keeping both knees bent. | 2. Have a slider under the heel of the working leg. | 3. Extend and bend the working lag applying gentle downwards pressure.

1. Lie on your back with bent knees and heels on a slider. | 2. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt (flatten your lower back on the ground). | 3. Press the heels into the ground to raise your hips off it. | 4. Extend and bend the working leg.

1. Bend your knees so your feet are flat on the floor with heels under knees and toes raised. | 2. Place sliders under your heels. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt (flatten your lower back against the ground). | 3. Push through your heels into the ground, lifting your hips up to the point where there is a straight line from your chest to your knees. | 4. Extend your legs in a slow, controlled manner, to lower your bum to the ground. | 5. Casually bend knees before repeating.
1. Stand up straight using a balancing aid. | 2. Shift your weight on one leg. | 3. Bend and extend the non-weight bearing leg. | 4. Knees should remain aligned.
1. Stand up straight using a balancing aid. | 2. Shift your weight on one leg. | 3. Bend the non-weight bearing leg and hold. | 4. Knees should remain aligned.

1. Lie on your back with slightly bent knees and heels on sliders. | 2. Pull your heels towards your glutes to lift your hips off the ground. | 3. Extend knees to starting position, but do not rest hips on ground.
1. Place a massage ball on a bench. | 2. Sit on the ball with your hamstring. | 3. Move around till you find a tight/sore spot. | 4. Extend and bend your knee to mobilise the hamstring.
1. Standing, split stance. | 2. Dynamically kick your back leg forward and up. | 3. Return to starting position.
1. Lie on your back with straight legs. | 2. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt and maintain the position. | 3. Kick one leg up to feel a stretch in the hamstring.

Exercise Name: Hamstring Stretch Seated Single Leg Isometric
Instructions: 1. Sit against a wall. | 2. Bend one leg and tuck the foot by the straight leg's knee. | 3. Dynamically reach forward towards your toes and return to starting position.

Exercise Name: Hamstring Stretch Static Standing Single Leg
Instructions: 1. From the standing position, bring one leg slightly forward. | 2. Raise your toes and lean over towards them. | 3. Maintain the position.

1. Place a theraband or stretch strap around your foot. | 2. Lie back onto the ground. | 3. Raise your leg to stretching point with the aid of the band (strap). | 4. Tug onto the strap on the end of range to dynamically stretch the hamstring.

1. Place a theraband around your foot. | 2. Lie back onto the ground. | 3. Raise your leg to stretching point with the aid of the band, keeping a slightly bent knee. | 4. Extend and bend your knee to actively stretch your hamstring.

1. Place a theraband or stretch strap around your foot. | 2. Lie back onto the ground. | 3. Raise your leg to stretching point with the aid of the band (strap). | 4. Tug onto the strap on the end of range to dynamically stretch the hamstring.
1. Start with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Stay on your toes, step right, tap your left toe to the ground, plant your right foot and raise your left leg. | 3. Then repeat in the opposite direction.
1. Stand straight, feet hip-width apart, engage core. | 2. Lift knees alternately, tap with same side hand. | 3. Continue rhythmically, maintain posture, increase speed as able.

1. Place a box behind you and one foot on it. Keep your chest up and the back straight | 2. Tilt at the hips to perform a deadlift. Use the box for balance and support | 3. Make sure you straighten your back leg when performing the deadlift. | 4. As you get comfortable with the movement, try to lift the leg off the box when you reach the end range of the deadlift.
1. Hold on to something stable and pull the leg on the opposing side straight up. Hold this position.
1. Stand tall, jog in place, bringing heels toward your glutes. | 2. Keep your core tight and swing arms naturally. | 3. Alternate legs quickly, maintaining a steady rhythm.
1. Stand tall, hinge at hips, and reach hands to the floor. | 2. Walk hands forward into a plank position. | 3. Walk feet towards hands and repeat the motion.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart with the bar on the ground at your side. | 2. Lift the bar to your side and walk for the allotted amount of time or distance. | 3. Set the bar down and switch sides.

Exercise Name: Machine Plate Loaded Kneeling Hamstring Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay down on the machine, placing your working leg beneath the padded lever. Position your leg so that the padded lever is below your calve muscle. | 2. Support yourself by grabbing the side handles of the machine, and slowly raise the weight with your legs. | 3. Pause at the apex of the motion, then slowly return to starting position.
1. Lay on the pad and grab the handles. | 2. Slip your legs into the belt loop. | 3. Push your legs back until they are horizontal with the ground. | 4. Lower back to the starting position.
1. Press yourself into the pads and put your calves against the lower pads. | 2. Flex your knee until you feel a contraction in your hamstring, then lower back to the start.

1. Adjust the back pad and ankle pad to suit your height. | 2. Disengage the knee pad and lower it as far as you can. | 3. Flex your knees against resistance, then extend until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. Hold a plate up to your chest. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Lie face-down on a stability ball, hips centered, feet anchored, hands behind your head. | 2. Engage your core, lift your upper body until aligned with legs, keeping your neck neutral. | 3. Lower your torso slowly back to the starting position, maintaining control and steady breathing.

1. Lie on your back, heels on a stability ball, arms flat, and core engaged. | 2. Lift hips, curl the ball toward you using your hamstrings, keeping control and balance. | 3. Extend legs back to start while keeping hips lifted, then repeat for desired reps.

1. Lie face down on a stability ball, hands on the floor, legs extended straight. | 2. Engage glutes and lower back, raising legs until aligned with your torso. | 3. Slowly lower legs back down without touching the ground, maintaining core engagement. Repeat.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Half Kneeling Goblet Romanian Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Place one knee on a bench and hold a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place one knee on a bench and hold a dumbbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place one knee on a bench. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Half Kneeling Goblet Romanian Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Place one knee on a bench and hold a kettlebell in a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place one knee on a bench and hold a kettlebell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Lay down on the machine, placing your legs beneath the padded lever. Position your legs so that the padded lever is below your calve muscles. | 2. Support yourself by grabbing the side handles of the machine, and slowly raise the weight with your legs, toes pointed straight. | 3. Pause at the apex of the motion, then slowly return to starting position.

1. Go to your knees and ask someone to hold your ankles. | 2. Put your hands in front of you | 3. With a slight bend in your knees slowly bring your body to the ground (slower is better) | 4. Push up and reset to the starting position.
1. Use an ankle attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Stand upright or try bending slightly forward. | 3. Flex at the knee and pull your ankle straight back.

1. Start by facing the TRX straps and positioning yourself in a push-up position with your hands on the ground and your feet in the TRX foot cradles. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and body in a straight line, bend your knees and bring your heels towards your glutes. | 3. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, then slowly lower your legs back to the starting position.

1. Position yourself on a glute ham raise machine or find a suitable substitute like a stability ball or bench. | 2. Adjust the equipment to fit your body by setting the footplate at an appropriate height and making sure your feet are securely anchored. | 3. Begin the movement by slowly lowering your upper body towards the ground while keeping your torso and legs aligned. | 4. Once you reach the lowest point where your body is parallel to the ground or as far as you can comfortably go, pause briefly. | 5. Engage your glutes and hamstrings again as you push yourself back up to the starting position, using the strength of your posterior chain muscles.

1. Sit on the machine. Adjust the back pad to where the leg pad is just above your knees. | 2. Adjust the leg pad that goes on your lower leg until it's on your achilles. | 3. Use the two handles to push your self back in the chair. Curl your legs as far as possible, and then extend your knees. (Do not hyperextend)
1. Bring a bench over to the cable stack, put the cable at head height (when seated). Use an ankle attachment. | 2. Sit on the bench. | 3. Flex at the knee and pull your ankle straight back.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Leg Laying Leg Curl
Instructions: 1. Bring a bench over to the cable stack, put the cable all the way at the bottom. Use an ankle attachment. | 2. Lay on the bench. | 3. Flex at the knee and pull your ankle straight back.

1. Sit back in the seat. Use the two handles to push yourself back into the chair. | 2. Flex your ankles and point your toes upward. | 3. Flex your knee bringing the pad backward, extend your knee without allowing the weight to touch back down.

Exercise Name: Machine Plate Loaded Kneeling Hamstring Curl
Instructions: 1. Lay down on the machine, placing your working leg beneath the padded lever. Position your leg so that the padded lever is below your calve muscle. | 2. Support yourself by grabbing the side handles of the machine, and slowly raise the weight with your legs. | 3. Pause at the apex of the motion, then slowly return to starting position.
1. Press yourself into the pads and put your calves against the lower pads. | 2. Flex your knee until you feel a contraction in your hamstring, then lower back to the start.

1. Adjust the back pad and ankle pad to suit your height. | 2. Disengage the knee pad and lower it as far as you can. | 3. Flex your knees against resistance, then extend until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings.

1. Stand with a shoulder width stance. Push your butt back while leaving your knees MOSTLY extended. | 2. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward to complete the rep. | 3. Do not push your hips all the way forward. This will hyperextend your spine. Just go to a normal standing position.

1. Stand with a barbell at your shins with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Bend forward at your hips and keep your knees as fully extended as possible. | 3. Grab the barbell and then extend your hips while maintaining a straight back. | 4. From the standing position, lower the weight in a controlled manner. | 5. You can either lower the weight to the floor or before you touch the floor, depending on your mobility.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart. The bar should be in a rack or box so it's lifted off the ground. | 2. Grab the barbell with an overhand grip, your hands should be much wider than shoulder-width apart. | 3. Hing forward at the hips keeping your knees mostly extended. Hinge until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you are back in a standing position.

1. Start with a straight bar or ez bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Leg Stiff Leg Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Start by standing on one leg with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two dumbbells. | 2. From this starting position, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbell towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 3. Once you feel a stretch in your hamstring, slowly return to the starting position. | 4. Make sure to keep your standing leg slightly bent and avoid rounding your back as you lower the dumbbell.

1. Grab the end of the landmine and stand perpendicular to the bar. | 2. Lift your inside leg and keep your outside leg planted. | 3. Push your hips back keeping your knees mostly extended. When you feel the stretch in your hams, push your hips forward until you are standing upright.

1. Stand in a staggered position. With the back leg bent and the front mostly extended. | 2. Push your hips back until you feel a stretch through your front hamstring. | 3. Push your hips back forward until you are standing.

1. Start with a straight bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back. | 2. Stand with a staggered stance. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Start with handles set to the bottom of the machine. Grab a box, stand on top of the box, squat the weight up into a standing position. | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Stand with a shoulder width stance holding one dumbbell. Push your butt back while leaving your knees MOSTLY extended. | 2. Reach toward the opposing leg. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward to complete the rep. | 3. Do not push your hips all the way forward. This will hyperextend your spine. Just go to a normal standing position.

1. Grip the bar with the palms facing forward, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than shoulder width. | 2. As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar, bring your torso back around 30 degrees while sticking your chest out. | 3. Pull the bar down to about chin level or a little lower in a smooth movement whilst squeezing the shoulder blades together. | 4. After a second of squeezing, slowly raise the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended.

1. Sit with your back straight on the machine and grip the handles. | 2. Pull the handles back using your arms. Your legs and torso should be at a 90 angle. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handles towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.
1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Grab both dumbbells and hinge forward at the hips. Make sure you keep a flat back. | 2. The closer your torso is to parallel with the ground the longer the range of motion will be at your shoulder. The better the results you'll get from the exercise. | 3. Let your arms hang freely, and then pull your elbow joint straight back toward the ceiling.

1. Grab a barbell with a shoulder width pronated or supinated grip. | 2. Bend forward at your hips while maintaining a flat back. | 3. Pull the weight toward your upper abdomen. | 4. Lower the weight in a controlled manner and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart bending forward at the hips as far as comfortable. Place off-hand on the same side thigh for stability. | 2. Hold the kettlebell in one hand, straight armed and pointing towards the floor. | 3. Keeping your arm straight, swing the kettlebell behind you as far as comfortable. | 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, shifting one foot behind you. Hold the kettlebell in the same hand as the leg shifted backwards. | 2. Bend forwards at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knee, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Rest your upper back on the bench and place soles of your feet firmly on the floor keeping torso and thighs suspended and parallel to the floor. | 2. Hold the kettlebell with both hands above your chest, keeping your arms straight. | 3. Keeping your arms straight, move the kettlebell in the direction of your head until your arms are parallel to the floor. | 4. Return to starting to position and repeat.
1. Find a wall to lean against, lay your tricep against the wall with your hand behind your back. | 2. Slowly lean into the wall. | 3. Return to starting position, then switch sides.

1. Stand up right and raise your hand to a full stretch above your head. | 2. Slowly lean across your body and trace the opposite hand down your leg. | 3. Hold at the bottom of the stretch, return to starting position and then switch sides.
1. Place both hands on the wall in front of you. | 2. Slowly lower your body until you feel the stretch. | 3. Hold at the bottom of the stretch, return to starting position.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. You can use any attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the top of the machine. | 2. Grab your attachment and walk a few steps back. Push your butt back to where you are leaning forward. Your ears should be between your arms. | 3. Initiate the movement with your shoulders and not your elbows. As you flex at the shoulder joint push your hips forward until your hips meet the attachment.

1. You can use any attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the top of the machine. | 2. Grab your attachment and walk a few steps back. Push your butt back to where you are leaning forward somewhat. | 3. Initiate the movement with your shoulders and not your elbows. Imagine trying to pull the attachment through your thighs at the bottom.

1. Use a handle attachment set all the way to the top of the cable crossover machine. | 2. Walk a few steps away from the cable machine. Face your body sideways. | 3. Face your palm up toward the ceiling. Then pull your elbow in toward your rib cage.

1. Place the band at about eye level. Fall into a kneeling position. | 2. The knee that is on the ground should be the same side as the working arm. Stick your chest out. | 3. And then pull your elbow straight back. Flex your lats and then extend into the starting position.
1. Place the band just above our level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back slightly. Extend and flex at the shoulder joint.
1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Let your arms hang freely, then pull your elbows straight back toward the ceiling.

1. Brace your off arm against something stable (bench, box). Stagger your stance so your leg on the side of your working arm is back. | 2. Try to get your torso to parallel with the ground. That will extend your range of motion. | 3. Let your arm hang freely and then pull your elbow back. Imagine you've got a tennis ball in your armpit and squeeze it each rep.

1. Position a barbell in a landmine or corner of a room and stand facing it with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grasp the end of the barbell with an overhand grip, keeping your arms straight and your shoulders relaxed. | 3. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso until it is almost parallel to the ground. | 4. Pull the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together as you row the weight up.

1. Position a barbell in a landmine or corner of a room and stand facing sideways with a staggered stance and your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grasp the end of the barbell with an overhand grip, keeping your arms straight and your shoulders relaxed. | 3. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso until it is almost parallel to the ground. | 4. Pull the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together as you row the weight up. | 5. *Named after the late John Meadows

1. Start hinged forward with a flat back and the plates resting on the floor. Make sure your elbows are fully extended. | 2. Pull the bar to your sternum. | 3. Return the plates back to the floor and let the bar come to a full dead stop. | 4. Then initiate the next rep.

1. Grab the barbell with an overhand grip. Hinge forward while keeping your back flat until your torso is about parallel with the ground. | 2. Let your arms hang freely. | 3. Pull the bar to your torso while tucking your elbows in slightly. | 4. Extend your elbows fully before initiating the next rep.

1. Begin by standing in front of a barbell with your feet about hip-width apart and your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the barbell with a pronated (overhand) grip, positioning the barbell about an inch away from your shins. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, use your back muscles to lift the barbell straight up towards your chest. | 4. As the barbell reaches your chest, rotate your wrists so that your palms are facing towards your body (supinated grip), and then lower the barbell back to the starting position.

1. Begin by standing in front of a barbell with your feet about hip-width apart. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the barbell with a supinated (underhand) grip, positioning the barbell about an inch away from your shins. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, use your back muscles to lift the barbell straight up towards your chest. | 4. As the barbell reaches your chest, pause briefly, and then lower the barbell back to the starting position.

1. Grab a dumbbell and hold with both hands. Point your dumbbell at the ceiling. | 2. Flex at the shoulder joint while keeping your elbows mostly extended. | 3. Flex until you feel a stretch in your lats then bring the dumbbell back to the ceiling.

1. The dumbbells should be set on the ground. Hinge forward while keeping a flat back. | 2. Pull one elbow back toward the ceiling and then return the dumbbell to the ground softly. | 3. Then pull with the other arm.
1. Place one hand and one knee on a bench. Make sure you keep a flat back. | 2. Pull the dumbbell toward the ceiling. | 3. Make sure to avoid any jerking or rotating.
1. Lay on an incline bench that is between 30-45 degrees high. | 2. Let your arms hang freely. Pull your elbows straight back toward the ceiling.

1. The dumbbells should be placed on the floor. | 2. Hinge forward with a flat back and grab the dumbbells. | 3. Pull both dumbbells back and your elbows toward the ceiling. | 4. Return the dumbbells back to the floor softly on each rep.

1. Start by hinging over with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbells to your sides, with your palms facing forward and your elbows slightly bent. | 3. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing in front of a flat bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Place your other hand on the bench for support, and bend at the waist so that your chest is parallel to the ground. | 3. From this starting position, row the dumbbell up towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blade together as you do so. | 4. Make sure to keep your elbow close to your body and your core engaged throughout the movement.

1. Start by placing your elbow on one knee. | 2. Hold a dumbbell in your other hand, with your palm facing inwards towards your body. | 3. From this starting position, row the dumbbell up towards your chest, keeping your elbow close to your body and your core engaged.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. Hold each plate to the side of you. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the plates to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. One at a time, lift the plate up. Return the plate to the floor and do the other side.

1. Lay flat on the ground with a plate on your chest. | 2. Push your hips up toward the ceiling and maintain that extended position. | 3. Extend your elbows mostly, break at the shoulder joint while maintaining hip extension and the slight bend in your elbows. | 4. Let the plate tap the floor (or get close) and then pull the plate back into the starting position.

1. Stand with feet staggered and one hand on a bench/box. Hold a dumbbell in the opposing hand. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips, keeping the back flat, and eyes facing forward. The weight should hang directly below the shoulders. | 3. Start with an overhand grip, as you pull rotate the dumbbell. When your upper arm reaches your side your palm should be facing forward.

1. Stand with feet staggered and one hand on your knee. Hold a dumbbell in the opposing hand. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips, keeping the back flat, and eyes facing forward.
