With bent elbows, raise your arms up to shoulder level, pausing at the at the end of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your arms back to starting position.

1. Grab two dumbbells while sitting on an incline bench upright with the dumbbells at your side. | 2. Raise the two dumbbells with your elbows being fully extended until the dumbbells are eye level. | 3. Lower the weights in a controlled manner to the starting position and repeat.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Seated Single Arm Arnold Press
Instructions: 1. Start by sitting on an incline bench and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing you and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is directly above your head. | 4. As you extend your arm, rotate your palm to face away from your body.

1. Sit on an upright bench , grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Press the dumbbells outward into a y shape.

1. Stand tall, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Press the dumbbells outward into a y shape.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Kneeling Bottoms Up Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by taking a kneeling position and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.

1. Lay on your side on an incline bench. Brace yourself by holding onto the bench. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, raise the dumbbell to the side. | 3. The end of the range of motion is when the dumbbell is pointed toward the ceiling. | 4. Make sure you don't flex and extend your elbow.

1. Lay flat on the bench and place your feet on the ground. | 2. Begin the exercise with the dumbbells held together above your chest, elbows slightly bent. | 3. Simultaneously lower the weights to either side. | 4. Pause when the weights are parallel to the bench, then raise your arms to the starting position.

1. Take a roughly shoulder width grip. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Pull your chin back and press the weight toward the ceiling by extending at the elbow joint and flexing at the shoulder joint. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly. | 4. Return to the start position with control. Pulling your chin back to allow the bar to pass your face safely.

1. Grab two dumbbells while standing upright with the dumbbells at your side. | 2. Raise the two dumbbells with your elbows being fully extended until the dumbbells are eye level. | 3. Lower the weights in a controlled manner to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand tall with an overhand grip on the barbell. Raise your arms until your fists are around eye level. | 2. Return to the start under control. This exercise is prone to using momentum when you begin to fatigue.

1. Stand up straight with feet shoulder width apart, holding the kettlebell in front of your pelvis. | 2. Keeping arms straight, raise the kettlebell slightly higher than head level. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.
1. Stand on the band with one or 2 feet depending on how heavy you want the band to be. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing the thighs. | 2. Keeping the elbows slightly bent, lift the plate up to the front of the body. | 3. Raise the plate up until the arms are fully extended, maintaining control of the plate. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

1. Lay flat on the incline bench with your feet on the ground. Raise the dumbbells until you have straight arms. | 2. Lower the dumbbells to your mid chest | 3. Raise the dumbbells until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cables should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Walk a few steps forward. Then press the weight forward. | 4. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.
1. Hold the end of the bar in front of you. | 2. Pop your hips, pull your elbows up to the ceiling, and get underneath the bar.

1. Hold the bar over one shoulder. Stand with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Dip at the hips and knees, generate some momentum and press the bar. | 3. As you press, split your stance. Bring the leg of the working arm back and the other forward.

1. Hold the bar with a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and sink into a squat. | 3. Push through your heels and squat back up. Use the momentum you generate at the legs to push the bar over head. | 4. Let the bar return to the goblet position before starting the next rep.
1. Hold medicine ball at chest. | 2. Jump, extending arms overhead. | 3. Return to starting position. Repeat for desired reps.
1. Hold the bosu vertically. | 2. Raise the bosu toward the ceiling while keeping your elbows mostly extended.
1. Face away from the cables. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cables should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cables should be set above height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

Exercise Name: Cable Decline Single Arm Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set above shoulder height. | 2. Bring one handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.
1. Face away from the cables. Use a rope attachment. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring the handle to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulder and elbow simultaneously.

Exercise Name: Barbell Behind The Neck Seated Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Take a roughly shoulder width grip. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Push your head foward and press the weight toward the ceiling by extending at the elbow joint and flexing at the shoulder joint. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the dumbbells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Sit tall and try not to arch your spine as you're pressing. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly.
1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 2. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Lie on the decline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.
1. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the bar to chin level or slightly higher.

1. Begin by sitting on the ground with your legs extended and a barbell in your hands, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, lift the barbell up from your chest and press it straight up above your head. | 3. Lower the barbell back down to your chest.

1. Stand facing the landmine leaning forward slightly with the end of the barbell held in one hand at your shoulder with your elbow positioned beneath your wrist. | 2. While keeping your elbow pointed forward, drive the bar directly overhead, switching hands at the top of the movement. Lower the bar back down to the other side of your body, mirroring the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps, switching hands at the top of each rep.

Exercise Name: Landmine Half Kneeling Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start facing the landmine on one knee with your other foot in front of you while holding the barbell in one hand at your shoulder on the same side as the knee that is on the ground. | 2. Drive the bar upwards while keeping your elbow pointed forward until your arm holding the bar is fully extending, then control the bar as your lower it back to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps, then switch sides.

1. Start by lying flat on your back with your legs extended towards the landmine attachment and your arms overhead, holding the landmine barbell with both hands while engaging your core muscles by pressing your lower back into the ground and drawing your belly button in towards your spine. | 2. Lift your legs off the ground, keeping them together and straight, and simultaneously raise your upper body off the ground, reaching the landmine barbell away from your face. | 3. Hold this position for the desired duration, then carefully lower the barbell to the ground.

1. Start in a kneeling position facing the barbell with one hand holding the end of the barbell at your shoulder with your elbow tucked beneath your wrist. | 2. Keeping your elbow pointing forward, drive the barbell up overhead until your arm is fully extended and switch the bar to your other hand at the top of the movement. | 3. Control the descent of the bar to your other shoulder and repeat movement for desired reps, switching hands at the top of each rep.

1. Start kneeling in front of the landmine, facing towards it, with your knees hip-width apart and your back straight while holding the end of the bar in both hands in front of your chest. | 2. Push the landmine up overhead by fully extending your arms until the weight is directly over your head. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the landmine back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand perpendicularly to the barbell, holding the end of the bar at your outer hip with your inner hand and your palm facing your body. | 2. While keeping your core braced and your arm straight, lift the barbell diagonally up and towards the direction of the landmine attachment, then return the bar to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Stand facing the landmine attachment while holding the end of the bar with one hand at your shoulder on the same side with your elbow tucked to your body underneath your wrist. | 2. Step back with the leg on the same side that you are holding the bar on and with control lower yourself down into a lunge position while keeping your core engaged and torso tall, then drive through your front heel as you step back to the starting position. | 3. Once your feet are back in the starting position, drive the bar up overhead until your arm is fully extended, then lower the bar back down to the starting position. | 4. Repeated for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

1. Stand facing the landmine, holding the end of the bar in both hands with your palms facing each other. | 2. Extend your arms upward, pressing the end of the bar up overhead. Pause at the top of the movement, then lower the bar with control back to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand perpendicularly to the barbell with the end of the bar in front of your feet. Squat down and hold the end of the bar with your hand closer to the landmine attachment with your palm facing your body. | 2. Drive your feet into the ground to start the motion. As your legs fully extend, pull the bar upwards with your hand and start to rotate your torso in towards the landmine attachment. As you do so, bring your other hand up to the bar and switch your grip. Press through the bar to extend your arm all the way upright, pivoting your back foot to allow for more trunk rotation. | 3. Perform the movement in reverse to return to the starting position. Repeat for desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Start sitting on the ground facing the landmine attachment with your legs open for stability while holding the end of the bar in a neutral grip with your hand resting at your shoulder and your elbow beneath your wrist. | 2. Leaning forward slightly, press the bar up into the air until your arm is fully extended. At the top of the movement, switch which hand is holding the end of the bar and lower the bar back down to the opposite shoulder. Perform again to return the bar to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Sit on the ground facing the landmine with your legs spread. Hold the end of the bar in both hands in front of your chest with your palms facing each other. | 2. While keeping your torso tall and core brace, drive the end of the bar upward until your arms are fully extended. Lean forward slightly for full range of motion in the shoulder joints. Lower the bar back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps.

Exercise Name: Landmine Seated Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Sit on the ground facing the landmine with your legs spread. Hold the end of the bar in one hand in front of that shoulder with your palm facing across your body. | 2. While keeping your torso tall and your core braced, drive the bar upwards until your arm is fully extended, leaning forward slightly for full range of motion in the shoulder joint. Lower the bar back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps on one side, then switch sides.

1. Stand in front of the landmine with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with one hand, palm facing in, and bring it to shoulder height with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Press the barbell overhead by extending your arm fully, pushing the weight upward. Keep your core engaged, your back straight, and your shoulder down throughout the movement. Pause briefly at the top of the movement with your arm fully extended overhead. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position at shoulder height with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

1. Stand in front of the landmine with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with one hand, palm facing in, and bring it to shoulder height with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Dip your body slightly then drive up through the ground to generate momentum as your extend your arm fully upwards. Pause briefly at the top of the rep, then lower the weight back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

Exercise Name: Landmine Single Arm Staggered Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Stand facing the bar in a split stance with one leg forward and bent and the other back and straight. Hold the bar in the hand on the side of the leg that is back with the end of the bar at your shoulder with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Drive the bar upwards until your arm is fully extended. Pause briefly before lowering the end of the bar back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.
1. Start in a standing position

1. Start with two dumbbells just above your shoulders. | 2. Press one dumbbell to the ceiling while keeping the other in place. | 3. Let the first dumbbell return to its starting position before pressing the other dumbbell.
1. Stand with both palms facing you. | 2. Begin to press the dumbbells to the ceiling while rotating your palms. | 3. When you reach elbow extension, your palms should be facing forward.

1. Start with two dumbbells near your shoulders with a neutral grip. | 2. Press one of the dumbbells toward the ceiling while keeping the other in position. | 3. Let the first dumbbell return to its starting position before pressing the other.

1. Lie on a flat bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Lie on an incline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.
1. Start with both dumbbells near your shoulders in a neutral grip. | 2. Press the dumbbells toward the ceiling. | 3. Make sure you don't arch your back as you fatigue.

1. Sit on an upright bench , grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your shoulder joint, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the dumbbells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart and hold two dumbbells overhead with both hands, using an overhand grip. | 2. Begin the squat by bending at the hips and knees, keeping your core tight and the dumbbells balanced overhead. | 3. Lower your body as far as you can while keeping the dumbbells overhead, then push back up to the starting position. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, making sure to keep your back straight, chest lifted, and the dumbbells stable overhead throughout the entire movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. From this starting position, dip your knees slightly and then quickly extend them as you press the dumbbells upwards. | 3. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement. | 4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Begin seated on an upright bench with your palms facing you. | 2. Begin pressing toward the ceiling. As you press, rotate your palms. | 3. As you extend your elbows fully your palms should be facing forward.

1. Sit on a bench with back support. Raise the dumbbells to shoulder height with your palms forward. | 2. Raise the dumbbells upwards and pause at the contracted position. | 3. Lower the weights back to starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing you and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is directly above your head. | 4. As you extend your arm, rotate your palm to face away from your body.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Neutral Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing your body and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, press the dumbbell upwards so that it is directly above your shoulder.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing forward and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbells to your shoulders, with your palms facing inward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, dip your knees slightly and then quickly extend them as you press the dumbbells upwards. | 4. As you press the dumbbells upwards, also push your hips forward to help generate additional power. | 5. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Start in a plank position. Push your hips up toward the ceiling. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat
1. Use a bench or an object to elevate your feet. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat
1. Hold your arms out to your sides. | 2. Rotate your arms forward in small circles.

1. Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart and hold a pole overhead, using an overhand grip. | 2. Begin the squat by bending at the hips and knees, keeping your core tight and the dumbbells balanced overhead. | 3. Lower your body as far as you can while keeping the dumbbells overhead, then push back up to the starting position. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, making sure to keep your back straight, chest lifted, and the dumbbells stable overhead throughout the entire movement.

Exercise Name: Medicine Ball Clean And Press Slam
Instructions: 1. Hold the medicine ball with an overhand grip. | 2. Lift the ball explosively, clean it to shoulder height. | 3. Press the ball overhead, then slam it to the ground.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a medicine ball. | 2. Circle the ball around your head, maintaining control. | 3. Complete the desired number of repetitions in both directions.
1. Hold medicine ball overhead. | 2. Step back into lunge position. | 3. Return to starting position. Repeat on other leg.
1. Toss medicine ball up, catch with both hands. | 2. Repeat toss and catch for desired reps.
1. Hold medicine ball at chest. | 2. Squat down, reach ball to one side. | 3. Stand up and repeat reach on other side.
1. Hold medicine ball at chest, facing wall. | 2. Squat down, then throw ball at wall. | 3. Catch and repeat for desired reps.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Bottoms Up Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding one kettlebell with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebell to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebell are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.
1. Start with kettlebells between legs. | 2. Swing kettlebells up to shoulder. | 3. Press kettlebells overhead.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, grip kettlebell, and swing it overhead. | 3. Extend hips and knees, lock out arms at the top.
1. Start with kettlebell in rack position. | 2. Dip at knees and hips. | 3. Explosively push kettlebell overhead, fully extending arms.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Clean And Press
Instructions: 1. Begin with the kettlebell between your legs. | 2. Hinge at your hips, and lift to shoulder, then press overhead.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs. | 2. Squat, grip kettlebell, explode hips, and lift kettlebell overhead. | 3. Lower kettlebell safely to start position.
1. Begin with a two kettlebells between your legs, hinge at hips, then swing it upwards explosively. | 2. As they rise, lock out arm overhead, wrist straight. | 3. Control the descent, then repeat.

1. Start with a kettlebell between your legs, hinge at hips, swing it upward. | 2. Lift kettlebell to chest level, elbows high, engaging shoulders. | 3. Lower kettlebell back down, maintaining control. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate one arm overhead and behind while keeping the other arm in front of you. | 3. Then rotate the other arm. | 4. Bring the original arm back to the starting position, then the other arm. Repeat.
1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate both arms overhead and behind you while leaving your elbows mostly extended.

1. Reach one arm behind your body, with your elbow pointing upward behind your head. | 2. Assist the stretch with your other hand on your elbow to engage your shoulder. | 3. Pause for a few seconds, then repeat the stretch with your other arm.

1. Place the top of your hand into the small of your back, your arm at a 90 degree angle. | 2. Hold your elbow with the other arm, and slowly pull the arm forward until you feel your shoulder engaged in the stretch. Pause at the apex of the stretch and return to the starting position. | 3. Return to starting position, and repeat with your other arm.

1. Start with your arms at either side. Begin by pushing your shoulders forward and in towards your chest. | 2. Continue the circular motion with your shoulders, pinching up towards your ears, and then extending your chest outwards while you finish the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. Stand upright making sure to maintain a flat back. Your starting position will have your palms facing forward. | 2. Use both your elbows and shoulders to press the weight directly overhead.

1. Stand between the two anchored bands, grasp them with an overhand grip, and position the bands at shoulder level. | 2. Brace your core and push the bands overhead, fully extending your arms. | 3. Lower the bands back to shoulder level, keeping your core engaged and arms straight. Repeat for desired number of reps.

1. Loop the band under one of your feet. The other end of the bed should be in your hand between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. Press the band straight up towards the ceiling. Until your elbow is fully extended.

1. Inhale and brace your abdominals | 2. Raise the arms vertically while keeping the elbows slightly bent | 3. Once the arms are parallel with the floor, rotate the plate clockwise and counterclockwise. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the feet. | 2. Bend the knees and hips to pick up the plate, keeping the back straight and core engaged. | 3. Stand up, lock the hips and legs, and press the plate overhead with straight arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

Exercise Name: Plate Curl To Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back behind the head to the starting position of a tricep extension. | 5. Push the plate back up overhead, then lower it back to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand tall holding two plates at your side. | 2. Lateral raise the plates to your side and continue until the plates are pointed at the ceiling. | 3. Let your shoulder joint naturally rotate. At the bottom you should have a neutral or overhand grip. By the time the plates are overhead, your palms should be facing forward.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate held in front of your face with both hands, palms facing each other. | 2. Rotate the plate around the head, keeping the arms extended and moving the plate in a circular motion. | 3. Complete one full circle, then reverse the direction to complete another circle.

1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a single weight plate overhead with both hands, keeping your arms extended straight above your head. | 2. Begin walking forward, taking slow and steady steps while maintaining a straight line. Your focus should be on maintaining balance and control of the weight plate overhead. | 3. As you walk, continue to keep your arms extended and the weight plate overhead. Try to maintain good posture and avoid leaning forward or backward, as this could result in losing control of the weight plate. | 4. Continue walking for a set distance or for a certain amount of time, keeping your focus on proper form and technique. When finished, return to the starting position and repeat as desired.

Exercise Name: Plate Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Brace your core and press the weight plate overhead until your arms are fully extended. Keep your shoulders down and back. | 2. While your arms are fully extended, lower the weight behind your head to perform the extension | 3. After completing the extension, lower the weight to your chest, and perform the overhead press. Repeat
1. Start in a standing position with a plate against your chest. | 2. Press the plate away from your body until your elbows are extended.

1. Hold the plate with both hands at chest height. | 2. Keeping your core tight and your chest up, squat down as low as you can go while keeping your feet flat on the ground. | 3. Hold the squat position and reach the plate forward, keeping your arms straight and your back straight. | 4. Return the plate to your chest while you hold the squat position and repeat reaching the plate in front of you

1. Stand holding a weight plate at chest height with both hands. | 2. Lower into a squat, extending the plate in front of you at chest height | 3. As you stand back up, pull the plate back into your chest.

1. Start with the plate at chest height. Begin a squat. | 2. Make sure to hit parallel depth. On your way back up, use the momentum you generate with your legs to help push the plate into an overhead position. | 3. Let the plate return to chest height before initiating the next squat.

1. Stand facing the TRX straps and hold onto the handles with an overhand grip, keeping your arms straight and hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. | 2. Keeping your core engaged, slowly raise your arms forward until they are overhead. | 3. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, then slowly lower your arms back to the starting position.

1. Start by setting up the TRX straps to a secure anchor point and adjust the straps so that they hang about waist height when you stand under them. | 2. Stand facing the TRX straps, grab the handles with both hands, and step forward so that your body is in a plank position with your hands directly beneath your shoulders. | 3. Lower your body down by bending your elbows until your chest nearly touches the handles. Keep your core tight and your body in a straight line. | 4. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms as you do so. Make sure to engage your chest, triceps, and core throughout the movement.

1. Hold the TRX straps and lean away from the anchor point until the straps are taut. | 2. Keep both elbows mostly extended and raise both arms out and upwards. | 3. You should make a Y shape with your arms during the back portion of the exercise.

1. Begin on your hands and knees with your wrists under your shoulders and your knees under your hips. | 2. Place your forearms on the floor and interlace your fingers. | 3. Place the crown of your head on the floor and tuck your toes under. | 4. Walk your feet towards your head and lift your hips up. | 5. Straighten your legs and find your balance. Hold for several breaths and then release.

1. Start seated or standing with your arms at your sides. | 2. Bring your hands behind your back and interlace your fingers with your palms facing up. | 3. Inhale and draw your shoulder blades together, lifting your chest. | 4. Exhale and gently press your hands down towards the floor as you continue to lift your chest.
1. Place feet on Bosu, hips high, hands on the floor. | 2. Lower the head towards the ground, then push back up. | 3. Keep legs straight and hips elevated throughout.

1. Start standing at the top of your mat with your feet wide apart. | 2. Interlace your fingers behind your back and inhale to expand your chest. | 3. Exhale and fold forward from your hips, bringing your hands up and over your head towards the ground. | 4. Hold for a few breaths and then release the hands and come back up to standing.
1. Stand tall with your palms facing yourself. | 2. As you press, rotate your arms.
1. Hold the handle attachments with your fists to the sky and elbows toward the floor. | 2. Press the handles to the ceiling.

1. Adjust seat and handlebar height for comfort and proper posture on the assault bike. | 2. Start pedaling with even, controlled motion, maintaining your desired resistance level. | 3. Monitor heart rate and intensity; increase or decrease resistance for an effective cardio workout.

1. Stand with the band looped under both feet and the other end of the band in both hands in an overhead press position. | 2. Do a light hop and bring both feet outward while pressing the band overhead.
1. Perform a jumping jack while crossing the feet.

1. Stand with feet together, arms at your sides, ready to jump. | 2. Jump while spreading legs and raising arms overhead. | 3. Return to starting position with legs together and arms at your sides. Repeat.

1. Sit on a bench with back support. Raise the bar to shoulder height with your palms forward. | 2. Raise the bar upwards and pause at the contracted position. | 3. Lower the weight back to starting position.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 1 Crosslateral Limb Raise 4Pt Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to the 4 point position (on all fours) | 2. 90 angles at hips and shoulder and neutral spine | 3. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 4. Hold for a split second and bring back to starting position

Exercise Name: Core Stability 2 Opposite Shoulder Tap 4Pt Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to the 4 point position (on all fours). 90 angles at hips and shoulder and neutral spine. | 2. Lift your knees slightly off the ground supporting your weight on palms and toes. | 3. Maintain a toe placement roughly at shoulder width (the wider the leg stance the easier the exercise - the narrower the stance the more difficult it becomes. | 4. Tap your opposite shoulder with your fingertips.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 4 Crosslateral Limb Raise Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Maintain a toe placement roughly at shoulder width (the wider the leg stance the easier the exercise - the narrower the stance the more difficult it becomes. | 3. Tap your opposite shoulder with your fingertips. | 4. Do not tilt or shift your hips. Do not round or arch your back.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 5 Crosslateral Limb Raise Into Knee Elbow Tuck Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 3. Hold for a split second and then try to bring your elbow to your opposite knee by driving both towards the centre of the body. | 4. Spine might curve slightly but you should not shift your hips during the movement.

Exercise Name: Core Stability Regression Crosslateral Limb Raise Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Tap the hand of the working arm on the ground to find your balance. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 3. Hold for a split second and then try to bring your elbow to your opposite knee by driving both towards the centre of the body. | 4. Spine might curve slightly but you should not shift your hips during the movement.

1. From the standing position perform a walkout (use to palms to "walk" into the push up position). | 2. Bring your leg to the side and place the foot by your palm. | 3. Rotate towards the ceiling and then towards the ground, pressing the hips towards the ground.
1. Lie on your front with your arms extended and above your head. | 2. Point the thumbs up. | 3. Try to raise your arms off the ground keeping them straight.

Exercise Name: Lat And Shoulder External Rotation Stretch 1 Kneeling Dowel
Instructions: 1. Kneel in front of a bench, placing your elbows on with palms facing up while holding the dowel at shoulder width. | 2. Sit your hips back onto your heels, pressing the head in between the arms. | 3. You should feel a stretch in your lats, triceps and deep in the shoulder joint. | 4. You can add movement (bend-extended arms) to mobilise the shoulder joint.

Exercise Name: Lat And Shoulder External Rotation Stretch 2 Kneeling Dowel
Instructions: 1. Kneel in front of a bench, placing your elbows on with palms facing up while holding the dowel at shoulder width. | 2. Sit your hips back onto your heels, pressing the head in between the arms. | 3. You should feel a stretch in your lats, triceps and deep in the shoulder joint. | 4. You can add movement (bend-extended arms) to mobilise the shoulder joint.

Exercise Name: Lat And Shoulder External Rotation Stretch 3 Kneeling Dowel
Instructions: 1. Kneel in front of a bench, placing your elbows on with palms facing up while holding the dowel at shoulder width. | 2. Sit your hips back onto your heels, pressing the head in between the arms. | 3. You should feel a stretch in your lats, triceps and deep in the shoulder joint. | 4. You can add movement (bend-extended arms) to mobilise the shoulder joint.

1. Start by setting up the rings to a secure anchor point and adjust the straps so that they hang about waist height when you stand under them. | 2. Stand facing the rings grab the handles with both hands, and step forward so that your body is in a plank position with your hands directly beneath your shoulders. | 3. Lower your body down by bending your elbows until your chest nearly touches the handles. Keep your core tight and your body in a straight line. | 4. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms as you do so. Make sure to engage your chest, triceps, and core throughout the movement.
1. Hold a barbell at shoulder height with a pronated grip. | 2. Press the barbell over your head. | 3. Lower it behind your head, then return to the front. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand tall with an overhand grip on the barbell. Raise your arms until your fists are pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Return to the start under control. This exercise is prone to using momentum when you begin to fatigue.

1. Sit on an incline bench with an overhand grip on the barbell. Raise your arms until your fists are pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Return to the start under control. This exercise is prone to using momentum when you begin to fatigue.

1. Stand tall with an overhand grip on the dumbbell. Raise your arms until your fists are pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Return to the start under control. This exercise is prone to using momentum when you begin to fatigue.
1. Take a half kneeling position while holding two dumbbells. | 2. Drive the dumbbells upwards.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Half Kneeling Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Take a half kneeling position while holding one dumbbell. | 2. Drive the dumbbell upwards.

1. Grab two dumbbells while sitting on an incline bench upright with the dumbbells at your side. | 2. Raise the two dumbbells with your elbows being fully extended until the dumbbells are eye level. | 3. Lower the weights in a controlled manner to the starting position and repeat.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Seated Single Arm Arnold Press
Instructions: 1. Start by sitting on an incline bench and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing you and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is directly above your head. | 4. As you extend your arm, rotate your palm to face away from your body.

1. Sit on an upright bench , grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Press the dumbbells outward into a y shape.

1. Stand tall, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Press the dumbbells outward into a y shape.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Kneeling Bottoms Up Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by taking a kneeling position and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.

1. With dumbbells in either hand, bend your knees with your feet slightly bowed out. Arch your back above your knees, and start with the weights touching in front of your chest. | 2. With bent elbows, raise your arms up to shoulder level, pausing at the at the end of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your arms back to starting position.

1. With dumbbells in either hand, bend your knees with your feet slightly bowed out. Arch your back above your knees, and start with the weights touching in front of your chest. | 2. With bent elbows, raise your arms up to shoulder level, pausing at the at the end of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your arms back to starting position.

1. Hinge forward at the hips while maintaining a flat back. Try to get your torso as close to parallel with the ground as your mobility will allow for. | 2. Let your arms hang in front of you. Pull your elbows back towards the ceiling while flaring your elbows outward.

Exercise Name: Cable High Single Arm Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arm. | 3. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your upper chest and then lower the kettlebell- repeat.

1. Stand facing away from the TRX straps and grab the handles with both hands. | 2. Step away so your body is leaning away from the anchor point. | 3. Flex your elbows and pull your elbows straight back behind your body. | 4. Make sure to keep your elbows flared outward.

1. Stand facing away from the TRX straps and grab the handles with both hands. | 2. Step forward so that your body is in a plank position, with your arms straight and your body in a straight line from your head to your heels. | 3. Keeping your arms straight, slowly lift your arms out to the side, keeping them at the same height as your shoulders. Your body should form a "T" shape.

1. Keep your back straight and bend forward slightly at the waist. | 2. With arms extended, raise the weights out to your sides until they are in line with your shoulders. | 3. Pause briefly and then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Plate Internally Rotated Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. With plates in either hand, bend your knees with your feet slightly bowed out. Hinge forward with a flat back. | 2. Maintain an overhand grip and internally rotated shoulders. | 3. Raise your arms backward toward the ceiling while maintaining a light band in your elbows.

1. Start by standing between the two anchored bands with your feet shoulder-width apart and the bands positioned at a high point. | 2. Grasp the ends of each band with your hands, keeping your palms facing each other. | 3. Keeping your arms slightly bent and your back straight, slowly pull the bands away from your body until your arms are extended straight out to the sides. Hold for a second, then slowly release back to the starting position. Repeat for desired reps.

Exercise Name: Internally Rotated Seated Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. Sit with your chest in your lap, dumbbells in hands, arms bent, internally rotate shoulders. | 2. Raise dumbbells out to sides, squeeze rear delts. | 3. Lower weights, repeat for reps.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, kettlebell in each hand, hinge at hips. | 2. Pull kettlebells while flaring your elbows, squeezing shoulder blades. Keep back flat.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. On the same side as the working arm, step back and rotate outwards. | 3. Pull your elbow back while flaring your elbow out.

Exercise Name: Cable High Internally Rotated Reverse Fly
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arms. Internally rotate the shoulders. | 3. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.
1. Start with the cables at the top. Use a rope attachment. Fall to a half kneeling position. | 2. Pull the metal piece in the middle of the rope to the bridge of your nose.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. Start with an overhand grip. As you pull your elbow back, rotate your palm until it faces upward.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Internally Rotated High Reverse Fly
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arms. Internally rotate the shoulders. | 3. From there, your shoulder should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Rear Delt Row
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment, grab with an overhand grip and take a position with the cable crossing your body. | 2. Pull your elbows back while flaring your elbows outward.

1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arm. | 3. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Internally Rotated Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. Sit with hinged over position, dumbbells in hands, arms slightly bent, internally rotate shoulders. | 2. Raise dumbbells out to sides, squeeze rear delts. | 3. Lower weights, repeat for reps.

1. Sit on a bench. Put your chest in your lap. Try to get your torso as close to parallel with the ground as your mobility will allow for. | 2. Let your arms hang in front of you. Pull your elbows back towards the ceiling while flaring your elbows outward.
1. Grab the band with a double overhand grip. Bring both feet outward while performing a little hop. | 2. As you hop, pull the band apart.

1. With dumbbells in either hand, lay on an incline bench that's at about 15-30 degrees. | 2. With bent elbows, raise your arms up to shoulder level, pausing at the at the end of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your arms back to starting position.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Laying Reverse Fly Internally Rotated
Instructions: 1. With dumbbells in either hand and an overhand grip, lay on an incline bench that is roughly 15 - 30 degrees high. | 2. With bent elbows, raise your arms up to shoulder level, pausing at the at the end of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your arms back to starting position.

1. Sit on a bench with one foot on the bench. | 2. Place the elbow on the inside of your elbow and use it for leverage. | 3. Point your fist toward the wall andthen toward the ceiling. Rotating a total of 90 degrees.
1. Hold your arms out to your sides. | 2. Rotate your arms backwards in small circles.
1. Hold your arms out to your sides. | 2. Rotate your arms forward in small circles.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a medicine ball. | 2. Circle the ball around your head, maintaining control. | 3. Complete the desired number of repetitions in both directions.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Bring one arm behind you and rest this arm on your back. With the other arm, hold the kettlebell at arms length close to the floor. | 4. Swing the kettlebell out and up towards the side of your body and then return to centre. Repeat.

1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate one arm overhead and behind while keeping the other arm in front of you. | 3. Then rotate the other arm. | 4. Bring the original arm back to the starting position, then the other arm. Repeat.
1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate both arms overhead and behind you while leaving your elbows mostly extended.

1. Stand with you feet shoulder width apart. Place one arm across the front of your chest at shoulder height, press the forearm of your other arm above the elbow, hooking the stretching arm with your hand. | 2. Press the arm until it is straight and rotate your upper torso to engage the stretch even deeper. | 3. Repeat with your other arm.

1. Start with your arms at either side. Begin by pushing your shoulders forward and in towards your chest. | 2. Continue the circular motion with your shoulders, pinching up towards your ears, and then extending your chest outwards while you finish the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. Facing the pulley, pull the weight towards you while keeping your arms parallel to the ground. | 2. Pull your hands back to both sides of your head and hold the position. | 3. Slowly return weight to starting position. Repeat.
1. Anchor the band at eye level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Use an overhand grip with both hands. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose flaring your elbows out.
1. Start with a band anchored to a high point. Stagger your stance. | 2. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose.
1. Grab the band with a shoulder width grip. Point your arms straight in front of you. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades and shoulder joint until the band taps your chest.

1. Hold the TRX straps and lean away from the anchor point. | 2. Pull your elbows back while externally rotating your shoulder joint. Your arms should make a W shape at the back portion of the exercise.

1. Begin in a tabletop position with your hands and knees on the ground. | 2. Walk your hands forward as you lower your chest towards the ground. | 3. Keep your hips over your knees and extend your arms out in front of you. | 4. Hold for a few breaths and then release.
1. Grab the two handles and hinge forward. | 2. Keep your elbows mostly extended and raise your arms straight out to the side.

1. From the standing position perform a walkout (use to palms to "walk" into the push up position). | 2. Bring your leg to the side and place the foot by your palm. | 3. Rotate towards the ceiling and then towards the ground, pressing the hips towards the ground.

Exercise Name: Lat And Shoulder External Rotation Stretch 1 Kneeling Dowel
Instructions: 1. Kneel in front of a bench, placing your elbows on with palms facing up while holding the dowel at shoulder width. | 2. Sit your hips back onto your heels, pressing the head in between the arms. | 3. You should feel a stretch in your lats, triceps and deep in the shoulder joint. | 4. You can add movement (bend-extended arms) to mobilise the shoulder joint.

Exercise Name: Lat And Shoulder External Rotation Stretch 2 Kneeling Dowel
Instructions: 1. Kneel in front of a bench, placing your elbows on with palms facing up while holding the dowel at shoulder width. | 2. Sit your hips back onto your heels, pressing the head in between the arms. | 3. You should feel a stretch in your lats, triceps and deep in the shoulder joint. | 4. You can add movement (bend-extended arms) to mobilise the shoulder joint.

Exercise Name: Lat And Shoulder External Rotation Stretch 3 Kneeling Dowel
Instructions: 1. Kneel in front of a bench, placing your elbows on with palms facing up while holding the dowel at shoulder width. | 2. Sit your hips back onto your heels, pressing the head in between the arms. | 3. You should feel a stretch in your lats, triceps and deep in the shoulder joint. | 4. You can add movement (bend-extended arms) to mobilise the shoulder joint.

1. With dumbbells in either hand, bend your knees with your feet slightly bowed out. Arch your back above your knees, and start with the weights touching in front of your chest. | 2. With bent elbows, raise your arms up to shoulder level, pausing at the at the end of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your arms back to starting position.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Head On Bench Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. With dumbbells in either hand, bend your knees with your feet slightly bowed out. Arch your back above your knees, place your head on the top of an incline bench, and start with the weights touching in front of your chest. | 2. With bent elbows, raise your arms up to shoulder level, pausing at the at the end of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your arms back to starting position.

1. Sit on the bench and hold a dumbbell with both hands. Raise the dumbbell overhead at arms length, holding the weight up with the palms of your hands. | 2. Keep your elbows in while you lower the weight behind your head, your upper arms stationary. | 3. Raise the weight back to starting position.

Exercise Name: Machine Cable V Bar Push Downs
Instructions: 1. Grip the pulley bar with palms facing down at shoulder width. | 2. Stand straight with a small forward incline. Keep your upper arms close to your body, and slowly bring the pulley bar down until your arms are fully extended. | 3. Pause when you are at the contracted position of the motion, then slowly raise the pulley bar back to the starting point.

1. Grip the edge of the bench with your hands, Keep your feet together and legs straight. | 2. Lower your body straight down. | 3. Slowly press back up to the starting point. | 4. TIP: Make this harder by raising your feet off the floor and adding weight.

1. Lay on a flat bench while holding a barbell with a shoulder-width grip. | 2. Fully extend your elbows until the barbell is directly over your chest. | 3. Begin to flex your elbows and allow the barbell to nearly touch your forehead. | 4. Extend your elbows back to the starting position and repeat.

1. Lie on your back with knees in the air and soles of your feet flat on the floor. | 2. Hold the kettlebell in both hands directly above your chest. | 3. Keeping your upper arms in place, bend your elbows to slowly bring the kettlebell in front of your forehead. | 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with legs shoulder width apart. | 2. Hold the kettlebell in both hands behind your head. | 3. Straighten arms bringing kettlebell above your head. | 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Lie on the floor with your upper back and soles of feet on the floor, knees bent, and pelvis and lower back suspended in the air. | 2. Hold the kettlebell in both hands directly above your chest. | 3. Keeping your upper arms in place, bend your elbows to bring the kettlebell to the floor above your head. | 4. Return the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.

1. Lie flat on your back. Keeping your arm straight, hold the kettlebell above your chest with your palm facing away from your body. | 2. Bend your arm, touching the kettlebell to the top of the shoulder opposite to the arm being worked. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Bend your left arm so your hand is at your shoulder, and hold your elbow with the opposite hand. | 2. Gently push on your elbow so it is raised by your head. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then repeat with the other arm.

1. Hold a band so it is in line with your spine. Hold the top with your right hand and the bottom with your left. | 2. Keeping the top still, pull down on the band. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then repeat with the other arm.

1. Raise your left arm above your head, and bend at the elbow so your hand is resting at the top of your back. | 2. Use the opposite hand to gently apply pressure to the elbow. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then repeat with the other arm.

1. Position your index fingers and thumbs so they are touching, forming a diamond shape | 2. Use a standard push up position | 3. Lower your chest towards your hands, keep your elbows close to your body | 4. Stop just before your chest touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With a narrow grip on the bar, straighten your arms | 2. Lower the bar to your lower-mid chest | 3. Slowly raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.
1. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Either use two handles or no attachment at all. Both sides of the cable crossover should be set to the top. | 2. Stand in the center of the machine holding each Cable in the opposing hand. Your upper arm should be at a 45 degree angle with your torso. | 3. Extend your elbows until you feel a contraction and then return to the starting position

1. You can use a straight bar, rope, easy bar, or two handles. The cable should be set all the way to the top of the machine. | 2. Face away from the machine with your elbows up and the attachment just behind your head. | 3. Extend at the elbows until you feel a contraction in your triceps and then flex at the elbow back to the starting position.

1. You can use any attachment. The cable should be all the way to the bottom of the machine. Face away from the machine. | 2. Point your elbows straight up toward the ceiling. | 3. From there, extend your elbows until your fists are pointed straight toward the ceiling.
1. Stand with one or both feet on band. Go up and over your head with the band to the starting position. | 2. Flex and extend your elbows.
1. Place the band just above eye level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back slightly. Extend and flex at the elbows.
1. Anchor a band to a stable point. | 2. Face away and begin with your elbows bent and fists by your temples. | 3. Extend your elbows until your triceps contract.

1. Lay flat on the floor or a bench with your fists extended to the ceiling and a neutral grip. | 2. Break at the elbows until your fists are by your temples. Then extend your elbows and flex your triceps at the top.
1. Take a shoulder width grip. Break at the elbows. Try to keep your elbows tucked in. Don't let them flare out. | 2. Stop the bar a few inches from your forehead and extend your elbows back up.

1. Be careful getting the bar into place overhead. Push your elbows forward while keeping your elbows tucked in. | 2. Look for what feels like a stretch in your triceps. Extend your elbows until your fists are pointed at the ceiling.

1. Start by lying on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Hold the dumbbells above your chest with your arms extended and your palms facing each other. This is the starting position. | 3. Slowly lower the dumbbells towards your forehead by bending your elbows. Keep your upper arms stationary and only move your forearms. | 4. Once the dumbbells are close to your forehead, reverse the motion by extending your elbows and returning to the starting position.

1. Lay flat on a bench with two dumbbells pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Break at the elbows until your forearms touch your biceps, then flex at the shoulder joint bringing your upper arms to the sides of your head. | 3. Bring your elbows back up until they are pointed at the ceiling, then extend your elbows.
1. Hold a dumbbell overhead. | 2. Flex at the elbows until the dumbbell is behind your head. | 3. Then extend your elbows until the dumbbell is back in the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bend at the waist and place your opposite hand on your knee for support. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm backwards so that the dumbbell is behind your body. | 4. Make sure to keep your elbow close to your body and your core engaged throughout the movement.

Exercise Name: Plate Curl To Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back behind the head to the starting position of a tricep extension. | 5. Push the plate back up overhead, then lower it back to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand or sit with a weight plate in your hands, arms extended straight above your head | 2. Lower the weight plate behind your head by bending at the elbows. | 3. Keep your elbows close to your head and shoulders relaxed. | 4. Push the weight plate back up to starting position, extending your arms fully.

1. Anchor the band to a high point and face away. Hold the band with both hands, placing your hands shoulder-width apart and keeping your elbows close to your body. | 2. Slowly extend your arms downward, keeping your elbows close to your body. Push the band down as far as you can, feeling the contraction in your triceps.

Exercise Name: Plate Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Brace your core and press the weight plate overhead until your arms are fully extended. Keep your shoulders down and back. | 2. While your arms are fully extended, lower the weight behind your head to perform the extension | 3. After completing the extension, lower the weight to your chest, and perform the overhead press. Repeat
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band with your right hand, with your arm at your side. | 2. Flex and extend your elbow.

1. Stand with a band anchored to a high point. Face away from the band. Hold the loop in one hand. | 2. Keep your elbow tucked in to your side. Extend your elbow. When you extend, don't let your upper arm raise. The band should land over your shoulder.
1. Stand facing away from a band which is anchored to a high point. | 2. Keep your elbow pointed forward, and extend and flex your elbow.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Overhead Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Stand tall with a single dumbbell extended overhead. | 2. Flex at the elbow letting the dumbbell travel behind your body. | 3. Try not to let your elbow flare outward.

1. Lay flat on a bench with two dumbbells extended toward the ceiling. | 2. Maintain an overhand grip. Flex at the elbows. | 3. The dumbbells will land on your upper chest/clavicle. | 4. Extend your elbows bringing the dumbbells back into their starting position. | 5. *Named after Dave Tate*
1. Hold the two TRX straps and lean forward. The straps should be over each shoulder. | 2. Keep your elbows tucked in and then flex and extend at the elbows.
1. Hold your body with arms locked above the equipment | 2. Lower your body slowly while leaning forward, flare out your elbows | 3. Raise your body above the bars until your arms are locked.

1. Loop the band around your mid-back. The ends of the bands should be around your hands between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. This exercise can be done from the knees or the toes depending on experience level. | 3. Begin by breaking at the elbows until your upper arm is by your side. Then extend at the elbows back into the top position.
1. Un-rack the bar and break at the elbows and shoulders. | 2. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.

1. Start in a bench press position with your feet planted on the bench and knees bent. | 2. Grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, positioning your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. | 3. Lift the barbell off the rack and lower it to your chest, keeping your elbows close to your sides. | 4. Push the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

1. Start in a bench press position with your legs elevated. Try to keep your knees with a slight bend in them. | 2. Unrack the bar then initiate the rep. | 3. Bring the bar to your torso and tap your ribcage before pressing back to the ceiling.

1. Start on the bench with your shoulder blades pulled back. | 2. As you initiate the first rep, tuck your elbows slightly until the bar is a few inches off your chest. | 3. Pause just off your chest for 1-3 seconds. Then press explosively.

1. Begin by sitting on the ground with your legs extended and a barbell in your hands, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, lift the barbell up from your chest and press it straight up above your head. | 3. Lower the barbell back down to your chest.

1. Start in a bench press position with two dumbbells. | 2. Break at one of your elbows first while keeping the other elbow extended. | 3. Your working arm should reach your side before pressing back to the ceiling. | 4. Then alternate to the other arm.

1. Start by lying flat on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Hold the dumbbells at chest level with your palms facing forward. | 3. Engage your core and press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Decline Alternating Single Arm Press
Instructions: 1. Lay on a decline bench with both arms extended in front of you. | 2. Break at one of your arms first bringing that arm to your side while keeping the other arm extended. | 3. Press the dumbbell back to the ceiling. Fully extend that arm before initiating on the other side.

1. Lay on a decline bench with both arms extended in front of you. | 2. Break at the elbows and bring your upper arms to your side. | 3. Once your upper arms have reached your side, press the dumbbells back to the ceiling.

1. Lie on the decline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing forward. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows flared out. As you lower the dumbbells, exhale deeply. | 3. Once your elbows reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position

1. Lie on the decline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Decline Single Arm Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Start by laying on a decline bench with two dumbbells. | 2. Position the dumbbell above your chest with your elbow bent and shoulder level. | 3. Slowly lower the dumbbell towards your chest, keeping your elbow close to your body and your core engaged while the other dumbbell remains pointed toward the ceiling. | 4. Once the dumbbell reaches your side, pause for a moment and then press the weight back up to the starting position. | 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching to your other arm.

1. Lay flat on a decline bench with two dumbbells pressed to one another. | 2. Break at the elbows and keep your elbows tucked as you bring the dumbbells to your chest. | 3. Continue to press the dumbbells into one another throughout the rep. | 4. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, press back toward the ceiling.

1. Lie on the flat bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing forward. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows flared out. As you lower the dumbbells, exhale deeply. | 3. Once your elbows reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position

1. Lie on the incline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing forward. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows flared out. As you lower the dumbbells, exhale deeply. | 3. Once your elbows reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position

1. Lie on a flat bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Lie on an incline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Sit on an upright bench , grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your shoulder joint, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Begin seated on an upright bench with your palms facing you. | 2. Begin pressing toward the ceiling. As you press, rotate your palms. | 3. As you extend your elbows fully your palms should be facing forward.

1. Lay flat on a bench with two dumbbells pressed to one another. | 2. Break at the elbows and keep your elbows tucked as you bring the dumbbells to your chest. | 3. Continue to press the dumbbells into one another throughout the rep. | 4. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, press back toward the ceiling.

1. Start by laying on a bench with two dumbbells. | 2. Position the dumbbell above your chest with your elbow bent and shoulder level. | 3. Slowly lower the dumbbell towards your chest, keeping your elbow close to your body and your core engaged while the other dumbbell remains pointed toward the ceiling. | 4. Once the dumbbell reaches your side, pause for a moment and then press the weight back up to the starting position. | 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching to your other arm.
1. Start in a standing position

1. Start with two dumbbells just above your shoulders. | 2. Press one dumbbell to the ceiling while keeping the other in place. | 3. Let the first dumbbell return to its starting position before pressing the other dumbbell.

1. Start with two dumbbells near your shoulders with a neutral grip. | 2. Press one of the dumbbells toward the ceiling while keeping the other in position. | 3. Let the first dumbbell return to its starting position before pressing the other.
1. Start with both dumbbells near your shoulders in a neutral grip. | 2. Press the dumbbells toward the ceiling. | 3. Make sure you don't arch your back as you fatigue.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the dumbbells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. From this starting position, dip your knees slightly and then quickly extend them as you press the dumbbells upwards. | 3. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement. | 4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing you and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is directly above your head. | 4. As you extend your arm, rotate your palm to face away from your body.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Neutral Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing your body and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, press the dumbbell upwards so that it is directly above your shoulder.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing forward and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Hold the plate with both hands at chest height. | 2. Keeping your core tight and your chest up, squat down as low as you can go while keeping your feet flat on the ground. | 3. Hold the squat position and reach the plate forward, keeping your arms straight and your back straight. | 4. Return the plate to your chest while you hold the squat position and repeat reaching the plate in front of you

1. Start in a pushup position with both hands on a plate. This will extend your range of motion. | 2. Break at the elbows and shoulders until your upper arm travels behind the body slightly. | 3. Then press back into the original position.

1. Start by placing two dumbbells on the floor, about shoulder-width apart. | 2. Position yourself in a plank position with your hands on top of the dumbbells, keeping your arms straight. | 3.
