Keep your feet together, with your toes resting on the floor. | 4. Engage your core and lower your body towards the floor by bending your arms, until your chest nearly touches the dumbbells. | 5. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms and engaging your chest, triceps and shoulders.

1. Start by setting up the TRX straps to a secure anchor point and adjust the straps so that they hang about waist height when you stand under them. | 2. Stand facing the TRX straps, grab the handles with both hands, and step forward so that your body is in a plank position with your hands directly beneath your shoulders. | 3. Lower your body down by bending your elbows until your chest nearly touches the handles. Keep your core tight and your body in a straight line. | 4. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms as you do so. Make sure to engage your chest, triceps, and core throughout the movement.

1. Place two blocks on the floor, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Kneel in front of the blocks, and lower your torso down so that your elbows are resting on the blocks, and your forehead is resting on the floor. | 3. Relax your arms, shoulders, and neck, and breathe deeply. | 4. Hold for a few breaths, then release.

1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. | 2. Bend your left knee and place your left foot on the floor, close to your right hip. | 3. Cross your right leg over your left leg, stacking your knees on top of each other. | 4. Bring your left arm up overhead, and bend your elbow so that your left hand reaches towards your upper back. Reach your right hand behind your back and try to clasp your left hand. Hold

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and place your hands on a table, chair, or any elevated surface in front of you. | 2. Walk your feet back until your torso is parallel to the ground, and your elbows are resting on the surface. | 3. Relax your head and neck, and breathe deeply. | 4. Hold for a few breaths, then release.

1. Start lying on your back perpendicularly to the barbell, holding the bar directly over your shoulder with the hand that's closer to the bar with your palm facing down towards your feet. | 2. While keeping your shoulder steady, bend your elbow and lower the end of the bar back towards your the ground next to your head. Keep your hinging elbow pointed down towards your feet. | 3. Drive through your palm to extend your elbow and return the bar to the starting position, then repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.
1. Place one hand on medicine ball, other on ground. | 2. Perform push-up, walking hands to switch positions.
1. Place one hand on Bosu, other on the floor. | 2. Lower chest to the ground, keeping the body straight. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.
1. Place feet on Bosu, hips high, hands on the floor. | 2. Lower the head towards the ground, then push back up. | 3. Keep legs straight and hips elevated throughout.
1. Place hands on Bosu, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Lower chest to the ground, keeping the body straight. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.
1. Place both hands on Bosu, wider than shoulder-width. | 2. Perform a pushup, then walk hands to the other side. | 3. Perform another pushup, repeat back and forth.
1. Use the belt attachment. Take a pushup position. | 2. Have your elbows at a 45 degree angle. Break at the elbows until your upper arm gets to your side. | 3. And then push up.
1. Lie on bench, hold kettlebell with both hands over chest. | 2. Lower kettlebells, elbows flared. | 3. Press kettlebells upward, fully extending arms. Repeat.

1. Use the bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Use the bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. Grab the bar with n overhand grip. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.
1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set to hip height. | 2. Hinge forward. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Use the rope attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Either use a handle or no attachment at all. The cable crossover should be set to the top. | 2. Stand in the center of the machine holding the cable in the opposing hand. Your upper arm should be at a 45 degree angle with your torso. | 3. Extend your elbow until you feel a contraction and then return to the starting position
1. Stand facing away from the cable, which is at the top of the cable stack. | 2. Keep your elbow pointed forward, and extend and flex your elbow.
1. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.

1. Lay flat on an incline bench with two dumbbells pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Break at the elbows until your forearms touch your biceps, then flex at the shoulder joint bringing your upper arms to the sides of your head. | 3. Bring your elbows back up until they are pointed at the ceiling, then extend your elbows.

1. Grip the edge of the boxes with your hands, Keep your feet together and legs straight. | 2. Lower your body straight down. | 3. Slowly press back up to the starting point. | 4. TIP: Make this harder by raising your feet off the floor and adding weight.
1. Start in a push-up position. | 2. Lower your chest, explode up, clap hands. | 3. Land softly, repeat for reps.
1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands forming a diamond shape under your chest. | 2. Lower your body, keeping elbows close. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.

1. Start by placing two plates or low boxes on the floor, about shoulder-width apart. | 2. Position yourself in a plank position with your hands on top of the boxes/plates, keeping your arms straight. | 3. Keep your feet together, with your toes resting on the floor. | 4. Engage your core and lower your body towards the floor by bending your arms, until your chest nearly touches the dumbbells. | 5. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms and engaging your chest, triceps and shoulders.
1. Start in a push-up position. | 2. Lower your chest, explode up. | 3. Land softly, repeat for reps.

1. Start by placing two boxes (or one) on the floor, about shoulder-width apart. | 2. Position yourself in a plank position with your hands on top of the box, keeping your arms straight. | 3. Put your knees on the floor. | 4. Engage your core and lower your body towards the floor by bending your arms, until your chest nearly touches the box. | 5. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms and engaging your chest, triceps and shoulders.
1. Begin in a push-up position on your knees. Break at the elbow and shoulder joint. | 2. Lower your body, keeping elbows close. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.
1. Begin in kneeling position. Hands shoulder width apart. Break at the elbows while letting your elbows fall to the floor. | 2. Extend your elbows until you are back in the starting position.
1. Begin in a plank position. Hands shoulder width apart. Break at the elbows while letting your elbows fall to the floor. | 2. Extend your elbows until you are back in the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Bottoms Up Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding one kettlebell with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebell to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebell are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.
1. Start flat on your back with the kettlebells extended over you. | 2. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.

1. Be careful getting the KB into place overhead. Push your elbows forward while keeping your elbows tucked in. | 2. Look for what feels like a stretch in your triceps. Extend your elbows until your fists are pointed at the ceiling.
1. Start flat on your back with a kettlebell extended over you. | 2. Bring your elbow to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.
1. Hold the smith bar and lean forward. | 2. Keep your elbows tucked in and then flex and extend at the elbows.

Exercise Name: Smith Machine Close Grip Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With a narrow grip on the bar, straighten your arms | 2. Lower the bar to your lower-mid chest | 3. Slowly raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Lie on the flat bench, grasp the bar at shoulder level with your palms facing forward. | 2. Slowly lower the bar to your chest, keeping your elbows flared out. | 3. Once you feel a stretch in your chest press the weight back up.
1. Take a shoulder width grip. Break at the elbows. Try to keep your elbows tucked in. Don't let them flare out. | 2. Stop the bar a few inches from your forehead and extend your elbows back up.

1. Attach the band to an anchor point that is about shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and elbow across your body until your arm is fully extended.

1. Laying on the floor with your knees bent and feet firmly on the floor, hold the kettlebell at your chest with both hands. | 2. Fully extend your arms, raising the kettlebell until your elbows are locked. | 3. Lower the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.

1. Laying on the floor with your knees bent and feet firmly on the floor, leave one arm resting to the side of the body. | 2. Using the other arm, hold the kettlebell at arms length directly upwards of your shoulder. | 3. Lower your arm until your upper arm to elbow is resting on the floor. | 4. Return to starting position.

1. Starting in a press up position with feet wide and one hand resting on the kettlebell, complete a full press up, lowering your chest towards the ground while keeping your body straight and returning to the starting position. | 2. Swap hands on the kettlebell, placing the hand originally on the kettlebell underneath your shoulder, complete another press up. | 3. Repeat.

1. Stand facing bench or sturdy elevated platform. | 2. Place hands on edge of bench or platform, slightly wider than shoulder width. | 3. Slowly lower your body until your chest almost touches the bench. | 4. Push body up until arms are extended.

1. Use a bench to elevate your feet. | 2. Put your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. | 3. Slowly lower your body until your chest almost touches the ground | 4. Raise your body until you almost lock your elbows.

1. Stand facing the landmine leaning forward slightly with the end of the barbell held in one hand at your shoulder with your elbow positioned beneath your wrist. | 2. While keeping your elbow pointed forward, drive the bar directly overhead, switching hands at the top of the movement. Lower the bar back down to the other side of your body, mirroring the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps, switching hands at the top of each rep.

1. Start in a kneeling position facing the barbell with one hand holding the end of the barbell at your shoulder with your elbow tucked beneath your wrist. | 2. Keeping your elbow pointing forward, drive the barbell up overhead until your arm is fully extended and switch the bar to your other hand at the top of the movement. | 3. Control the descent of the bar to your other shoulder and repeat movement for desired reps, switching hands at the top of each rep.

1. Start kneeling in front of the landmine, facing towards it, with your knees hip-width apart and your back straight while holding the end of the bar in both hands in front of your chest. | 2. Push the landmine up overhead by fully extending your arms until the weight is directly over your head. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the landmine back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand facing the landmine, holding the end of the bar in both hands with your palms facing each other. | 2. Extend your arms upward, pressing the end of the bar up overhead. Pause at the top of the movement, then lower the bar with control back to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Start sitting on the ground facing the landmine attachment with your legs open for stability while holding the end of the bar in a neutral grip with your hand resting at your shoulder and your elbow beneath your wrist. | 2. Leaning forward slightly, press the bar up into the air until your arm is fully extended. At the top of the movement, switch which hand is holding the end of the bar and lower the bar back down to the opposite shoulder. Perform again to return the bar to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Sit on the ground facing the landmine with your legs spread. Hold the end of the bar in both hands in front of your chest with your palms facing each other. | 2. While keeping your torso tall and core brace, drive the end of the bar upward until your arms are fully extended. Lean forward slightly for full range of motion in the shoulder joints. Lower the bar back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps.

Exercise Name: Landmine Seated Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Sit on the ground facing the landmine with your legs spread. Hold the end of the bar in one hand in front of that shoulder with your palm facing across your body. | 2. While keeping your torso tall and your core braced, drive the bar upwards until your arm is fully extended, leaning forward slightly for full range of motion in the shoulder joint. Lower the bar back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps on one side, then switch sides.

1. Starting lying on your back perpendicularly to the barbell while holding the end of the bar in your hand that is further away from the landmine attachment. Your elbow should be rest on the ground at a 45 to 60 degree angle from your torso, with your wrist stacked over your elbow. | 2. Drive the end of the bar upwards, squeezing your chest at the top of the movement. Lower the bar back down until your elbow gently touches the ground. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

1. Stand in front of the landmine with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with one hand, palm facing in, and bring it to shoulder height with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Press the barbell overhead by extending your arm fully, pushing the weight upward. Keep your core engaged, your back straight, and your shoulder down throughout the movement. Pause briefly at the top of the movement with your arm fully extended overhead. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position at shoulder height with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

1. Stand in front of the landmine with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with one hand, palm facing in, and bring it to shoulder height with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Dip your body slightly then drive up through the ground to generate momentum as your extend your arm fully upwards. Pause briefly at the top of the rep, then lower the weight back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

Exercise Name: Landmine Single Arm Staggered Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Stand facing the bar in a split stance with one leg forward and bent and the other back and straight. Hold the bar in the hand on the side of the leg that is back with the end of the bar at your shoulder with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Drive the bar upwards until your arm is fully extended. Pause briefly before lowering the end of the bar back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.
1. Stand with both palms facing you. | 2. Begin to press the dumbbells to the ceiling while rotating your palms. | 3. When you reach elbow extension, your palms should be facing forward.

1. Sit on the machine and grab the handles with a neutral grip. | 2. Adjust the machine to get the longest range of motion possible. | 3. Press until your elbows are not extended but not hyperextended.

Exercise Name: Medicine Ball Chest Press Partner Toss
Instructions: 1. Stand tall, partner tosses medicine ball to chest. | 2. Catch ball and press it back to partner. Repeat.
1. Place hands on medicine ball, in push-up position. | 2. Perform push-up, maintaining proper form.
1. Lie on a bench, hold kettlebells above chest. | 2. Lower them to chest, then push up. | 3. Repeat for desired reps, maintaining form.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.
1. Start with kettlebell in rack position. | 2. Dip at knees and hips. | 3. Explosively push kettlebell overhead, fully extending arms.

1. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Sit tall and try not to arch your spine as you're pressing. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Clean And Press
Instructions: 1. Begin with the kettlebell between your legs. | 2. Hinge at your hips, and lift to shoulder, then press overhead.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring the handle to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulder and elbow simultaneously.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Incline Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set fairly low. | 2. Bring the handle across your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulder and elbow simultaneously.

1. Stand in the middle of the two bands with feet shoulder-width apart. Step forward with one foot to create tension in the bands. | 2. Hold one band in each hand, palms facing forward. Start the exercise with your arms extended in front of you, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. | 3. Lower your arms to the sides of your chest, maintaining control of the band. | 4. Push your arms back up to the starting position, keeping your core engaged and maintaining control of the band.

1. Stand between the two anchored bands, grasp them with an overhand grip, and position the bands at shoulder level. | 2. Brace your core and push the bands overhead, fully extending your arms. | 3. Lower the bands back to shoulder level, keeping your core engaged and arms straight. Repeat for desired number of reps.

1. Stand with the band looped under both feet and the other end of the band in both hands in an overhead press position. | 2. Do a light hop and bring both feet outward while pressing the band overhead.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 2 Opposite Shoulder Tap 4Pt Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to the 4 point position (on all fours). 90 angles at hips and shoulder and neutral spine. | 2. Lift your knees slightly off the ground supporting your weight on palms and toes. | 3. Maintain a toe placement roughly at shoulder width (the wider the leg stance the easier the exercise - the narrower the stance the more difficult it becomes. | 4. Tap your opposite shoulder with your fingertips.

Exercise Name: Elbow Extensor Isometric Seated Overhead Dumbbell
Instructions: 1. Sit on a box or bench without any back support. | 2. Raise the weight over your head and extend your elbow. | 3. From there, bend the elbow 1/4 of the way. | 4. Hold isometrically for the prescribed amount of time.

Exercise Name: Elbow Extensor Mobilisation Kneeling Lacrosse Ball
Instructions: 1. Kneel in front of a bench and place a massage ball on it. | 2. Place your tricep (back of the arm) on the ball with the elbow bent. Try to find a tight, painful spot. | 3. Once you have found it, apply gentle pressure on the ball. | 4. Once you get comfortable with the pain extend and bend your arm.

1. Leap sideways, land on right foot, left leg behind to the side. | 2. Drop into a single-leg burpee, right leg only, hands to ground. | 3. Return to standing on right, leap sideways to left, repeat with left leg.
1. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Keep legs straight or bent. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.
1. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Place knees on pad. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.

1. Sit on the machine and grab the handles with an overhand grip. | 2. Adjust the machine to get the longest range of motion possible. | 3. Press until your elbows are not extended but not hyperextended.

1. Start by setting up the rings to a secure anchor point and adjust the straps so that they hang about waist height when you stand under them. | 2. Stand facing the rings grab the handles with both hands, and step forward so that your body is in a plank position with your hands directly beneath your shoulders. | 3. Lower your body down by bending your elbows until your chest nearly touches the handles. Keep your core tight and your body in a straight line. | 4. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms as you do so. Make sure to engage your chest, triceps, and core throughout the movement.

1. Attach the ring straps to a high point. Stand on your tip toes. | 2. Your arms should be extended in front of you. | 3. Break at the elbows until your forearms touch your biceps. Then extend your elbows back to the start.

1. Position rings shoulder-width apart, grasp handles, extend legs behind. | 2. Lower chest to rings, bend one elbow, while extending your other arm out to the side. Push yourself back to the start. | 3. Then switch arms and repeat.
1. Lie on bench, hold kettlebell with both hands over chest. | 2. Lower kettlebells, elbows flared. | 3. Press kettlebells upward, fully extending arms. Repeat.

1. Place a plate on your back. Position your index fingers and thumbs so they are touching, forming a diamond shape. | 2. Use a standard push up position | 3. Lower your chest towards your hands, keep your elbows close to your body | 4. Stop just before your chest touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.
1. Begin in a push-up position on your knees. Break at the elbow and shoulder joint. | 2. Lower your body, keeping elbows close. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Seated Single Arm Arnold Press
Instructions: 1. Start by sitting on an incline bench and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing you and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is directly above your head. | 4. As you extend your arm, rotate your palm to face away from your body.

1. Sit on an upright bench , grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Press the dumbbells outward into a y shape.

1. Use a dip belt to attach a dumbbell to yourself. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Keep legs straight or bent. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.

1. Stand tall, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Press the dumbbells outward into a y shape.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Kneeling Bottoms Up Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by taking a kneeling position and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Use a dip belt to attach a plate to yourself. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Keep legs straight or bent. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.
1. Loop the band around your back. The two end loops in each of your hands. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and elbow across your body until your arm is fully extended.
1. Anchor the band to a stable point. | 2. Hinge forward. Extend and flex at the elbow.
1. Sit on the machine and grab the handles. | 2. Press the handles down until your elbows are nearly extended.

1. Adjust the pad to suit your height. | 2. Grab the v bar (or other attachment) and extend your elbows until they are almost fully extended. | 3. Flex your elbows and look to feel a stretch at the bottom of each rep.

Exercise Name: Machine Plate Loaded Decline Chest Press
Instructions: 1. Adjust the seat pad to match your height. | 2. Press the weight forward until your elbows are nearly extended. Return to the starting position with out letting the weight rest at the bottom until finishing your set.

Exercise Name: Machine Plate Loaded Incline Chest Press
Instructions: 1. Adjust the seat pad to match your height. | 2. Press the weight forward until your elbows are nearly extended. Return to the starting position with out letting the weight rest at the bottom until finishing your set.

Exercise Name: Machine Plate Loaded Low Incline Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Adjust the seat pad to match your height. | 2. Press the weight forward until your elbows are nearly extended. Return to the starting position with out letting the weight rest at the bottom until finishing your set.
1. Sit on the machine and place the back of your upper arm on the bench. | 2. Extend your elbows until you feel a contraction in your triceps. | 3. Bring the weight back to the starting position.

1. You can use any attachment. The cable should be even with your mid-back. Face away from the machine. | 2. Point your elbows straight forward. Press the weight straight toward the ceiling. | 3. As you return to the start, push your elbows forward. Try to touch your biceps to your forearms at the bottom of each rep.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Overhead Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set to your mid-back. Face away from the machine. | 2. Point your elbows straight up toward the ceiling. | 3. From there, extend your elbows until your fists are pointed straight toward the ceiling.
1. Unrack the barbell. Break at the elbows and begin lowering the barbell. | 2. Lower the barbell to your neck before extending your elbows back to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Bench Braced Single Arm Overhead Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Lay sideways on an incline bench and press the elbow of the working arm into the bench. | 2. Use your free arm to pull your upper body into the bench. | 3. Break at the elbow until your elbow is fully flexed, then extend your elbow until the dumbbell is pointed at the ceiling.
1. Lay flat on a bench. | 2. Push your elbows forward until your biceps touch your forearms. Then extend your elbows until back at the starting position.

1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With a narrow grip on the bar, straighten your arms | 2. Lower the bar to your lower-mid chest | 3. Slowly raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.
1. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Lay flat on the floor or a bench with your fists extended to the ceiling and a neutral grip. | 2. Break at the elbows until your fists are by your temples. Then extend your elbows and flex your triceps at the top.

1. Grip the edge of the bench with your hands, Keep your feet together and legs straight. | 2. Lower your body straight down. | 3. Slowly press back up to the starting point. | 4. TIP: Make this harder by raising your feet off the floor and adding weight.

1. Position your index fingers and thumbs so they are touching, forming a diamond shape | 2. Use a standard push up position | 3. Lower your chest towards your hands, keep your elbows close to your body | 4. Stop just before your chest touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

1. Lay on a flat bench while holding a barbell with a shoulder-width grip. | 2. Fully extend your elbows until the barbell is directly over your chest. | 3. Begin to flex your elbows and allow the barbell to nearly touch your forehead. | 4. Extend your elbows back to the starting position and repeat.

1. Lay flat on a bench with two dumbbells pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Break at the elbows until your forearms touch your biceps, then flex at the shoulder joint bringing your upper arms to the sides of your head. | 3. Bring your elbows back up until they are pointed at the ceiling, then extend your elbows.

1. Use the bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Use the bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. Grab the bar with n overhand grip. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.
1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set to hip height. | 2. Hinge forward. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Use the rope attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Lay flat on an incline bench with two dumbbells pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Break at the elbows until your forearms touch your biceps, then flex at the shoulder joint bringing your upper arms to the sides of your head. | 3. Bring your elbows back up until they are pointed at the ceiling, then extend your elbows.

1. Grip the edge of the boxes with your hands, Keep your feet together and legs straight. | 2. Lower your body straight down. | 3. Slowly press back up to the starting point. | 4. TIP: Make this harder by raising your feet off the floor and adding weight.

Exercise Name: Smith Machine Close Grip Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With a narrow grip on the bar, straighten your arms | 2. Lower the bar to your lower-mid chest | 3. Slowly raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Place a plate on your back. Position your index fingers and thumbs so they are touching, forming a diamond shape. | 2. Use a standard push up position | 3. Lower your chest towards your hands, keep your elbows close to your body | 4. Stop just before your chest touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With a narrow grip on the bar, straighten your arms | 2. Lower the bar to your lower-mid chest | 3. Slowly raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.
1. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Grip the edge of the bench with your hands, Keep your feet together and legs straight. | 2. Lower your body straight down. | 3. Slowly press back up to the starting point. | 4. TIP: Make this harder by raising your feet off the floor and adding weight.

1. Position your index fingers and thumbs so they are touching, forming a diamond shape | 2. Use a standard push up position | 3. Lower your chest towards your hands, keep your elbows close to your body | 4. Stop just before your chest touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

1. Lay on a flat bench while holding a barbell with a shoulder-width grip. | 2. Fully extend your elbows until the barbell is directly over your chest. | 3. Begin to flex your elbows and allow the barbell to nearly touch your forehead. | 4. Extend your elbows back to the starting position and repeat.

1. Lay flat on a bench with two dumbbells pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Break at the elbows until your forearms touch your biceps, then flex at the shoulder joint bringing your upper arms to the sides of your head. | 3. Bring your elbows back up until they are pointed at the ceiling, then extend your elbows.

1. Use the bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Use the bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. Grab the bar with n overhand grip. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.
1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set to hip height. | 2. Hinge forward. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Use the rope attachment. The cable should be set all the way at the top of the machine. | 2. Make sure to keep your upper arm glued at your side. Extend your elbows until you feel your triceps contract.

1. Lay flat on an incline bench with two dumbbells pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Break at the elbows until your forearms touch your biceps, then flex at the shoulder joint bringing your upper arms to the sides of your head. | 3. Bring your elbows back up until they are pointed at the ceiling, then extend your elbows.

1. Grip the edge of the boxes with your hands, Keep your feet together and legs straight. | 2. Lower your body straight down. | 3. Slowly press back up to the starting point. | 4. TIP: Make this harder by raising your feet off the floor and adding weight.

Exercise Name: Smith Machine Close Grip Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With a narrow grip on the bar, straighten your arms | 2. Lower the bar to your lower-mid chest | 3. Slowly raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Place a plate on your back. Position your index fingers and thumbs so they are touching, forming a diamond shape. | 2. Use a standard push up position | 3. Lower your chest towards your hands, keep your elbows close to your body | 4. Stop just before your chest touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

1. Sit on a bench with dumbbells in both hands, palms facing your body, back straight. | 2. Elevate your shoulders and hold the contracted position at the apex of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your shoulders back to starting position.

1. Place the bar on a lower rung so that when gripped your arms are fully extended and your back is straight. | 2. Grip at shoulder width, raise the bar with your shoulders and pause at the contracted position. | 3. Slowly lower the bar back to starting position.

1. Standing up straight with feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Holding the kettlebell in both hands in front of your pelvis, engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. | 3. Release the shrug and repeat

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Holding the kettlebell in both hands engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. Release the shrug.
1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Nod your head forward, bringing your chin to your chest. | 3. You will feel the stretch across your neck.

1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Keeping your chest facing forward, turn your head 90 degrees to the left. Then return to centre point. | 3. Repeat, turning your head in the other direction.

1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Place your left hand on your head and gently pull your head down towards your left shoulder. Then return to centre point. | 3. Repeat, using your right hand pulling towards your right shoulder.

1. Use a bench or an object like a chair to elevate your feet. | 2. Slowly lower your body (scapula) while keeping your elbows locked (this is key) | 3. Slowly raise your body back to the start position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the Barbell with both hands in front just past shoulder width. | 2. Bend forward at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. | 4. Release the shrug.

1. Use a handle attachment on both sides of crossover. With cable attachment set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Grab both handles and make sure you are centered in the machine. Let your arms hang freely. | 3. Pull your shoulder blades up and in towards your ears. Let your shoulder blades depress back to the starting position.
1. Place the band under your feet. Stand upright. | 2. Elevate your shoulder blades and then depress back to the starting position.
1. Stand tall with two dumbbells. Pull your shoulder blades up. Give a one second squeeze at the top.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart, with a barbell in front of you. | 2. Bend down and grab the barbell with an overhand grip, your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Keep your back straight and your shoulders down as you grip the bar. | 3. Stand up straight, lifting the barbell off the ground and pulling it toward your hips. Keep your elbows close to your body and your shoulders down as you do this. | 4. Once the barbell is at your hips, raise your shoulders as high as you can, holding the position for a moment.
1. Lay sideways on a bench letting your arm hang freely. | 2. Pull your shoulder blade and joint toward the ceiling.

1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a single weight plate overhead with both hands, keeping your arms extended straight above your head. | 2. Begin walking forward, taking slow and steady steps while maintaining a straight line. Your focus should be on maintaining balance and control of the weight plate overhead. | 3. As you walk, continue to keep your arms extended and the weight plate overhead. Try to maintain good posture and avoid leaning forward or backward, as this could result in losing control of the weight plate. | 4. Continue walking for a set distance or for a certain amount of time, keeping your focus on proper form and technique. When finished, return to the starting position and repeat as desired.
1. Stand tall with a weight plate overhead. | 2. Elevated and depress your scapula. | 3. Avoid leaning forward or backwards to keep pressure off of your lumbar spine.

1. Leaning across the back section of the bench, with feet firmly on the floor and with arms hanging to the sides. | 2. Holding the kettlebell in both hands engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. Release the shrug.
1. Use a bench or an object to elevate your feet. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up toward the ceiling until the attachment is just below your chin then extend until your elbows are fully extended.

1. Use a bar attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Stand up with the attachment in hand, walk a couple of steps back make sure you are standing upright and not leaning backwards. | 3. Retract your shoulder blades and then protract to return to the starting position.
1. Anchor the band at shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades straight back in schools. Then protract to the starting position.

1. Loop the band under one of your feet. The other end of the bed should be in your hand between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. Press the band straight up towards the ceiling. Until your elbow is fully extended.
1. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the bar to chin level or slightly higher.

1. Begin by sitting on the ground with your legs extended and a barbell in your hands, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, lift the barbell up from your chest and press it straight up above your head. | 3. Lower the barbell back down to your chest.
1. Lay on an incline bench with your arms hanging freely. | 2. Pull your shoulder blades back toward the ceiling.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding dumbbells with both hands in front just past shoulder width. | 2. Bend forward at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together.

1. Hold the TRX straps and lean away from the anchor point until the straps are taut. | 2. Keep both elbows mostly extended and raise both arms out and upwards. | 3. You should make a Y shape with your arms during the back portion of the exercise.

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and your arms at your sides. | 2. Cross your right arm over your left arm, bringing your palms together in front of your chest. | 3. Lower your arms down so that your palms face down towards the ground, and your right elbow is resting on top of your left elbow. | 4. Hold for a few breaths, then switch sides.

1. Sit cross-legged on the floor and bring your arms out to the sides at shoulder height. | 2. Cross your right arm over your left, bending both elbows so that your forearms are parallel to the floor. | 3. Lift your elbows towards the ceiling and bring your hands together, then drop your chin towards your chest. | 4. Hold for a few breaths, then release your arms and repeat on the other side.

1. Begin by sitting cross-legged on the floor. | 2. Slowly drop your chin towards your chest, feeling a stretch in the back of your neck. | 3. Inhale and lift your head up, then exhale and drop your right ear towards your right shoulder. | 4. Hold for a few breaths, then switch sides and repeat the stretch.

1. Sit cross-legged on the floor and interlace your fingers behind your head. | 2. Drop your chin to your chest and roll your head to the right, bringing your right ear towards your right shoulder. | 3. Slowly roll your head back to center, then over to the left so that your left ear is close to your left shoulder. | 4. Repeat the movement from side to side, keeping your shoulders relaxed and breathing deeply.

Exercise Name: Thread The Needle Hip Over Knees
Instructions: 1. Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position. | 2. Slide your right knee up between your hands and place your right foot close to your left wrist. | 3. Take your left leg back and lower it down to the ground, keeping your toes tucked. | 4. Twist your torso to the right and reach your right arm underneath your left arm, threading the needle. Hold for a few breaths, then switch sides.
1. Place toes on Bosu, hands on the floor. | 2. Pike hips up, shrug shoulders, engage core.
1. Stand tall and hold the two handle attachments. | 2. Pull your shoulder blades straight up toward the ceiling.
1. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the bar to chin level or slightly higher. | 3. lower the bar and repeat.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold one kettlebell in each hand at your sides. | 2. Lift your shoulders upward while keeping arms straight. | 3. Lower shoulders back down, repeat for desired reps.

1. Start with a kettlebell between your legs, hinge at hips, swing it upward. | 2. Lift kettlebell to chest level, elbows high, engaging shoulders. | 3. Lower kettlebell back down, maintaining control. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Use a handle attachment. With the cable attachment set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Grab one handle and make sure you are centered in the machine. Let your arm hang freely. | 3. Pull your shoulder blade up and in towards your ears. Let your shoulder blade depress back to the starting position.

1. Use a rope attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up toward the ceiling until the attachment is just below your chin then extend until your elbows are fully extended.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Start in a plank position. Push your hips up toward the ceiling. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat

1. Start in a plank position and raise your hips toward the ceiling. | 2. Slowly lower your body (scapula) while keeping your elbows locked (this is key) | 3. Slowly raise your body back to the start position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand with an overhand grip. | 2. Keep your back straight and chest lifted, engage your core to maintain balance. | 3. Begin the movement by lifting the dumbbell straight up towards your chin, keeping your elbow close to your body and the weight in line with your shoulder. | 4. Continue to lift the weight until it reaches the chin or neck level, keeping the elbow high and close to the body. | 5. Lower the weight back down to the starting position with control.

Exercise Name: Seated Upper Trap And Suprispinatus Stretch
Instructions: 1. Sit on the back of your palm. | 2. Straighten the back and pull the shoulders back. | 3. Lean your head to the opposite side.

1. Place a tube roller or half tube on the ground parallel to your body. | 2. Lie on the tube making sure your whole back and neck are supported. | 3. Knees bent and on the ground, lower back flat on the tube and chin tucked in. | 4. Bring your arms by you hips and pull shoulders back. | 5. This is your starting position. Raise arms and drop them back towards the ground over your head

1. Place a foam roller on the floor perpendicular to your body. | 2. Sit and lie back onto it aiming for your mid back to be in contact with the roller. | 3. Gently tilt your hips backward, squeeze glutes and engage core to protect the lower back. | 4. Support head on palms, elbows rotated in. Slightly lift hips off the ground.

1. Bring yourself on all 4's. Push the ground away from you, rounding back and shoulders as much as possible. | 2. To enhance the spine flexion suck the belly button in and tuck the tailbone (coccyx) under. Hold this position for a brief moment | 3. Now do the exact opposite, try to bend the spine backwards. Go back and forth on these positions

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.
1. Have a seat on the machine, and grab each handle. | 2. Pull your shoulder blades straight up toward the ceiling.
1. Grab both handles and stand upright. Make sure you keep a flat back while lifting to the starting position. | 2. Pull your shoulder blades straight up toward the ceiling.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width, and keep your back straight. | 2. Drive through your legs, extending your hips, knees, and ankles explosively while pulling the barbell upward. | 3. As the bar rises, pull it close to your body, leading with your elbows until it reaches chest level.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, gripping the barbell with a wide (snatch-width) grip. Keep your back straight, chest up, and bar close to your body. | 2. Drive through your legs, extending your hips, knees, and ankles while pulling the barbell up explosively. | 3. Shrug your shoulders forcefully and pull the bar as high as possible, keeping elbows above the bar. | 4. Lower the bar back to the starting position in a controlled manner and reset for the next rep.

1. Sit on a bench with dumbbells in both hands, palms facing your body, back straight. | 2. Elevate your shoulders and hold the contracted position at the apex of the motion. | 3. Slowly lower your shoulders back to starting position.
1. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the bar to chin level or slightly higher.

1. Place the bar on a lower rung so that when gripped your arms are fully extended and your back is straight. | 2. Grip at shoulder width, raise the bar with your shoulders and pause at the contracted position. | 3. Slowly lower the bar back to starting position.
1. Stand tall with two dumbbells. Pull your shoulder blades up. Give a one second squeeze at the top.

1. Use a handle attachment on both sides of crossover. With cable attachment set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Grab both handles and make sure you are centered in the machine. Let your arms hang freely. | 3. Pull your shoulder blades up and in towards your ears. Let your shoulder blades depress back to the starting position.
1. Place toes on Bosu, hands on the floor. | 2. Pike hips up, shrug shoulders, engage core.
1. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the bar to chin level or slightly higher. | 3. lower the bar and repeat.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold one kettlebell in each hand at your sides. | 2. Lift your shoulders upward while keeping arms straight. | 3. Lower shoulders back down, repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold one kettlebell in each hand at your sides, and lean forward. | 2. Lift your shoulders backward while keeping arms straight. | 3. Lower shoulders back down, repeat for desired reps.

1. Use a handle attachment. With the cable attachment set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Grab one handle and make sure you are centered in the machine. Let your arm hang freely. | 3. Pull your shoulder blade up and in towards your ears. Let your shoulder blade depress back to the starting position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Start in a plank position and raise your hips toward the ceiling. | 2. Slowly lower your body (scapula) while keeping your elbows locked (this is key) | 3. Slowly raise your body back to the start position.

1. Use a bench or an object like a chair to elevate your feet. | 2. Slowly lower your body (scapula) while keeping your elbows locked (this is key) | 3. Slowly raise your body back to the start position.

1. From the standing or seated position straighten your back. | 2. Pull the shoulders back but keep them relaxed. | 3. Move shoulders towards from your ears and return to the starting, relaxed position.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.

1. Grip the bar with the palms facing forward, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than shoulder width. | 2. As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar, bring your torso back around 30 degrees while sticking your chest out. | 3. Pull the bar down to about chin level or a little lower in a smooth movement whilst squeezing the shoulder blades together. | 4. After a second of squeezing, slowly raise the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended.

1. Use the Straight Bar attachment. Hold with an underhand grip. | 2. Hold the attachment as you sit on the machine and put your legs under the leg pads. | 3. Pull the bar to your clavicle, then raise back up until your arm are extended.

1. Use the Straight Bar attachment. | 2. Hold the attachment as you sit on the machine and put your legs under the leg pads. | 3. Pull the bar to your clavicle, then raise back up until your arm are extended.

1. Use the V Bar attachment. | 2. Hold the attachment as you sit on the machine and put your legs under the leg pads. | 3. Pull the bar to your clavicle, then raise back up until your arm are extended.

1. While seated on a bench, place your palms on the bench by your sides | 2. Palm placement should allow room for the fingers to grip the edge of the bench | 3. Try to lift your bodyweight off the bench by pushing the palms into the bench | 4. Lockout your elbows and repeat or hold isometrically

1. While seated on a bench, place your palms on the bench by your sides | 2. Palm placement should allow room for the fingers to grip the edge of the bench | 3. Try to lift your bodyweight off the bench by pushing the palms into the bench | 4. Lockout your elbows and hold isometrically
1. From the standing or seated position straighten your back. | 2. Pull the shoulders back but keep them relaxed. | 3. Move shoulders away from your ears and return to the starting, relaxed position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Maintain the natural arch in your back, squeezing your shoulder blades and raising your chest. | 2. Grip the bar across your shoulders and support it on your upper back. Unwrack the bar by straightening your legs, and take a step back. | 3. Bend your knees as you lower the weight without altering the form of your back until your hips are below your knees. | 4. Raise the bar back to starting position, lift with your legs and exhale at the top.

1. Place your legs on the platform with your feet at shoulder width. | 2. Release the weight and extend your legs fully, without locking your knees. | 3. Lower the weight until your legs are at a 90 angle (but DO NOT allow your butt and lower back to rise off of the pad. This will put your lower back in a rounded position, which is very dangerous.) | 4. Raise the weight back to starting position.

1. Sit on the machine with your back against the cushion and adjust the machine you are using so that your knees are at a 90 degree angle at the starting position. | 2. Raise the weight by extending your knees outward, then lower your leg to the starting position. Both movements should be done in a slow, controlled motion.

1. Hold the weight tucked into your upper chest area, keeping your elbows in. Your feet should be slightly wider than shoulder width. | 2. Sink down into the squat, keeping your elbows inside the track of your knees. | 3. Push through your heels while keeping your chest up and return to starting position.

1. Stand with your back to a bench (or raised surface) and place one of your feet on the bench. | 2. Squat down until your front leg is about parallel to the floor. | 3. Go back to the starting position. After completing the desired amount of reps, switch legs and repeat.

1. Standing up straight, using a bench as a step, raise one foot onto the bench and hold the kettlebell in the same arm as the straight leg. | 2. Stand and bring both feet onto the bench. Slowly lower your leg back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat.

1. Hold the weight tucked into your upper chest area, keeping your elbows in. Your feet should be slightly wider than your shoulders. | 2. Sink down into the squat, keeping your elbows inside the track of your knees. | 3. Push through your heels while keeping your chest up and return to the starting position.

1. Hold the weight tucked into your upper chest area, keeping your elbows in. Your feet should be slightly wider than your shoulders and the heels slightly raised on a surface. | 2. Sink down into the squat, keeping your elbows inside the track of your knees. | 3. Push through your heels while keeping your chest up and return to the starting position.

1. Stand straight with your feet slightly apart and hold a kettlebell in one hand. | 2. Bring the same leg as the arm holding the kettlebell behind you, squat down until your back knee touches the ground, keeping your back straight. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand straight with your feet slightly apart and hold a kettlebell in one hand. | 2. Bring the same leg as the arm holding the kettlebell in front of you, squat down until your thigh is parallel to the ground, keeping your back straight. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand straight with your feet shoulder width apart. Keep your back straight and hold the kettlebell in front of your pelvis. | 2. Take a large step to one side, holding the kettlebell low and lunge into the bent leg. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat

1. Lay flat on your belly. Extend one arm out in front of you, placing your palm on the floor. With your other arm, grab the top of your foot. | 2. Keeping your upper leg flat on the floor, pull your foot towards your buttocks to engage the stretch. | 3. Pause for a few seconds, and then repeat the stretch with your other leg.

1. Lay flat on your belly, with both hands reach back and grab the tops of your feet. | 2. Keeping your upper legs flat on the ground, pull both of your feet towards your buttocks. | 3. Pause at the apex of the stretch, then return to starting position.

1. Place one foot flat on the ground in front of you at a 90 degree angle. With your other leg, balance upon your knee, placing the tip of your foot against the wall behind you for balance. | 2. Place your hands on your knee in front of you, and lean forward so that your knee extends over your foot. | 3. Pause at the apex of the stretch, and slowly return to starting position. Repeat with your other leg.

1. Stand perpendicular to a wall, using one arm against the wall for balance. With your other arm, grab the top of your foot. | 2. Pull your leg upwards and back to engage your quads, pausing at the apex of the stretch for a few seconds. | 3. Return to starting position and repeat with your other leg.
1. Take a slow, lateral step to the right. | 2. Extend the left knee, and drive your weight into your right side. | 3. Flex your knee and lower your body. | 4. Push back to the starting position.

1. Step forward with one leg. | 2. Lower your body until your rear knee nearly touches the ground. | 3. Ensure you remain upright, and your front knee stay above the front foot. | 4. Push off the floor with your front foot until you return to the starting position. Switch legs.
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Start by doing a regular squat, then engage your core and jump up explosively. | 3. When you land, lower your body back into the squat position.
1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. flex your knees and hips and sit back into the squat while lowering your body | 3. Continue down to full depth | 4. Return to starting position.
1. Place the barbell on your back | 2. Step your foot back and around while simultaneously bringing the weight down. | 3. Return to start and repeat on other leg.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Get your elbows directly underneath the bar, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.

1. You can use a straight or EZ bar on this exercise. Cable should be set all to the bottom. | 2. Grab the attachment and walk back a few steps. Take a split stance. One leg in front and one behind. | 3. Break at the knees and hips to initiate the split squat. Make sure your back knee touches the floor. | 4. Squat back up into a standing position.
1. Stand upright facing away from the cable crossover with the cable set to the height of your hips. Use an ankle/wrist attachment. | 2. Extend at the knee against the cable.
1. Anchor a band to a stable point. | 2. Place the loops of the band behind your knees. | 3. Perform a normal squat and extend your knees against the band at the top.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your head by the anchor point of the band, which should be 6 to 12 inches above your head | 2. Place the band around your midfoot and extend at the knees and hip.

1. Stand with a shoulder width grip. Both feet should be on the band with the band loops in each of your hand. | 2. Push your butt back and also break at the knees. | 3. Try to hit parallel depth (bottom of your leg should be parallel with the ground). If you can't tell your squat depth, then try squatting in front of a mirror and watch your form.

1. Holding the dumbbell in a goblet squat place your foot on a bench or box. | 2. Break at the hips and knees. Try to go to the point where your hamstring is parallel with the ground. Or until your back knee taps the floor. | 3. Make sure to keep your back flat and your elbows directly under your fists.

1. Find a box or bench that is roughly knee height or a few inches lower. (The lower the box is the lower the mobility requirement). | 2. You can either place your toes or the top of your foot on the box. Point your front foot forward or slightly turned outwards and break at the knees and hips simultaneously. | 3. Aim to get your front leg to hit parallel depth (hamstring parallel with the ground) or lower. | 4. The further forward your front foot is, the longer the Range of Motion is at your hips. The further back your front foot is, the longer the ROM at your knees.

1. Measure your hands by the markings on the bar to make sure you're even. Then throw your elbows underneath the bar. | 2. The bar should be set so high on your shoulders it digs into your neck a bit. Make sure to push your elbows up to the ceiling for the entire rep. To make sure you don't get too pitched forward. | 3. Use the squat stance you would use for a back or goblet squat. Push your hips back to initiate the squat. Break at the knees until you hit parallel depth. | 4. Squat back up to a standing position.

1. Measure your shoulders against the bar to make sure you're even. Throw your shoulders under the bar. The bar should be digging into your neck slightly. | 2. Make sure to push your elbows up to the ceiling for the entire rep. To make sure you don't get too pitched forward. | 3. Use the squat stance you would use for a back or goblet squat. Push your hips back to initiate the squat. Break at the knees until you hit parallel depth. | 4. Squat back up to a standing position.

1. Place the bar on top of your traps. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees. Push your elbows forward to keep yourself from getting pitched too far forward. | 3. Aim to get your hamstrings to parallel with the floor. | 4. Push your heels into the floor and squat back to a standing position.

1. Pull your shoulder blades back really hard and place the bar on your posterior delts. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees to initiate the squat. | 3. Aim to get your hamstrings to parallel with the ground. Push your heels into the floor and squat back up to a standing position.

1. Find a box or bench that is roughly knee height or a few inches lower. (The lower the box is the lower the mobility requirement). | 2. You can either place your toes or the top of your foot on the box. Point your front foot forward or slightly turned outwards and break at the knees and hips simultaneously. | 3. Aim to get your front leg to hit parallel depth (hamstring parallel with the ground) or lower. | 4. The further forward your front foot is, the longer the Range of Motion is at your hips. The further back your front foot is, the longer the ROM at your knees.

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and place a barbell on the floor in front of you. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, positioning your hands just outside of your hips. | 3. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, lift the barbell off the floor by extending your hips and knees. | 4. As you lift the barbell, pull your shoulders back and squeeze your glutes to fully extend your hips at the top of the movement.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell at your shoulders with an overhand grip. | 2. Step forward with your right foot and bend both knees to lower your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. | 3. Push off your right foot to return to the starting position.

1. Stand in front of a step or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell at your shoulders with an overhand grip. | 2. Step up onto the bench with your right foot, pushing off your foot to raise your body up onto the bench. | 3. Bring your left foot up onto the bench and stand up straight, keeping the barbell at your shoulders. | 4. Step back down with your left foot, followed by your right foot, to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your heels on a plate or low step. | 2. Bend your knees and lower your body into a squat position. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and feet on a plate. Place the bar in a front rack position. | 2. Bend your knees and lower your body into a squat position, keeping your heels raised off the ground. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell at your shoulders with an overhand grip. | 2. Step out to the side with your right foot and bend your right knee to lower your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. | 3. Push off your right foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Repeat on the opposite side by stepping out with your left foot.

1. Stand in front of a box or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell resting on your upper back. | 2. Lower your body into a squat position, sitting back onto the box and pausing for a moment before standing back up. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the standing position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell resting on your upper back. | 2. Lower your body into a squat position, pausing for a moment at the bottom of the movement before standing back up. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the standing position.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart, with your toes pointed slightly outward. | 2. Place a barbell on the floor behind you, with the weight plates on either side. | 3. Bend down and grab the barbell with an overhand grip, your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Keep your back straight and your shoulders down as you grip the bar. | 4. Stand up straight, lifting the barbell off the ground and pulling it toward your hips. Keep your elbows close to your body and your shoulders down as you do this.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart, with a barbell on your shoulders. Your feet should be slightly pointed outward, and your shoulders should be down and relaxed. | 2. Step backward with one foot, lowering your body until your front thigh is parallel to the ground and your back knee is hovering just above the ground. | 3. Push off your back foot, returning to the starting position.

1. Start with a box or bench behind you and one of your feet on the box/bench. | 2. The balls of your feet should be planted on the box/bench. | 3. Drive through the ball of your foot extending your knees until you're upright and standing on the box.

1. Start by standing with your feet about hip-width apart, with a barbell on your shoulders. Your feet should be slightly pointed outward, and your shoulders should be down and relaxed. | 2. Place a step or box beside you, and step up onto it with one foot. Your other foot should remain on the ground. | 3. Push off your grounded foot, raising your body up onto the step. | 4. Step back down with the same foot, returning to the starting position.

1. Take a large step forward with one leg, and lower your body until your back knee nearly touches the ground. Your front knee should be bent at a 90-degree angle, and your back leg should be straight. | 2. Push through the heel of your front foot to raise your body back to the starting position.

1. Begin by standing in front of a sturdy box or bench that is about knee-height, holding a barbell across your upper back and shoulders, using an overhand grip. | 2. Place your right foot on the box and push through the heel to lift your body up and onto the box, keeping your left foot off the ground. | 3. Step back down with your right foot, lowering your left foot to the ground.

1. Begin by standing in front of a sturdy box or bench that is about knee-height, holding a barbell across your upper back and shoulders, using an overhand grip. | 2. Place your right foot on the box and push through the heel to lift your body up and onto the box. | 3. Step back down with your right foot.

1. Begin by standing in front of a sturdy box or bench that is about knee-height, holding a barbell across your upper back and shoulders, using an overhand grip. | 2. Sit back and lower your body down until your glutes tap the top of the box, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and stand up, bringing your body back to the starting position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet about hip-width apart and holding a barbell in the crook of your arms, near your belly. Your palms should be facing towards your body. | 2. Sit back and lower your body down until your thighs are parallel to the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and stand back up to the starting position.

1. Grab a stick of some sort or hold onto something stable (rack, bench). | 2. Grab a box that is knee height or slightly lower. | 3. Hold the stick in your right arm and put your right leg on the box. | 4. Begin your squat by breaking at the knees. Get your knee close to the floor or all the way to the floor. Make sure to keep your chest tall.

1. Step your left foot diagonally behind your right leg, crossing it behind your body. Bend your knees and lower your hips until your left thigh is parallel to the floor and your right knee is hovering just above the ground. | 2. Push through your right foot to straighten your legs and return to the starting position. | 3. Repeat the movement with your other leg.

1. Step forward with one leg and lower your body until your front thigh is parallel to the floor and your back knee almost touches the ground. Keep your chest up and your front foot flat on the floor. | 2. Push through your front foot to straighten your legs and return to the starting position. | 3. Repeat the movement with your other leg.

1. Place your heels on a plate or very low step. | 2. Keep your chest tall and initiate the squat by pushing your hips back and breaking at the knees. | 3. You should notice yourself able to squat lower than normal.

1. Engage your core by drawing your belly button towards your spine. This will help to stabilize your body. | 2. Take a large step to the side with your right foot, planting it firmly on the ground. | 3. As you step, bend your right knee and lower your hips until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. Your left leg should remain straight. | 4. Push through your right heel to return to the starting position. Repeat on the opposite side by stepping out with your left foot.

1. Take a big step backwards with your left leg, lowering your body until your left thigh is parallel to the ground and your right knee is bent at a 90-degree angle. | 2. Push through your right heel to return to standing, bringing your left leg back to starting position. | 3. Repeat the movement on the other side, stepping backwards with your right leg and lowering your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground and your left knee is bent at a 90-degree angle.
1. Take a split stance. Make sure to keep your chest tall. | 2. Bring your rear knee to the floor or close to it. | 3. Drive through your front heel and your rear foot back to the starting position.

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing each other. | 2. Take a big step forward with your right foot, lowering your hips until your right thigh is parallel to the ground and your left knee is hovering just above the floor. | 3. Push through your right heel to straighten your right leg and return to the starting position.

1. Holding the dumbbell in a goblet squat place your foot on a bench or box. | 2. Break at the hips and knees. Try to go to the point where your hamstring is parallel with the ground. Or until your back knee taps the floor. | 3. Make sure to keep your back flat and your elbows directly under your fists.

1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Step your left foot behind and to the right of your right foot, crossing it behind your right leg. | 3. Bend your knees and lower your hips down and back, as if you were about to sit in a chair. | 4. Push through your right heel to straighten your right leg and return to the starting position.

1. Hold a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Step forward with one of your legs while bending at your back leg. Bring your back knee to the floor or close to the floor. | 3. Push through your front leg explosively to get back to your starting position.

1. Engage your core by drawing your belly button towards your spine. This will help to stabilize your body. Hold a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Take a large step to the side with your right foot, planting it firmly on the ground. | 3. As you step, bend your right knee and lower your hips until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. Your left leg should remain straight. | 4. Push through your right heel to return to the starting position. Repeat on the opposite side by stepping out with your left foot.

1. Hold a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Take a big step backwards with your left leg, lowering your body until your left thigh is parallel to the ground and your right knee is bent at a 90-degree angle. | 3. Push through your right heel to return to standing, bringing your left leg back to starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement on the other side, stepping backwards with your right leg and lowering your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground and your left knee is bent at a 90-degree angle.

1. Hold a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Take a large step forward with one leg, and lower your body until your back knee nearly touches the ground. Your front knee should be bent at a 90-degree angle, and your back leg should be straight. | 3. Push through the heel of your front foot to raise your body back to the starting position.

1. Engage your core by drawing your belly button towards your spine. This will help to stabilize your body. Hold a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Take a large step to the side with your right foot and reach toward the floor with your single dumbbell. | 3. As you step, bend your right knee and lower your hips until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. Your left leg should remain straight. | 4. Push through your right heel to return to the starting position. Repeat on the opposite side by stepping out with your left foot.

1. Hold two dumbbells by your side. | 2. Take a big step backwards with your left leg, lowering your body until your left thigh is parallel to the ground and your right knee is bent at a 90-degree angle. | 3. Push through your right heel to return to standing, bringing your left leg back to starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement on the other side, stepping backwards with your right leg and lowering your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground and your left knee is bent at a 90-degree angle.

1. Hold a dumbbell in a goblet position. | 2. Take a large step forward with one leg, and lower your body until your back knee nearly touches the ground. Your front knee should be bent at a 90-degree angle, and your back leg should be straight. | 3. Push through the heel of your front foot to raise your body back to the starting position.

1. Place two dumbbells on your shoulders and make sure you force your elbows upward. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees. | 3. When you reach parallel (hamstrings parallel with the ground) pause for 1-3 seconds. Then push through your heels back to the starting position.
