1. Laying on the floor with your knees bent and feet firmly on the floor, hold the kettlebell at your chest with both hands. | 2. Fully extend your arms, raising the kettlebell until your elbows are locked. | 3. Lower the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.

1. Lie on the floor with your knees bent and feet firmly on the floor, with your arms to the side of your body. | 2. Holding a kettlebell in one hand, keeping your arm fully extended with a slight bend in the elbow and your forearms facing upwards, lift the kettlebell above your chest. | 3. Lower the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.

1. Laying on the floor with your knees bent and feet firmly on the floor, leave one arm resting to the side of the body. | 2. Using the other arm, hold the kettlebell at arms length directly upwards of your shoulder. | 3. Lower your arm until your upper arm to elbow is resting on the floor. | 4. Return to starting position.

1. Starting in a press up position with feet wide and one hand resting on the kettlebell, complete a full press up, lowering your chest towards the ground while keeping your body straight and returning to the starting position. | 2. Swap hands on the kettlebell, placing the hand originally on the kettlebell underneath your shoulder, complete another press up. | 3. Repeat.

1. Raise your arms to shoulder height, fully extended in front of you. | 2. Slowly bring your arms behind your back still at shoulder height. | 3. Pause for a few seconds and then return to starting position.

1. Place your arms behind your back and clasp your hands together. | 2. Slowly extend your elbows until they are locked then lift them away from you. | 3. Pause in this position for a few seconds and then return them to starting position.

1. Lay on your side with one hand just in front of you. | 2. With a slight bend in your arm, rotate your arm around your body as slowly as possible. | 3. Return to the starting position and then repeat on the other side.

1. Using a raised wall, place your arm at a 90 degree angle against it. | 2. With a staggered stance, lean into the wall extending your chest. | 3. Pause for a few seconds and then return to starting position and repeat on opposite side.

1. Place your hands firmly on the ground, directly under shoulders. | 2. Flatten your back so your entire body is straight and slowly lower your body | 3. Draw shoulder blades back and down, keeping elbows tucked close to your body | 4. Exhale as you push back to the starting position.

1. Stand facing bench or sturdy elevated platform. | 2. Place hands on edge of bench or platform, slightly wider than shoulder width. | 3. Slowly lower your body until your chest almost touches the bench. | 4. Push body up until arms are extended.

1. Use a bench to elevate your feet. | 2. Put your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. | 3. Slowly lower your body until your chest almost touches the ground | 4. Raise your body until you almost lock your elbows.

1. Use a handle attachment set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Walk a few steps forward. Then press the weight forward. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cables should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Walk a few steps forward. Then press the weight forward. | 4. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

1. Attach the band to an anchor point that is about shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and bring your arm across your body until you feel a contraction in your pecs.

1. Attach the band to an anchor point that is about shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and elbow across your body until your arm is fully extended.

1. Loop the band around your mid-back. The ends of the bands should be around your hands between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. This exercise can be done from the knees or the toes depending on experience level. | 3. Begin by breaking at the elbows until your upper arm is by your side. Then extend at the elbows back into the top position.
1. Un-rack the bar and break at the elbows and shoulders. | 2. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.

1. Start in a bench press position with your feet planted on the bench and knees bent. | 2. Grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, positioning your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. | 3. Lift the barbell off the rack and lower it to your chest, keeping your elbows close to your sides. | 4. Push the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

1. Start in a bench press position with your legs elevated. Try to keep your knees with a slight bend in them. | 2. Unrack the bar then initiate the rep. | 3. Bring the bar to your torso and tap your ribcage before pressing back to the ceiling.

1. Start on the bench with your shoulder blades pulled back. | 2. As you initiate the first rep, tuck your elbows slightly until the bar is a few inches off your chest. | 3. Pause just off your chest for 1-3 seconds. Then press explosively.

1. Start by lying flat on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Hold the dumbbells at chest level with your palms facing forward. | 3. Engage your core and press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended.

1. Lay on a bench with two dumbbells extended in front of you. | 2. You should have a slight bend in your elbows and maintain that bend. Your shoulder joint should do all the movement. | 3. Bring the dumbbells out to your side. Stop the dumbbells before going behind your body. | 4. Bring the dumbbells back together at the top.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Decline Alternating Single Arm Press
Instructions: 1. Lay on a decline bench with both arms extended in front of you. | 2. Break at one of your arms first bringing that arm to your side while keeping the other arm extended. | 3. Press the dumbbell back to the ceiling. Fully extend that arm before initiating on the other side.

1. Lay on a decline bench with both arms extended in front of you. | 2. Break at the elbows and bring your upper arms to your side. | 3. Once your upper arms have reached your side, press the dumbbells back to the ceiling.

1. Lay flat on a decline bench press with the dumbbells pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Maintain a slight bend in your elbows. Bring the dumbbells out to the side, stopping the dumbbells before they pass your torso. | 3. Bring the dumbbells together to finish the rep.

1. Lie on the decline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing forward. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows flared out. As you lower the dumbbells, exhale deeply. | 3. Once your elbows reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position

1. Lie on the decline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Decline Single Arm Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Start by laying on a decline bench with two dumbbells. | 2. Position the dumbbell above your chest with your elbow bent and shoulder level. | 3. Slowly lower the dumbbell towards your chest, keeping your elbow close to your body and your core engaged while the other dumbbell remains pointed toward the ceiling. | 4. Once the dumbbell reaches your side, pause for a moment and then press the weight back up to the starting position. | 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching to your other arm.

1. Lay flat on a decline bench with two dumbbells pressed to one another. | 2. Break at the elbows and keep your elbows tucked as you bring the dumbbells to your chest. | 3. Continue to press the dumbbells into one another throughout the rep. | 4. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, press back toward the ceiling.

1. Lie on the flat bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing forward. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows flared out. As you lower the dumbbells, exhale deeply. | 3. Once your elbows reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position

1. Lie on the incline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing forward. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows flared out. As you lower the dumbbells, exhale deeply. | 3. Once your elbows reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position

1. Lay flat on the incline bench with your feet on the ground. Raise the dumbbells until you have straight arms. | 2. Lower the dumbbells to your mid chest | 3. Raise the dumbbells until you've locked your elbows.

1. Lay on an incline bench with two dumbbells extended in front of you. | 2. You should have a slight bend in your elbows and maintain that bend. Your shoulder joint should do all the movement. | 3. Bring the dumbbells out to your side. Stop the dumbbells before going behind your body. | 4. Bring the dumbbells back together at the top.

1. Lay on a bench with two dumbbells extended in front of you in an overhand grip. | 2. You should have a slight bend in your elbows and maintain that bend. Your shoulder joint should do all the movement. | 3. Bring the dumbbells out to your side. Stop the dumbbells before going behind your body. | 4. Bring the dumbbells back together at the top.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Internally Rotated Incline Chest Fly
Instructions: 1. Lay on an incline bench with two dumbbells extended in front of you. | 2. You should have a slight bend in your elbows and maintain that bend. Your shoulder joint should do all the movement. You should have an overhand grip. | 3. Bring the dumbbells out to your side. Stop the dumbbells before going behind your body. | 4. Bring the dumbbells back together at the top.

1. Lie on a flat bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Lie on an incline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Lay flat on a bench with two dumbbells pressed to one another. | 2. Break at the elbows and keep your elbows tucked as you bring the dumbbells to your chest. | 3. Continue to press the dumbbells into one another throughout the rep. | 4. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, press back toward the ceiling.

1. Start by laying on a bench with two dumbbells. | 2. Position the dumbbell above your chest with your elbow bent and shoulder level. | 3. Slowly lower the dumbbell towards your chest, keeping your elbow close to your body and your core engaged while the other dumbbell remains pointed toward the ceiling. | 4. Once the dumbbell reaches your side, pause for a moment and then press the weight back up to the starting position. | 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching to your other arm.

1. Start standing with your feet hip-width apart. Lower your body into a squat position, placing your hands on the ground in front of you. | 2. Quickly jump your feet back into a plank position, keeping your body in a straight line from your head to your toes. | 3. Perform a push-up, keeping your core tight and your elbows close to your body. | 4. Jump your feet back towards your hands, and then jump up into the air, reaching your arms overhead. | 5. Land softly and immediately lower your body back into the squat position to repeat the movement.

1. Secure two resistance bands to a sturdy anchor point (e.g. a door anchor, a post, etc.) at chest height. | 2. Stand facing away from the anchor point with feet shoulder-width apart and hold each end of the band in each hand. | 3. Start with arms fully extended and parallel to the floor. | 4. Keeping arms straight, slowly bring your arms together in front of your chest.

1. Stand in the middle of the two bands with feet shoulder-width apart. Step forward with one foot to create tension in the bands. | 2. Hold one band in each hand, palms facing forward. Start the exercise with your arms extended in front of you, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. | 3. Lower your arms to the sides of your chest, maintaining control of the band. | 4. Push your arms back up to the starting position, keeping your core engaged and maintaining control of the band.

1. Start with both feet hip-width apart and step on the middle of the band with both feet. Hold the handles of the band in each hand and position the band above your chest, with your palms facing down. | 2. Keeping your elbows slightly bent, slowly raise your arms out to the sides until they are parallel with the floor. Make sure to internally rotate your shoulder joints by bringing your shoulder blades together and rotating your forearms inward towards your torso. | 3. Hold the position for a few seconds and then slowly lower your arms back to the starting position, keeping the internal rotation of your shoulder joints throughout the movement.

1. Start in a pushup position with both hands on a plate. This will extend your range of motion. | 2. Break at the elbows and shoulders until your upper arm travels behind the body slightly. | 3. Then press back into the original position.

Exercise Name: Plate Glute Bridge to Chest Press
Instructions: 1. Lay flat on the ground with a plate on your chest. | 2. Push your hips up toward the ceiling and maintain that extended position. | 3. With your hips up, press the plate toward the ceiling.

1. Start by placing two dumbbells on the floor, about shoulder-width apart. | 2. Position yourself in a plank position with your hands on top of the dumbbells, keeping your arms straight. | 3. Keep your feet together, with your toes resting on the floor. | 4. Engage your core and lower your body towards the floor by bending your arms, until your chest nearly touches the dumbbells. | 5. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms and engaging your chest, triceps and shoulders.

1. Start in a high plank position with a pair of dumbbells positioned under your shoulders. Your hands should grip the dumbbells, palms facing each other. | 2. Keep your core engaged and your back straight as you row one dumbbell up towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body. | 3. Lower the dumbbell back down to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

1. Start by adjusting the TRX straps to chest height. Stand facing the TRX with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grasp the TRX handles with both hands, keeping your arms extended and your shoulders away from your ears. | 3. Lean forward, keeping your arms extended and your core engaged. Your body should form a slight diagonal line from your ankles to your head. | 4. Slowly bring your arms towards each other, in front of your chest, while keeping your core engaged and your body in a stable position.

1. Start by setting up the TRX straps to a secure anchor point and adjust the straps so that they hang about waist height when you stand under them. | 2. Stand facing the TRX straps, grab the handles with both hands, and step forward so that your body is in a plank position with your hands directly beneath your shoulders. | 3. Lower your body down by bending your elbows until your chest nearly touches the handles. Keep your core tight and your body in a straight line. | 4. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms as you do so. Make sure to engage your chest, triceps, and core throughout the movement.

1. Start in a bench press position with two dumbbells. | 2. Break at one of your elbows first while keeping the other elbow extended. | 3. Your working arm should reach your side before pressing back to the ceiling. | 4. Then alternate to the other arm.

1. Lie on your stomach with your arms at your sides. | 2. Bend your knees and bring your heels towards your buttocks. | 3. Reach back with your hands and grab your ankles. | 4. Inhale and lift your chest off the ground, pulling your legs up and back with your hands. | 5. Keep your gaze forward and hold the pose for a few breaths before releasing back to the ground.

1. Stand facing a wall with your arms extended and your palms pressing into the wall at shoulder height. | 2. Slowly begin to walk your feet away from the wall, keeping your arms straight and your hands pressing into the wall. | 3. Walk until your arms are fully extended and your body is at a 45-degree angle to the ground. | 4. Repeat From High to Low Angles starting above the shoulder, and ending below the chest.

1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and your arms at your sides. | 2. Press your feet into the ground and engage your leg muscles. | 3. Lift your chest and roll your shoulders back and down. | 4. Take a deep breath in, and as you exhale, release any tension in your body and relax your muscles.

1. Start in mountain pose, standing with your feet hip-width apart and arms at your sides. | 2. Shift your weight onto your left foot and bend your right knee, bringing the sole of your right foot to the inside of your left thigh. | 3. Bring your hands together in front of your heart, or raise them overhead. | 4. Hold the pose for a few breaths, then release and repeat on the other side.

1. Start in mountain pose, standing with your feet hip-width apart and arms at your sides. | 2. Step your left foot back about 3-4 feet and turn it slightly inward, while keeping your right foot facing forward. | 3. Inhale and raise your arms overhead, then exhale and bend your right knee, bringing it directly over your ankle. | 4. Hold the pose for a few breaths, then inhale and return to mountain pose. Repeat on the other side.

1. Start in mountain pose, standing with your feet hip-width apart and arms at your sides. | 2. Step your left foot back about 3-4 feet and turn it slightly inward, while keeping your right foot facing forward. | 3. Inhale and raise your arms to shoulder height, parallel to the ground, with your palms facing down. | 4. Exhale and bend your right knee, bringing it directly over your ankle while keeping your left leg straight. | 5. Look over your right hand and hold the pose for a few breaths, then inhale and return to mountain pose. Repeat on the other side.

1. Sit on the floor with your legs stretched out in front of you. | 2. Place a yoga block behind you, horizontally, at the base of your spine. | 3. Slowly recline over the block, supporting yourself with your forearms, until your back is resting on the block. | 4. Relax your arms at your sides, palms facing up, and breathe deeply.

Exercise Name: Landmine Alternating Lunge To Chest Press
Instructions: 1. Stand facing the landmine with feet hip-width apart and holding the end of the landmine barbell with both hands, keeping elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Step backward with the right foot, lunge down, and press the landmine away from your chest. | 3. Push through the left heel to return to the starting position while pulling the landmine back to your chest. | 4. Repeat on the opposite side, alternating for the desired number of reps.

1. Starting lying on your back perpendicularly to the barbell while holding the end of the bar in your hand that is further away from the landmine attachment. Your elbow should be rest on the ground at a 45 to 60 degree angle from your torso, with your wrist stacked over your elbow. | 2. Drive the end of the bar upwards, squeezing your chest at the top of the movement. Lower the bar back down until your elbow gently touches the ground. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

1. Sit on the machine and grab the handles with a neutral grip. | 2. Adjust the machine to get the longest range of motion possible. | 3. Press until your elbows are not extended but not hyperextended.

Exercise Name: Medicine Ball Chest Press Partner Toss
Instructions: 1. Stand tall, partner tosses medicine ball to chest. | 2. Catch ball and press it back to partner. Repeat.
1. Hold medicine ball at chest, feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Extend arms forward, slamming ball to the ground. | 3. Catch the ball on the rebound and repeat for reps.
1. Stand in front of a wall holding a medicine ball. | 2. Press the ball forward, extending arms and tossing it. | 3. Catch the ball and return to the starting position.
1. Place hands on medicine ball, in push-up position. | 2. Perform push-up, maintaining proper form.
1. Place one hand on medicine ball, other on ground. | 2. Perform push-up, walking hands to switch positions.
1. Stand on Bosu with feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Drop into squat position and place hands on Bosu. | 3. Jump feet back into plank, perform a pushup, then jump back to squat.
1. Stand on Bosu with feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Drop into squat position and place hands on Bosu. | 3. Jump feet back to plank, then jump back to squat.
1. Place one hand on Bosu, other on the floor. | 2. Lower chest to the ground, keeping the body straight. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.
1. Place hands on Bosu, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Lower chest to the ground, keeping the body straight. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.
1. Place both hands on Bosu, wider than shoulder-width. | 2. Perform a pushup, then walk hands to the other side. | 3. Perform another pushup, repeat back and forth.
1. Lay on the flat bench. | 2. Tuck your elbows slightly, press the handles toward the ceiling.
1. Lay flat on the bench. | 2. Keep your elbows mostly extended and lower your arms toward the floor.
1. Use the belt attachment. Take a pushup position. | 2. Have your elbows at a 45 degree angle. Break at the elbows until your upper arm gets to your side. | 3. And then push up.
1. Lie on a bench, hold kettlebells above chest. | 2. Lower them to chest, then push up. | 3. Repeat for desired reps, maintaining form.
1. Lie on bench, hold kettlebell with both hands over chest. | 2. Lower kettlebells, elbows flared. | 3. Press kettlebells upward, fully extending arms. Repeat.
1. Lie flat on a bench, holding a kettlebell in each hand above your chest. | 2. Slowly lower the kettlebells outwards, then lift them back up to the starting position.
1. Place the cable anchor at a lower level than your shoulders. | 2. Sit on the bench, leave your elbows mostly extended. | 3. Bring your fists together and flex your pecs.

1. Bring a bench over to the cables, set the cables just below shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Press the weight forward. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cables should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

1. Bring a bench over to the cables, set the cables above shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Press the weight forward. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cables should be set above height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

Exercise Name: Cable Decline Single Arm Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set above shoulder height. | 2. Bring one handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Decline Bench Chest Fly
Instructions: 1. Bring a bench over to the cables, set the cable above shoulder height. | 2. Bring the handle to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Press the weight forward. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct while your elbow stays in a fixed position.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Bench Chest Fly
Instructions: 1. Bring a bench over to the cables, set the cable just below shoulder height. | 2. Bring the handle to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Press the weight forward. From there, your shoulder should horizontally abduct and adduct while your elbow stays in a fixed position.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Incline Chest Fly
Instructions: 1. Place the cable anchor at a lower level than your shoulders. | 2. Sit on the bench, leave your elbows mostly extended. | 3. Bring your arm across your chest and flex your pec.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring the handle to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulder and elbow simultaneously.

1. Adjust seat and handlebar height for comfort and proper posture on the assault bike. | 2. Start pedaling with even, controlled motion, maintaining your desired resistance level. | 3. Monitor heart rate and intensity; increase or decrease resistance for an effective cardio workout.

1. Adjust seat and handlebar height for comfort and proper posture on the assault bike. | 2. Start pedaling with even, controlled motion, maintaining your desired resistance level. Then keep the motion going with only your arms.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.
1. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the dumbbells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.
1. Start in a push-up position. | 2. Lower your chest, explode up, clap hands. | 3. Land softly, repeat for reps.
1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands forming a diamond shape under your chest. | 2. Lower your body, keeping elbows close. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.

1. Start by placing two plates or low boxes on the floor, about shoulder-width apart. | 2. Position yourself in a plank position with your hands on top of the boxes/plates, keeping your arms straight. | 3. Keep your feet together, with your toes resting on the floor. | 4. Engage your core and lower your body towards the floor by bending your arms, until your chest nearly touches the dumbbells. | 5. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms and engaging your chest, triceps and shoulders.
1. Start in a push-up position. | 2. Lower your chest, explode up. | 3. Land softly, repeat for reps.

1. Start by placing two boxes (or one) on the floor, about shoulder-width apart. | 2. Position yourself in a plank position with your hands on top of the box, keeping your arms straight. | 3. Put your knees on the floor. | 4. Engage your core and lower your body towards the floor by bending your arms, until your chest nearly touches the box. | 5. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms and engaging your chest, triceps and shoulders.
1. Begin in a push-up position on your knees. Break at the elbow and shoulder joint. | 2. Lower your body, keeping elbows close. | 3. Push back up to the starting position.
1. Start flat on your back with the kettlebells extended over you. | 2. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.
1. Start flat on your back with a kettlebell extended over you. | 2. Bring your elbow to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.
1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 2. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Lie on the flat bench, grasp the bar at shoulder level with your palms facing forward. | 2. Slowly lower the bar to your chest, keeping your elbows flared out. | 3. Once you feel a stretch in your chest press the weight back up.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.
1. Place hands on the bar, in push-up position. | 2. Lower yourself to the bar, maintaining proper form.

1. Grip the edge of the boxes with your hands, Keep your feet together and legs straight. | 2. Lower your body straight down. | 3. Slowly press back up to the starting point. | 4. TIP: Make this harder by raising your feet off the floor and adding weight.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cables should be set fairly low. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Incline Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set fairly low. | 2. Bring the handle across your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulder and elbow simultaneously.
1. Loop a band around your back. Start with both arms extended at your side. | 2. As you perform the jack. Bring both arms together and make a little clap.

1. From the standing position perform a walkout (use to palms to "walk" into the push up position). | 2. Bring your leg to the side and place the foot by your palm. | 3. Rotate towards the ceiling and then towards the ground, pressing the hips towards the ground.
1. Lie on your back and flatten you lower back against the ground | 2. Pull one knee towards your chest and then across your body till it forces your lower back into a rotated position.

Exercise Name: Cardio Skater To Single Leg Burpee
Instructions: 1. Leap sideways, land on right foot, left leg behind to the side. | 2. Drop into a single-leg burpee, right leg only, hands to ground. | 3. Return to standing on right, leap sideways to left, repeat with left leg.
1. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Keep legs straight or bent. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.
1. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Place knees on pad. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.

1. Sit on the machine and grab the handles with an overhand grip. | 2. Adjust the machine to get the longest range of motion possible. | 3. Press until your elbows are not extended but not hyperextended.

1. Adjust seat height so handles align with chest. Sit and grip handles with elbows slightly bent. | 2. Slowly bring handles together in front, keeping tension. Focus on squeezing chest muscles. | 3. Return handles to starting position with controlled motion. Keep chest up throughout. Repeat for reps.

1. Start by setting up the rings to a secure anchor point and adjust the straps so that they hang about waist height when you stand under them. | 2. Stand facing the rings grab the handles with both hands, and step forward so that your body is in a plank position with your hands directly beneath your shoulders. | 3. Lower your body down by bending your elbows until your chest nearly touches the handles. Keep your core tight and your body in a straight line. | 4. Push your body back up to the starting position, straightening your arms as you do so. Make sure to engage your chest, triceps, and core throughout the movement.

1. Start by adjusting the rings straps to chest height. Stand facing the rings with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Grasp the rings' handles with both hands, keeping your arms extended and your shoulders away from your ears. | 3. Lean forward, keeping your arms extended and your core engaged. Your body should form a slight diagonal line from your ankles to your head. | 4. Slowly bring your arms towards each other, in front of your chest, while keeping your core engaged and your body in a stable position.

1. Position rings shoulder-width apart, grasp handles, extend legs behind. | 2. Lower chest to rings, bend one elbow, while extending your other arm out to the side. Push yourself back to the start. | 3. Then switch arms and repeat.

1. Support your weight on your forearms and toes (plank). | 2. Allow your upper back to sink in between the shoulder blades. | 3. Push your elbows into the ground and slightly forward, and move the shoulder blades away from the spine.

1. Support your weight with your forearms on the bosu and toes on the floor (plank). | 2. Allow your upper back to sink in between the shoulder blades. | 3. Push your elbows into the ground and slightly forward, and move the shoulder blades away from the spine.

1. Support your weight on your forearms and toes (plank). | 2. Allow your upper back to sink in between the shoulder blades. | 3. Push your elbows into the ground and slightly forward, and move the shoulder blades away from the spine.

1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and the feet flat on the floor. | 2. Hold a dumbbell over your shoulder with a straight arm. | 3. Form the sign of the cross adding a protraction (punch) on every end of the cross, including the middle position.
1. Lie on bench, hold kettlebell with both hands over chest. | 2. Lower kettlebells, elbows flared. | 3. Press kettlebells upward, fully extending arms. Repeat.

1. Place your hands firmly on the ground, directly under shoulders. | 2. Flatten your back so your entire body is straight and slowly lower your body | 3. Draw shoulder blades back and down, keeping elbows tucked close to your body. Bring chest all the way to the floor and raise hands off the ground. | 4. Exhale as you push back to the starting position.

1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar with a reverse grip. | 2. Lower the bar to your lower chest | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Use a dip belt to attach a dumbbell to yourself. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Keep legs straight or bent. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.

Draw shoulder blades back and down, keeping elbows tucked close to your body | 4. Exhale as you push back to the starting position.

1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar with a reverse grip. | 2. Lower the bar to your lower chest | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar with a reverse grip. | 2. Lower the dumbbells to your lower chest. | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Use a dip belt to attach a dumbbell to yourself. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Keep legs straight or bent. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.

1. Place your hands firmly on the ground, directly under shoulders. | 2. Flatten your back so your entire body is straight, raise one leg off the ground, and slowly lower your body | 3. Draw shoulder blades back and down, keeping elbows tucked close to your body | 4. Exhale as you push back to the starting position.

1. Use a dip belt to attach a plate to yourself. Grip bars with arms straight, shoulders above hands. Keep legs straight or bent. | 2. Lower slowly until elbows are at 90 degrees. | 3. Push back up to start position, extending arms fully.
1. Sit on the machine and grab the handles. | 2. Press the handles down until your elbows are nearly extended.

1. Place your hands firmly on the ground, directly under shoulders. Place your feet on the stability ball. | 2. Flatten your back so your entire body is straight and slowly lower your body | 3. Draw shoulder blades back and down, keeping elbows tucked close to your body | 4. Exhale as you push back to the starting position.
1. Stand straight and hold the end of the Barbell | 2. Keep your hips and shoulders facing forward, bend to one side slowly | 3. Return to the upright position. | 4. Switch hands and repeat.

1. Stand with a shoulder width stance. Begin with the dumbbell near one of your quads. | 2. Rotate at your upper spine to engage the obliques. | 3. You can pivot your back foot to keep from generating too much torque at the knee.

1. Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart and hold the kettle bell with both hands against your hip. | 2. Keeping your arms straight, swing the kettlebell upwards and across your body towards your shoulder, raising the kettlebell to head height rotating your hips as you do so. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Set the cable at about nipple level. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, then rotate your torso with your arms extended against the resistance. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Sit on the floor and flex your knees and hips to a 90 degree angle. | 2. Your feet should be hovering off the ground. (If that's too hard start with heels on the floor) | 3. Rotate your upper spine to engage your obliques.

1. Sit on the floor with your legs bent, knees together and feet raised slightly off the floor. | 2. Starting on one side and sitting up straight with your core muscles engaged, lift the kettlebell off the floor with both hands and bring it across your body to the other side, rotating your chest towards the floor as you do so. | 3. Tap the kettlebell lightly on the floor and bring the kettlebell back across your body to the starting position, rotating your chest towards the floor. | 4. Repeat, keeping the legs bent and feet raised throughout the exercise.

1. Place the band at an anchor point that is shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Start with your fingers interlocked around the band and your fists connected to your chest. | 3. Extend at the elbows pressing the band away from your body until your elbows are fully extended.

1. Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart. Hold the kettlebell in one hand and extend your arm above your head. | 2. Keeping your legs straight and the kettlebell above your head, lower the relaxed arm towards the ground, twisting your body towards the side of the raised arm. | 3. Return to the starting potion, tilt your pelvis forward and repeat.

1. Use a handle attachment, set the cable at nipple level, walk a few steps away, and face sideways. | 2. Start with both hands on the handle and your fists against your chest. | 3. Press the handle forward until your elbows are fully extended, then pull the handle back to your chest.

1. Stand upright. | 2. After completing the desired amount of reps with the left arm, switch to the right arm and lean to the left. | 3. Reach up with your left arm and then lean slowly to the right. Lean until a stretch is felt in the obliques.
1. Stand upright. | 2. Reach with both hands upwards until you can interlock your fingers. | 3. With your hands above your head, lean back until a stretch is felt in the abdominals.

1. Hover your heels just off the ground. | 2. Stick your chest out and maintain a flat back. Make all the movement happen at your mid and upper spine. | 3. Point your chest to the left, then rotate at the spine until your chest is pointed right.

1. Start with your elbow and hip on the ground. Either neutral fist or flat hand on the ground. | 2. Begin in a side plank position, and then drop your hips to the floor. | 3. Pull your hips back to the ceiling to finish the rep.

1. Begin in an elbow side plank position. | 2. Reach for the ceiling with your off hand. | 3. Rotate at the mid and upper spine and reach through the open space between the floor and your torso. | 4. Reach backwards, and then rotate back into the starting position.
1. Press your elbow into the floor. | 2. Pick your hips up off the ground and maintain this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you don't let your chest fall forward or backward.
1. Press your hand into the ground and pick up your hip off the ground. | 2. Open your chest and maintain this position for the allotted amount of time.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a barbell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the barbell down towards the ground. | 3. As the barbell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the barbell on the opposite side of your body.

1. Take a half kneeling position. Start with the dumbbell by your knee on the side of the kneeling leg. | 2. Rotate at the upper spine, holding the dumbbell away from your body with nearly extended elbows.

1. Start in a kneeling position with your shoulder blades pulled back. | 2. The dumbbell should begin by one of your hips. | 3. Rotate at the spine and bring the dumbbell from your hip, 180 degrees around your body. The dumbbell should land at eye level.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell overhead. | 2. From this starting position, bend to the side as far as you can while keeping your feet planted and your core engaged.

1. Start by lying on your side with your feet stacked on top of each other and a dumbbell on your hip. | 2. Place your bottom elbow on the ground beneath your shoulder and engage your core to raise your hips off the ground. | 3. Your hips will do all the moving. Think, "hips up, hips down."

1. Start by lying on your side with your feet stacked on top of each other and a dumbbell on your hip. | 2. Place your bottom hand on the ground beneath your shoulder and engage your core to raise your hips off the ground. | 3. From this starting position, hold the side plank position for the desired amount of time, making sure to keep your body straight and your hips level.

1. Start by sitting on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground | 2. Engage your core muscles by pulling your belly button toward your spine. | 3. Slowly twist your upper body to the right, keeping your feet flat on the ground and your back straight. | 4. Hold for a second and then twist to the left, holding for another second.

1. Stand with a plate extended away from your body. Elbows mostly extended. | 2. Rotate at the upper spine while keeping your lumbar spine in a neutral position. | 3. Do not let the plate go behind your body.

1. Stand with a shoulder width stance. Begin with the plate near one of your quads. | 2. Rotate at your upper spine to engage the obliques. | 3. You can pivot your back foot to keep from generating too much torque at the knee.

1. Start by sitting on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Hold a dumbbell in both hands with your arms extended straight in front of you. | 2. Twist your torso to the right, bringing the dumbbell towards the ground, then return to the center. Repeat on the left side, twisting to the left and bringing the dumbbell towards the ground. | 3. Continue this twisting motion, alternating sides, for the desired number of repetitions. Keep your core engaged and avoid swinging your arms to generate momentum.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart and place your right hand on the right hip. | 2. Hold a dumbbell with the left hand. Bend at the hips to the side. | 3. Make sure you don't start to lean forward to try and force a longer range of motion.

1. Lie on your side with your legs straight and your feet resting in the TRX foot cradles. | 2. Prop yourself up on your forearm and engage your core to maintain a straight line from your head to your feet.

1. Place your feet in the TRX stirrups and get in to a hand plank position. | 2. Pull both knees to your right elbow. | 3. Extend your legs back to the starting position, then pull both knees to the left elbow.
1. Hold a dumbbell over one shoulder. | 2. Initiate the squat by pushing your hips back. | 3. Avoid doing any twisting. Try to keep your shoulders even.

1. Step back with your right foot into a lunge position, both knees bent at 90 degrees. | 2. Twist your torso to the right, keeping the plate close to your chest. | 3. Push through your front foot to return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.
1. Stand straight with the plate held at your side | 2. Keep your hips and shoulders facing forward, bend to one side slowly | 3. Return to the upright position. | 4. Switch hands and repeat

Exercise Name: Gate Pose Variation Arm Extended on Side
Instructions: 1. Start on your knees and extend your right leg out to the side. | 2. Raise your right arm above your head and reach towards the left side of the room. | 3. Gently bend your body to the left side and rest your left hand on your left thigh. | 4. Look up towards your right hand and hold the pose for a few breaths before switching sides.

1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. | 2. Bend your right knee and bring your heel towards your perineum. | 3. Place your left hand on the outside of your right knee and twist your body to the right. | 4. Reach your right hand towards your left foot and look up towards the ceiling. Hold the pose for a few breaths before switching sides.

1. Sit comfortably on the floor with your legs crossed. | 2. Inhale and raise your right arm above your head. | 3. As you exhale, bend your body to the left side and rest your left hand on the ground. | 4. Look up towards the ceiling and hold the pose for a few breaths. Then switch sides and repeat the pose on the other side.

1. Lie down on your back with your arms stretched out to your sides. | 2. Bend your right knee and bring it towards your chest. | 3. Slowly twist your body to the left side, bringing your right knee across your body towards the ground on the left side. | 4. Look towards your right hand and hold the pose for a few breaths before switching sides.

1. Start in a downward facing dog position. | 2. Shift your weight onto your left hand and foot, and lift your right leg towards the ceiling. | 3. Slowly bend your right knee and shift your weight onto your right hand as you open up your chest towards the ceiling. | 4. Look towards your right hand and hold the pose for a few breaths before switching sides.
1. Lie on one side, forearm on Bosu, elbow under shoulder. | 2. Lift hips to create a side plank. | 3. Hold the side plank position, then switch sides.
1. Place hand on Bosu, arm straight, facing sideways. | 2. Stack feet and lift hips to side plank. | 3. Hold the side plank position, then switch sides.

Exercise Name: Bosu Ball Hand Sideplank Hip Abduction
Instructions: 1. Start in a side plank with hand on Bosu. | 2. Lift the top leg while keeping the body stable. | 3. Lower the leg back down.

1. Set up the landmine attachment and load weight. | 2. Stand facing the landmine, holding the weight away from your chest. | 3. Step backward with one leg, lunge down while twisting your torso toward the front leg, return to starting position, and repeat on the other side.

1. Kneel down facing the landmine with your knees hip-width apart and your back straight. Grasp the landmine barbell with both hands, interlacing your fingers and holding it above and slightly in front of your body. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, twist your torso to one side, rotating your arms and the landmine along with it. Pause briefly at the end of the twist, feeling the contraction in your oblique muscles. | 3. Slowly rotate back to the starting position, then twist to the opposite side, repeating the same motion. | 4. Repeat both sides of the rotation for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand facing the landmine, with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with both hands, interlacing your fingers and holding it at chest height. Position your arms straight out in front of you, parallel to the floor, with your elbows slightly bent. | 2. While keeping your core engaged, rotate your torso and the landmine to one side. Twist through your waist, using your oblique muscles to generate the movement. Pivot on the ball of your opposite foot as you rotate away from it. | 3. Rotate back to the starting position, then perform the same movement in the opposite direction. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Start sitting on the ground facing the landmine attachment, holding the end of the bar in both hands slightly in front of and above your chest while holding your feet off the ground and knees bent. | 2. Bending your elbows as little as possible and keeping your core tight and feet elevated, lower the end of the bar with control to the ground on one side of your body, then contract your obliques to return the bar to the center. Repeat on the other side. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Exercise Name: Medicine Ball Half Kneeling Wood Chopper
Instructions: 1. Kneel with one knee down, holding a medicine ball. | 2. Rotate torso and until the medicine ball is pointed the opposite direction. | 3. Repeat the movement on the other side.
1. Kneel, holding a medicine ball. | 2. Rotate torso and slam the ball diagonally down and across. | 3. Repeat the movement on the other side.
1. Stand facing partner, side by side. | 2. Toss medicine ball to partner's side. | 3. Catch and repeat toss on other side.
1. Lift medicine ball overhead. | 2. Slam ball down to one side. | 3. Catch and repeat slam to the other side.
1. Hold medicine ball at chest. | 2. Step back into lunge position, extend your arms, twist torso. | 3. Return to starting position. Repeat on other leg.
1. Sit with knees bent, feet off ground. | 2. Twist torso side to side, touching medicine ball to ground.
1. Hold medicine ball with both hands and arms extended. | 2. Swing ball diagonally across body, engaging core.
1. Stand sideways next to a wall. | 2. Swing medicine ball across your body and toss off the wall. | 3. Catch and repeat toss on the other side.
1. Hold the end of the bar. Start with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Bring both arms to one side and keep your elbows mostly extended. | 3. Rotate back and forth and try to resist twisting too much.
1. Hold medicine ball with both hands and arms extended. | 2. Swing ball diagonally across body, engaging core.
1. Hold the attachment with both hands and take a kneeling position. | 2. Rotate across your body.
1. Hold one of the handle attachments. | 2. Stand upright, lean to the opposing side of the cable.
1. Hold the attachment in one hand and raise your arm over head. | 2. Turn one foot outward and one foot forward. | 3. Lean to the side while reaching for your foot.
1. Start in a side plank position. | 2. Reach your top arm under your body. | 3. Return to the plank position.
1. Stand with kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, grab kettlebell, pull to chest and rotate at the torso

Exercise Name: Cable Half Kneeling High To Low Wood Chopper
Instructions: 1. Set the cable just over your head. Take a half kneeling position. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, then rotate your torso with your arms extended against the resistance. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

Exercise Name: Cable Half Kneeling Low To High Wood Chopper
Instructions: 1. Set the cable at a low position. Take a half kneeling position. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, then rotate your torso with your arms extended against the resistance. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Set the cable at nipple level. Take a half kneeling position. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, then rotate your torso with your arms extended against the resistance. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Set the cable just over your head. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, push the handle down until your elbow is extended. Flex your obliques until you feel a contraction. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Use a handle attachment, set the cable at nipple level, walk a few steps away, and face sideways. | 2. Start with both hands on the handle and your fists against your chest. | 3. Press the handle forward until your elbows are fully extended, then rotate away from the cable stack. | 4. Then pull the handle back to your chest.

1. Set the cable at the bottom of the stack. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, grab the handle, lean away from the cable. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart. Hold the kettlebell in your bottom hand and extend the other arm above your head. | 2. Keeping your legs straight and the kettlebell inside your thigh, lower the kettlebell towards the ground, twisting your body towards the side of the raised arm. | 3. Return to the starting position, tilt your pelvis forward and repeat.
1. Lay on your side with your knees bent. | 2. Hold the bar extended over you. | 3. Lift yourself up by flexing your obliques.
1. Stand beside the bar. | 2. Keep your hips and shoulders facing forward, bend to one side slowly | 3. Return to the upright position. | 4. Switch hands and repeat.

Exercise Name: Smith Machine Side Plank Up Down
Instructions: 1. Start by lying on your side with your feet stacked on top of each other and the bar on your hip. | 2. Place your bottom elbow on the ground beneath your shoulder and engage your core to raise your hips off the ground. | 3. Your hips will do all the moving. Think, "hips up, hips down."

1. Stand perpendicularly to the barbell with the end of the bar in front of your feet. Squat down and hold the end of the bar with your hand closer to the landmine attachment with your palm facing your body. | 2. Drive your feet into the ground to start the motion. As your legs fully extend, pull the bar upwards with your hand and start to rotate your torso in towards the landmine attachment. As you do so, bring your other hand up to the bar and switch your grip. Press through the bar to extend your arm all the way upright, pivoting your back foot to allow for more trunk rotation. | 3. Perform the movement in reverse to return to the starting position. Repeat for desired number of reps before switching sides.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 1 Crosslateral Limb Raise 4Pt Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to the 4 point position (on all fours) | 2. 90 angles at hips and shoulder and neutral spine | 3. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 4. Hold for a split second and bring back to starting position

Exercise Name: Core Stability 2 Opposite Shoulder Tap 4Pt Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to the 4 point position (on all fours). 90 angles at hips and shoulder and neutral spine. | 2. Lift your knees slightly off the ground supporting your weight on palms and toes. | 3. Maintain a toe placement roughly at shoulder width (the wider the leg stance the easier the exercise - the narrower the stance the more difficult it becomes. | 4. Tap your opposite shoulder with your fingertips.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 4 Crosslateral Limb Raise Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Maintain a toe placement roughly at shoulder width (the wider the leg stance the easier the exercise - the narrower the stance the more difficult it becomes. | 3. Tap your opposite shoulder with your fingertips. | 4. Do not tilt or shift your hips. Do not round or arch your back.

Exercise Name: Core Stability 5 Crosslateral Limb Raise Into Knee Elbow Tuck Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 3. Hold for a split second and then try to bring your elbow to your opposite knee by driving both towards the centre of the body. | 4. Spine might curve slightly but you should not shift your hips during the movement.

Exercise Name: Core Stability Regression Crosslateral Limb Raise Push Up Position
Instructions: 1. Bring yourself to a strict push-up position | 2. Tap the hand of the working arm on the ground to find your balance. Raise opposite limbs till they are parallel to the ground | 3. Hold for a split second and then try to bring your elbow to your opposite knee by driving both towards the centre of the body. | 4. Spine might curve slightly but you should not shift your hips during the movement.

Exercise Name: Crosslateral Core Stabilisation Unilateral Load Kettlebell
Instructions: 1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a kettlebell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Hing forward with a flat back and lift the kettlebell. | 3. Hold the kettlebell at your side and make sure to not lean to one side.

1. Lay on your back. Extend your straight arms above the chest and raise your bent knees till they are over your hips. | 2. Lower opposite limbs towards the ground. You can feel the ground but do not rest on or tap off of the ground. | 3. Maintain a flat lower back throughout the movement (lower back should be in contact with the ground).

1. Lay on your back. Extend your straight arms above the chest and raise your bent knees till they are over your hips. | 2. Lower limbs of the same side towards the ground. You can feel the ground but do not rest on or tap off of the ground. | 3. Maintain a flat lower back throughout the movement (lower back should be in contact with the ground).

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a kettlebell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the kettlebell down towards the ground. | 3. As the kettlebell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the kettlebell on the opposite side of your body.
1. Standing straight with a kettlebell in one hand, walk for a specified distance or duration. | 2. Stay upright and don't lean to one side.

1. Start from the standing position with an upright posture. | 2. Cross your right leg over the left and raise your right arm over your head. | 3. Lean towards your left and reach with your right arm as far to the left as possible. | 4. Repeat on the opposite side by crossing the left leg over the right. | 5. You can do the same exercise against a wall or by holding onto a pull-up bar.

1. Start from a seated position with an upright posture. | 2. Cross your right leg over the left and raise your right arm over your head. | 3. Lean towards your left and reach with your right arm as far to the left as possible. | 4. Repeat on the opposite side by crossing the left leg over the right. | 5. You can do the same exercise against a wall or by holding onto a pull-up bar.

1. Sit on your heels and reach out your arms on the floor while pressing the chest towards the ground. | 2. Bend your spine towards one side and reach over with your arms. | 3. Do the same on the opposite side.
1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. | 2. Reach right hand to right heel. | 3. Switch sides, left hand to left heel. Repeat.
1. Lie on your side, knees bent, hands behind head. | 2. Bring your elbow towards your knees and flex your obliques.
1. Lie on your side, legs straight, hand behind head. | 2. Lift both legs and upper body simultaneously. | 3. Squeeze obliques, then lower back down. Repeat on both sides.
1. Lay flat on your back with both hands over one leg. | 2. Reach toward your knee flexing your abs and obliques. | 3. Do the prescribed amount of reps, then switch sides.
1. Lie on back, arms out, legs together. | 2. Lift legs to 90 degrees. | 3. Rotate legs side to side, keeping shoulders grounded.

1. Start on all fours then bring your chest to the ground. Place one hand on the ground in front of you. The other hand behind your head/ear. | 2. On the side of the hand that is behind your head, rotate until your elbow is pointed at the ceiling and then hold this position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart with the bar on the ground at your side. | 2. Lift the bar to your side and walk for the allotted amount of time or distance. | 3. Set the bar down and switch sides.
1. Lie sideways on a stability ball, feet anchored, hands behind head, core engaged. | 2. Crunch sideways by contracting obliques, bringing your upper body toward your hip.
1. Sit on a box or bench | 2. Keep one foot off the ground by pulling onto your knee, or by crossing one leg over the opposite knee. | 3. Try to form the letters of the Alphabet with your foot.

1. Sit on a bench with your bare foot on the ground. | 2. Slightly raise your big toe before trying to move it towards the opposite side (abduction). | 3. Expect he range of motion is very limited and the movement to be very difficult. | 4. It helps a lot having your toe on a line as benchmark.
1. Sit on a bench with your bare foot on the ground. | 2. Raise your big toe as far as it can go, without moving the rest of the toes.

1. From the standing position press the big toe into the ground till you feel the inside part of your foot raise off the ground | 2. The arch of your foot should now look more pronounced. | 3. Do not roll your foot out to lift the inside part of your foot.

1. Sit on a bench or box. Press the big toe into the ground till you feel the inside part of your foot raise off the ground | 2. The arch of your foot should now look more pronounced. Do not roll your foot out to lift the inside part of your foot | 3. You should perform the exercise bare foot or with socks, but do not wear shoes.

1. Sit on a step or low box, preferably with a back support. Extend both legs and wrap the band around the balls of the working foot | 2. Pass the band around the other foot as shown in the video. Hold the end of the band with the opposite arm of the working foot | 3. The ankle should be at 90 and turned inwards (inversion) before you start the movement. Turn the ankle out, without moving the rest of the leg.
1. Stand up straight with a relatively narrow stance. | 2. Roll your feet out and balance. | 3. Make sure you do not roll out excessively or you are risking re-injury.

1. Sit on a step or low box, preferably with a back support. Extend both legs and cross the working leg over the non working leg. | 2. Wrap the band around the balls of the working foot. Pass the band around the other foot as shown in the video. | 3. Hold the end of the band with the same arm as the working foot. The ankle should be at 90 and turned outwards (eversion) before you start the movement | 4. Turn the ankle in, without moving the rest of the leg.

1. Stand upright with a braced core. | 2. Choose the supporting leg and shift your weight on that, while lifting the other slightly off the ground. | 3. Try to maintain your balance while bouncing a tennis ball off the wall or ground.

1. Place the supporting leg on the middle of a bosu ball. | 2. Keep the knee of the suspended leg slightly bent. | 3. Try to maintain your balance on the bosu ball while bouncing a tennis ball off the wall.

1. Stand with feet together, arms in front at chest level, palms touching. | 2. Spread legs wide, simultaneously swing arms out to sides, palms facing forward. | 3. Jump back to starting position, bringing arms together again quickly. Repeat rhythmically.
1. Stand tall, feet together, arms by sides, ready to move. | 2. Step right foot out, simultaneously raise arms above head. | 3. Step right foot in, lower arms, repeat left, maintain rhythm.

1. Adjust the seat to match your height. | 2. Press your back into the back pad. | 3. Press upwards until your elbows are nearly extended. But not fully extended. | 4. Lower until the plates nearly touch back down.

1. Adjust the seat to match your height. | 2. Press your back into the back pad. | 3. Press upwards until your elbows are nearly extended. But not fully extended. | 4. Lower until the plates nearly touch back down.

1. Lay flat on the bench and place your feet on the ground. | 2. Begin the exercise with the dumbbells held together above your chest, elbows slightly bent. | 3. Simultaneously lower the weights to either side. | 4. Pause when the weights are parallel to the bench, then raise your arms to the starting position.

1. Stand up straight with dumbbells at either side, palms facing your hips. | 2. Raise your arms on either side with a slight bend in your elbow until they are parallel with the floor. Pause at the top of the motion. | 3. Slowly return your arms down to starting position.

1. Sit on a bench with back support. Raise the dumbbells to shoulder height with your palms forward. | 2. Raise the dumbbells upwards and pause at the contracted position. | 3. Lower the weights back to starting position.

1. Grab two dumbbells while standing upright with the dumbbells at your side. | 2. Raise the two dumbbells with your elbows being fully extended until the dumbbells are eye level. | 3. Lower the weights in a controlled manner to the starting position and repeat.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Stand up straight with feet shoulder width apart, holding the kettlebell in front of your pelvis. | 2. Keeping arms straight, raise the kettlebell slightly higher than head level. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with feet shoulder width apart holding a kettlebell with one hand at your side. | 2. Keeping your arm straight, swing the kettlebell up and out, away from your body to around head height, holding on to the kettlebell firmly so it does not change position in your hand. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with feet shoulder width apart holding a kettlebell with one hand at your side. | 2. Keeping your arm straight, swing the kettlebell up and out, away from your body to around head height. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Place the top of your hand into the small of your back, your arm at a 90 degree angle. | 2. Hold your elbow with the other arm, and slowly pull the arm forward until you feel your shoulder engaged in the stretch. Pause at the apex of the stretch and return to the starting position. | 3. Return to starting position, and repeat with your other arm.

1. Start with your arms at either side. Begin by pushing your shoulders forward and in towards your chest. | 2. Continue the circular motion with your shoulders, pinching up towards your ears, and then extending your chest outwards while you finish the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. Reach one arm behind your body, with your elbow pointing upward behind your head. | 2. Assist the stretch with your other hand on your elbow to engage your shoulder. | 3. Pause for a few seconds, then repeat the stretch with your other arm.
1. Use a bench or an object to elevate your feet. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat

1. Use a handle attachment. The cables should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Walk a few steps forward. Then press the weight forward. | 4. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. Stand upright making sure to maintain a flat back. Your starting position will have your palms facing forward. | 2. Use both your elbows and shoulders to press the weight directly overhead.

Exercise Name: Cable Low Single Arm Lateral Raise
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. You should vertically abduct at the shoulder raising your arm straight out to the side. | 3. Raise until your arm is parallel with the ground and then back to the starting position.

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up toward the ceiling until the attachment is just below your chin then extend until your elbows are fully extended.
1. Stand on the band with one or 2 feet depending on how heavy you want the band to be. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.
1. Grab the band at shoulder width. Raise your arms straight out to the side. | 2. The band should scrape against your shirt.

1. Loop the band under one of your feet. The other end of the bed should be in your hand between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. Press the band straight up towards the ceiling. Until your elbow is fully extended.

1. Stand tall with an overhand grip on the barbell. Raise your arms until your fists are around eye level. | 2. Return to the start under control. This exercise is prone to using momentum when you begin to fatigue.

1. Take a roughly shoulder width grip. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Pull your chin back and press the weight toward the ceiling by extending at the elbow joint and flexing at the shoulder joint. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly. | 4. Return to the start position with control. Pulling your chin back to allow the bar to pass your face safely.
1. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the bar to chin level or slightly higher.

1. Begin by sitting on the ground with your legs extended and a barbell in your hands, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, lift the barbell up from your chest and press it straight up above your head. | 3. Lower the barbell back down to your chest.
1. Lay on an incline bench and let your arms freely. | 2. Lateral raise your arms straight out to the side until your arms are about parallel with the ground.

1. Lie on the decline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Lay flat on the incline bench with your feet on the ground. Raise the dumbbells until you have straight arms. | 2. Lower the dumbbells to your mid chest | 3. Raise the dumbbells until you've locked your elbows.

1. Lie on a flat bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Lie on an incline bench, grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Sit on an upright bench , grasp a pair of dumbbells and hold them at shoulder level with your palms facing each other. Keep your elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Slowly lower the dumbbells to your shoulder joint, keeping your elbows bent and close to your body. | 3. Once the dumbbells reach your chest, pause for a moment and then press them back up to the starting position. | 4. This variation is much easier on the shoulder joints.

1. Begin seated on an upright bench with your palms facing you. | 2. Begin pressing toward the ceiling. As you press, rotate your palms. | 3. As you extend your elbows fully your palms should be facing forward.
1. Start in a standing position

1. Start with two dumbbells just above your shoulders. | 2. Press one dumbbell to the ceiling while keeping the other in place. | 3. Let the first dumbbell return to its starting position before pressing the other dumbbell.
1. Stand with both palms facing you. | 2. Begin to press the dumbbells to the ceiling while rotating your palms. | 3. When you reach elbow extension, your palms should be facing forward.

1. Start with two dumbbells near your shoulders with a neutral grip. | 2. Press one of the dumbbells toward the ceiling while keeping the other in position. | 3. Let the first dumbbell return to its starting position before pressing the other.
1. Start with both dumbbells near your shoulders in a neutral grip. | 2. Press the dumbbells toward the ceiling. | 3. Make sure you don't arch your back as you fatigue.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the dumbbells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. From this starting position, dip your knees slightly and then quickly extend them as you press the dumbbells upwards. | 3. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement. | 4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing you and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is directly above your head. | 4. As you extend your arm, rotate your palm to face away from your body.

Exercise Name: Dumbbell Single Arm Neutral Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing your body and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, press the dumbbell upwards so that it is directly above your shoulder.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in one hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbell to your shoulder, with your palm facing forward and your elbow bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arm upwards so that the dumbbell is overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand. | 2. Bring the dumbbells to your shoulders, with your palms facing inward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, dip your knees slightly and then quickly extend them as you press the dumbbells upwards. | 4. As you press the dumbbells upwards, also push your hips forward to help generate additional power. | 5. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the feet. | 2. Bend the knees and hips to pick up the plate, keeping the back straight and core engaged. | 3. Stand up, lock the hips and legs, and press the plate overhead with straight arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.
