Step back with the leg on the same side that you are holding the bar on and with control lower yourself down into a lunge position while keeping your core engaged and torso tall, then drive through your front heel as you step back to the starting position. | 3. Once your feet are back in the starting position, drive the bar up overhead until your arm is fully extended, then lower the bar back down to the starting position. | 4. Repeated for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

1. Stand perpendicularly to the barbell with the end of the bar in front of your feet. Squat down and hold the end of the bar with your hand closer to the landmine attachment with your palm facing your body. | 2. Drive your feet into the ground to start the motion. As your legs fully extend, pull the bar upwards with your hand and start to rotate your torso in towards the landmine attachment. As you do so, bring your other hand up to the bar and switch your grip. Press through the bar to extend your arm all the way upright, pivoting your back foot to allow for more trunk rotation. | 3. Perform the movement in reverse to return to the starting position. Repeat for desired number of reps before switching sides.
1. Hold the bar in a goblet position. | 2. Stand tall, push your knees forward until your calves touch your hamstrings. | 3. Make sure to keep your hips extended.

1. Hold the end of the bar in a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees. | 3. Reach at least parallel with the ground before pushing through your heels back to the starting position.
1. Stand with a wide stance and straddle over the end of the bar. | 2. Bend at the hips and knees, and grab the bar. | 3. Stand up with the bar.

1. Hold the bar with a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and sink into a squat. | 3. Push through your heels and squat back up. Use the momentum you generate at the legs to push the bar over head. | 4. Let the bar return to the goblet position before starting the next rep.

1. Measure your shoulders against the bar to make sure you're even. Wrap a pair of lifting straps around the bar. Hold the ends of the straps. Throw your shoulders under the bar. The bar should be digging into your neck slightly. | 2. Make sure to push your elbows up to the ceiling for the entire rep. To make sure you don't get too pitched forward. | 3. Use the squat stance you would use for a back or goblet squat. Push your hips back to initiate the squat. Break at the knees until you hit parallel depth. | 4. Squat back up to a standing position.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, one foot slightly behind. Bar on your back. | 2. Lower into a squat, keeping weight on front heel. | 3. Return to standing, engaging glutes and core.

1. Have the barbell in a high bar position and place your foot on a plate or a low box. | 2. Put all of your weight on your front foot and lean forward. | 3. Lower until your calves touch your hamstrings and then extend back up.

1. Begin by standing with your feet on a plate and holding a barbell in the crook of your arms, near your belly. Your palms should be facing towards your body. | 2. Step back with one foot off the plate and lower your back knee to the floor. | 3. Push through your front leg and bring your back foot to the plate.

1. Stand on a platform, barbell in front rack, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step back, lowering knee toward floor, keeping chest upright and core engaged. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start, keeping bar stable throughout.

1. Stand on a platform, barbell on your back, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step back, lowering knee toward floor, keeping chest upright and core engaged. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start, keeping bar stable throughout.

1. Stand on a platform, bar on your back, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step back, lowering knee toward floor, keeping chest upright and core engaged. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start, keeping bar stable throughout.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Maintain the natural arch in your back, squeezing your shoulder blades and raising your chest. | 2. Grip the bar across your shoulders and support it on your upper back. Unwrack the bar by straightening your legs, and take a step back. | 3. Bend your knees as you lower the weight without altering the form of your back until your hips are below your knees. | 4. Raise the bar back to starting position, lift with your legs and exhale at the top.
1. Place the barbell on your back | 2. Step your foot back and around while simultaneously bringing the weight down. | 3. Return to start and repeat on other leg.

1. Stand facing the barbell while holding the end of the bar at your side with one hand. | 2. With the leg on the same side of your body as the barbell, lunge backward and across your body at a 45 degree angle while keeping your weight on your front heel to lower your back knee gently to the ground. | 3. Drive through your front heel as you step back to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Start facing the barbell while holding the end of the bar in the goblet position in front of your chest with your elbows close to your sides. | 2. Step backward and across your body with one leg at a 45 degree angle while keeping your weight on your front heel to gently lower your back knee to the ground. | 3. Drive through your front heel as you step back up and to the starting position. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Maintain the natural arch in your back, squeezing your shoulder blades and raising your chest. | 2. Grip the bar across your shoulders and support it on your upper back. Unwrack the bar by straightening your legs, and take a step back. | 3. Bend your knees as you lower the weight without altering the form of your back until your hips are below your knees. | 4. Raise the bar back to starting position, lift with your legs and exhale at the top.
1. Place the barbell on your back | 2. Step your foot back and around while simultaneously bringing the weight down. | 3. Return to start and repeat on other leg.

1. Stand facing the barbell while holding the end of the bar at your side with one hand. | 2. With the leg on the same side of your body as the barbell, lunge backward and across your body at a 45 degree angle while keeping your weight on your front heel to lower your back knee gently to the ground. | 3. Drive through your front heel as you step back to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Start facing the barbell while holding the end of the bar in the goblet position in front of your chest with your elbows close to your sides. | 2. Step backward and across your body with one leg at a 45 degree angle while keeping your weight on your front heel to gently lower your back knee to the ground. | 3. Drive through your front heel as you step back up and to the starting position. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

1. Hold the end of the bar in a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees. | 3. Reach at least parallel with the ground before pushing through your heels back to the starting position.

1. Hold the bar with a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and sink into a squat. | 3. Push through your heels and squat back up. Use the momentum you generate at the legs to push the bar over head. | 4. Let the bar return to the goblet position before starting the next rep.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Maintain the natural arch in your back, squeezing your shoulder blades and raising your chest. | 2. Grip the bar across your shoulders and support it on your upper back. Unwrack the bar by straightening your legs, and take a step back. | 3. Bend your knees as you lower the weight without altering the form of your back until your hips are below your knees. | 4. Raise the bar back to starting position, lift with your legs and exhale at the top.
1. Place the barbell on your back | 2. Step your foot back and around while simultaneously bringing the weight down. | 3. Return to start and repeat on other leg.

1. Stand facing the barbell while holding the end of the bar at your side with one hand. | 2. With the leg on the same side of your body as the barbell, lunge backward and across your body at a 45 degree angle while keeping your weight on your front heel to lower your back knee gently to the ground. | 3. Drive through your front heel as you step back to the starting position, and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Start facing the barbell while holding the end of the bar in the goblet position in front of your chest with your elbows close to your sides. | 2. Step backward and across your body with one leg at a 45 degree angle while keeping your weight on your front heel to gently lower your back knee to the ground. | 3. Drive through your front heel as you step back up and to the starting position. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

1. Hold the end of the bar in a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and break at the knees. | 3. Reach at least parallel with the ground before pushing through your heels back to the starting position.

1. Hold the bar with a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and sink into a squat. | 3. Push through your heels and squat back up. Use the momentum you generate at the legs to push the bar over head. | 4. Let the bar return to the goblet position before starting the next rep.
1. Hold the bar in a goblet position. | 2. Stand tall, push your knees forward until your calves touch your hamstrings. | 3. Make sure to keep your hips extended.
1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 2. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.
1. Un-rack the bar and break at the elbows and shoulders. | 2. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.

1. Start in a bench press position with your feet planted on the bench and knees bent. | 2. Grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, positioning your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. | 3. Lift the barbell off the rack and lower it to your chest, keeping your elbows close to your sides. | 4. Push the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

1. Start in a bench press position with your legs elevated. Try to keep your knees with a slight bend in them. | 2. Unrack the bar then initiate the rep. | 3. Bring the bar to your torso and tap your ribcage before pressing back to the ceiling.

1. Start on the bench with your shoulder blades pulled back. | 2. As you initiate the first rep, tuck your elbows slightly until the bar is a few inches off your chest. | 3. Pause just off your chest for 1-3 seconds. Then press explosively.

Exercise Name: Landmine Alternating Lunge To Chest Press
Instructions: 1. Stand facing the landmine with feet hip-width apart and holding the end of the landmine barbell with both hands, keeping elbows bent and close to your body. | 2. Step backward with the right foot, lunge down, and press the landmine away from your chest. | 3. Push through the left heel to return to the starting position while pulling the landmine back to your chest. | 4. Repeat on the opposite side, alternating for the desired number of reps.

1. Starting lying on your back perpendicularly to the barbell while holding the end of the bar in your hand that is further away from the landmine attachment. Your elbow should be rest on the ground at a 45 to 60 degree angle from your torso, with your wrist stacked over your elbow. | 2. Drive the end of the bar upwards, squeezing your chest at the top of the movement. Lower the bar back down until your elbow gently touches the ground. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar with a reverse grip. | 2. Lower the bar to your lower chest | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.
1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 2. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.

1. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar with a reverse grip. | 2. Lower the bar to your lower chest | 3. Raise the bar until you've locked your elbows.
1. Stand straight and hold the end of the Barbell | 2. Keep your hips and shoulders facing forward, bend to one side slowly | 3. Return to the upright position. | 4. Switch hands and repeat.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a barbell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the barbell down towards the ground. | 3. As the barbell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the barbell on the opposite side of your body.

1. Set up the landmine attachment and load weight. | 2. Stand facing the landmine, holding the weight away from your chest. | 3. Step backward with one leg, lunge down while twisting your torso toward the front leg, return to starting position, and repeat on the other side.

1. Kneel down facing the landmine with your knees hip-width apart and your back straight. Grasp the landmine barbell with both hands, interlacing your fingers and holding it above and slightly in front of your body. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, twist your torso to one side, rotating your arms and the landmine along with it. Pause briefly at the end of the twist, feeling the contraction in your oblique muscles. | 3. Slowly rotate back to the starting position, then twist to the opposite side, repeating the same motion. | 4. Repeat both sides of the rotation for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand facing the landmine, with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with both hands, interlacing your fingers and holding it at chest height. Position your arms straight out in front of you, parallel to the floor, with your elbows slightly bent. | 2. While keeping your core engaged, rotate your torso and the landmine to one side. Twist through your waist, using your oblique muscles to generate the movement. Pivot on the ball of your opposite foot as you rotate away from it. | 3. Rotate back to the starting position, then perform the same movement in the opposite direction. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand perpendicularly to the barbell with the end of the bar in front of your feet. Squat down and hold the end of the bar with your hand closer to the landmine attachment with your palm facing your body. | 2. Drive your feet into the ground to start the motion. As your legs fully extend, pull the bar upwards with your hand and start to rotate your torso in towards the landmine attachment. As you do so, bring your other hand up to the bar and switch your grip. Press through the bar to extend your arm all the way upright, pivoting your back foot to allow for more trunk rotation. | 3. Perform the movement in reverse to return to the starting position. Repeat for desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Start sitting on the ground facing the landmine attachment, holding the end of the bar in both hands slightly in front of and above your chest while holding your feet off the ground and knees bent. | 2. Bending your elbows as little as possible and keeping your core tight and feet elevated, lower the end of the bar with control to the ground on one side of your body, then contract your obliques to return the bar to the center. Repeat on the other side. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.
1. Hold the end of the bar. Start with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Bring both arms to one side and keep your elbows mostly extended. | 3. Rotate back and forth and try to resist twisting too much.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart with the bar on the ground at your side. | 2. Lift the bar to your side and walk for the allotted amount of time or distance. | 3. Set the bar down and switch sides.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a barbell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the barbell down towards the ground. | 3. As the barbell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the barbell on the opposite side of your body.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart with the bar on the ground at your side. | 2. Lift the bar to your side and walk for the allotted amount of time or distance. | 3. Set the bar down and switch sides.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Stand tall with an overhand grip on the barbell. Raise your arms until your fists are around eye level. | 2. Return to the start under control. This exercise is prone to using momentum when you begin to fatigue.

1. Take a roughly shoulder width grip. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Pull your chin back and press the weight toward the ceiling by extending at the elbow joint and flexing at the shoulder joint. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly. | 4. Return to the start position with control. Pulling your chin back to allow the bar to pass your face safely.
1. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the bar to chin level or slightly higher.

1. Begin by sitting on the ground with your legs extended and a barbell in your hands, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, lift the barbell up from your chest and press it straight up above your head. | 3. Lower the barbell back down to your chest.

1. Stand facing the landmine leaning forward slightly with the end of the barbell held in one hand at your shoulder with your elbow positioned beneath your wrist. | 2. While keeping your elbow pointed forward, drive the bar directly overhead, switching hands at the top of the movement. Lower the bar back down to the other side of your body, mirroring the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps, switching hands at the top of each rep.

Exercise Name: Landmine Half Kneeling Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start facing the landmine on one knee with your other foot in front of you while holding the barbell in one hand at your shoulder on the same side as the knee that is on the ground. | 2. Drive the bar upwards while keeping your elbow pointed forward until your arm holding the bar is fully extending, then control the bar as your lower it back to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps, then switch sides.

1. Start by lying flat on your back with your legs extended towards the landmine attachment and your arms overhead, holding the landmine barbell with both hands while engaging your core muscles by pressing your lower back into the ground and drawing your belly button in towards your spine. | 2. Lift your legs off the ground, keeping them together and straight, and simultaneously raise your upper body off the ground, reaching the landmine barbell away from your face. | 3. Hold this position for the desired duration, then carefully lower the barbell to the ground.

1. Start in a kneeling position facing the barbell with one hand holding the end of the barbell at your shoulder with your elbow tucked beneath your wrist. | 2. Keeping your elbow pointing forward, drive the barbell up overhead until your arm is fully extended and switch the bar to your other hand at the top of the movement. | 3. Control the descent of the bar to your other shoulder and repeat movement for desired reps, switching hands at the top of each rep.

1. Start kneeling in front of the landmine, facing towards it, with your knees hip-width apart and your back straight while holding the end of the bar in both hands in front of your chest. | 2. Push the landmine up overhead by fully extending your arms until the weight is directly over your head. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the landmine back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand perpendicularly to the barbell, holding the end of the bar at your outer hip with your inner hand and your palm facing your body. | 2. While keeping your core braced and your arm straight, lift the barbell diagonally up and towards the direction of the landmine attachment, then return the bar to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Stand facing the landmine attachment while holding the end of the bar with one hand at your shoulder on the same side with your elbow tucked to your body underneath your wrist. | 2. Step back with the leg on the same side that you are holding the bar on and with control lower yourself down into a lunge position while keeping your core engaged and torso tall, then drive through your front heel as you step back to the starting position. | 3. Once your feet are back in the starting position, drive the bar up overhead until your arm is fully extended, then lower the bar back down to the starting position. | 4. Repeated for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

1. Stand facing the landmine, holding the end of the bar in both hands with your palms facing each other. | 2. Extend your arms upward, pressing the end of the bar up overhead. Pause at the top of the movement, then lower the bar with control back to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Stand perpendicularly to the barbell with the end of the bar in front of your feet. Squat down and hold the end of the bar with your hand closer to the landmine attachment with your palm facing your body. | 2. Drive your feet into the ground to start the motion. As your legs fully extend, pull the bar upwards with your hand and start to rotate your torso in towards the landmine attachment. As you do so, bring your other hand up to the bar and switch your grip. Press through the bar to extend your arm all the way upright, pivoting your back foot to allow for more trunk rotation. | 3. Perform the movement in reverse to return to the starting position. Repeat for desired number of reps before switching sides.

1. Start sitting on the ground facing the landmine attachment with your legs open for stability while holding the end of the bar in a neutral grip with your hand resting at your shoulder and your elbow beneath your wrist. | 2. Leaning forward slightly, press the bar up into the air until your arm is fully extended. At the top of the movement, switch which hand is holding the end of the bar and lower the bar back down to the opposite shoulder. Perform again to return the bar to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

1. Sit on the ground facing the landmine with your legs spread. Hold the end of the bar in both hands in front of your chest with your palms facing each other. | 2. While keeping your torso tall and core brace, drive the end of the bar upward until your arms are fully extended. Lean forward slightly for full range of motion in the shoulder joints. Lower the bar back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps.

Exercise Name: Landmine Seated Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Sit on the ground facing the landmine with your legs spread. Hold the end of the bar in one hand in front of that shoulder with your palm facing across your body. | 2. While keeping your torso tall and your core braced, drive the bar upwards until your arm is fully extended, leaning forward slightly for full range of motion in the shoulder joint. Lower the bar back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for desired number of reps on one side, then switch sides.

1. Stand in front of the landmine with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with one hand, palm facing in, and bring it to shoulder height with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Press the barbell overhead by extending your arm fully, pushing the weight upward. Keep your core engaged, your back straight, and your shoulder down throughout the movement. Pause briefly at the top of the movement with your arm fully extended overhead. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position at shoulder height with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

1. Stand in front of the landmine with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the landmine barbell with one hand, palm facing in, and bring it to shoulder height with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Dip your body slightly then drive up through the ground to generate momentum as your extend your arm fully upwards. Pause briefly at the top of the rep, then lower the weight back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps on one side before switching sides.

Exercise Name: Landmine Single Arm Staggered Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Stand facing the bar in a split stance with one leg forward and bent and the other back and straight. Hold the bar in the hand on the side of the leg that is back with the end of the bar at your shoulder with your elbow tucked beneath your hand. | 2. Drive the bar upwards until your arm is fully extended. Pause briefly before lowering the end of the bar back down to the starting position with control. | 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.
1. Hold the end of the bar in front of you. | 2. Pop your hips, pull your elbows up to the ceiling, and get underneath the bar.

1. Hold the bar over one shoulder. Stand with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Dip at the hips and knees, generate some momentum and press the bar. | 3. As you press, split your stance. Bring the leg of the working arm back and the other forward.

1. Hold the bar with a goblet position. | 2. Push your hips back and sink into a squat. | 3. Push through your heels and squat back up. Use the momentum you generate at the legs to push the bar over head. | 4. Let the bar return to the goblet position before starting the next rep.

Exercise Name: Barbell Behind The Neck Seated Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Take a roughly shoulder width grip. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Push your head foward and press the weight toward the ceiling by extending at the elbow joint and flexing at the shoulder joint. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. With straight arms unrack the bar. | 3. Lower the bar to your mid chest | 4. Raise the bar (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Sit on an incline bench with an overhand grip on the barbell. Raise your arms until your fists are pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Return to the start under control. This exercise is prone to using momentum when you begin to fatigue.
1. Hold a barbell at shoulder height with a pronated grip. | 2. Press the barbell over your head. | 3. Lower it behind your head, then return to the front. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand tall with an overhand grip on the barbell. Raise your arms until your fists are pointed toward the ceiling. | 2. Return to the start under control. This exercise is prone to using momentum when you begin to fatigue.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip the barbell with a wide overhand grip, and keep your back straight and core engaged. | 2. Lift the barbell by explosively extending your hips, knees, and ankles while keeping the bar close to your body. | 3. As the bar reaches chest level, rotate your wrists and elbows up and back, transitioning into an overhead press. | 4. Fully extend your arms overhead, stabilize the bar, then lower it back to the starting position with control.

1. Start with the barbell on your shoulders in a front rack position, feet hip-width apart. Slightly bend your knees and dip straight down. | 2. Explosively extend your legs and push the barbell upward, generating momentum with your legs. | 3. As the bar rises, quickly split your legs (one forward, one back) and drop under the bar, locking your arms overhead. | 4. Bring your front foot back, then your back foot forward to a stable standing position with the bar locked overhead.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, barbell over midfoot. Grip the bar wide (outside shoulders), hook grip recommended. | 2. Keep chest up, back straight, and drive through heels to lift the bar off the ground, keeping it close to your body. | 3. As the bar reaches mid-thigh, explode upwards by extending hips, knees, and ankles, shrugging shoulders and pulling the bar high. | 4. Drop under the bar slightly, catching it overhead with arms locked out. Stand up fully to complete the lift.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, grip the bar just outside your knees. Pull the bar from the floor by driving through your legs, keeping your back straight. | 2. As the bar reaches your hips, extend explosively, shrug, and drop under to catch it in a front squat position with elbows high. Stand up tall. | 3. Dip slightly, then drive through your legs to push the bar overhead. | 4. Stabilize the bar overhead, lock arms, then bring feet together before lowering the bar safely.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, barbell over midfoot. Grip the bar wide with an overhand grip, chest up, and back straight. | 2. Lift the bar by driving through your legs, keeping it close to your body. Extend your hips and knees while maintaining a straight back. | 3. Explosively extend your hips, knees, and ankles while shrugging your shoulders. Pull yourself under the bar as it moves upward. | 4. Drop into a deep squat while locking the bar overhead. Stabilize, then stand up fully to complete the lift.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Maintain the natural arch in your back, squeezing your shoulder blades and raising your chest. | 2. Grip the bar across your shoulders and support it on your upper back. Unwrack the bar by straightening your legs, and take a step back. | 3. Bend your knees as you lower the weight without altering the form of your back until your hips are below your knees. | 4. Raise the bar back to starting position, lift with your legs and exhale at the top.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.
1. Set up rings at a high point. | 2. Grip rings and lean back, arms extended. | 3. Pull chest to rings, keeping body straight.

1. Stand holding gymnastic rings with your arms extended in front of you, palms facing up. | 2. Curl rings towards shoulders, squeezing biceps. | 3. Slowly lower rings back to starting position, keeping control. Repeat.
1. Grasp the chin-up bar with an overhand grip, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Place your feet on the ground, legs bent slightly. | 3. Use your legs to assist as you pull your chin above the bar.
1. Grasp the chin-up bar with an underhand grip, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Place your feet on the ground, legs bent slightly. | 3. Use your legs to assist as you pull your chin above the bar.
1. Grasp the chin-up bar with an underhand grip, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Place your feet on the ground, legs bent slightly. | 3. Use your legs to assist as you pull your chest to the bar.
1. Grasp the chin-up bar with a mixed grip, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Place your feet on the ground, legs bent slightly. | 3. Use your legs to assist as you pull your chin above the bar.
1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with an underhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.
1. Place your elbow on one knee and your hand underneath the other leg. Keep the leg that's over your hand extended. | 2. Curl the working arm and use your leg as the resistance.
1. Hang from a bar with your feet on the floor. | 2. Break at the elbows and curl your body towards the bar.
1. Grab the bar with a close grip. Feet on the floor. | 2. Break at the elbow and curl your body toward the bar.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body in an "L" position and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up and lean backwards. Try to touch your chest to the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the rings shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the rings. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the rings shoulder width apart with a pronated grip (palms facing away). | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up and rotate your fists until your chin is past the rings. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.
1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.
1. Use a bench or an object to elevate your feet. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat

1. Start in a plank position. Push your hips up toward the ceiling. | 2. Lower your head towards the floor by bending your elbows | 3. Push through your hands and return to the starting pike position. | 4. Repeat

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grab a door frame or a rack and place your feet near the frame. | 2. Start with your elbows extended, row your body towards your hands. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. Pull your legs up until you're in an "L" position. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.
1. Grasp the rings with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the rings. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Stand with your feet a little past shoulder width apart with a slight bend at your knee. Place your hands behind the back of your head. | 2. Keeping your back straight, rotate your hips to bring your shoulders down towards the floor. Stop when your chest is parallel with the floor.

1. Lie face down on the floor with your arms fully extended in front of you. | 2. Simultaneously raise your arms, legs and chest off of the floor and hold the position. | 3. Slowly lower your arms, legs and chest back to the starting position. Repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent and raise one leg. | 2. Without changing the bend in your knee, bend at your hips, and lower your torso until it's almost parallel to the floor. | 3. Tense your glutes and then bring yourself back to the starting position.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Lie face down on a stability ball, hands on the floor, legs extended straight. | 2. Engage glutes and lower back, raising legs until aligned with your torso. | 3. Slowly lower legs back down without touching the ground, maintaining core engagement. Repeat.

1. Lie face-down on a stability ball, hips centered, feet anchored, hands behind your head. | 2. Engage your core, lift your upper body until aligned with legs, keeping your neck neutral. | 3. Lower your torso slowly back to the starting position, maintaining control and steady breathing.

1. Place one knee on a bench. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Lay flat on your back with your knees bent and your feet flat on the ground, about a foot from your lower back. | 2. Place your fingertips on your temples with your palms facing out. | 3. Draw your belly into the base of your spine to engage the muscles, then raise your head and shoulders off the floor. Return to starting position and repeat.

1. Lay on your back with your arms palms down on either side. | 2. Keep your legs together and as straight as possible. | 3. Slowly raise your legs to a 90 angle, pause at this position, or as high as you can reach your legs, and then slowly lower your legs back down. | 4. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise.

1. Place forearms on the ground with your elbows bent at a 90 angle aligned beneath your shoulders, with your arms parallel at shoulder-width. | 2. Your feet should be together, with only your toes touching the floor. | 3. Lift your belly off the floor and form a straight line from your heels to the crown of your head and hold.

1. Grab the bar and hang, your body still and your legs straight. | 2. Slowly draw your knees up to your chest | 3. Once you have raised your knees as high as possible, lower your legs and repeat. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise. | 4. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise.

1. Hover your heels just off the ground. | 2. Stick your chest out and maintain a flat back. Make all the movement happen at your mid and upper spine. | 3. Point your chest to the left, then rotate at the spine until your chest is pointed right.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your hands further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Start in a kneeling position with your hands planted on the ground. | 2. Pick your knees up off the ground. Hold in this position with a flat back.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your arms extended over head. | 2. Pick your upper back and your legs off the ground. Your body should be in a banana shape. | 3. Hold in this position.

1. To perform a bodyweight mountain climber, start in a plank position with your hands placed directly under your shoulders. | 2. Bring your right knee towards your chest, keeping your foot close to your hand. Quickly switch legs, bringing your left knee towards your chest. | 3. Continue this movement, alternating legs, at a quick pace for a set amount of time or repetitions.

1. Start standing with your feet hip-width apart. Lower your body into a squat position, placing your hands on the ground in front of you. | 2. Quickly jump your feet back into a plank position, keeping your body in a straight line from your head to your toes. | 3. Perform a push-up, keeping your core tight and your elbows close to your body. | 4. Jump your feet back towards your hands, and then jump up into the air, reaching your arms overhead. | 5. Land softly and immediately lower your body back into the squat position to repeat the movement.
1. Lie on your back. | 2. Bend knees, hands behind head. | 3. Twist torso, touch elbow to opposite knee. Repeat.
1. Start on hands and knees. | 2. Extend right arm and left leg. | 3. Hold for a few seconds, then switch sides.

1. Lie on your back, arms extended upward, legs raised with knees bent. | 2. Lower opposite arm and leg to floor, keeping back pressed against ground. | 3. Alternate sides, maintain core engagement, and repeat for desired reps or time.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your elbows further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Lie flat, knees bent. | 2. Lift upper body. | 3. Lower back down
1. Sit in a v position. | 2. Pull legs and torso together. | 3. Extend back into the starting position.
1. Start from a kneeling plank position. | 2. Go to one elbow then the other. Try to avoid rocking back and forth.
1. Start from a plank position. | 2. Go to one elbow then the other. Try to avoid rocking back and forth.

1. Support your weight on forearms and toes. | 2. Ensure you maintain a neutral lower back (do not poke the bum into the air). | 3. Point your toes to push your bodyweight forward then drive the elbows into the ground to push your bodyweight back.
1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. | 2. Reach right hand to right heel. | 3. Switch sides, left hand to left heel. Repeat.

1. Perform a reverse crunch and then kick your legs up toward the ceiling. | 2. Flex at the hips and knees until your hips land back on the bench, then kick your legs back out to the starting position.
1. Perform a reverse crunch and then kick your legs up toward the ceiling. | 2. With your hips and knees extended, lower yourself slowly back to the start position.
1. Lie on your back, arms by sides, legs straight. | 2. Lift one leg to a 45-degree angle. | 3. Lower leg, lift opposite leg; alternate smoothly.
1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat on the floor. | 2. Raise both knees towards your chest. | 3. Lower back down without touching the floor; repeat for desired reps.

1. Lie on your back, legs bent and lifted off the ground. | 2. Lower one leg to the ground until your foot taps the ground, keep your other leg up. | 3. Alternate sides for the prescribed amount of reps.
1. Lie on your back, hands under your buttocks or on the ground for support. | 2. Lift legs off the ground, alternate crossing them in a scissor motion.
1. Lift both legs off the ground. | 2. Bring both legs outward, then cross both legs over one another. | 3. Alternating which leg goes on top.
1. Lay flat on your back with both hands over one leg. | 2. Reach toward your knee flexing your abs and obliques. | 3. Do the prescribed amount of reps, then switch sides.
1. Lie on your back, knees bent, hands behind head. | 2. Crunch up, flexing the spine and your abs.
1. Lay on your back with knees bent and your feet together. | 2. Keep your arms extended overhead. Swing your arms to generate some momentum and sit up.
1. Begin in an elbow plank position with your core engaged. | 2. Bring your right knee towards your right elbow. | 3. Return to plank, then switch legs quickly. Repeat.

1. To perform a bodyweight mountain climber, start in a plank position with your hands placed directly under your shoulders. | 2. Bring your right knee towards your chest, keeping your foot close to your hand. Quickly switch legs, bringing your left knee towards your chest. | 3. Continue this movement, alternating legs, at a slow pace for a set amount of time or repetitions.
1. Start in a plank position with hands under shoulders. | 2. Jump one foot forward, switch legs mid-air. | 3. Alternate legs quickly, maintaining a steady plank.

1. Start in a plank position with hands directly under shoulders. | 2. Drive knees toward left elbow. | 3. Go back to starting position, then drive knees to right elbow, mimicking a zigzag slalom motion.
1. Begin in a plank position, hands under shoulders, feet together. | 2. Jump feet forward, landing outside hands in a low squat. | 3. Explode back to plank, repeat continuously for desired reps.

1. Grasp the rings, keeping your arms extended and your shoulders away from your ears. | 2. Keep your abs engaged, roll forward onto your toes, and extend your arms in front of you. | 3. Slowly lower your body down toward the ground, keeping your arms straight and your abs engaged. | 4. When your head gets between your arms, pause for a moment and then use your abs to pull your body back up to the starting position.
1. Grip bar, hang with arms extended, body straight. | 2. Engage core, lift knees towards chest. | 3. Hold that position for the specified amount of time.
1. Grip bar, hang with arms extended, body straight. | 2. Engage core, lift knees towards chest. | 3. Lower legs back down, maintain controlled movement.

1. Start in a plank position, hands under shoulders, body straight. | 2. Jump feet wide, then back together, like a jumping jack. | 3. Keep core tight, maintain plank form, repeat for desired time or reps.

1. Start in a plank position. | 2. Raise your arm out in front of you. | 3. Return to the starting position, then raise the opposing arm. | 4. Make sure to keep your hips stable. If you're unable to, try performing this exercise from the knees.
1. Hang from a bar with arms fully extended. | 2. Lift legs to form an "L" shape. | 3. Hold for allotted amount of time keeping your abs flexed.

1. Lie on your back, holding a stability ball between your feet, arms extended overhead. | 2. Engage your core, lift your legs and arms, passing the ball from feet to hands. | 3. Lower arms and legs back down, then repeat, passing the ball back to feet.

1. Lie on your back, legs extended, stability ball between your feet, arms out for support. | 2. Engage your core, lift your legs, and rotate them side to side in a controlled motion. | 3. Keep your upper body stable, move slowly, and return to center before switching directions.

1. Place feet on a stability ball, hands on the floor in a push-up position. | 2. Lower your chest toward the floor, then push up while tucking knees toward your chest. | 3. Extend legs back to starting position, maintaining control and stability throughout the movement.
1. Place your feet on the ball and get in to a plank position. | 2. Pull your hips straight up toward the ceiling. | 3. Lower your hips until you're back in a plank position.

1. Start in a plank position with your feet on a stability ball and hands on the floor. | 2. Engage your core and tuck your knees toward your chest, rolling the ball forward carefully. | 3. Extend your legs back to the starting position, maintaining balance and control throughout the movement.

1. Kneel behind a stability ball, place forearms on top, and engage your core muscles. | 2. Lift knees, balance on toes, and slowly move forearms in small controlled circles. | 3. Maintain a stable torso, avoid excessive movement, and reverse direction after several rotations.
1. Start by lying flat on your back on a ball with your feet flat on the floor and your knees bent. | 2. Engage your core muscles and flex your spine until you feel your abs contract.

1. Lay on your back with your arms palms down on either side. | 2. Keep your legs together and as straight as possible. | 3. Slowly raise your legs to a 90 angle, pause at this position, or as high as you can reach your legs, and then slowly lower your legs back down. | 4. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise.

1. Grab the bar and hang, your body still and your legs straight. | 2. Slowly draw your knees up to your chest | 3. Once you have raised your knees as high as possible, lower your legs and repeat. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise. | 4. Duration of these movements should be slow so that you do not utilize momentum, enabling you to get the most out of the exercise.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your hands further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Start in a kneeling position with your hands planted on the ground. | 2. Pick your knees up off the ground. Hold in this position with a flat back.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your arms extended over head. | 2. Pick your upper back and your legs off the ground. Your body should be in a banana shape. | 3. Hold in this position.

1. To perform a bodyweight mountain climber, start in a plank position with your hands placed directly under your shoulders. | 2. Bring your right knee towards your chest, keeping your foot close to your hand. Quickly switch legs, bringing your left knee towards your chest. | 3. Continue this movement, alternating legs, at a quick pace for a set amount of time or repetitions.
1. Lie on your back. | 2. Bend knees, hands behind head. | 3. Twist torso, touch elbow to opposite knee. Repeat.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your elbows further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Sit in a v position. | 2. Pull legs and torso together. | 3. Extend back into the starting position.
1. Lie on your back, arms by sides, legs straight. | 2. Lift one leg to a 45-degree angle. | 3. Lower leg, lift opposite leg; alternate smoothly.
1. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat on the floor. | 2. Raise both knees towards your chest. | 3. Lower back down without touching the floor; repeat for desired reps.

1. To perform a bodyweight mountain climber, start in a plank position with your hands placed directly under your shoulders. | 2. Bring your right knee towards your chest, keeping your foot close to your hand. Quickly switch legs, bringing your left knee towards your chest. | 3. Continue this movement, alternating legs, at a slow pace for a set amount of time or repetitions.
1. Grip bar, hang with arms extended, body straight. | 2. Engage core, lift knees towards chest. | 3. Hold that position for the specified amount of time.
1. Grip bar, hang with arms extended, body straight. | 2. Engage core, lift knees towards chest. | 3. Lower legs back down, maintain controlled movement.
1. Place your feet on the ball and get in to a plank position. | 2. Pull your hips straight up toward the ceiling. | 3. Lower your hips until you're back in a plank position.

1. Start in a plank position with your feet on a stability ball and hands on the floor. | 2. Engage your core and tuck your knees toward your chest, rolling the ball forward carefully. | 3. Extend your legs back to the starting position, maintaining balance and control throughout the movement.

1. Lay flat on your back with your knees bent and your feet flat on the ground, about a foot from your lower back. | 2. Place your fingertips on your temples with your palms facing out. | 3. Draw your belly into the base of your spine to engage the muscles, then raise your head and shoulders off the floor. Return to starting position and repeat.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your hands further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Start in a kneeling position with your hands planted on the ground. | 2. Pick your knees up off the ground. Hold in this position with a flat back.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your arms extended over head. | 2. Pick your upper back and your legs off the ground. Your body should be in a banana shape. | 3. Hold in this position.
1. Lie on your back. | 2. Bend knees, hands behind head. | 3. Twist torso, touch elbow to opposite knee. Repeat.

1. Start in a hand plank position and walk your elbows further out until your ears are between your biceps. | 2. Hold in this position for the allotted amount of time. | 3. Make sure you keep a flat back for the whole set.
1. Lie flat, knees bent. | 2. Lift upper body. | 3. Lower back down

1. Point your toes into the floor. | 2. Slowly walk forwards and backward | 3. Keep your heels in the air as long as possible while walking. | 4. It may be beneficial to do this last at the end of your workout.

1. Balance on the balls of your feet on the platform or plates, leaning forward to use the wall to assist with balance. | 2. Lower the heels of your feet towards the ground and pause, then push through the balls of your feet like you are standing tip toe, pausing at the apex of the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.
1. Walk forward and push your toe into the ground | 2. Lift you heel off the ground each step and tense your calf muscle | 3. Repeat on each leg and walk forward slowly
1. Hold on to something for balance. | 2. Hinge forward and maintain that position. Calf raise until you feel a contraction in your calfs.

1. Hold onto something for balance. Raise one foot off the ground. | 2. Raise your heel upwards while keeping your knees stationary. | 3. Pause when your heels are fully extended and then slowly return to the starting position and repeat.
1. Sit on a box or bench, place your heels on a step or plate. | 2. Raise your toes straight toward the ceiling.

1. Balance on the balls of your feet on the platform or plates, leaning forward to use the wall to assist with balance. | 2. Lower the heels of your feet towards the ground and pause, then push through the balls of your feet like you are standing tip toe, pausing at the apex of the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.
1. Walk forward and push your toe into the ground | 2. Lift you heel off the ground each step and tense your calf muscle | 3. Repeat on each leg and walk forward slowly

1. Hold onto something for balance. Raise one foot off the ground. | 2. Raise your heel upwards while keeping your knees stationary. | 3. Pause when your heels are fully extended and then slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.
1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with an underhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grab a door frame or a rack and place your feet near the frame. | 2. Start with your elbows extended, row your body towards your hands. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body in an "L" position and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.
1. Hang from a bar with arms fully extended. | 2. Lift legs to form an "L" shape. | 3. Hold for allotted amount of time keeping your abs flexed.
1. Grip a pull-up bar with palms facing forward. | 2. Hang with arms fully extended. | 3. Hold for recommended amount of time, keeping your core engaged.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up and lean backwards. Try to touch your chest to the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the rings shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you) | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the rings. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Grab the rings shoulder width apart with a pronated grip (palms facing away). | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up and rotate your fists until your chin is past the rings. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Lie down with your knees bent and your feet flat on the floor. | 2. Push your hips up so that your butt is elevated and your back straight. | 3. Tense your glutes and raise your hips towards the ceiling. | 4. Once you are at the highest point you can manage, hold the position for a few seconds, and then slowly return to the starting position

1. Stand with your back to a bench (or raised surface) and place one of your feet on the bench. | 2. Squat down until your front leg is about parallel to the floor. | 3. Go back to the starting position. After completing the desired amount of reps, switch legs and repeat.

1. Tense your glutes and raise your hips towards the ceiling. | 2. Once you are at the highest point you can manage, hold the position for a few seconds, and then slowly return to the starting position. | 3. Push your hips up, so that your butt is elevated and your back straight. | 4. Lie down with one knee bent and and one with a slight bend.
1. Take a slow, lateral step to the right. | 2. Extend the left knee, and drive your weight into your right side. | 3. Flex your knee and lower your body. | 4. Push back to the starting position.

1. Step forward with one leg. | 2. Lower your body until your rear knee nearly touches the ground. | 3. Ensure you remain upright, and your front knee stay above the front foot. | 4. Push off the floor with your front foot until you return to the starting position. Switch legs.
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Start by doing a regular squat, then engage your core and jump up explosively. | 3. When you land, lower your body back into the squat position.
1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. flex your knees and hips and sit back into the squat while lowering your body | 3. Continue down to full depth | 4. Return to starting position.

1. Stand with your feet a little past shoulder width apart with a slight bend at your knee. Place your hands behind the back of your head. | 2. Keeping your back straight, rotate your hips to bring your shoulders down towards the floor. Stop when your chest is parallel with the floor.

1. Get down on all fours and position your hands under your shoulders and your knees under your hips. | 2. Kick back with one leg and squeeze your glutes. | 3. Slowly return to starting position by bending your knee and lowering your leg. | 4. Switch Legs. Repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent and raise one leg. | 2. Without changing the bend in your knee, bend at your hips, and lower your torso until it's almost parallel to the floor. | 3. Tense your glutes and then bring yourself back to the starting position.

1. Grab a stick of some sort or hold onto something stable (rack, bench). | 2. Grab a box that is knee height or slightly lower. | 3. Hold the stick in your right arm and put your right leg on the box. | 4. Begin your squat by breaking at the knees. Get your knee close to the floor or all the way to the floor. Make sure to keep your chest tall.

1. Step your left foot diagonally behind your right leg, crossing it behind your body. Bend your knees and lower your hips until your left thigh is parallel to the floor and your right knee is hovering just above the ground. | 2. Push through your right foot to straighten your legs and return to the starting position. | 3. Repeat the movement with your other leg.

1. Step forward with one leg and lower your body until your front thigh is parallel to the floor and your back knee almost touches the ground. Keep your chest up and your front foot flat on the floor. | 2. Push through your front foot to straighten your legs and return to the starting position. | 3. Repeat the movement with your other leg.

1. Place your heels on a plate or very low step. | 2. Keep your chest tall and initiate the squat by pushing your hips back and breaking at the knees. | 3. You should notice yourself able to squat lower than normal.

1. Engage your core by drawing your belly button towards your spine. This will help to stabilize your body. | 2. Take a large step to the side with your right foot, planting it firmly on the ground. | 3. As you step, bend your right knee and lower your hips until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. Your left leg should remain straight. | 4. Push through your right heel to return to the starting position. Repeat on the opposite side by stepping out with your left foot.
1. Take a split stance. Make sure to keep your chest tall. | 2. Bring your rear knee to the floor or close to it. | 3. Drive through your front heel and your rear foot back to the starting position.

1. Start standing with your feet hip-width apart. Lower your body into a squat position, placing your hands on the ground in front of you. | 2. Quickly jump your feet back into a plank position, keeping your body in a straight line from your head to your toes. | 3. Perform a push-up, keeping your core tight and your elbows close to your body. | 4. Jump your feet back towards your hands, and then jump up into the air, reaching your arms overhead. | 5. Land softly and immediately lower your body back into the squat position to repeat the movement.

Exercise Name: Bodyweight Feet Elevated Figure Four Glute Bridge
Instructions: 1. Start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet on top of a sturdy box, bench or elevated surface. | 2. Drive through your heels to lift your hips off the floor, making sure to keep your feet and knees pointing forward.

1. Start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet on top of a sturdy box, bench or elevated surface. | 2. Drive through your heels to lift your hips off the floor, making sure to keep your feet and knees pointing forward.

Exercise Name: Bodyweight Feet Elevated Single Leg Glute Bridge
Instructions: 1. Start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet on top of a sturdy box, bench or elevated surface. Lift one leg off the box. | 2. Drive through your heel to lift your hips off the floor, making sure to keep your feet and knees pointing forward.

Exercise Name: Bodyweight Feet Elevated Staggered Glute Bridge
Instructions: 1. Start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet in a staggered position on the box. | 2. Drive through your heels to lift your hips off the floor, making sure to keep your feet and knees pointing forward.

1. Stand in front of a box. | 2. *Start with a low box if this is your first time* | 3. Sink into a quarter of half squat and then pop your hips forward. | 4. Try to land in the middle of the box as softly as possible to minimise impact on your joints.

1. Stand on top of a box. Step off of the box and land on the floor. | 2. Land as softly as possible. Squat as you land to minimise impact on your joints. | 3. Go straight into another hop after you've landed. This will help you learn to absorb impact.
1. Setup two boxes. One to jump on and one to sit. | 2. Go from a seated position and pop your hips forward forcefully. | 3. Jump and land on the box softly.
1. Stand with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Jump onto your box and land with one foot. | 3. Try to land in the middle of the box and land as softly as possible.
1. Start in a standing position. | 2. Lunge forward, switch legs mid-air. | 3. Land and repeat.

Exercise Name: Bodyweight Figure Four Heels Elevated Hip Thrust
Instructions: 1. Start by lying on a bench with your foot resting on top of a box, and cross one leg over the other. | 2. Push through your heels and raise your hips towards the ceiling, keeping your feet flat on the box. | 3. Engage your glutes at the top of the movement, pause briefly and then lower your hips back down to the starting position.
1. Put your shoulder blades on a bench. Both feet on a low box or a plate. | 2. Start with your hips up. | 3. Drop your hips and then push your hips up toward the ceiling.
1. Start with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Jump laterally and fall into a squat. Tap the ground. | 3. Jump the opposite direction
1. Hold a dumbbell in goblet position. | 2. Squat down to parallel depth and then halfway back up. | 3. Stay in this short range of motion for the duration of the set.

Exercise Name: Bodyweight Single Leg Heels Elevated Hip Thrust
Instructions: 1. Start by lying on a bench with your foot on a plate or low box. | 2. Lift one leg off the ground and engage your glutes to raise your hips up towards the ceiling. | 3. From this starting position, slowly lower your hips back down to the starting position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width. | 2. Step forward with your right foot and bend both knees to lower your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. | 3. Push off your right foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Step back with the same leg until the back knee taps the floor.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width. | 2. Step forward with your right foot and bend both knees to lower your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. | 3. Push off your right foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Step back with the same leg until the back knee taps the floor.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Start by doing a regular squat, then engage your core and jump up explosively. | 3. Narrow your stance while in the air, and land softly. Go directly into another rep.

1. Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart and hold a pole overhead, using an overhand grip. | 2. Begin the squat by bending at the hips and knees, keeping your core tight and the dumbbells balanced overhead. | 3. Lower your body as far as you can while keeping the dumbbells overhead, then push back up to the starting position. | 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, making sure to keep your back straight, chest lifted, and the dumbbells stable overhead throughout the entire movement.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Start by doing a regular squat, tap the floor, then engage your core and jump up explosively. | 3. Bring your feet mostly together, tap your toes back to the floor, then bring your feet back their original width.
1. Place the barbell on your back | 2. Step your foot back and around while simultaneously bringing the weight down. | 3. Return to start and repeat on other leg.
1. Stand tall, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step right, lunge to side. | 3. Return, then lunge left.
1. Stand with feet together. | 2. Step back with right foot. | 3. Return to starting position, then lunge with left foot.
1. Abduct at the hips and raise your leg out to the side. | 2. Return to the starting position and stop just short of your foot touching back to the ground (to keep tension on the muscle).

1. Begin by standing in front of a sturdy box or bench that is about knee-height. | 2. Place your right foot on the box and push through the heel to lift your body up and onto the box, bring your off leg all the way through until your leg is parallel with the ground. | 3. Step back down with your right foot, lowering your left foot to the ground.

Exercise Name: Hamstring Bridge With Elevated Legs Box Unilateral
Instructions: 1. Lie on your back. Place one heel on a box or bench, having a 90 angle at hip and knee. | 2. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt (flatten your lower back against the ground). | 3. Push through your heel into the box, lifting your hips up to the point where there is a straight line from your chest to your knees.

Exercise Name: Hamstring Bridge With Elevated Legs Box Bilateral
Instructions: 1. Lie on your back. Place your heels on a box or bench, having a 90 angle at hips and knees. | 2. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt (flatten your lower back against the ground). | 3. Push through your heels into the box, lifting your hips up to the point where there is a straight line from your chest to your knees.

1. Lie on your back with knees slightly bent and heels dug in. | 2. Perform a posterior pelvic tilt (flatten your lower back on the ground). | 3. Press the heels into the ground to raise your hips off it. | 4. Hold the position for the specified duration.

Exercise Name: Glute Bridge Isometric Hold Single Alternate
Instructions: 1. Lie on your back. Bend your knees so your feet are flat on the floor with heels under knees | 2. Push through your heels into the ground, lifting your hips up to the point where there is a straight line from your chest to your knees. Squeeze your bum at the top of the movement | 3. Maintain the top position and extend one leg at the time.

1. Lie down with your knees bent and your feet flat on the floor. | 2. Push your hips up so that your butt is elevated and your back straight. | 3. Tense your glutes and raise your hips towards the ceiling. | 4. Once you are at the highest point you can manage, hold the position for a few seconds, and raise one leg off the ground. | 5. Lower slowly to the start position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Step forward with your right foot and bend both knees to lower your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. | 3. Push off your right foot to return to the starting position. Then switch legs.

1. Take a step forward shifting your weight onto the front leg. | 2. Bend the knee of the front leg so the knee of the back leg comes close to the ground. | 3. Stand up and go into lunging with the opposite leg.

1. Stand in front of a box or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart. | 2. Lower your body into a squat position, sitting back onto the box and pausing for a moment before standing back up. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the standing position.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, one foot slightly behind. | 2. Lower into a squat, keeping weight on front heel. | 3. Return to standing, engaging glutes and core.

1. Sit with one leg in front of you flat on the ground. | 2. While the other leg is to your side, also flat on the ground with your foot pointed backwards. | 3. Hold this position for the prescribed amount of time then change sides.
1. Stand on one leg, extend the other forward for balance. | 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and core tight. | 3. Press through your heel to stand back up, repeat.
1. Stand on a platform, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step back, lowering knee toward floor, keeping chest upright and core engaged. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.
1. Place your foot on a plate or a low box. | 2. Put all of your weight on your front foot and lean forward. | 3. Lower until your calves touch your hamstrings and then extend back up.

1. Stand on a platform, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step back, lowering knee toward floor, keeping chest upright and core engaged. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start, keeping bar stable throughout.

Exercise Name: Stability Ball Single Leg Hip Thrust
Instructions: 1. Lie on the ball, one foot on the ground. | 2. Lift one leg off the ground and engage your glutes to raise your hips up towards the ceiling. | 3. From this starting position, slowly lower your hips back down to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Stability Ball Straight Leg Glute Bridge
Instructions: 1. Lie on your back, heels on a stability ball, legs straight, arms by your sides. | 2. Press through your heels, lift hips, engage glutes and core, forming a straight line. | 3. Slowly lower hips, maintaining control, then repeat for reps.

1. Start by lying flat on your back with your feet resting on top of a ball. | 2. Push through your heels and raise your hips towards the ceiling, keeping your feet flat on the bar. | 3. Engage your glutes at the top of the movement, pause briefly and then lower your hips back down to the starting position.

1. Sit on the floor, place upper back on a stability ball, feet flat, knees bent. | 2. Drive hips upward by squeezing glutes, forming a straight line from shoulders to knees. | 3. Lower hips slowly without touching the floor, maintaining core engagement, then repeat.

1. Lie face down on a stability ball, hands on the floor, legs extended straight. | 2. Engage glutes and lower back, raising legs until aligned with your torso. | 3. Slowly lower legs back down without touching the ground, maintaining core engagement. Repeat.

1. Lie face-down on a stability ball, hips centered, feet anchored, hands behind your head. | 2. Engage your core, lift your upper body until aligned with legs, keeping your neck neutral. | 3. Lower your torso slowly back to the starting position, maintaining control and steady breathing.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, placing a stability ball between your lower back and wall. | 2. Slowly squat down by bending knees to 90 degrees, keeping back straight and core engaged. | 3. Press through heels, straighten legs, and return to standing while maintaining balance and control.

1. Place one knee on a bench. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knee mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Step your left foot diagonally behind your right leg, crossing it behind your body. Bend your knees and lower your hips until your left thigh is parallel to the floor and your right knee is hovering just above the ground. | 2. Push through your right foot to straighten your legs and return to the starting position. | 3. Repeat the movement with your other leg.
1. Place the barbell on your back | 2. Step your foot back and around while simultaneously bringing the weight down. | 3. Return to start and repeat on other leg.
1. Abduct at the hips and raise your leg out to the side. | 2. Return to the starting position and stop just short of your foot touching back to the ground (to keep tension on the muscle).

1. Stand in front of a box. | 2. *Start with a low box if this is your first time* | 3. Sink into a quarter of half squat and then pop your hips forward. | 4. Try to land in the middle of the box as softly as possible to minimise impact on your joints.

1. Stand on top of a box. Step off of the box and land on the floor. | 2. Land as softly as possible. Squat as you land to minimise impact on your joints. | 3. Go straight into another hop after you've landed. This will help you learn to absorb impact.
1. Setup two boxes. One to jump on and one to sit. | 2. Go from a seated position and pop your hips forward forcefully. | 3. Jump and land on the box softly.
1. Stand with a shoulder width stance. | 2. Jump onto your box and land with one foot. | 3. Try to land in the middle of the box and land as softly as possible.

1. Sit on the floor, place upper back on a stability ball, feet flat, knees bent. | 2. Drive hips upward by squeezing glutes, forming a straight line from shoulders to knees. | 3. Lower hips slowly without touching the floor, maintaining core engagement, then repeat.

1. Stand with your feet a little past shoulder width apart with a slight bend at your knee. Place your hands behind the back of your head. | 2. Keeping your back straight, rotate your hips to bring your shoulders down towards the floor. Stop when your chest is parallel with the floor.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent and raise one leg. | 2. Without changing the bend in your knee, bend at your hips, and lower your torso until it's almost parallel to the floor. | 3. Tense your glutes and then bring yourself back to the starting position.

1. Go to your knees and ask someone to hold your ankles. | 2. Put your hands in front of you | 3. With a slight bend in your knees slowly bring your body to the ground (slower is better) | 4. Push up and reset to the starting position.

1. Take a big step backwards with your left leg, lowering your body until your left thigh is parallel to the ground and your right knee is bent at a 90-degree angle. | 2.
