Instructions: 1. Begin with the kettlebell between your legs. | 2. Hinge at your hips, and lift to shoulder, then press overhead.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Sit tall and try not to arch your spine as you're pressing. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly.
1. Start flat on your back with the kettlebells extended over you. | 2. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.
1. Start flat on your back with a kettlebell extended over you. | 2. Bring your elbow to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.

1. Be careful getting the KB into place overhead. Push your elbows forward while keeping your elbows tucked in. | 2. Look for what feels like a stretch in your triceps. Extend your elbows until your fists are pointed at the ceiling.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Bottoms Up Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding one kettlebell with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebell to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebell are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.
1. Lie on bench, hold kettlebell with both hands over chest. | 2. Lower kettlebells, elbows flared. | 3. Press kettlebells upward, fully extending arms. Repeat.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Kneeling Bottoms Up Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by taking a kneeling position and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Lie on the floor with your upper back and soles of feet on the floor, knees bent, and pelvis and lower back suspended in the air. | 2. Hold the kettlebell in both hands directly above your chest. | 3. Keeping your upper arms in place, bend your elbows to bring the kettlebell to the floor above your head. | 4. Return the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.

1. Be careful getting the KB into place overhead. Push your elbows forward while keeping your elbows tucked in. | 2. Look for what feels like a stretch in your triceps. Extend your elbows until your fists are pointed at the ceiling.

1. Standing up straight with feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Holding the kettlebell in both hands in front of your pelvis, engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. | 3. Release the shrug and repeat

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Holding the kettlebell in both hands engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. Release the shrug.

1. Leaning across the back section of the bench, with feet firmly on the floor and with arms hanging to the sides. | 2. Holding the kettlebell in both hands engage your shoulder blades, as if you are trying to touch them together. Release the shrug.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold one kettlebell in each hand at your sides. | 2. Lift your shoulders upward while keeping arms straight. | 3. Lower shoulders back down, repeat for desired reps.

1. Start with a kettlebell between your legs, hinge at hips, swing it upward. | 2. Lift kettlebell to chest level, elbows high, engaging shoulders. | 3. Lower kettlebell back down, maintaining control. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold one kettlebell in each hand at your sides. | 2. Lift your shoulders upward while keeping arms straight. | 3. Lower shoulders back down, repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold one kettlebell in each hand at your sides, and lean forward. | 2. Lift your shoulders backward while keeping arms straight. | 3. Lower shoulders back down, repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Standing up straight, using a bench as a step, raise one foot onto the bench and hold the kettlebell in the same arm as the straight leg. | 2. Stand and bring both feet onto the bench. Slowly lower your leg back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat.

1. Hold the weight tucked into your upper chest area, keeping your elbows in. Your feet should be slightly wider than your shoulders. | 2. Sink down into the squat, keeping your elbows inside the track of your knees. | 3. Push through your heels while keeping your chest up and return to the starting position.

1. Hold the weight tucked into your upper chest area, keeping your elbows in. Your feet should be slightly wider than your shoulders and the heels slightly raised on a surface. | 2. Sink down into the squat, keeping your elbows inside the track of your knees. | 3. Push through your heels while keeping your chest up and return to the starting position.

1. Stand straight with your feet slightly apart and hold a kettlebell in one hand. | 2. Bring the same leg as the arm holding the kettlebell behind you, squat down until your back knee touches the ground, keeping your back straight. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand straight with your feet slightly apart and hold a kettlebell in one hand. | 2. Bring the same leg as the arm holding the kettlebell in front of you, squat down until your thigh is parallel to the ground, keeping your back straight. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand straight with your feet shoulder width apart. Keep your back straight and hold the kettlebell in front of your pelvis. | 2. Take a large step to one side, holding the kettlebell low and lunge into the bent leg. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat
1. Hold kettlebell at your side. | 2. Step forward, lunge, and return. | 3. Repeat with opposite leg.
1. Hold kettlebells in front rack. | 2. Step back and lunge diagonally.
1. Start with kettlebells in front rack. | 2. Step forward into lunge. | 3. Return to starting position.
1. Hold kettlebell in front rack. | 2. Step sideways into a lunge position. | 3. Return to start position. Repeat.
1. Start with kettlebell in front rack. | 2. Step back into lunge. | 3. Return to start position.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Front Rack Single Arm Lateral Lunge
Instructions: 1. Hold kettlebell in front rack. | 2. Step sideways, lunge.
1. Hold kettlebells close to chest. | 2. Squat down, keeping chest up. | 3. Stand up, extending hips fully.
1. Hold kettlebells in front of you. | 2. Step sideways, lunge down and let the kettlebells land between your legs. | 3. Push off, return to start. Repeat.
1. Hold kettlebells at your side. | 2. Step backward, lower body.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Front Rack Forward Lunge
Instructions: 1. Hold kettlebell in front rack position. | 2. Step forward, lunge. Bringing your back knee to the floor. | 3. Extend your knee and return to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Front Rack Reverse Lunge
Instructions: 1. Hold kettlebell in front rack position. | 2. Step backward, lunge. Bring your back knee to the floor. | 3. Extend your knee back into the starting position.

1. Stand with feet wide apart, toes pointing slightly outward, and kettlebell on the floor between your feet. | 2. Bend at hips and knees, keeping back straight, and grip the kettlebell handle. | 3. Lift the kettlebell by extending hips and knees, stand up straight, and return to the starting position.

1. Standing up straight, using a bench as a step, raise one foot onto the bench and hold the kettlebell in the same arm as the straight leg. | 2. Stand and bring both feet onto the bench. Slowly lower your leg back down to the starting position. | 3. Repeat.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Front Rack Step Up
Instructions: 1. Stand in front of a step or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell at one shoulder. | 2. Step up onto the bench with your right foot, pushing off your foot to raise your body up onto the bench.

1. Stand in front of a step or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold kettlebells at your shoulders. | 2. Step up onto the bench with your right foot, pushing off your foot to raise your body up onto the bench.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Step Up Balance
Instructions: 1. Begin by standing in front of a sturdy box or bench that is about knee-height, holding a kettlebell in one hand | 2. Place your right foot on the box and push through the heel to lift your body up and onto the box, keeping your left foot off the ground. | 3. Step back down with your right foot, lowering your left foot to the ground.

1. Stand in front of a box or bench with your feet shoulder-width apart with a kettlebell in a goblet position. | 2. Lower your body into a squat position, sitting back onto the box and pausing for a moment before standing back up. | 3. Push through your heels to return to the standing position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, one foot slightly behind. Hold kettlebell in a goblet position. | 2. Lower into a squat, keeping weight on front heel. | 3. Return to standing, engaging glutes and core.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width. Kettlebell at your side. | 2. Step forward with your right foot and bend both knees to lower your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground. | 3. Push off your right foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Step back with the same leg until the back knee taps the floor.
1. Hold a kettlebell at your chest, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step one leg diagonally back into a lunge. | 3. Alternate legs, keeping your chest up and core engaged.
1. Hold one kettlebell with one or both hands, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step out to one side, bending the knee. | 3. Push off, return to center, then switch sides.

1. Hold two kettlebells by your side. | 2. Take a big step backwards with your left leg, lowering your body until your left thigh is parallel to the ground and your right knee is bent at a 90-degree angle. | 3. Push back up and switch legs, alternating each rep.

1. Stand tall, holding kettlebells by your sides, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step forward with one leg, lowering until both knees form 90 angles. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start, and switch legs.

1. Grab a stick of some sort or hold onto something stable (rack, bench). | 2. Grab a box that is knee height or slightly lower. | 3. Hold the stick in your right arm, kettlebell in the other and put your right leg on the box. | 4. Begin your squat by breaking at the knees. Get your knee close to the floor or all the way to the floor. Make sure to keep your chest tall.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Front Rack Deficit Reverse Lunge
Instructions: 1. Stand on a platform, kettlebells in front rack position, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step back, lowering knee toward floor, keeping chest upright and core engaged. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start.

1. Stand on a platform, kettlebells in each hand, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step back, lowering knee toward floor, keeping chest upright and core engaged. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start.

1. Place your foot on a plate or a low box. Hold two kettlebells in each hand. | 2. Put all of your weight on your front foot and lean forward. | 3. Lower until your calves touch your hamstrings and then extend back up.
1. Hold a kettlebell at your chest, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step one leg diagonally back into a lunge. | 3. Alternate legs, keeping your chest up and core engaged.
1. Hold kettlebell in front rack. | 2. Step sideways into a lunge position. | 3. Return to start position. Repeat.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Front Rack Single Arm Lateral Lunge
Instructions: 1. Hold kettlebell in front rack. | 2. Step sideways, lunge.
1. Hold kettlebells in front of you. | 2. Step sideways, lunge down and let the kettlebells land between your legs. | 3. Push off, return to start. Repeat.
1. Hold a kettlebell at your chest, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step one leg diagonally back into a lunge. | 3. Alternate legs, keeping your chest up and core engaged.
1. Hold a kettlebell at your chest, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step one leg diagonally back into a lunge. | 3. Alternate legs, keeping your chest up and core engaged.

1. Laying on the floor with your knees bent and feet firmly on the floor, hold the kettlebell at your chest with both hands. | 2. Fully extend your arms, raising the kettlebell until your elbows are locked. | 3. Lower the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.

1. Lie on the floor with your knees bent and feet firmly on the floor, with your arms to the side of your body. | 2. Holding a kettlebell in one hand, keeping your arm fully extended with a slight bend in the elbow and your forearms facing upwards, lift the kettlebell above your chest. | 3. Lower the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.

1. Laying on the floor with your knees bent and feet firmly on the floor, leave one arm resting to the side of the body. | 2. Using the other arm, hold the kettlebell at arms length directly upwards of your shoulder. | 3. Lower your arm until your upper arm to elbow is resting on the floor. | 4. Return to starting position.

1. Starting in a press up position with feet wide and one hand resting on the kettlebell, complete a full press up, lowering your chest towards the ground while keeping your body straight and returning to the starting position. | 2. Swap hands on the kettlebell, placing the hand originally on the kettlebell underneath your shoulder, complete another press up. | 3. Repeat.
1. Lie on a bench, hold kettlebells above chest. | 2. Lower them to chest, then push up. | 3. Repeat for desired reps, maintaining form.
1. Lie on bench, hold kettlebell with both hands over chest. | 2. Lower kettlebells, elbows flared. | 3. Press kettlebells upward, fully extending arms. Repeat.
1. Lie flat on a bench, holding a kettlebell in each hand above your chest. | 2. Slowly lower the kettlebells outwards, then lift them back up to the starting position.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.
1. Start flat on your back with the kettlebells extended over you. | 2. Bring your elbows to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.
1. Start flat on your back with a kettlebell extended over you. | 2. Bring your elbow to the floor, rest for a second to remove all the momentum from the rep, then press to a lockout.
1. Lie on bench, hold kettlebell with both hands over chest. | 2. Lower kettlebells, elbows flared. | 3. Press kettlebells upward, fully extending arms. Repeat.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Sit on the floor with your legs bent, knees together and feet raised slightly off the floor. | 2. Starting on one side and sitting up straight with your core muscles engaged, lift the kettlebell off the floor with both hands and bring it across your body to the other side, rotating your chest towards the floor as you do so. | 3. Tap the kettlebell lightly on the floor and bring the kettlebell back across your body to the starting position, rotating your chest towards the floor. | 4. Repeat, keeping the legs bent and feet raised throughout the exercise.

1. Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart and hold the kettle bell with both hands against your hip. | 2. Keeping your arms straight, swing the kettlebell upwards and across your body towards your shoulder, raising the kettlebell to head height rotating your hips as you do so. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart. Hold the kettlebell in one hand and extend your arm above your head. | 2. Keeping your legs straight and the kettlebell above your head, lower the relaxed arm towards the ground, twisting your body towards the side of the raised arm. | 3. Return to the starting potion, tilt your pelvis forward and repeat.
1. Stand with kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, grab kettlebell, pull to chest and rotate at the torso

1. Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart. Hold the kettlebell in your bottom hand and extend the other arm above your head. | 2. Keeping your legs straight and the kettlebell inside your thigh, lower the kettlebell towards the ground, twisting your body towards the side of the raised arm. | 3. Return to the starting position, tilt your pelvis forward and repeat.
1. Standing straight with a kettlebell in one hand, walk for a specified distance or duration. | 2. Stay upright and don't lean to one side.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a kettlebell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the kettlebell down towards the ground. | 3. As the kettlebell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the kettlebell on the opposite side of your body.
1. Hold two kettlebells in each hand. | 2. Keep your shoulders blades pulled back and walk for a specified duration.
1. Stand tall holding two kettlebells in each hand. | 2. March in place for the desired amount of reps or time.

1. Standing straight with a kettlebell in one hand, lift the knee of one leg off the floor to knee height. | 2. Bring the leg back to standing and repeat with the other leg, keeping the kettlebell on the same side. | 3. Repeat.

1. Standing straight with kettlebells, start walking towards a set point. Pulling your knee up toward the ceiling. | 2. Make sure to keep your chest tall and shoulder blades pulled back. | 3. Try to keep your stride distance roughly the same.

1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding a kettlebell at one side of your body, with your palms facing your thighs. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and knees to lower the kettlebell down towards the ground. | 3. As the kettlebell reaches the ground, use your legs and glutes to push through your heels and extend your hips and knees to raise your body back to the starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, then switch sides and repeat the exercise with the kettlebell on the opposite side of your body.

1. Stand up straight with feet shoulder width apart, holding the kettlebell in front of your pelvis. | 2. Keeping arms straight, raise the kettlebell slightly higher than head level. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with feet shoulder width apart holding a kettlebell with one hand at your side. | 2. Keeping your arm straight, swing the kettlebell up and out, away from your body to around head height, holding on to the kettlebell firmly so it does not change position in your hand. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with feet shoulder width apart holding a kettlebell with one hand at your side. | 2. Keeping your arm straight, swing the kettlebell up and out, away from your body to around head height. | 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.
1. Start with kettlebells between legs. | 2. Swing kettlebells up to shoulder. | 3. Press kettlebells overhead.
1. Begin with a two kettlebells between your legs, hinge at hips, then swing it upwards explosively. | 2. As they rise, lock out arm overhead, wrist straight. | 3. Control the descent, then repeat.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs. | 2. Hinge at hips, grip kettlebell, and swing it overhead. | 3. Extend hips and knees, lock out arms at the top.
1. Start with kettlebell in rack position. | 2. Dip at knees and hips. | 3. Explosively push kettlebell overhead, fully extending arms.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Clean And Press
Instructions: 1. Begin with the kettlebell between your legs. | 2. Hinge at your hips, and lift to shoulder, then press overhead.
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between legs. | 2. Squat, grip kettlebell, explode hips, and lift kettlebell overhead. | 3. Lower kettlebell safely to start position.

1. Start with a kettlebell between your legs, hinge at hips, swing it upward. | 2. Lift kettlebell to chest level, elbows high, engaging shoulders. | 3. Lower kettlebell back down, maintaining control. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

1. Position the bench between 45 and 60 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. Position the bench between 30 and 45 degrees. | 2. Lay flat on the bench with your feet on the ground. | 3. Lower the kettlebells to your mid chest | 4. Raise the kettlebells (slowly and controlled) until you've locked your elbows.

1. There should be a straight line from your elbow to fist (vertical forearms). | 2. Sit tall and try not to arch your spine as you're pressing. | 3. Press until your elbows are extended and push your head forward slightly.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your chest and lower - repeat.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Bottoms Up Single Arm Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding one kettlebell with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebell to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebell are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Kneeling Bottoms Up Overhead Press
Instructions: 1. Start by taking a kneeling position and holding a kettlebell in each hand with the bottom of the kettlebell facing up. | 2. Bring the kettlebells to your shoulders, with your palms facing forward and your elbows bent. | 3. From this starting position, extend your arms upwards so that the kettlebells are overhead. | 4. Make sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart, holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Lift the kettlebell upwards towards your upper chest and then lower the kettlebell- repeat.

Exercise Name: Kettlebell Single Arm Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding the kettlebell with both hands in front of your thighs. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the kettlebell to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. Bring one arm behind you and rest this arm on your back. With the other arm, hold the kettlebell at arms length close to the floor. | 4. Swing the kettlebell out and up towards the side of your body and then return to centre. Repeat.
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, kettlebell in each hand, hinge at hips. | 2. Pull kettlebells while flaring your elbows, squeezing shoulder blades. Keep back flat.

1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Raise your arms out to your sides, bringing them up to shoulder level. | 3. Rotate your palms so they are facing the ceiling. | 4. Then, change direction and rotate the arms as much as you can.

1. Stand an arms width away from the wall. | 2. Raise your arms out behind you, and place them on the wall with your fingers pointing up. | 3. Bend your knees whilst keeping your hands in the same position.
1. Bend your arm at the elbow, raising your hand to your shoulder. | 2. Using your other hand, stretch the arm down to its full extent.
1. Stand facing the wall, an arm's width away. | 2. Place your hand on the wall with your fingers pointing down. | 3. Lean slightly into the wall to feel the stretch in your bicep.

1. Stand one foot in front of the other with the wall to your right, an arms width away. | 2. Place your hand on the wall, fingers pointing away from you. | 3. Gently lean forward, keeping your hand stationary. | 4. Repeat with the other arm.

Exercise Name: Traps mid back Stretch Variation Two
Instructions: 1. Sit on the ground and lay one leg flat and the other over the top. | 2. Hold your leg with the same side arm and slowly rotate your hips and back. | 3. Hold at the peak of the stretch, then slowly return to starting position. | 4. Switch sides and repeat.

Exercise Name: Traps mid back Stretch Variation One
Instructions: 1. Stand up with your feet shoulder width apart. Place one arm across the front of your chest at shoulder height, press the forearm of your other arm above the elbow, hooking the stretching arm with your hand. | 2. Press the arm until it is straight and rotate your upper torso to engage the stretch even deeper. | 3. Repeat with your other arm.

1. Lay flat against the ground with your knees at an angle and your feet flat against the floor. | 2. Grab your legs just below the knees, and pull your legs towards your chest. | 3. Pause at the apex of the stretch, then return to the starting position.

1. Lay on your back with your arms at either side. | 2. Raise your knees so that they are pointing straight towards the ceiling. Keeping your legs pressed together, rotate your hips to either side. | 3. Repeat this motion as necessary.

1. Lay flat on the floor with your arms at either side. | 2. With one leg, hook one foot under the joint of your other leg. | 3. Rotate your hips so that your knees are pointing sideways, keeping your hooked leg flat against the floor. | 4. Pause at the apex of the stretch and repeat with your other leg.

1. Sit on the floor with the tops of your feet pointed and flat on the ground. Move your arms out in front of you in the diving position, placing your palms flat against the ground. | 2. With your arms fully extended, rest your buttocks on the heels of your feet, you can crawl your hands forward to extend the stretch if need be. | 3. Hold the extended position for a few seconds, and return to starting position.

1. Lay on a ball or a Bosu ball with your feet firmly planted on the floor. | 2. Lean all the way back until you feel a stretch in your abdomen. | 3. Crunch upwards and hold for a 1-2 count. | 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Stand upright. | 2. After completing the desired amount of reps with the left arm, switch to the right arm and lean to the left. | 3. Reach up with your left arm and then lean slowly to the right. Lean until a stretch is felt in the obliques.
1. Stand upright. | 2. Reach with both hands upwards until you can interlock your fingers. | 3. With your hands above your head, lean back until a stretch is felt in the abdominals.

1. Lay on your stomach on the floor with your forearms flat on the ground. | 2. Extend your elbows and push your upper body upwards. | 3. Push your upper body upwards until you feel a stretch in your abs, then return to the starting position and repeat.

1. Balance the balls of your feet on the platform, leaning forward to use the wall to assist with balance. Engage your calves so that your feet are flat before beginning the stretch. | 2. Lower the heels of your feet towards the ground and pause, then push through the balls of your feet like you are standing tip toe, pausing at the apex of the stretch. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. With both feet flat on the ground, place one leg in front of your shoulder, your other leg should mirror this position behind your other shoulder. In the starting position both of your knees should be straight. | 2. Place the palms of your hands against the wall at shoulder height in front of you, lean towards the wall and bend your front leg at the knee while keeping your back leg straight. | 3. Pause at the apex of the stretch and return to the starting position. Switch the position of your legs and repeat.

1. Place the ball of your foot against the wall with your heel on the ground. Place your hands on the wall in front of your shoulders. | 2. Keeping your knee straight, slowly lean towards the wall, pause for a few seconds when you feel the stretch extending through your calf muscle. | 3. Return to the starting position, and repeat the stretch with your other leg.
1. Raise your arm to shoulder height at 90 degrees to your body. | 2. Press lightly on your hand and push towards you. | 3. Rotate the arm across your body. | 4. Switch sides and repeat.
1. Place your hands together. | 2. Rotate your arms and hands 180 degrees. | 3. Hold at the peak of the stretch. | 4. Return to starting position.
1. Place your hand against a wall, palms facing upward, with finger tips touching. | 2. Slowly lean into your palm. | 3. Hold at the peak of the stretch. | 4. Return to starting position.
1. Place your palm flush against the wall. | 2. Take one step forward and straighten your arm slowly to extend your bicep. | 3. Hold at the peak of the stretch. | 4. Return to starting position.

1. Lay flat and bring your left leg to 90 degrees. | 2. Hold your left leg with both hands and slowly rotate your hips to the right hand side. | 3. Hold at the peak of the stretch, then slowly return to starting position. | 4. Switch sides and repeat.

1. Sit on the ground and lay one leg flat and the other over the top. | 2. Hold your leg with the same side arm and slowly rotate your hips and back. | 3. Hold at the peak of the stretch, then slowly return to starting position. | 4. Switch sides and repeat.

1. On your front, place one leg forward and then stretch out the same side arm across the mat/floor. | 2. Fully extend your leg and arm. | 3. Hold at the peak of the stretch, then slowly return to starting position. | 4. Switch sides and repeat.

1. Sit on the floor with your legs out in front of you. | 2. Reach forward to try and touch your toes. Reach as far forward as you can go. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then return to starting position.

1. Sit on the floor with one leg outstretched and the other bent at the knee, foot resting on the opposite inner thigh. | 2. Reach forward to touch the toes of the outstretched leg. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then return to starting position.
1. Stand with one foot in front of the other. | 2. Bend your rear leg as much as you can, keeping the front leg straight. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then return to starting position.

1. Lie down with your legs reaching up the wall. your bum should be slightly off the floor. | 2. Bend one leg and leave the other outstretched. | 3. Push your thigh towards the wall. | 4. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then return to starting position.
1. Find a wall to lean against, lay your tricep against the wall with your hand behind your back. | 2. Slowly lean into the wall. | 3. Return to starting position, then switch sides.

1. Stand up right and raise your hand to a full stretch above your head. | 2. Slowly lean across your body and trace the opposite hand down your leg. | 3. Hold at the bottom of the stretch, return to starting position and then switch sides.
1. Place both hands on the wall in front of you. | 2. Slowly lower your body until you feel the stretch. | 3. Hold at the bottom of the stretch, return to starting position.

1. Stand with you feet shoulder width apart. Place one arm across the front of your chest at shoulder height, press the forearm of your other arm above the elbow, hooking the stretching arm with your hand. | 2. Press the arm until it is straight and rotate your upper torso to engage the stretch even deeper. | 3. Repeat with your other arm.

1. Place the top of your hand into the small of your back, your arm at a 90 degree angle. | 2. Hold your elbow with the other arm, and slowly pull the arm forward until you feel your shoulder engaged in the stretch. Pause at the apex of the stretch and return to the starting position. | 3. Return to starting position, and repeat with your other arm.

1. Start with your arms at either side. Begin by pushing your shoulders forward and in towards your chest. | 2. Continue the circular motion with your shoulders, pinching up towards your ears, and then extending your chest outwards while you finish the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. Reach one arm behind your body, with your elbow pointing upward behind your head. | 2. Assist the stretch with your other hand on your elbow to engage your shoulder. | 3. Pause for a few seconds, then repeat the stretch with your other arm.

1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate one arm overhead and behind while keeping the other arm in front of you. | 3. Then rotate the other arm. | 4. Bring the original arm back to the starting position, then the other arm. Repeat.
1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate both arms overhead and behind you while leaving your elbows mostly extended.

1. Reach one arm behind your body, with your elbow pointing upward behind your head. | 2. Assist the stretch with your other hand on your elbow to engage your shoulder. | 3. Pause for a few seconds, then repeat the stretch with your other arm.

1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate one arm overhead and behind while keeping the other arm in front of you. | 3. Then rotate the other arm. | 4. Bring the original arm back to the starting position, then the other arm. Repeat.
1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate both arms overhead and behind you while leaving your elbows mostly extended.

1. Place the top of your hand into the small of your back, your arm at a 90 degree angle. | 2. Hold your elbow with the other arm, and slowly pull the arm forward until you feel your shoulder engaged in the stretch. Pause at the apex of the stretch and return to the starting position. | 3. Return to starting position, and repeat with your other arm.

1. Start with your arms at either side. Begin by pushing your shoulders forward and in towards your chest. | 2. Continue the circular motion with your shoulders, pinching up towards your ears, and then extending your chest outwards while you finish the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. Reach one arm behind your body, with your elbow pointing upward behind your head. | 2. Assist the stretch with your other hand on your elbow to engage your shoulder. | 3. Pause for a few seconds, then repeat the stretch with your other arm.

1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate one arm overhead and behind while keeping the other arm in front of you. | 3. Then rotate the other arm. | 4. Bring the original arm back to the starting position, then the other arm. Repeat.
1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate both arms overhead and behind you while leaving your elbows mostly extended.

1. Stand with you feet shoulder width apart. Place one arm across the front of your chest at shoulder height, press the forearm of your other arm above the elbow, hooking the stretching arm with your hand. | 2. Press the arm until it is straight and rotate your upper torso to engage the stretch even deeper. | 3. Repeat with your other arm.

1. Start with your arms at either side. Begin by pushing your shoulders forward and in towards your chest. | 2. Continue the circular motion with your shoulders, pinching up towards your ears, and then extending your chest outwards while you finish the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate one arm overhead and behind while keeping the other arm in front of you. | 3. Then rotate the other arm. | 4. Bring the original arm back to the starting position, then the other arm. Repeat.
1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate both arms overhead and behind you while leaving your elbows mostly extended.

1. Bend your left arm so your hand is at your shoulder, and hold your elbow with the opposite hand. | 2. Gently push on your elbow so it is raised by your head. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then repeat with the other arm.

1. Hold a band so it is in line with your spine. Hold the top with your right hand and the bottom with your left. | 2. Keeping the top still, pull down on the band. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then repeat with the other arm.

1. Raise your left arm above your head, and bend at the elbow so your hand is resting at the top of your back. | 2. Use the opposite hand to gently apply pressure to the elbow. | 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds then repeat with the other arm.
1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Nod your head forward, bringing your chin to your chest. | 3. You will feel the stretch across your neck.

1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Keeping your chest facing forward, turn your head 90 degrees to the left. Then return to centre point. | 3. Repeat, turning your head in the other direction.

1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder width apart. | 2. Place your left hand on your head and gently pull your head down towards your left shoulder. Then return to centre point. | 3. Repeat, using your right hand pulling towards your right shoulder.

1. Lay flat on your belly. Extend one arm out in front of you, placing your palm on the floor. With your other arm, grab the top of your foot. | 2. Keeping your upper leg flat on the floor, pull your foot towards your buttocks to engage the stretch. | 3. Pause for a few seconds, and then repeat the stretch with your other leg.

1. Lay flat on your belly, with both hands reach back and grab the tops of your feet. | 2. Keeping your upper legs flat on the ground, pull both of your feet towards your buttocks. | 3. Pause at the apex of the stretch, then return to starting position.

1. Place one foot flat on the ground in front of you at a 90 degree angle. With your other leg, balance upon your knee, placing the tip of your foot against the wall behind you for balance. | 2. Place your hands on your knee in front of you, and lean forward so that your knee extends over your foot. | 3. Pause at the apex of the stretch, and slowly return to starting position. Repeat with your other leg.

1. Stand perpendicular to a wall, using one arm against the wall for balance. With your other arm, grab the top of your foot. | 2. Pull your leg upwards and back to engage your quads, pausing at the apex of the stretch for a few seconds. | 3. Return to starting position and repeat with your other leg.

1. Raise your arms to shoulder height, fully extended in front of you. | 2. Slowly bring your arms behind your back still at shoulder height. | 3. Pause for a few seconds and then return to starting position.

1. Place your arms behind your back and clasp your hands together. | 2. Slowly extend your elbows until they are locked then lift them away from you. | 3. Pause in this position for a few seconds and then return them to starting position.

1. Lay on your side with one hand just in front of you. | 2. With a slight bend in your arm, rotate your arm around your body as slowly as possible. | 3. Return to the starting position and then repeat on the other side.

1. Using a raised wall, place your arm at a 90 degree angle against it. | 2. With a staggered stance, lean into the wall extending your chest. | 3. Pause for a few seconds and then return to starting position and repeat on opposite side.

1. Stand upright. | 2. After completing the desired amount of reps with the left arm, switch to the right arm and lean to the left. | 3. Reach up with your left arm and then lean slowly to the right. Lean until a stretch is felt in the obliques.
1. Stand upright. | 2. Reach with both hands upwards until you can interlock your fingers. | 3. With your hands above your head, lean back until a stretch is felt in the abdominals.

1. Place the top of your hand into the small of your back, your arm at a 90 degree angle. | 2. Hold your elbow with the other arm, and slowly pull the arm forward until you feel your shoulder engaged in the stretch. Pause at the apex of the stretch and return to the starting position. | 3. Return to starting position, and repeat with your other arm.

1. Start with your arms at either side. Begin by pushing your shoulders forward and in towards your chest. | 2. Continue the circular motion with your shoulders, pinching up towards your ears, and then extending your chest outwards while you finish the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. Reach one arm behind your body, with your elbow pointing upward behind your head. | 2. Assist the stretch with your other hand on your elbow to engage your shoulder. | 3. Pause for a few seconds, then repeat the stretch with your other arm.

1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate one arm overhead and behind while keeping the other arm in front of you. | 3. Then rotate the other arm. | 4. Bring the original arm back to the starting position, then the other arm. Repeat.
1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate both arms overhead and behind you while leaving your elbows mostly extended.

1. Stand with you feet shoulder width apart. Place one arm across the front of your chest at shoulder height, press the forearm of your other arm above the elbow, hooking the stretching arm with your hand. | 2. Press the arm until it is straight and rotate your upper torso to engage the stretch even deeper. | 3. Repeat with your other arm.

1. Start with your arms at either side. Begin by pushing your shoulders forward and in towards your chest. | 2. Continue the circular motion with your shoulders, pinching up towards your ears, and then extending your chest outwards while you finish the motion. | 3. Repeat as necessary.

1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate one arm overhead and behind while keeping the other arm in front of you. | 3. Then rotate the other arm. | 4. Bring the original arm back to the starting position, then the other arm. Repeat.
1. Start with the pole in front of you with an overhand wider than shoulder width grip. | 2. Rotate both arms overhead and behind you while leaving your elbows mostly extended.

1. Use a handle attachment set all the way to the top of the cable crossover machine. | 2. Walk a few steps away from the cable machine. Face your body sideways. | 3. Face your palm up toward the ceiling. Then pull your elbow in toward your rib cage.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Start with a neutral grip. Flex at the elbow. While flexing twist your palm. When you hit the top of the movement your palm should be facing upward.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Face your palm downwards. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Use a neutral grip thumb facing up pinky-facing down). Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a row bar. | 2. Pull the handles back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handles towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Underhand Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm upward. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Neutral Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm toward the midline of your body. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. Start with an overhand grip. As you pull your elbow back, rotate your palm until it faces upward.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. On the same side as the working arm, step back and rotate outwards. | 3. Pull your elbow back while flaring your elbow out.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine and sit on the bench. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Face your palm downwards. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine and sit on the bench. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Use a neutral grip thumb facing up pinky-facing down). Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Sit on a bench facing away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a bar attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a rope attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Use a neutral grip thumb facing up pinky-facing down). Flex at the elbow and extend.
1. Stand facing away from the cables and grab two handle attachments. | 2. Take a neutral grip, flex your elbows, and extend.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set to about elbow height. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. | 3. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. Face your palm forward. Flex at the elbow and extend.

1. Use a bar attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Stand up with the attachment in hand, walk a couple of steps back make sure you are standing upright and not leaning backwards. | 3. Retract your shoulder blades and then protract to return to the starting position.

1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a row bar. | 2. Pull the handles back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handles towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Underhand Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm upward. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Neutral Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm toward the midline of your body. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Rear Delt Row
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment, grab with an overhand grip and take a position with the cable crossing your body. | 2. Pull your elbows back while flaring your elbows outward.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Get your elbows directly underneath the bar, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.

1. Start with a straight bar or ez bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back. | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement while lifting one of your legs. Then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. Compete your given amount of reps, then switch to opposite leg. | 4. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back.

1. This exercise works best with a rope attachment but can be done with anything. The attachment should be set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine, straddle the cable itself, and grab the attachment. Walk a few steps away. | 3. Break at the hips while maintaining a flat back and mostly extended knees. | 4. Push hips forward until you are back in a standing position.

Exercise Name: Cable Standing Straight Leg Glute Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set to the bottom of the crossover machine. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Place the bar in your elbows, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.

Exercise Name: Cable Incline Bench Straight Leg Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. Put the bench at incline level. The cable should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Use an ankle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set to hip height. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set halfway up the crossover machine. | 2. Start with a bent knee position. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

Exercise Name: Cable Standing Straight Leg Mid Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set to halfway up the crossover machine. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet about hip-width apart and holding the bar in the crook of your elbows, with your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and lower your torso forward until it is nearly parallel to the ground. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and raise your body back to the starting position.

1. Start with a straight bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back. | 2. Stand with a staggered stance. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Start with handles set to the bottom of the machine. Grab a box, stand on top of the box, squat the weight up into a standing position. | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Use a double handle attachment and set the cable all the way to the top. | 2. Face away from the cable tower and walk a few steps forward. | 3. Push your hips back, and flex your abs. | 4. Return to the starting standing position and repeat.

1. Use a double handle attachment and set the cable all the way to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps forward then fall into a kneeling position. | 3. Push your hips back and flex your abs, then push hips forward until in the starting position.

1. Use a rope attachment and set the cable all the way to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps forward then fall into a kneeling position. | 3. Push your hips back and flex your abs, then push hips forward until in the starting position.

1. Use a rope attachment and set the cable all the way to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps forward then fall into a kneeling position. | 3. Push your hips back and flex your abs, then push hips forward until in the starting position.

1. Use a rope attachment and set the cable all the way to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps forward then fall into a kneeling position. | 3. Push your hips back and flex your abs, then push hips forward until in the starting position.

1. Use a straight bar or ez bar attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Walk a few steps back. | 3. Pull your heels straight up until you feel a contraction in your calves and then back to original position.

1. Use a straight bar or ez bar attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Walk a few steps back. | 3. Pull your heels straight up until you feel a contraction in your calves and then back to original position.
1. Put on a dip belt and attach the cable carabiner to the chain/strap. | 2. Take a few steps back and stand tall. Raise up onto the balls of your feet and hold for a 1 count.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Start with your elbow at a 90 angle with your palm facing up. Flex and extend at the wrist.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cable should be set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine. Stagger your stance so you have a better base of support. | 3. Start with your elbow at a 90 degree angle with your palm facing down. Flex and extend at the wrist.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Get your elbows directly underneath the bar, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.

1. You can use a straight or EZ bar on this exercise. Cable should be set all to the bottom. | 2. Grab the attachment and walk back a few steps. Take a split stance. One leg in front and one behind. | 3. Break at the knees and hips to initiate the split squat. Make sure your back knee touches the floor. | 4. Squat back up into a standing position.

1. Start with a straight bar or ez bar attachment set to the bottom of the machine. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back on any exercise.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment. Squat the weight up into a standing position and walk a few steps back. | 2. Push your butt back to initiate the movement while lifting one of your legs. Then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. Compete your given amount of reps, then switch to opposite leg. | 4. To protect yourself from injury, always maintain a flat back.

1. This exercise works best with a rope attachment but can be done with anything. The attachment should be set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Face away from the cable machine, straddle the cable itself, and grab the attachment. Walk a few steps away. | 3. Break at the hips while maintaining a flat back and mostly extended knees. | 4. Push hips forward until you are back in a standing position.

1. Use an ankle attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Face sideways with the ankle attachment on your outside leg. Walk a few steps away. | 3. Abduct at the hips and raise your leg out to the side. | 4. Return to the starting position and stop just short of your foot touching back to the ground (to keep tension on the muscle).

Exercise Name: Cable Standing Straight Leg Glute Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set to the bottom of the crossover machine. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Place the bar in your elbows, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.

1. Use an ankle attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Take a quadruped position with the cable going across your planted leg. | 3. Abduct at the hips and raise your leg out to the side. | 4. Return to the starting position and stop just short of the cables touching back down (to keep tension on the muscle).

Exercise Name: Cable Incline Bench Straight Leg Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. Put the bench at incline level. The cable should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Use an ankle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set to hip height. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Bring the cable all the way to the bottom of the stack. Use an ankle attachment. | 2. Keeping your feet together, move your legs out to the sides and then back to the midline of your body. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set halfway up the crossover machine. | 2. Start with a bent knee position. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

Exercise Name: Cable Standing Straight Leg Mid Kickback
Instructions: 1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set to halfway up the crossover machine. | 2. Push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Use an ankle attachment. The cable should be set to the bottom of the crossover machine. | 2. Break at the knee, push your ankle straight back, extending at the hip. Hold for a one count when you feel a contraction in your glutes. | 3. Then flex at the hips until you are back into your original position.

1. Begin by standing with your feet about hip-width apart and holding the bar in the crook of your elbows, with your palms facing towards your body. | 2. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, bend at the hips and lower your torso forward until it is nearly parallel to the ground. | 3. Push through your heels to extend your hips and raise your body back to the starting position.

Push your butt back to initiate the movement and then push your butt forward until you're back in a standing position. | 3. 1. Put on a dip belt and attach the strap/ chain to the cable's carabiner. | 2. Take a few steps back and take a split stance. | 3. Lower into a split squat, letting the weight pull you forward. As you squat back to the starting position push yourself backwards against the resistance.

1. You can use any attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the top of the machine. | 2. Grab your attachment and walk a few steps back. Push your butt back to where you are leaning forward. Your ears should be between your arms. | 3. Initiate the movement with your shoulders and not your elbows. As you flex at the shoulder joint push your hips forward until your hips meet the attachment.

1. You can use any attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the top of the machine. | 2. Grab your attachment and walk a few steps back. Push your butt back to where you are leaning forward somewhat. | 3. Initiate the movement with your shoulders and not your elbows. Imagine trying to pull the attachment through your thighs at the bottom.

1. Use a handle attachment set all the way to the top of the cable crossover machine. | 2. Walk a few steps away from the cable machine. Face your body sideways. | 3. Face your palm up toward the ceiling. Then pull your elbow in toward your rib cage.

1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a row bar. | 2. Pull the handles back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handles towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Underhand Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm upward. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Neutral Grip Row
Instructions: 1. Place the cable at shoulder height. Use a handle attachment. Face your palm toward the midline of your body. | 2. Pull the handle back using your arms. Push out your chest. | 3. Pull the handle towards your body until your hands are beside your abdomen.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. Start with an overhand grip. As you pull your elbow back, rotate your palm until it faces upward.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. On the same side as the working arm, step back and rotate outwards. | 3. Pull your elbow back while flaring your elbow out.

1. Use a handle attachment set all the way to the top of the cable crossover machine. | 2. Walk a few steps away from the cable machine. Face your body sideways. | 3. Face your palm forward. Then pull your elbow in toward your rib cage.

1. Facing the pulley, pull the weight towards you while keeping your arms parallel to the ground. | 2. Pull your hands back to both sides of your head and hold the position. | 3. Slowly return weight to starting position. Repeat.

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. Stand upright making sure to maintain a flat back. Your starting position will have your palms facing forward. | 2. Use both your elbows and shoulders to press the weight directly overhead.

Exercise Name: Cable Low Single Arm Lateral Raise
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. You should vertically abduct at the shoulder raising your arm straight out to the side. | 3. Raise until your arm is parallel with the ground and then back to the starting position.

Exercise Name: Cable High Single Arm Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arm. | 3. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up toward the ceiling until the attachment is just below your chin then extend until your elbows are fully extended.

Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment, grab with an overhand grip and take a position with the cable crossing your body. | 2. Pull your elbows back while flaring your elbows outward.

1. Place the cable at the same height as your fist when your arms are at your side and stand with the cable crossing your body. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, lift your arm until it's parallel with the floor.

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up toward the ceiling until the attachment is just below your chin then extend until your elbows are fully extended.

1. Use a handle attachment on both sides of crossover. With cable attachment set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Grab both handles and make sure you are centered in the machine. Let your arms hang freely. | 3. Pull your shoulder blades up and in towards your ears. Let your shoulder blades depress back to the starting position.

1. Use a bar attachment. Cable should be set all the way to the bottom. | 2. Stand up with the attachment in hand, walk a couple of steps back make sure you are standing upright and not leaning backwards. | 3. Retract your shoulder blades and then protract to return to the starting position.

1. Use a rope attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up toward the ceiling until the attachment is just below your chin then extend until your elbows are fully extended.

Pull your shoulder blade up and in towards your ears. Let your shoulder blade depress back to the starting position.

Pull your shoulder blade up and in towards your ears. Let your shoulder blade depress back to the starting position.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Get your elbows directly underneath the bar, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.

1. You can use a straight or EZ bar on this exercise. Cable should be set all to the bottom. | 2. Grab the attachment and walk back a few steps. Take a split stance. One leg in front and one behind. | 3. Break at the knees and hips to initiate the split squat. Make sure your back knee touches the floor. | 4. Squat back up into a standing position.
1. Stand upright facing away from the cable crossover with the cable set to the height of your hips. Use an ankle/wrist attachment. | 2. Extend at the knee against the cable.

1. Start with a straight bar or easy bar attachment . | 2. Place the bar in your elbows, squat straight up and then walk back a few steps. | 3. Break at your knees and hips to initiate the squat. Make sure you maintain a flat back. | 4. Squat all the way back to a standing position.
1. Use an ankle/wrist attachment. Pull the cable under the bench and attach it at your ankle. | 2. Extend at the knee against the cable.

1. Put on a dip belt and attach the strap/ chain to the cable's carabiner. | 2. Take a few steps back and take a split stance. | 3. Lower into a split squat, letting the weight pull you forward. As you squat back to the starting position push yourself backwards against the resistance.

1. Put on a dip belt. Attach the strap/chain to the cable's carabiner. | 2. Take a few steps back. Begin to squat by flexing at the knees and hips. | 3. Let the weight pull you forward as you squat. Then push your toes through the front of your shoes as you squat back to the start position.

1. Bring the cable all the way to the bottom of the stack. Use an ankle attachment. | 2. Keeping your feet together, move your legs out to the sides and then back to the midline of your body. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
1. Stand upright facing away from the cable crossover with the cable set to the height of your hips. Use an ankle/wrist attachment. | 2. Extend at the knee against the cable.

1. Use a handle attachment set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Walk a few steps forward. Then press the weight forward. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cables should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Walk a few steps forward. Then press the weight forward. | 4. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Incline Chest Fly
Instructions: 1. Place the cable anchor at a lower level than your shoulders. | 2. Sit on the bench, leave your elbows mostly extended. | 3. Bring your arm across your chest and flex your pec.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Incline Bench Press
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set fairly low. | 2. Bring the handle across your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulder and elbow simultaneously.

Instructions: 1. Bring a bench over to the cables, set the cable just below shoulder height. | 2. Bring the handle to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Press the weight forward. From there, your shoulder should horizontally abduct and adduct while your elbow stays in a fixed position.

1. Set the cable at about nipple level. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, then rotate your torso with your arms extended against the resistance. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Use a handle attachment, set the cable at nipple level, walk a few steps away, and face sideways. | 2. Start with both hands on the handle and your fists against your chest. | 3. Press the handle forward until your elbows are fully extended, then pull the handle back to your chest.

Exercise Name: Cable Half Kneeling Low To High Wood Chopper
Instructions: 1. Set the cable at a low position. Take a half kneeling position. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, then rotate your torso with your arms extended against the resistance. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Set the cable at nipple level. Take a half kneeling position. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, then rotate your torso with your arms extended against the resistance. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

Exercise Name: Cable Half Kneeling High To Low Wood Chopper
Instructions: 1. Set the cable just over your head. Take a half kneeling position. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, then rotate your torso with your arms extended against the resistance. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Use a handle attachment, set the cable at nipple level, walk a few steps away, and face sideways. | 2. Start with both hands on the handle and your fists against your chest. | 3. Press the handle forward until your elbows are fully extended, then rotate away from the cable stack. | 4. Then pull the handle back to your chest.

1. Set the cable just over your head. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, push the handle down until your elbow is extended. Flex your obliques until you feel a contraction. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Set the cable at the bottom of the stack. Use a handle attachment. | 2. Face sideways, grab the handle, lean away from the cable. | 3. After completing your given number of reps, face the opposite direction and repeat.

1. Use a handle attachment. The cables should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. Walk a few steps forward. Then press the weight forward. | 4. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. Stand upright making sure to maintain a flat back. Your starting position will have your palms facing forward. | 2. Use both your elbows and shoulders to press the weight directly overhead.

Exercise Name: Cable Low Single Arm Lateral Raise
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. You should vertically abduct at the shoulder raising your arm straight out to the side. | 3. Raise until your arm is parallel with the ground and then back to the starting position.

1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up toward the ceiling until the attachment is just below your chin then extend until your elbows are fully extended.

1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set to shoulder height. | 2. Bring the handle to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulder and elbow simultaneously.

Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment. Bring a bench over to the cables. The cable should be set above shoulder height. | 2. Bring one handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.

Bring both of the handles to your chest and make sure you are in the center of the cable crossover. | 3. From there, you should flex and extend at both the shoulders and elbows simultaneously.
