1. Use a handle attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. You should vertically abduct at the shoulder raising your arms straight out to the side. | 3. Raise until your arms are parallel with the ground and then back to the starting position.
1. Face away from the cables. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.

Exercise Name: Cable Rope Single Arm Low Lateral Raise
Instructions: 1. Use a rope attachment with the cable set all the way to the bottom of the machine. | 2. You should vertically abduct at the shoulder raising your arms straight out to the side. | 3. Raise until your arms are parallel with the ground and then back to the starting position.

1. Place the cable at the same height as your fist when your arms are at your side and stand with the cable crossing your body. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, lift your arm until it's parallel with the floor.
1. Face away from the cables. Use a rope attachment. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.

1. Use a rope attachment with the cable set to the bottom of the machine. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up toward the ceiling until the attachment is just below your chin then extend until your elbows are fully extended.
1. Stand tall, hold the cable handle with a neutral grip, your elbow should be at a 90 degree angle. | 2. Rotate your shoulder by bringing your forearm across your body.

1. Facing the pulley, pull the weight towards you while keeping your arms parallel to the ground. | 2. Pull your hands back to both sides of your head and hold the position. | 3. Slowly return weight to starting position. Repeat.

Exercise Name: Cable High Single Arm Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arm. | 3. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Rear Delt Row
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment, grab with an overhand grip and take a position with the cable crossing your body. | 2. Pull your elbows back while flaring your elbows outward.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. Start with an overhand grip. As you pull your elbow back, rotate your palm until it faces upward.
1. Place the cable at shoulder height. | 2. On the same side as the working arm, step back and rotate outwards. | 3. Pull your elbow back while flaring your elbow out.
1. Start with the cables at the top. Use a rope attachment. Fall to a half kneeling position. | 2. Pull the metal piece in the middle of the rope to the bridge of your nose.

1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arm. | 3. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

Exercise Name: Cable Single Arm Internally Rotated High Reverse Fly
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arms. Internally rotate the shoulders. | 3. From there, your shoulder should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.

Exercise Name: Cable High Internally Rotated Reverse Fly
Instructions: 1. Use a handle attachment or no attachment at all. The cable should be set to the top. | 2. Walk a few steps away with the cable coming from the opposing side of the working arms. Internally rotate the shoulders. | 3. From there, your shoulders should horizontally abduct and adduct, while your elbows stay in a fixed position.
1. Hold the cable handle in one hand, elbow bent at 90 degrees going across your torso. | 2. Rotate your arm outward, keeping your elbow stable.

1. Bring the cable all the way to the bottom of the stack. Use an ankle attachment. | 2. Keeping your feet together, move your legs out to the sides and then back to the midline of your body. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. Point your palms straight forward. | 2. Flex your elbow until you feel your biceps contract. Then fully extend elbows.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. Use a neutral grip. | 2. Flex your elbow until you feel your biceps contract. Then fully extend elbows.

1. Place the band at about eye level. Fall into a kneeling position. | 2. The knee that is on the ground should be the same side as the working arm. Stick your chest out. | 3. And then pull your elbow straight back. Flex your lats and then extend into the starting position.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. . Point your palms toward your thighs. | 2. Flex your elbow until you feel your biceps contract. Then fully extend elbows.
1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Let your arms hang freely, then pull your elbows straight back toward the ceiling.
1. Anchor a band to a high point. | 2. Start with your feet staggered and your elbows high. | 3. Flex your elbows while keeping your arms high. Curl the band to your forehead.
1. Start with the band anchored to something high with your feet staggered and a neutral grip. | 2. Keep your elbows high. Curl until your fists are at your forehead.
1. Start with a band attached to a high point, your feet staggered, and an overhand grip. | 2. Flex your elbows pulling your forearms to your biceps. Your fists should land by your forehead.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with the band under both feet. | 2. Grasp the handles of the band with both hands, keeping your arms straight and extended in front of you. | 3. Keep your back straight, abs engaged, and shoulders relaxed as you curl your hands towards your shoulders, bending at the elbows.

1. Start by standing on the center of the band with both feet, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Hold the band with both hands, palms facing down, arms extended straight in front of you. | 3. Slowly curl your hands towards your shoulders, pulling the band tight, then lower your arms back to the starting position, keeping tension on the band throughout the exercise.

Exercise Name: Band Squat Hold Single Arm Row
Instructions: 1. Anchor the band to a stable point and take a half squat position. | 2. Hold the band loop in one hand and pull your elbow straight back.
1. Anchor the band to a stable point. | 2. Take a half squat position and hold there. | 3. Perform a row while holding the squat position.
1. Anchor the band to a high point. Go into a seated position. | 2. Grab the loop of the band and pull your upper arm to your side.
1. Anchor band to a stable point. | 2. Step back until there is no slack in the band and hold the end of the band with one hand. | 3. Pull through the elbow straight back.
1. Anchor the band at shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades straight back in schools. Then protract to the starting position.
1. Grab the band with a shoulder width grip. Point your arms straight in front of you. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades and shoulder joint until the band taps your chest.
1. Start with a band anchored to a high point. Stagger your stance. | 2. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose.

1. Start by standing between the two anchored bands with your feet shoulder-width apart and the bands positioned at a high point. | 2. Grasp the ends of each band with your hands, keeping your palms facing each other. | 3. Keeping your arms slightly bent and your back straight, slowly pull the bands away from your body until your arms are extended straight out to the sides. Hold for a second, then slowly release back to the starting position. Repeat for desired reps.
1. Anchor the band at hip level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back while keeping your back flat until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings.

1. Anchor the band to the lowest point possible. Straddle the band and then grab with both hands. | 2. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 3. Push your butt back until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Then extend the hips back into the starting position.

1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Hinge until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 4. Push your hips back forward until you are in a standing position.

1. Place the band at the highest anchor point you have available. Grab both ends of the band and fall into a kneeling position. | 2. Push your hips back flexing at the spine. | 3. Squeeze your abs and then extend at the hips and spine back to the starting position.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. | 2. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 3. Lean back slightly. Raise your heels straight up and down
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. Use a neutral grip. | 2. Flex your elbow until you feel your biceps contract. Then fully extend elbows.
1. Attach band to a low anchor point. . Point your palms toward your thighs. | 2. Flex your elbow until you feel your biceps contract. Then fully extend elbows.
1. Start with a band attached to a high point, your feet staggered, and an overhand grip. | 2. Flex your elbows pulling your forearms to your biceps. Your fists should land by your forehead.

1. Start by standing on the center of the band with both feet, shoulder-width apart. | 2. Hold the band with both hands, palms facing down, arms extended straight in front of you. | 3. Slowly curl your hands towards your shoulders, pulling the band tight, then lower your arms back to the starting position, keeping tension on the band throughout the exercise.
1. Anchor a band to a stable point. | 2. Place the loops of the band behind your knees. | 3. Perform a normal squat and extend your knees against the band at the top.
1. Anchor the band at hip level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back while keeping your back flat until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings.

1. Get into a quadruped position. Loop the band around both of your wrists and one of your feet. | 2. Extend your knee and hip straight back until you feel like contraction in the glutes. | 3. Flex at the knee until back in the starting position.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your head by the anchor point of the band, which should be 6 to 12 inches above your head | 2. Place the band around your midfoot and extend at the knees and hip.

1. Anchor the band to the lowest point possible. Straddle the band and then grab with both hands. | 2. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 3. Push your butt back until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Then extend the hips back into the starting position.

1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Hinge until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 4. Push your hips back forward until you are in a standing position.

1. Stand with a shoulder width grip. Both feet should be on the band with the band loops in each of your hand. | 2. Push your butt back and also break at the knees. | 3. Try to hit parallel depth (bottom of your leg should be parallel with the ground). If you can't tell your squat depth, then try squatting in front of a mirror and watch your form.

1. Attach the band around your ankle. Stand with feet hip-width apart, feet facing forward, and hands on hips. | 2. Lift your right leg away from your body to the side, keeping your knee straight. This is your starting position. | 3. Maintaining proper form, move your right leg as far to the side as you can, keeping your left leg planted firmly on the ground. Hold for a second and then return your right leg to the starting position.

1. Attach a band to a stable anchor point, such as a door handle or post. | 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and place the band around your ankles. | 3. Keeping your feet together, move your legs out to the sides and then back to the midline of your body. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
1. Place a band either just below or above your knees. | 2. Get into a quarter squat position. | 3. Step side to side without letting there be any slack in the band to keep tension on the band.

Exercise Name: Band Squat Hold Single Arm Row
Instructions: 1. Anchor the band to a stable point and take a half squat position. | 2. Hold the band loop in one hand and pull your elbow straight back.
1. Anchor the band to a stable point. | 2. Take a half squat position and hold there. | 3. Perform a row while holding the squat position.

1. Stand with a shoulder width grip. Both feet should be on the band with the band looped over both hands. | 2. Push your butt back and also break at the knees. | 3. Try to hit parallel depth (bottom of your leg should be parallel with the ground). If you can't tell your squat depth, then try squatting in front of a mirror and watch your form.

1. Attach the band around your ankle. Stand with feet hip-width apart, feet facing forward, and hands on hips. | 2. Lift your right leg away from your body to the side, keeping your knee straight. This is your starting position. | 3. Maintaining proper form, move your right leg as far to the side as you can, keeping your left leg planted firmly on the ground. Hold for a second and then return your right leg to the starting position.
1. Place a band either just below or above your knees. | 2. Get into a quarter squat position. | 3. Step side to side without letting there be any slack in the band to keep tension on the band.
1. Anchor the band at hip level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back while keeping your back flat until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings.

1. Anchor the band to the lowest point possible. Straddle the band and then grab with both hands. | 2. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 3. Push your butt back until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Then extend the hips back into the starting position.

1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Hinge until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. | 4. Push your hips back forward until you are in a standing position.

1. Loop the band around a sturdy anchor point such as a weightlifting rack or a door handle. | 2. Lie on your back with your heels placed inside the band. Make sure the band is centered under your heels and your feet are hip-width apart. | 3. Using your hamstrings, curl your heels towards your glutes while keeping your hips on the ground.

1. Place the band at about eye level. Fall into a kneeling position. | 2. The knee that is on the ground should be the same side as the working arm. Stick your chest out. | 3. And then pull your elbow straight back. Flex your lats and then extend into the starting position.
1. Place the band just above our level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back slightly. Extend and flex at the shoulder joint.
1. Stand on your band with both feet. | 2. Hinge forward at the hips while keeping a flat back. | 3. Let your arms hang freely, then pull your elbows straight back toward the ceiling.

Exercise Name: Band Squat Hold Single Arm Row
Instructions: 1. Anchor the band to a stable point and take a half squat position. | 2. Hold the band loop in one hand and pull your elbow straight back.
1. Anchor the band to a stable point. | 2. Take a half squat position and hold there. | 3. Perform a row while holding the squat position.
1. Anchor the band to a high point. Go into a seated position. | 2. Grab the loop of the band and pull your upper arm to your side.
1. Anchor band to a stable point. | 2. Step back until there is no slack in the band and hold the end of the band with one hand. | 3. Pull through the elbow straight back.
1. Anchor the band at eye level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Use an overhand grip with both hands. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose flaring your elbows out.
1. Stand on the band with one or 2 feet depending on how heavy you want the band to be. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.
1. Grab the band at shoulder width. Raise your arms straight out to the side. | 2. The band should scrape against your shirt.
1. Grab the band with a shoulder width grip. Point your arms straight in front of you. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades and shoulder joint until the band taps your chest.

1. Loop the band under one of your feet. The other end of the bed should be in your hand between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. Press the band straight up towards the ceiling. Until your elbow is fully extended.
1. Start with a band anchored to a high point. Stagger your stance. | 2. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose.
1. Anchor a band to a low point and stand with the band crossing your body. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, lift your arm until it's parallel with the floor.

1. Anchor a band to a point that is the same height as your fist when your arms are at your side and stand with the band crossing your body. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, lift your arm until it's parallel with the floor.

1. Stand between the two anchored bands, grasp them with an overhand grip, and position the bands at shoulder level. | 2. Brace your core and push the bands overhead, fully extending your arms. | 3. Lower the bands back to shoulder level, keeping your core engaged and arms straight. Repeat for desired number of reps.

1. Start by standing between the two anchored bands with your feet shoulder-width apart and the bands positioned at a high point. | 2. Grasp the ends of each band with your hands, keeping your palms facing each other. | 3. Keeping your arms slightly bent and your back straight, slowly pull the bands away from your body until your arms are extended straight out to the sides. Hold for a second, then slowly release back to the starting position. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.
1. Grab the band at shoulder width. Raise your arms straight out to the side. | 2. The band should scrape against your shirt.

1. Loop the band under one of your feet. The other end of the bed should be in your hand between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. Press the band straight up towards the ceiling. Until your elbow is fully extended.
1. Anchor a band to a low point and stand with the band crossing your body. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, lift your arm until it's parallel with the floor.

1. Anchor a band to a point that is the same height as your fist when your arms are at your side and stand with the band crossing your body. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, lift your arm until it's parallel with the floor.

1. Stand between the two anchored bands, grasp them with an overhand grip, and position the bands at shoulder level. | 2. Brace your core and push the bands overhead, fully extending your arms. | 3. Lower the bands back to shoulder level, keeping your core engaged and arms straight. Repeat for desired number of reps.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.
1. Stand on the band with one or 2 feet depending on how heavy you want the band to be. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.

1. Loop the band under one of your feet. The other end of the bed should be in your hand between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. Press the band straight up towards the ceiling. Until your elbow is fully extended.

1. Stand between the two anchored bands, grasp them with an overhand grip, and position the bands at shoulder level. | 2. Brace your core and push the bands overhead, fully extending your arms. | 3. Lower the bands back to shoulder level, keeping your core engaged and arms straight. Repeat for desired number of reps.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.
1. Anchor the band at eye level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Use an overhand grip with both hands. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose flaring your elbows out.
1. Grab the band with a shoulder width grip. Point your arms straight in front of you. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades and shoulder joint until the band taps your chest.
1. Start with a band anchored to a high point. Stagger your stance. | 2. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose.

1. Start by standing between the two anchored bands with your feet shoulder-width apart and the bands positioned at a high point. | 2. Grasp the ends of each band with your hands, keeping your palms facing each other. | 3. Keeping your arms slightly bent and your back straight, slowly pull the bands away from your body until your arms are extended straight out to the sides. Hold for a second, then slowly release back to the starting position. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Attach the band to an anchor point that is about shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and elbow across your body until your arm is fully extended.
1. Stand with one or both feet on band. Go up and over your head with the band to the starting position. | 2. Flex and extend your elbows.
1. Place the band just above eye level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Push your hips back slightly. Extend and flex at the elbows.

1. Loop the band around your mid-back. The ends of the bands should be around your hands between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. This exercise can be done from the knees or the toes depending on experience level. | 3. Begin by breaking at the elbows until your upper arm is by your side. Then extend at the elbows back into the top position.
1. Anchor a band to a stable point. | 2. Face away and begin with your elbows bent and fists by your temples. | 3. Extend your elbows until your triceps contract.

1. Stand in the middle of the two bands with feet shoulder-width apart. Step forward with one foot to create tension in the bands. | 2. Hold one band in each hand, palms facing forward. Start the exercise with your arms extended in front of you, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. | 3. Lower your arms to the sides of your chest, maintaining control of the band. | 4. Push your arms back up to the starting position, keeping your core engaged and maintaining control of the band.

1. Stand between the two anchored bands, grasp them with an overhand grip, and position the bands at shoulder level. | 2. Brace your core and push the bands overhead, fully extending your arms. | 3. Lower the bands back to shoulder level, keeping your core engaged and arms straight. Repeat for desired number of reps.

1. Anchor the band to a high point and face away. Hold the band with both hands, placing your hands shoulder-width apart and keeping your elbows close to your body. | 2. Slowly extend your arms downward, keeping your elbows close to your body. Push the band down as far as you can, feeling the contraction in your triceps.
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band with your right hand, with your arm at your side. | 2. Flex and extend your elbow.

1. Stand with a band anchored to a high point. Face away from the band. Hold the loop in one hand. | 2. Keep your elbow tucked in to your side. Extend your elbow. When you extend, don't let your upper arm raise. The band should land over your shoulder.
1. Stand facing away from a band which is anchored to a high point. | 2. Keep your elbow pointed forward, and extend and flex your elbow.
1. Loop the band around your back. The two end loops in each of your hands. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and elbow across your body until your arm is fully extended.
1. Anchor the band to a stable point. | 2. Hinge forward. Extend and flex at the elbow.
1. Stand with one or both feet on band. Go up and over your head with the band to the starting position. | 2. Flex and extend your elbows.
1. Anchor the band at shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades straight back in schools. Then protract to the starting position.

1. Loop the band under one of your feet. The other end of the bed should be in your hand between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. Press the band straight up towards the ceiling. Until your elbow is fully extended.
1. Place the band under your feet. Stand upright. | 2. Elevate your shoulder blades and then depress back to the starting position.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.
1. Anchor a band to a stable point. | 2. Place the loops of the band behind your knees. | 3. Perform a normal squat and extend your knees against the band at the top.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your head by the anchor point of the band, which should be 6 to 12 inches above your head | 2. Place the band around your midfoot and extend at the knees and hip.

1. Stand with a shoulder width grip. Both feet should be on the band with the band loops in each of your hand. | 2. Push your butt back and also break at the knees. | 3. Try to hit parallel depth (bottom of your leg should be parallel with the ground). If you can't tell your squat depth, then try squatting in front of a mirror and watch your form.
1. Anchor a band to something stable and set up a bench. | 2. Run through the band underneath the bench and loop around your feet. | 3. Flex and extend your knees.

Exercise Name: Band Squat Hold Single Arm Row
Instructions: 1. Anchor the band to a stable point and take a half squat position. | 2. Hold the band loop in one hand and pull your elbow straight back.
1. Anchor the band to a stable point. | 2. Take a half squat position and hold there. | 3. Perform a row while holding the squat position.

1. Stand with a shoulder width grip. Both feet should be on the band with the band looped over both hands. | 2. Push your butt back and also break at the knees. | 3. Try to hit parallel depth (bottom of your leg should be parallel with the ground). If you can't tell your squat depth, then try squatting in front of a mirror and watch your form.

1. Attach a band to a stable anchor point, such as a door handle or post. | 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and place the band around your ankles. | 3. Keeping your feet together, move your legs out to the sides and then back to the midline of your body. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Attach the band to an anchor point that is about shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and bring your arm across your body until you feel a contraction in your pecs.

1. Attach the band to an anchor point that is about shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and elbow across your body until your arm is fully extended.

1. Loop the band around your mid-back. The ends of the bands should be around your hands between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. This exercise can be done from the knees or the toes depending on experience level. | 3. Begin by breaking at the elbows until your upper arm is by your side. Then extend at the elbows back into the top position.

1. Secure two resistance bands to a sturdy anchor point (e.g. a door anchor, a post, etc.) at chest height. | 2. Stand facing away from the anchor point with feet shoulder-width apart and hold each end of the band in each hand. | 3. Start with arms fully extended and parallel to the floor. | 4. Keeping arms straight, slowly bring your arms together in front of your chest.

1. Stand in the middle of the two bands with feet shoulder-width apart. Step forward with one foot to create tension in the bands. | 2. Hold one band in each hand, palms facing forward. Start the exercise with your arms extended in front of you, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. | 3. Lower your arms to the sides of your chest, maintaining control of the band. | 4. Push your arms back up to the starting position, keeping your core engaged and maintaining control of the band.

1. Start with both feet hip-width apart and step on the middle of the band with both feet. Hold the handles of the band in each hand and position the band above your chest, with your palms facing down. | 2. Keeping your elbows slightly bent, slowly raise your arms out to the sides until they are parallel with the floor. Make sure to internally rotate your shoulder joints by bringing your shoulder blades together and rotating your forearms inward towards your torso. | 3. Hold the position for a few seconds and then slowly lower your arms back to the starting position, keeping the internal rotation of your shoulder joints throughout the movement.
1. Loop the band around your back. The two end loops in each of your hands. | 2. Extend your shoulder joint and elbow across your body until your arm is fully extended.

1. Loop the band around your mid-back. The ends of the bands should be around your hands between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. This exercise can be done from the knees or the toes depending on experience level. | 3. Begin by breaking at the elbows until your upper arm is by your side. Then extend at the elbows back into the top position.

1. Place the band at an anchor point that is shoulder height. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Start with your fingers interlocked around the band and your fists connected to your chest. | 3. Extend at the elbows pressing the band away from your body until your elbows are fully extended.
1. Stand on the band with one or 2 feet depending on how heavy you want the band to be. | 2. With your elbows extended raise your fists straight up to the ceiling until they are at eye level.
1. Grab the band at shoulder width. Raise your arms straight out to the side. | 2. The band should scrape against your shirt.

1. Loop the band under one of your feet. The other end of the bed should be in your hand between your thumb and pointer finger. | 2. Press the band straight up towards the ceiling. Until your elbow is fully extended.
1. Anchor a band to a low point and stand with the band crossing your body. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, lift your arm until it's parallel with the floor.

1. Anchor a band to a point that is the same height as your fist when your arms are at your side and stand with the band crossing your body. | 2. While keeping your elbow mostly extended, lift your arm until it's parallel with the floor.

1. Stand between the two anchored bands, grasp them with an overhand grip, and position the bands at shoulder level. | 2. Brace your core and push the bands overhead, fully extending your arms. | 3. Lower the bands back to shoulder level, keeping your core engaged and arms straight. Repeat for desired number of reps.

1. Stand with one or both feet on one end of a band. Take a double overhand roughly shoulder width grip. | 2. Pull your elbows straight up the ceiling. Aim to get the band to chin level or slightly higher.
1. Anchor the band at eye level. Take a few steps away until the band is taut. | 2. Use an overhand grip with both hands. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose flaring your elbows out.
1. Grab the band with a shoulder width grip. Point your arms straight in front of you. | 2. Retract your shoulder blades and shoulder joint until the band taps your chest.
1. Start with a band anchored to a high point. Stagger your stance. | 2. Pull the band to the bridge of your nose.

1. Start by standing between the two anchored bands with your feet shoulder-width apart and the bands positioned at a high point. | 2. Grasp the ends of each band with your hands, keeping your palms facing each other. | 3. Keeping your arms slightly bent and your back straight, slowly pull the bands away from your body until your arms are extended straight out to the sides. Hold for a second, then slowly release back to the starting position. Repeat for desired reps.

1. Attach a band to a stable anchor point, such as a door handle or post. | 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and place the band around your ankles. | 3. Keeping your feet together, move your legs out to the sides and then back to the midline of your body. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

Exercise Name: Plate Curl To Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back behind the head to the starting position of a tricep extension. | 5. Push the plate back up overhead, then lower it back to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

1. Lower into a squat position, keeping the plate at chest height. | 2. Slowly curl the plate towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body. | 3. Hold for a moment at the top of the curl before lowering the plate back to chest height. | 4. Repeat the curls as you hold the squat position.

1. Make sure to keep your elbow close to your body and your core engaged throughout the movement. | 2. Bend forward at your hips while maintaining a flat back. | 3. Pull the plate toward your upper abdomen. | 4. Lower the weight in a controlled manner and repeat.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you). Use a dip belt and the let the weight hang between your legs. | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

Exercise Name: Plate Internally Rotated Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. With plates in either hand, bend your knees with your feet slightly bowed out. Hinge forward with a flat back. | 2. Maintain an overhand grip and internally rotated shoulders. | 3. Raise your arms backward toward the ceiling while maintaining a light band in your elbows.

1. Keep your back straight and bend forward slightly at the waist. | 2. With arms extended, raise the weights out to your sides until they are in line with your shoulders. | 3. Pause briefly and then lower the weights back to the starting position.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. Place a plate on your chest. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. Weight hanging between your legs. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate in front of the feet, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend the hips and knees to grip the plate with palms facing the body. | 3. Keeping the back straight, stand up while lifting the plate off the ground. | 4. Return the plate back to the starting position by bending the hips and knees, keeping control of the plate.

Exercise Name: Plate Single Leg Pinch Grip Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and facing forwards. Grip the sides of a weight plate with your palms facing down. | 2. Balance on one foot, as you raise the weight keep your arms and back straight, while you bring your other foot back towards the ground | 3. Keep four raised leg straight and in alignment with your back as you lower the plate back down to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held in front of you, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held behind the neck and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Engage your core and straighten your legs to lift the plate off the ground. | 2. Stand on one leg, keeping the other leg off the ground, while holding the plate in front of your body. | 3. Keep your back straight and maintain a neutral head position while looking straight ahead. | 4. Lower the plate back down to the ground while keeping your balance on one leg.

1. Stand facing the plate with your feet shoulder-width apart and the plate positioned between your feet. | 2. Bend down and grasp the plate from the top edges with both hands, making sure your thumbs and fingers are evenly spaced. | 3. Keep your back straight, chest up and core engaged, and stand up with the plate, keeping it close to your body. | 4. Lower the plate back down to the ground, keeping control and maintaining good posture.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a weight plate. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plate towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 4. Once the plate is below your knees, drive through your heels to stand back up to the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two plates with a pinch grip. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plates towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged.

1. Lay flat on the ground on your stomach with your arms extended overhead. Hold a plate with a neutral grip. | 2. Lift your legs and chest off the ground simultaneously and hold for a 1 count at the top. | 3. Relax your lower back and lower your legs and chest back to the floor.
1. Hold a plate in both hands. | 2. Pull your arms and legs off the ground while and hold that position.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. Hold a plate up to your chest. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a single weight plate overhead with both hands, keeping your arms extended straight above your head. | 2. Begin walking forward, taking slow and steady steps while maintaining a straight line. Your focus should be on maintaining balance and control of the weight plate overhead. | 3. As you walk, continue to keep your arms extended and the weight plate overhead. Try to maintain good posture and avoid leaning forward or backward, as this could result in losing control of the weight plate. | 4. Continue walking for a set distance or for a certain amount of time, keeping your focus on proper form and technique. When finished, return to the starting position and repeat as desired.

1. Start by sitting on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground | 2. Engage your core muscles by pulling your belly button toward your spine. | 3. Slowly twist your upper body to the right, keeping your feet flat on the ground and your back straight. | 4. Hold for a second and then twist to the left, holding for another second.

1. Start by lying on your back on a mat with your legs bent and feet flat on the ground. | 2. Hold a weight plate over your head with both hands, making sure to keep your arms straight. | 3. Engage your core and use your abdominal muscles to sit up, keeping the weight plate towards the ceiling.

1. Get into a kneeling position with both forearms pressed into the ground. | 2. Place a weight plate on your back (or have a partner do it for you). | 3. Hold the plank for the allotted amount of time.

1. Start in a kneeling position with your hands planted on the ground. | 2. Place a weight plate on your back or have a friend do it for you. | 3. Pick your knees up off the ground. Hold in this position with a flat back.
1. Lay flat on the ground with your arms extended over head holding a weight plate. | 2. Pick your upper back and your legs off the ground. Your body should be in a banana shape.
1. Start from a plank position. Place a plate on your back. | 2. Go to one elbow then the other. Try to avoid rocking back and forth.

Exercise Name: Plate Single Leg Pinch Grip Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and facing forwards. Grip the sides of a weight plate with your palms facing down. | 2. Balance on one foot, as you raise the weight keep your arms and back straight, while you bring your other foot back towards the ground | 3. Keep four raised leg straight and in alignment with your back as you lower the plate back down to the starting position.
1. Stand straight with the plate held at your side | 2. Keep your hips and shoulders facing forward, bend to one side slowly | 3. Return to the upright position. | 4. Switch hands and repeat

1. Make sure to keep your elbow close to your body and your core engaged throughout the movement. | 2. Bend forward at your hips while maintaining a flat back. | 3. Pull the plate toward your upper abdomen. | 4. Lower the weight in a controlled manner and repeat.

1. Stand facing the plate with your feet shoulder-width apart and the plate positioned between your feet. | 2. Bend down and grasp the plate from the top edges with both hands, making sure your thumbs and fingers are evenly spaced. | 3. Keep your back straight, chest up and core engaged, and stand up with the plate, keeping it close to your body. | 4. Lower the plate back down to the ground, keeping control and maintaining good posture.
1. Stand tall holding two plates in each hand with a pinch grip. | 2. Walk for the desired distance or time.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two plates with a pinch grip. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plates towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. Place a plate on your chest. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you). Use a dip belt and the let the weight hang between your legs. | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.
1. Attach weight to yourself using a dip belt. Grip a pull-up bar with palms facing forward. | 2. Hang with arms fully extended. | 3. Hold for recommended amount of time, keeping your core engaged.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight plate in front of your chest with both hands. | 2. Keep your back straight, lower your body as if you were sitting back into a chair. | 3. Go as low as you can while keeping your heels flat on the ground, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the feet. | 2. Bend the knees and hips to pick up the plate, keeping the back straight and core engaged. | 3. Stand up, lock the hips and legs, and press the plate overhead with straight arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand holding a weight plate at chest height with both hands. | 2. Lower into a squat, extending the plate in front of you at chest height | 3. As you stand back up, pull the plate back into your chest.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the feet. | 2. Bend the knees and hips to pick up the plate, keeping the back straight and core engaged. | 3. Stand up while pulling the plate towards the chest. | 4. Keep shoulder level while keeping the elbows high and in front of the plate.

1. Hold the plate with both hands at chest height. | 2. Keeping your core tight and your chest up, squat down as low as you can go while keeping your feet flat on the ground. | 3. Hold the squat position and reach the plate forward, keeping your arms straight and your back straight. | 4. Return the plate to your chest while you hold the squat position and repeat reaching the plate in front of you

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso. | 2. Step back and across the body with the right foot, bending both legs to lower into a lunge position. | 3. Push through the front foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Repeat on the other side by stepping back and across with the left foot. | 5. Continue alternating sides for desired reps.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate in front of the feet, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend the hips and knees to grip the plate with palms facing the body. | 3. Keeping the back straight, stand up while lifting the plate off the ground. | 4. Return the plate back to the starting position by bending the hips and knees, keeping control of the plate.

1. Lower into a squat position, keeping the plate at chest height. | 2. Slowly curl the plate towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body. | 3. Hold for a moment at the top of the curl before lowering the plate back to chest height. | 4. Repeat the curls as you hold the squat position.

Exercise Name: Plate Single Leg Pinch Grip Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and facing forwards. Grip the sides of a weight plate with your palms facing down. | 2. Balance on one foot, as you raise the weight keep your arms and back straight, while you bring your other foot back towards the ground | 3. Keep four raised leg straight and in alignment with your back as you lower the plate back down to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held in front of you, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held behind the neck and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart and the plate held in front of the torso. | 2. Take a step to the side with one foot, bending the knee and lowering the hips into a lunge. | 3. Push through the front foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Repeat on the other side by stepping to the other side with the other foot.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart and the plate held in front of the torso. | 2. Take a step forward with one foot, bending the front knee to lower the hips into a lunge. | 3. Push through the front foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Repeat on the other side by stepping forward with the other foot.

1. Engage your core and straighten your legs to lift the plate off the ground. | 2. Stand on one leg, keeping the other leg off the ground, while holding the plate in front of your body. | 3. Keep your back straight and maintain a neutral head position while looking straight ahead. | 4. Lower the plate back down to the ground while keeping your balance on one leg.

1. Step back with your right foot into a lunge position, both knees bent at 90 degrees. | 2. Twist your torso to the right, keeping the plate close to your chest. | 3. Push through your front foot to return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

1. Hold the plate at chest height close to your body | 2. Take a big step backwards with your left leg, lowering your body until your left thigh is parallel to the ground and your right knee is bent at a 90-degree angle. | 3. Push through your right heel to return to standing, bringing your left leg back to starting position. | 4. Repeat the movement on the other side, stepping backwards with your right leg and lowering your body until your right thigh is parallel to the ground and your left knee is bent at a 90-degree angle.

1. Hold a weight plate at arm's length overhead, with your arms fully extended. The plate should be directly above your head and your elbows should be locked. | 2. Begin to bend your knees, lowering your body as far as you can while keeping the weight plate overhead. Make sure to keep your back straight and your chest lifted. | 3. Once your thighs are parallel to the ground or as low as you can go, pause for a moment. | 4. Push through your heels to return to a standing position, keeping the weight plate overhead the entire time.

1. Stand on a plate with both feet. | 2. Step back with one foot to the floor and let your back knee get close to or tap the floor. | 3. Push through your front leg until both feet are back on the plate.

Exercise Name: Plate Glute Bridge to Chest Press
Instructions: 1. Lay flat on the ground with a plate on your chest. | 2. Push your hips up toward the ceiling and maintain that extended position. | 3. With your hips up, press the plate toward the ceiling.

1. Lay flat on the ground with a plate on your chest. | 2. Push your hips up toward the ceiling and maintain that extended position. | 3. Extend your elbows mostly, break at the shoulder joint while maintaining hip extension and the slight bend in your elbows. | 4. Let the plate tap the floor (or get close) and then pull the plate back into the starting position.

1. Stand tall with a plate overhead. | 2. Step with one foot forward bringing your back knee to the floor. Gently tap your knee then drive through your front leg. | 3. Go back to a standing position and then step forward with the opposing legs.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, with a weight plate held in both hands at chest height. | 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your back straight and your weight in your heels. | 3. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the floor, then pause for a moment. | 4. Hold the squat position for the desired amount of time, keeping the weight plate steady and your core engaged.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a weight plate. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plate towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 4. Once the plate is below your knees, drive through your heels to stand back up to the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two plates with a pinch grip. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plates towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged.

1. Start with the plate at chest height. Begin a squat. | 2. Make sure to hit parallel depth. On your way back up, use the momentum you generate with your legs to help push the plate into an overhead position. | 3. Let the plate return to chest height before initiating the next squat.

1. Stand on a platform, Holding a plate to your chest, feet hip-width apart. | 2. Step back, lowering knee toward floor, keeping chest upright and core engaged. | 3. Push through front foot, return to start.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. Hold a plate up to your chest. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso. | 2. Step back and across the body with the right foot, bending both legs to lower into a lunge position. | 3. Push through the front foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Repeat on the other side by stepping back and across with the left foot. | 5. Continue alternating sides for desired reps.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso. | 2. Step back and across the body with the right foot, bending both legs to lower into a lunge position. | 3. Push through the front foot to return to the starting position. | 4. Repeat on the other side by stepping back and across with the left foot. | 5. Continue alternating sides for desired reps.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate in front of the feet, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend the hips and knees to grip the plate with palms facing the body. | 3. Keeping the back straight, stand up while lifting the plate off the ground. | 4. Return the plate back to the starting position by bending the hips and knees, keeping control of the plate.

Exercise Name: Plate Single Leg Pinch Grip Deadlift
Instructions: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and facing forwards. Grip the sides of a weight plate with your palms facing down. | 2. Balance on one foot, as you raise the weight keep your arms and back straight, while you bring your other foot back towards the ground | 3. Keep four raised leg straight and in alignment with your back as you lower the plate back down to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held in front of you, and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, the plate held behind the neck and the knees slightly bent. | 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping the back straight, until the torso is parallel to the floor. | 3. Push through the hips to return to the starting position.

1. Engage your core and straighten your legs to lift the plate off the ground. | 2. Stand on one leg, keeping the other leg off the ground, while holding the plate in front of your body. | 3. Keep your back straight and maintain a neutral head position while looking straight ahead. | 4. Lower the plate back down to the ground while keeping your balance on one leg.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a weight plate. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plate towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. | 4. Once the plate is below your knees, drive through your heels to stand back up to the starting position.

1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding two plates with a pinch grip. | 2. Place one foot slightly behind the other, with the heel of your back foot elevated. | 3. From this starting position, bend at the hips and knees to lower the plates towards the ground, keeping your back straight and your core engaged.

1. Set up a bar at mid way up your quad. Place the working leg against the bar. | 2. Place one foot behind. You should only be on your toes on that back foot. Your front foot should be planted flat the entire time. | 3. Bend your back knee and push your hips back. Look for a stretch in your front hamstring. | 4. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward again until you're back in a standing position.

1. Place a barbell at about midway up your thigh. Press your quads into the barbell. Hold a plate up to your chest. | 2. Push your hips back while leaving your knees mostly extended. Look for a stretch in your hamstrings. | 3. When you feel the stretch, push your hips forward until you're back in a standing position.

1. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. Hold each plate to the side of you. | 2. Bend forward at the hips bringing the plates to the floor while you slightly bend your knees, keeping your back straight. | 3. One at a time, lift the plate up. Return the plate to the floor and do the other side.

1. Make sure to keep your elbow close to your body and your core engaged throughout the movement. | 2. Bend forward at your hips while maintaining a flat back. | 3. Pull the plate toward your upper abdomen. | 4. Lower the weight in a controlled manner and repeat.

1. Stand facing the plate with your feet shoulder-width apart and the plate positioned between your feet. | 2. Bend down and grasp the plate from the top edges with both hands, making sure your thumbs and fingers are evenly spaced. | 3. Keep your back straight, chest up and core engaged, and stand up with the plate, keeping it close to your body. | 4. Lower the plate back down to the ground, keeping control and maintaining good posture.

1. Lay flat on the ground with a plate on your chest. | 2. Push your hips up toward the ceiling and maintain that extended position. | 3. Extend your elbows mostly, break at the shoulder joint while maintaining hip extension and the slight bend in your elbows. | 4. Let the plate tap the floor (or get close) and then pull the plate back into the starting position.

1. Lay underneath a fixed horizontal bar and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip. Place a plate on your chest. | 2. Pull your body straight up to the bar. | 3. Return to the starting position, your arms fully extended. Repeat.

1. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, arms and shoulders fully extended. Weight hanging between your legs. | 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. | 3. Lower your body back to starting position.

1. Grab the bar shoulder width apart with a supinated grip (palms facing you). Use a dip belt and the let the weight hang between your legs. | 2. With your body hanging and arms fully extended, pull yourself up until your chin is past the bar. | 3. Slowly return to starting position. Repeat.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the feet. | 2. Bend the knees and hips to pick up the plate, keeping the back straight and core engaged. | 3. Stand up, lock the hips and legs, and press the plate overhead with straight arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand holding a weight plate at chest height with both hands. | 2. Lower into a squat, extending the plate in front of you at chest height | 3. As you stand back up, pull the plate back into your chest.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

1. Hold the plate with both hands at chest height. | 2. Keeping your core tight and your chest up, squat down as low as you can go while keeping your feet flat on the ground. | 3. Hold the squat position and reach the plate forward, keeping your arms straight and your back straight. | 4. Return the plate to your chest while you hold the squat position and repeat reaching the plate in front of you

Exercise Name: Plate Curl To Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back behind the head to the starting position of a tricep extension. | 5. Push the plate back up overhead, then lower it back to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

1. Inhale and brace your abdominals | 2. Raise the arms vertically while keeping the elbows slightly bent | 3. Once the arms are parallel with the floor, rotate the plate clockwise and counterclockwise. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing the thighs. | 2. Keeping the elbows slightly bent, lift the plate up to the front of the body. | 3. Raise the plate up until the arms are fully extended, maintaining control of the plate. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate held in front of your face with both hands, palms facing each other. | 2. Rotate the plate around the head, keeping the arms extended and moving the plate in a circular motion. | 3. Complete one full circle, then reverse the direction to complete another circle.

Exercise Name: Plate Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Brace your core and press the weight plate overhead until your arms are fully extended. Keep your shoulders down and back. | 2. While your arms are fully extended, lower the weight behind your head to perform the extension | 3. After completing the extension, lower the weight to your chest, and perform the overhead press. Repeat

1. Stand tall holding two plates at your side. | 2. Lateral raise the plates to your side and continue until the plates are pointed at the ceiling. | 3. Let your shoulder joint naturally rotate. At the bottom you should have a neutral or overhand grip. By the time the plates are overhead, your palms should be facing forward.

Exercise Name: Plate Internally Rotated Rear Delt Fly
Instructions: 1. With plates in either hand, bend your knees with your feet slightly bowed out. Hinge forward with a flat back. | 2. Maintain an overhand grip and internally rotated shoulders. | 3. Raise your arms backward toward the ceiling while maintaining a light band in your elbows.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and grip two plates in each hand at your sides. | 2. Keeping your arms straight, raise the plates out to your sides until they are in line with your shoulders. | 3. Lower the plates back to your sides with control. Repeat for desired number of reps.

1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a single weight plate overhead with both hands, keeping your arms extended straight above your head. | 2. Begin walking forward, taking slow and steady steps while maintaining a straight line. Your focus should be on maintaining balance and control of the weight plate overhead. | 3. As you walk, continue to keep your arms extended and the weight plate overhead. Try to maintain good posture and avoid leaning forward or backward, as this could result in losing control of the weight plate. | 4. Continue walking for a set distance or for a certain amount of time, keeping your focus on proper form and technique. When finished, return to the starting position and repeat as desired.

1. Keep your back straight and bend forward slightly at the waist. | 2. With arms extended, raise the weights out to your sides until they are in line with your shoulders. | 3. Pause briefly and then lower the weights back to the starting position.

1. Start with the plate at chest height. Begin a squat. | 2. Make sure to hit parallel depth. On your way back up, use the momentum you generate with your legs to help push the plate into an overhead position. | 3. Let the plate return to chest height before initiating the next squat.
1. Start in a standing position with a plate against your chest. | 2. Press the plate away from your body until your elbows are extended.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the feet. | 2. Bend the knees and hips to pick up the plate, keeping the back straight and core engaged. | 3. Stand up, lock the hips and legs, and press the plate overhead with straight arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and the plate in front of the torso, palms facing forward. | 2. Curl the plate up to the front of the shoulder while keeping the elbows close to the body. | 3. Rotate the palms to face forward and press the plate overhead, locking out the arms. | 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position, keeping control of it, and repeat for desired reps.

Rotate the plate around the head, keeping the arms extended and moving the plate in a circular motion. | 3. Complete one full circle, then reverse the direction to complete another circle.

At the bottom you should have a neutral or overhand grip. By the time the plates are overhead, your palms should be facing forward.

Keep your elbows close to your head and shoulders relaxed. | 4. Push the weight plate back up to starting position, extending your arms fully.

Exercise Name: Plate Overhead Press To Tricep Extension
Instructions: 1. Brace your core and press the weight plate overhead until your arms are fully extended. Keep your shoulders down and back. | 2. While your arms are fully extended, lower the weight behind your head to perform the extension | 3. After completing the extension, lower the weight to your chest, and perform the overhead press.
